column2: After having served the Bronx for 80 years, the Third Avenue El will cease passenger operations at midnight next Saturday and will be replaced by a fleet of 60 air-conditioned buses.

This small town, situated in i Idaho's scenic big Wood River Valley, was shaken last week when the man who brought the London Bridge to Arizona announced plans to build a housing development that would triple the town's population.

This is a muscular fantasy. Characters bounce through time, transcendental yo-yos. "The Dark Is Rising" houses a mail-order gift catalogue of magical equipment: six secret signs that must be collected (circles quartered, looking, I judge, like so many jeweled hot cross buns);

To the Editor: Helen Vendler's review of my book of poems, "Angel Fire," is puzzling to me. Perhaps it is my own fault. When my first books were published, I felt that the "truth" about them (or about anyone's work) did exist, somehow-though critics might differ widely in their opinions.

WHY is it always raining on Gerald Freedman's parade? In these days of star directors, can't he have his place in the sun too? But there he was, last month, at the opening-night party for his latest effortGinastera's "Beatrix Cenci" at the City Opera-when a woman who should have known better marched up and asked him, "Where have you been?"

The "Age of Sail" may stage a surprise comeback in radically new form. German engineers, spurred in part by depletion of the world's known fuel-oil reserves, have been at work on the problem, and the Federal Maritime Administration in this country has been reported "cooperative."
Some 28 Massachusetts communities, contending that they are not prepared to open kindergartens by next September, have asked the state Department of Education to extend that deadline.

A world? More like a number of worlds, I said to myself, or hunks of habitat. Stand as long as you like staring into one of these-the corner of a wood in New England, for example, where a bird scuttles through the underbrush not six feet away from you, and another flies up to sit on an overhanging branch and swing there. The ground looks wet, and, in fact, it is.

TEHERAN--Iran today finds itself wedged between two of the world's tensest crisis areas. To the west lies Iraq, with which it is on very bad terms, and the festering Middle East, already riven by wars. To the east lies Pakistan, which shows signs of coming apart.
Two Cornell University engineers theorize that the planet Saturn is encompassed by a giant ring of hydrogen gas atoms shaped like a slightly

BIRMINGHAM, Ala.-The words come hard for one who has supported Richard Nixon and his'. Administration, but they must be said: Watergate is the President's Becket and like Henry II he cannot escape the full brunt of responsibility for the actions of his subordinates.
ON an unusually lively and provocative session of "The Dick Cavett Show" a few weeks ago, the subject for the evening was "The Administration and the Media."
The police in Hillsdale, N. J., continued their search yesterday for a 7-year-old girl who disappeared Friday while delivering Girl Scout cookies near her home.

South Africa will have to send promising nonwhite tennis players on overseas trips if she is to keep faith with promises made to the rest of the world, the retiring president of the South African Lawn Tennis Union said today.

ALBANY-City-bound motorist on the Long Island Expressway will no longer have to sit bumper-to-bumper in traffic jams, fuming because they do not know what the road conditions are ahead or if they should give up on the expressway and try an alternate route.

SHOREHAM, L. I.-Within the next five years, the Shoreham-Wading River Free School District, a loose-knit group of a half dozen small communities along the wooded North Shore of Long Island in Suffolk County, may soon be vying for a rather exclusive honor-that of the richest school district in New York State.

A Federal judge here has ruled that a city judge should expunge all the remaining records of charges made more than six years ago against 86 young men and women arrested at a leftist gathering on the Upper West Side.
The National Audubon Society and The New York Times have been named as defendants in a $12-million libel suit filed by three science professors in Federal Court here.
Miss Shirley Jean Mawer and Peter George Markwith were married at noon today in the Livingston United Methodist Church by the Rev. Randall Bean.

Are there any programs in the United States similar to Canada's, programs that encourage young people to travel in their own country? A survey of the Interior, Commerce and Transportation Departments indicates that, with a few minor exceptions, the answer is "no."

It may be that as standard equipment the Brewers will have to start including for their County Stadium a helicopter along with such routine baseball park items as a batting cage, a power mower, rakes and seed.
Common Cause plans to ask the Federal District Court Monday to force production of missing Republican financial records within 72 hours.

NEW DELHI--The cartoon on the front-page of a New Delhi newspaper showed a harried figure, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan, gripping a key to a box labeled "IndoBangla package." Mr. Bhutto was exclaiming over the phone: "How can I be sure that you are not trying to pressurize me by making this damn sensible offer?"
The Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott, said today that the position taken by Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst on executive privilege was "extremely broad . . . too broad."
HEMPSTEAD, L.I.-- Consciousness-raising talk groups have been used in the women's movement, in contrast to therapy, with the explanation, "We're not sick, we're oppressed."

Tony Jacklin of England, former British and United States Open champion, sank a four-foot par putt on the final hole today and gained a one-stroke victory over Valentin Barrios of Spain in the Italian open golf championship.
MADISON-Travel broadens the mind, they say. And so does a week or two of "lively deepthink in a lovely forest" right in New Jersey, savs Drew University.

Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Malamed have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margery Joan Malamed, to Mark Sanders Germain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Germain of White Plains. A November wedding is planned.
When Ch. Purston Pinmoney Pedlar, a West Highland white terrier was named best in show at the big International fixture in Chicago, it brought cheers on both sides of the Atlantic.
Linda Goodwill, who lay flat on her back fox seven months with tuberculosis of the spine and was told she would never ride a horse again, won the first race of the year for women jockeys today.
Despite the impact that collective bargaining has on our daily lives, the general public-and even the majority of businessmen - are only dimly aware of the negotiation process.
TRENTON-A long and complex controversy, one that has had a substantial bearing on the size of automobile insurance premiums in the state, is on the verge of final resolution.
Venezuela is developing new relations with Cuba through personal contacts, including official exchanges.

Even as the smallest of the major service branches, the Marine Corps will need 50,000 new enlisted Volunteers this year-many of whom must have aptitudes to learn such skills as computer operations, electronics and aircraft maintenance.

RIDGEFIELD-All that is missing, perhaps, is a German oom-pah band, but, then again, the customers that one is likely to find at Kocher's House of Quality Meats are hardly the kind who would prefer dancing in the aisles to placing their orders.

A Federal grand jury is investigating H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, to determine whether his office had a role in the initial Watergate bugging operation and any subsequent attempt to obstruct the inquiry into the case, sources close to the case said today.

The Easter sun is expected to shine through scattered clouds today and the temperature will be a bit warmer than it was last Sunday when New Yorkers enjoyed ideal spring weather. This was the prediction issued yesterday by the National Weather Service.
The best possible news for science-fiction readers is the eagerly awaited HALL OF FAME, VOL. II, edited by Ben Bova and issued in two sections, called A and B (Doubleday, $9.95 each).

More than100 American residents of Lebanon concluded a 25-mile Easter peace march in support of the Palestinian movement today and were greeted by thousands of Arabs shouting for Arab-American friendship.
Entering yesterday's game against Montreal, Harry Parker had only two concerns-finding an apartment and hoping the Mets would score some runs.

Physical condition rather than strategic analysis has become the main question in the National Basketball Association playoff series between the New York Knicks and Boston Celtics, which resumes today at 2 P.M. at Madison Square Garden.

T'S the best hobby a man can have," said Ernst Johne, a bee keeper, at the beginning of what turned out to be a fascinating afternoon. Mr. Johne keeps his bees in New York City, on the grounds of the Riverdale Country School in the Bronx, where he and his wife, Gerda, help with maintenance of the school buildings.

PHNOM PENH-It looked last week as though Washington had finally prevailed on President Lon Nol to pull the Cambodian Government together for an 11th-hour stand against Communist forces battering at the approaches to the capital.
The problem for President Nixon now is that his Administration has been crippled at the Watergate, with almost four long years to go, and very little cushion of goodwill or affection to fall back on.
Harvard's heavyweight crew defeated Brown today to win the Stein Trophy for the ninth year on the Charles River. Alan Sheahy, a sophomore, stroked for the Crimson.
Just as the Blackwoodconvention is probably the most misused device in bidding, the high-low signal is no doubt the most misused strategy in defensive play.
Theodore N. Beckman, a noted economist and former Ohio State University professor, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

Eating dog has been common enough in Taiwan, especially among Chinese of Cantonese origin, that a leading medical institute once had to appeal to the public to reduce consumption because of a serious shortage of animals for research.

In her recent titles, P. D. James has followed the exploits of Scotland Yard's Adam Dalgliesh, a major figure in the contemporary detective novel. in Mrs. James's latest, AN UNSUITABLE JOB FOR A WOMAN (Scribner's, $5.95), Dalgliesh does not appear until the finatchapter Yet he permeates the whole book.

To THE EDITOR: EADING John Canaday's April I discussion of the Metropolitan Museum admissions policy, I found myself in agreement on principle, but I'd like to suggest a different form of protest, rather than his strategy of paying only a penny.
To the aluminum producers of the Pacific Northwest the "energy crisis" is more than an abstract worry. It's costing them profits when demand for aluminum is high.
The Knickerbocker College baseball conference has 10 games scheduled this week. All 10 teams will play with Hunter, Pace and Pratt having three games each. Lehman, the defending champion, plays once.

Isle of Wight remained unbeaten this year with a convincing 11/2-length triumph in the $25,000 Irvin Paul Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The 2-5 favorite took control in a 29 4/5-second opening quarter and went on to his sixth victory this year, coming home in 29 seconds flat.

Rutgers has been without a varsity basketball coach for more than a month. The university's football coach, Frank Burns, and director of athletics, Fred Gruninger, are serving under one-year interim agree: ments.

In observance of Easter, the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences and the Bloomfield Public Library are featuring special exhibits of intricately colored EasteF eggs.
NEW BRUNSWICK-The city's Police Department and Rutgers University are teaming up in a research project that will bring mounted patrols to this urban center.

TRENTON-With the final session of the State Senate scheduled for this Thursday and the last meeting of the Assembly set for the following Monday, the New Jersey Legislature is adjourning unusually early this year.

When Paul Revere sounded the alarm throughout every Middlesex village and farm to notify his fellow Colonials that the British were coming, he did it deliberately. But when Carlton Fisk aroused a different segment of the Boston populace into bristling action last year, he did it accidentally. If it embarrassed him at the time, he no longer regrets it.
Joyce Maynard is 20 years old. She goes to Yale. Perhaps the single most significant fact of her life is that 5,000 hours of it - by her reckoninghave been spent in front of the TV.
The "Shroud of Turin," venerated by some as the burial cloth of Jesus, may soon undergo an examination to determine its authenticity.

FAR HILLS-Two years ago, Malcolm S. Forbes, the millionaire publisher, was riding one of his nine motorcycles in Newark. To avoid traffic, he zipped onto the Garden State Parkway, only to zip right off again when a toll collector reminded him that the parkway banned motorcycles.

The political and personal feuding between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay has become a routine feature of New York life that, by now, probably leaves as many people yawning as yearning for the truth in the charges of dereliction and incompetence that flash between Albany and City Hall.

The Princeton University Chapel was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Elizabeth Mapes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Mapes of Princeton, to Joseph Leonard Wood 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wood of Riverside, Conn.
The Security Council today passed a resolution condemning Is;:ael's military attacks in Lebanon.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Kochanczyk have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Mary Kochanczyk, to Donald Arthur Underwood, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lee C. Underwood of Canton, Ohio.

WEDNESDAY will be flower show day at the Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street. Daffodils in all shapes and sizes will star among the spring flowers. There will also be competitive flower designs by society members.
Hai-Kyung Lee, a young soprano from Korea, made her New York debut Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall--a rather premature appearance judging from Miss Lee's present technical limitations.
Mr. and Mrs. Vaughn W. Griffin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vicki Rae Griffin, to William H. Walters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Walters of Manhasset, L.l.
Felton McLellan Johnston, torrner secretary of the Senate, lied at his home here last night after a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

Several hundred Hasidic Jews converged on the Borough Park police station in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon to protest an assault on two of their number on a neighborhood street the night before. The demonstrators demanded additional police protection.

WASHINGTON--Nearly 20 years ago, the Defense Department and Levcrett Saltonstall of Massachusetts, then Chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, were caught up in a political tug-of-war over closing the Naval Rope Walk, an antiquated shed at the Boston Navy Yard where hawsers were made for the Navy.

In a golden run-on passage praising American women, H. L. Mencken declared that they were "fecund as the shad." This is a compliment minted by a true son of the Atlantic Coast in a time before zero population growth had turned ovulation into a guilty act.
Andy Messersmith, the golden angel in last winter's big swap between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the California Angels, is making a swift impression on the National League.

A sleek black and tan Doberman pinscher, Ch. Galaxy's Corry Carina, from Glen Cove, L. I., was best of 3,022 dogs in Reston Park today at the largest outdoor event this year in the East, the 60th show of the Old Dominion Kennel Club.

A bitter and divisive primary fight for the Democratic nomination for Governor is in pros pect here next year, and the Republicans are organizing an effort to regain the political control they lost 20 years ago.
To the Editor: As we learned from a visit to Zermatt, Switzerland, success has come to that town in the worst way. It has overbuilt and overpriced itself.

State Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals, yesterday called for centralization and computerization or all court records.

Mr. and Mrs. Clifford M. Baker Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Myers Baker, to A. Kendall Sydnor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydnor of Lynchburg, Va., where his father is president of the Virginia Dunbrik Company, Inc. manufacturers of concrete products and building supplies.

Merian C. Cooper, the Hollywood director, producer and author who created "King Kong" and spent three years making a film of the 50-foot ape who defied airplanes from a perch atop the Empire State Building, died yesterday of cancer in Mercy Hospital, San Diego. He was 78 years old.

ChrisEvert and Evonne Goolagong won semifinal matches in the $20,000 Masters tennis tournament today, setting up their third meeting in a final on the United States Lawn Tennis Association tour.
Hubert Green, a former Florida State golfer, maintained his one-stroke lead over Bob Murphy today in the third round of the $75,000 Tallahassee Open.

TULSA. The sound stage in the university sports center was set for the taping of another prime-time television special. Prerecorded orchestral music boomed from giant unseen speakers overhead. Young girls darted about under the camera lenses holding cue cards. Pianist Roger Williams, the featured guest star, waited in the wings for his slot on the program, while onstage, members of a ranking college basketball team bounced around in front of a makeshift backboard.
HACKENSACK - Everything may not be coming up roses-or radishes-for New Jersey gardeners this spring and summer.

Construction has begun on a $15-million, 36-story tower at Lincoln Square that will house facilities for the Mormon Church. The building, which will contain 324 rental apartments that will be available to the public, is at Two Lincoln Square, between 65th and 66th Streets, opposite Lincoln Center.

All Cuban radio stations have banned records by American and British pop and folk singers in an apparent move to make young Cuban listeners develop a greater taste for Cuban music and Latin American and Spanish music.

This limitation is nowhere better illustrated than in man's groping attempts to deal with the so-called energy crisis.

Mackell.

Mackell.
Like some kind of tenacious sea monster, the idea of building a new bridge over Long Island Sound has refused to let go, despite a series of rough legal, administrative and legislative blows.

The meat boycott is a memory, but the high prices are still a fact. Many housewives are finding that they must change the way they allocate funds for such basic items as food, housing, savings, clothing and others.

The United Nations Security Council's twin acts of condemning the Israeli military raid on Beirut and of deciding to undertake a basic review of the entire Middle East question are regarded here as a major diplomatic success for Egypt.

The use or misuse of inside information to profit in the stock market has always been a controversial topic in Wall Street. Lately, the controversy has escalated, due largely to the scandal surrounding the Equity Funding Corporation of America. .

Leon J. Mohn Jr., a divisional sales manager of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile manufacturer, died Saturday at the Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 51 years old and lived in West-port, Conn., and Hampton Bays, L. I.
Under the pressures of protectionist moves in the United States and increased costs for imports from Japan, South Korea is considering shifting some of her purchases from Japan to America.

A few hours before game time this morning, an elderly woman at the Yankees' downtown hotel kept insisting this after noon's contest with the Brewers had been postponed be cause of wet grounds. She ad dressed her remarks, in particular, to Sparky Lyle, maintaining she had heard the report on the radio. .
Louis Napolitano, an assistant corporation counsel of New York City from 1952 to 1967, died today at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. He was 78 Street here.
Six armed Indians were arrested today after occupying the 11-acre site of a proposed Governor's mansion,charging that onstruction would destroy an ancient burial ground.

Leaking gas accumulating beneath the floor of a low-income apartment house near the Mexican border exploded this morning, killing seven persons, five of them in two families. The one-story building was severely damaged.

Political activism is moribund at colleges and universities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and students have taken on the superficial appearance of their self-centered, socially indifferent, All American campus counterparts of the nineteen-fifties.

The body of 7-year-old Joan D'Alessandro, whose disappearance from her home here on Thursday while delivering Girl Scout cookies had set off a wide search, was discovered today in a wooded area beside Route 210 in Harriman State Park, Rockland County, N.Y.

John Havlicek's availability for the fifth game of the Knicks-Celtics series in Boston Wednesday is uncertain. "I had my shoulder X-rayed and there are no breaks, just torn muscles," the injured Celtics star said here yesterday. "I have to be optimistic."
Pope Paul VI, in an Easter message, voiced concern today over the "rough winds of an uncertain situation" in Indochina that were jeopardizing hopes for an end to the long war there.

Gary Jarrett scored three goals and Ron Buchanan two today in leading the Cleveland Crusaders to a 5-2 victory over the New England Whalers. The victory kept alive Cleveland's hopes in the World Hockey Association East Division final playoffs.

More increases in short-term interest rates lie ahead, increases encouraged by Federal money managers in their campaign to restrain a booming economy without preventing small borrowers from obtaining credit.
Australia and the West Indies scored only 134 runs in the second day of the fifth cricket test today. Play was brightened only by a lively seventh - wicket stand between Rod Marsh and Kerry O'Keeffe.

In one of the strongest public statements yet by a member of the President's own political party, Senator Edward W. Brooke said today that Mr. Nixon could not escape responsibility for the Watergate affair "under any circumstances" without an explanation of why he had not known what was going on.

The University of California, Los Angeles, won the recruiting battle for Richard Washington, a 7-footer from Benson Tech High School here. Washington was the No. 1 schoolboy prospect in the nation. John Wooden, the U.C.L.A. coach, made a rare recruiting appearance during the season to watch Washington and said Washington could have started for the Bruins last season. .

Foreign Minister Abba Eban summoned the French Ambassador to Jerusalem today and showed him "proof" that French-built Mirage warplanes were delivered to Egypt from Libya, an Israeli Government statement said.

The need for strengthening the private pension plans on which 30 million workers depend for much of their old-age protection was ably delineated in the message President Nixon sent to Congress the other day. Unfortunately, the reform program he has recommended fails to match his rhetoric.

Is the Kremlin coalition that unseated Nikita Khrushchev nine years ago finally beginning to break up? If so, the unusual quiet that has ruled in the publicly visible portion of the Soviet political scene since 1964 may give way to a new era of dramatic political collisions, not unlike those of the decade after 1947.

Jim McMillian scored 28 points and Wilt Chamberlain grabbed 25 rebounds as the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Golden State Warriors, 12670, and took a 3-0 lead in their four-of-seven game National Basketball Association semifinal playoff series last night.

G. Gordon Liddy, the leader of the Watergate break-in, has turned down a White House request that he change his mind and begin telling all he knows about the bugging of the Democrats to the Federal grand jury, sources close to the case said today.
Walt Frazier had scored 12 points and the knicks were trailing, 76-60, with 10 minutes to play against the Boston Celtics yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

Maj. Joseph S. Abbott Jr., who spent the last five Easters in the "Hanoi Hilton," decorated eggs with his wife and seven children this weekend and sat down with them today to a baked ham and a bunnycake with "ears" lined with pink coconut.

Nick Saviano of Los Altos Hills, Calif., and Barbara Goldman of Fort Lee, N. J., won titles in the 18-year-division as the sixth annual Easter Bowl junior indoor tennis championships ended here yesterday.
Charges of persistent nationalism were reported today to have been raised at a high-level Communist party meeting in the Ukraine, the second most populous republic of the Soviet Union.
Easter Sunday dawned clear and sultry. By 10 A.M., the temperature reached 70 degrees. It was a day for church-going, for strolling along Fifth Avenue, for lounging in Central Park.

G. Gordon Liddy, the leader of the Watergate break-in, has turned down a White House request that he change his mind and begin telling all he knows about the bugging of the Democrats to the Federal grand jury, sources close to the case said today.

Political activism is moribund at colleges and universities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and students have taken on the superficial appearance of their self-centered, socially indifferent, All. American campus counterparts of the nineteen-fifties.
More quietly, but almost as vigorously as she withdrew from the world during the Cultural Revolution, China is returning to the international scene.

The State Social Services Commissioner, Abe Lavine, warned local welfare departments today that they faced stiff fiscal penalties if they failed to comply with the state agency's new face-to-face eligibility re-certification policy for welfare recipients.
A 150-year-old log cabin that served as a boyhood home to Abraham Lincoln was discovered during a recent project in this north-central Kentucky city as part of a flood-control project.
The Associated Press announced yesterday that it would introduce next year a new system of facsimile photo transmission by wire, using laser beams.

Luther Dean Eagle, sports editor of The Louisville Courier-Journal, died yesterday after a heart attack in his automobile. He was 58 years old. Dean Eagle, as he was known, joined The Courier-Journal in 1941.

THE THEORY OF THE LEISURE CLASS. By Thorstein Veblen. With an Introduction by John Kenneth Galbraith. 261 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $6.95. First published in 1899, Thorstein Veblen's "The Theory of the Leisure Class" is probably the most original, ironical and revealing analysis ever to be made of American society.

A union spokesman said today that Ozark Air Lines had made "no formal indication" that it wished to resume negotiations with members of the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association, which went on strike Thursday, closing down Ozark operations.
The Suffolk County police have arrested the 47-year-old wife of a Huntington, L. I. business executive and charged her with the murder of her husband.
Lee Trevino called him the greatest golfer in the world after Jack Nicklaus won the Tournament of Champions by one stroke today.

With food prices continuing to climb, Mrs. Millicent H. Fenwick, director of the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs who has been making forays into food stores about the state, acknowledged that she had never worked so hard in her life.

The hypocrisy with which the Security Council condemned Israel's military actions in Lebanon came as no surprise in the wake of a debate dominated by anti-Israeli bias. The only unexpected feature of the vote, with eleven members favoring the resolution and four abstaining, was the fact that the United States chose to abstain rather than to condemn what was clearly an unfair judgment against Israel.

Ten weeks from now the Government will be out of the grain business for the first time in 25 years. The once-huge surpluses of wheat, corn and other grains that cost the taxpayer billions of dollars to buy and store, or to give away, will be gone.

The once-proud Democratic party of Virginia, which had regularly elected Governors since the days of Reconstruction until losing the office in 1969, will probably not even nominate a candidate for Governor in 1973.
More meat cuts showed small price decreases last week as shoppers stocked up for Easter and Passover meals, but most meat items resisted consumer pressure and cost the same.
"City government is a $ 10 billion corporation," says Controller Abraham D. Beame. "Would you pick someone with no experience to manage it?"

In dancing, as in many of the performing arts, the difference between the extraordinarily good and the great is both small and infinite. Small because in measurable quantity the variation is not all that large, and yet infinite because this is also a variation in immeasurable quality.

Just in time for the playwright's 409th birthday, the Folger Shakespeare Library has been given a homemade, handwritten personal diary that records the earliest known purchase of a work done by William Shakespeare.
Officials last night reported a threat to hijack an airliner to Moscow as a means of freeing Hitler's deputy, Rudolf Hess, from Spandau Prison in West Berlin.

The questions of who did what and with whose approval in the Watergate affair must of course be asked in the effort to punish past wrongdoings and prevent future scandals of this nature. Inevitably, too, any proceedings involving those close to the summit of power exercise a lurid hold on the public's fascination.

A man shot his grandmother dead, according to the authorities, wounded two other .persons in an argument at his home today, then went on a shooting rampage that left five others dead and seven wounded.

"The Adventures of Don Quixote," on the Columbia Broadcasting System from 9 to 11 this evening, stars Rex Harrison. A good deal of publicity has been generated by the fact that It stars Rex Harrison. Unfortunately, the production's biggest flaw is the performance of its star.
Kudith's Pilot, who spent most of last summer recovering from an injured leg, captured the junior working hunter championship today at the concluding session of the threeday Boulder Brook horse show.

Two foreign newspapers carried articles yesterday that Premier Giulio Andreotti of Italy and President Nixon discussed during their meeting last week a plan for a 42-country consortium to construct another Suez. Canal, parallel to and west of the existing canal.

To the Editor: I am troubled by President Nixon's New Federalism. The philosophy underlying it is simplistic and displays little sensitivity to the glaring inequalities in contemporary American society.

A Palestinian guerrilla said at a news conference here today that he and two companions had infiltrated from Lebanon Friday on a "suicide" mission to sabotage a bus station. Israeli security forces said that they caught the heavily armed men two miles inside the border yesterday.

Richard Drukker, publisher of The Herald-News and The Daily Advance of Dover, died Friday night on a visit to Tampa, Fla. He had been suffering from heart disease. He was 67 years old and lived at 66 Virginia Avenue in nearby Clifton.
The production of energy is the world's second largest industry, exceeded only by agriculture in its essential importance to modern society.

The only profitable thing the two robbers can do with the loot they stole from a Uniondale movie theater manager this morning is sell it to a paper-recycling center. For their efforts, the robbers got nothing but a bag of old newspapers.

Dr. Simon A. Beisler, formerly president of the medical board| of Roosevelt Hospital and former chief of its urology department died Friday at his home, 116 East 68th Street. His age was 73. Dr. Beisler, who retired recently, was also a former president of the American Urological Association.

Six newsmen, including one American, were superficially wounded by mortar shrapnel today as they accompanied Cambodian soldiers in a road-sweeping operation 11 miles south of Phnom Penh. All were taken to a hospital in the capital and released after being treated for wounds.
Despite the stalemate in negotiations with Indians at Wounded Knee, S. D., the Federal Government plans to move forward within the next few weeks with reorganization of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

Ken Rosewall captured his third straight World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today by defeating Arthur Ashe, 6-3, 7-6, in the final.

Gale Fitzgerald is a patient young woman. The Montclair State College senior, who is majoring in physical education, had a taste of being an Olympian last summer at Munich, but now she must wait until 1976 for the Olympic Games in Montreal.

Members of a fundamentalist mountain sect prayed last night for the judge who ordered the congregation not to handle deadly snakes or distribute poison at their religious services after two members died from drinking strychnine.

Tile Jose Molina Bailes Espafioles, which appeared Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, is a flashy, mediumsized Spanish dance company. No one can accuse it of over-refinement, but then it would be unjust to charge it with any sort of refinement. Mr. Molina's approach is pure show business and, in this respect, a good time can be had by nearly all.

Overflowing old Salem Square and the path to God's Acre graveyard, about 35,000 people stood under the night sky early today for the start of Easter Day services that the Moravian Church, a pre-Luther denomination, has held here every year since 1772.
Doctors at the Washington Hospital Center have successfully used acupuncture as anesthesia in four recent abortions and plan to use the ancient Chinese technique in other kinds of surgery.

Amid growing public concern over the Watergate affair, the Gallup Poll reports, President Nixon's popularity has fallen 14 percentage points since the late January Vietnam peace settlement and five points alone in the first week of April.

Dunc Rousseau poked home a rebound at 15 minutes 29 seconds of the third period to break a scoreless tie and the Winnipeg Jets went on to a 2-0 victory over the Houston Aeros tonight.

Weather Service in Newark said the temperature had climbed to 84 degrees in mid-afternoon. The record high for April 22 is 86, set in 1962.
