President Nixon telephoned his personal reassurances to his embattled aide John W. Dean 3d yesterday, wishing him a "happy Easter" and telling him "You're still my counsel," a source close to Mr. Dean said today.

Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities. The average rate for 3-month bills in this week's sale is 6.251 per cent while the average rate for 3-month bills in last week's sale was 6.187 per cent.

Roughly a decade ago the late Nikita Khrushchev was loudly proclaiming that the Soviet Union would soon "bury" the United States economically. By 1970, he predicted, his country would out-produce this nation, thus proving the superiority of socialism over capitalism. Today's reality is stunningly different. Not only is the United States still far ahead of the Soviet Union in gross national product, but Moscow has even become dependent on this country.

The Federal Government yesterday started criminal contempt proceedings here against Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who left the country recently during an investigation of his mutual-fund activities.
Gulf Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it would make an exchange offer to holders of its own common stock and certain convertible securities.
A Queens housewife who had been buying wines by the case phoned her dealer last week to replenish her supply of an imported Burgundy.

Mrs. Maxine Dannenberg Johnston, a member of the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association from 1955 to 1967, died today in Valley Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 209 West Glen Avenue.
Two women were injured tonight, one critically, in the explosion of blasting caps that they were working on at the Hercules Powder Corporation plant here.

Interest rates continued to Climb yesterday in the absence of action to tighten economic controls. Trading, however, was described as light and the bond market recovered some of its losses late in the day following

Three hundred members of the Ananda Marga Yoga Society held a day-long demonstration here today and one of their members was arrested while protesting the alleged mistreatment of their spiritual leader, Shrii Shrii Anandamurti, who has been in jail in India for 14 months.
Prof. Emile Despres of Stanford University, considered by fellow economists as one of the more original thinkers of his time, died today at his home in nearby Portola Valley. He was 63 years old.
The Sperry Rand Corporation had, in the fiscal year ended March 31, " a record year of many changes," J. Paul Lyet, chairman, said in an interview here yesterday.

Drivers of trucks that deliver wet and dry cement to construction sites in the city went on strike yesterday in a dispute over a new contract. Spokesmen for building contractors said that the impact of the walkout was serious on major construction projects where poured cement was needed for foundations, flooring and other purposes, and could quickly upset building schedules.
Spring Mills, Inc., has begun construction of a textile plant in Indonesia for the P. T. Daraion Textile Manufacturing Corporation, in which Springs is the managing partner and largest stockholder.
Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson said today that the Administration in tended to provide technical as sistance to the cities that will he hurt by a cutback in militarybases.

More than 100 employes of the Marshall Space Flight Center were told today that their jobs were being terminated, effective June 1. Dr. Rocco A. Petrone, director of the center, signed dismissal notices for 108 persons, 87 of them in Huntsville and 21 at other Marshall installations, to reduce the number of Civil Service jobs at the center to 5,214 by June.

Vandals invaded the offices and school of the Negro Action Group at 270 East Second Street on the Lower East Side over the weekend and damaged several classrooms and destroyed office equipment, the police reported yesterday.

Fifty years ago the halls of Congress echoed with rhetoric over a battle that has now-been resurrected through the persistence of an obscure Illinois dairyman and the discoveries of modern nutritional research.
The stock market absorbed another drubbing yesterday in light trading as Wall Street reopened for business after the three-day Easter weekend.

To the Editor: On March 11, President Nixon reiterated his long-standing opposition to eliminating the criminal penalties for use, possession or sale of marijuana. In so doing, he ignored the findings of every major study and official inquiry about marijuana, and disregarded the conclusions of the National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse, which he appointed.

A Federal judge sentenced two men today for illegally importing a 1,500-pound Mayan artifact from Guatemala. Clive Hollinshead, 48 years old of Santa Fe Springs, Calif., and Johnnie Brown Fell, 50, of Mobile Ala., were convicted March 15 by a Federal jury.
The New York Mets will test the western half of the Na- tional League for the first time tonight when they open a six game trip in the Astrodomeagainst the Houston Astros.
The Montreal Canadiens have the Philadelphia Flyers hanging, on the ropes, but the coach of, the "Broad Street Bullies" has not given up hope.

The Uris Buildings Corporation announced yesterday that the British Land Company, Ltd., intended to make a cash tender offer for all the outstanding common stock of Uris. As much as $153-million could be involved.

In the May issue of the Salt Water Sportsman, Hal Lyman and Frank Wollner offer the astonishing theory that sun spots and accompanying solar flares are the major factor in the success or failure of the breeding efforts of striped bass in a given year.

Cemetery workers walked out of a State Board of Inquiry hearing yesterday, protesting that they were not being treated even-handedly. John R. Harold, counsel for Local 365 of the Cemetery Workers and Greens Attendants, said that Sam Cimaglia, local president, had been subpoenaed to appear but that the board had failed to subpoena officials of some of the cemeteries.

The Board of Estimate yesterday gave final approval to a proposal that would give builders a bonus in floor space in return for contributions to a city fund to be used to improve parks in the vicinity of the buildings to be constructed. The vote was 12 to 10.

The first round of a tournament often presents a curious aspect to the spectators. The players. strolling around to peer over shoulders or leaning back in their chairs to follow the other games on the large wall-mounted demonstration boards, seem to be giving more time and concentration to their activity between moves than to what's going on at their own tables.

Nine unions representing Japan's railroad, communications, postal, and Government employes rejected Premier Kakuei Tanaka's offer of a new contract today, setting the stage for a week of crippling strikes.

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: ASSESSMENTS Affirmed a decision that a property owner is not entitled to a hearing when local government assesses a share of the cost of a public improvement against him and imposes a lien on his property when he fails to pay.

Thomas J. Mackell resigned yesterday as Queens District Attorney, 12 days after he was indicted on charges of covering up a criminal investigation and five days after Governor Rock efeller said he had begun pro ceedings to remove him from office.

The Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, has an atypical soul show running through Thursaday. Ir place of the high-energy belters and the soft harmonizers who usually appear there, the theater has booked a nightclub chanteuse who is a practitioner of what might be called soul avant-garde.

The Supreme Court dismissed today an appeal by Reader's Digest from a decision by the Washington State Supreme Court that the magazine's "sweepstakes" direct mail advertising campaign violated that state's

Dr. Julia M. Jones, a leader in the fight on tuberculosis as physician in charge of the pulmonary disease section at Harlem Hospital, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, where she was a professor of clinical medicine.

Herbert Stein, President Nixon's top economic adviser, said today that the Administration was studying the possibility of increasing some taxes as a way of holding down rising demandin the American economy.

Hawaii's public school teachers returned to their classrooms today, ending a two-week strike while negotiations continued on a new contract. During the strike 90 per cent of the 9,000 state teachers remained away from their classrooms and over 90 per cent of Hawaii's more than 181,000 public school students stayed away from school and went instead to the beaches and recreation areas.

ALBANY, April 23--Governor Rockefeller is expected soon to name Albert A. Blinder, a New York City lawyer and the son-in-law of the State Senate Democratic minority leader, Joseph Zaretzki, to a judgeship on the State Court of Claims, reliable sources in the Legislature said today.
Several thousand children and parents rolled Easter eggs on the White House South Lawn today amid band music and circus acts. Some of the children left with more eggs than they brought.

Twenty-five Social Serv ices Department patrolmen in New York City who stayed off their jobs to protest the shooting of one of their un armed colleagues were sus pended by the Human Resources Administration, which described their actionas illegal.

Billy Wilder gave Charles Eames a present. In return, the film director--and the world--got what some considered the biggest, ugliest, most costly chair available, a chair that holds you like a baseball glove does a ball, that swivels and rocks, that was the first since soda fountain seating to boast a pedestal.
Kevin Loughery quit the Philadelphia 76ers as coach last night and announced that he had agreed to a long-term contract with the New York Nets of the American Basketball Association.

Marie Catherine Byron, who retired in 1953 as administrator of the Mary Harkness Convalescent Home of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Port Chester, N. Y., died Saturday in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 84 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.
Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, took his campaign for Ameri can trade concessions directly to American Senators today and evidently made some headway.

Henry A. Kissinger said yesterday that the United States planned to build "a new Atlantic charter" with its European allies this year to overcome the economic, military and diplomatic strains that have developed in the alliance recently.
Following is the text of an address delivered at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday by Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser for national security, at a luncheon of The Associated Press:
A local Asian driver, 27-year-old millionaire Shehkar Mehta, won the 21st East African safari today in the closest finish ever recorded in the 20 years of this rally.
A group of white South African athletes decried today racial discrimination in their country's sports and called for "equal and unimpaired opportunity" for all athletes.

The man who classified the Pentagon papers "top secret-sensitive" testified today that he did so in a routine manner without being aware of Government regulations concerning the classification of documents to protect the national defense.

The city Health Department has listed 12 more food processing establishments in New York City where health code violations persisted at the time of a second inspection. Unless the violations are corrected, a third and final inspection scheduled for next week can result in closing orders.
Gov. Wendell R. Anderson signed the controversial Leech Lake Indian Reservation hunting and fishing agreement to-day, calling it "the most sensitive bill that has reached my desk this session."

New traffic patterns will go into effect in the Bronx starting this morning in preparation for the shutdown of the Third Avenue elevated line at midnight Saturday. Traffic Commissioner Benjamin Ward announced that, commencing at 5 A.M., Third Avenue would be made oneway northbound from Boston Road to East 184th Street.
G. McMurtrie Godley, who has been United States Ambassador to Laos since July 24, 1969, left Vientiane today for the United States and a new position.

Stocks on the American Stock Exchange and the over the-counter market declined yesterday in listless trading. Brokers reported that investors remained concerned over inflation and especially the sharp rise in living costs.

Dalip Singh Saund, the first native of India to be elected to the United States Congress, died at his home here today at the age of 73. During his 1962 campaign for a fourth term in the House of Representatives, Mr. Saund was incapacitated by a massive stroke.

With Governor. Cahill's administra tion already hit by one political scandal and the threat of an other, the new indictments of two top Republicans with close ties to the Governor are a break that Democrats and Mr. Cahill's enemies inside the Republicanparty were not counting on.

" We were lucky, awful lucky," said Dave DeBusschere. He sat on a table in the trainer's room, back braced against the wall. Exhaustion made that huge body sag and weariness was etched on every feature as he added, "I couldn't have gone another minute." If it had been necessary, he could have gone many more minutes because that's the type of fierce competitor he always has been. But it wasn't necessary.
Dr. W. Kenneth Riland, a New York osteopath who,has treated President Nixon and has served as Governor Rockefeller's personal physician, pleaded not guilty in Federal Court here

Playbill, the magazine for theatergoers, will radically alter its editorial format and advertising thrust next September, in a major effort to lift the failing 89-year-old publication into the profit column.

A letter written by George Washington on his retirement from military service, in which he expresses his philosophy of government, will be one of tile historical items offered in an auction of important autographs May 8 at Sotheby Parke Bernet.

Whit Burnett, who, as founder and editor of Story magazine, helped discover such writers as William Saroyan, Truman Capote and J. D. Salinger, died of a heart attack Sunday night while attending a dinner party in Norwalk, Conn.
Jacob Gelberman, chief of the operations division of the New York District of the Army Corps of Engineers, died yesterday at his home in West Hempstead, L.I. His age was 63.

The radio talk shows that deal explicitly with sex have been disappearing from the air. In the few weeks since March 28, when Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, attacked what he called "topless radio" for broad. casting "prurient trash," nu merous stations have removed the programs or toned them down.
Fighting in South Vietnam during the last few days has declined to its lowest level since the Jan. 28 cease-fire took effect, Saigon and American officials reported yesterday.
William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshore-men's Association from 1953 to 1963, was found dead last night behind the wheel of his auto after it crashed into a parkedcar. He was 70.

The head of the Kentucky State Racing Commission said today that he had rejected a request by the trainer of two top Kentucky Derby prospects to permit the colts to run as separate betting interests rather than as an entry.

State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist announced today the appointment of Sterling S. Keyes, of Baltimore, to the new post of coordinator of the department's service to New York City, effective July 1.

Tom Young, who gained his coaching fame at American University, was named the Rutgers' basketball coach yesterday. The 40-year-old Young had a 61-37 won-lost record in his four-season stay with the Eagles, including a 21-5 mark last season.

The Bolivian Cabinet resigned today to give President Hugo Banzer Suarez freedom to put together a new one, it was officially announced. Foreign Minister Mario R. Gutierrez read to newsmen the text of a letter to the President in which the ministers saidr;

The National Mediation Board yesterday arranged a meeting between officials of the Port Authority Trans Hudson commuter lines and the striking carmen's union, which has kept the line shut for 23 days. The meeting, set for tomorrow, is expected to lead to a resumption of negotiations that were broken off on the eve of the strike. The line connects points in New Jersey with two terminals in Manhattan.
The State Department today denied that a senior American diplomat in Phnom Penh had encouraged Cambodian officials to expel a correspondent for United Press International.

John Wojtowicz, a former bank teller, was sentenced today to a 20-year prison term for the armed robbery of a Brooklyn bank--a holdup that he said he had committed to obtain money for a sex-change operation for his male "wife."

Englehard Minerals and Chemicals Corporaton plans to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the company's common, stock. The purchases will be made from time to time either on or off the New York Stock Exchange.
The Defense Department esti mated today that of 300,000 Army enlisted men who served in Vietnam between 1970 and 1972, fewer than 4,000 are civilian drug addicts.
Timothy Leary, the drug cultist, was sentenced to six months to five years in prison today for his 1970 escape from the California men's colony.

The New York Times Company reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the first quarter of 1973 had risen to $4-million, or 35 cents a share. This was a gain of nearly 64 per cent over the comparable quarter last year, when net income was $2.4-million, or 21 cents a share.

Left-wing extremists seized the national Public Works Ministry today and held it most of the day, surrendering the 12-story building only after a personal appeal from President Salvador Allende Gossens.
TORONTO -- The surging Canadian nationalism that today affects so much intellectual activity in this country has inevitably drawn Canadian literature into the vortex of chauvinist controversy.

CRYSTAL AND FOX, a play by Brian Friel. Directed by Patrick Conlon; set ling by Philip Gilliam; lighting by Judy Rasmuson; costumes by Mr. Gilliam and Jennifer von Mayrhauser; incidental music by Ted Auletta; production stage manager, Ginny Freadman. Presented by Sheila Conlon, associated Producer, Carmel Quinn. At the McAlpin Rocktop Theater, Broadway and 34th Street.

The Supreme Court agreed to-day to decide whether school systems that require female teachers to quit their jobs four or five months before they expect children are engaging in unconstitutional discrimination based on sex.
Twelve witnesses were called before a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday in connection with an investigation into "unusual betting patterns" in superfecta races at New York harness racing tracks.
One of the great pairs in the classical tradition of American bidding emerged from semiretirement and convincingly captured the New York Grand National title during the week-end.

For the 30 or so network television salesmen in town these are long, hectic days--million-dollar days. Right now they're vying with one another to sell as much of the hundreds of millions of dollars of their 1973-74 inventory of commercial prime-time "up front"--52-week contracts.

Those who are out of work in a time of prosperity suffer psychological misery as well as economic misfortune. Despite the distinct economic improvement in the last year, 5 per cent of the work force is still unemployed. That statistic stands for 4.5 million persons including 300,000 Vietnam war veterans and about a half-million persons who have been seeking work for six months or longer, the so-called "hard-core unemployed."
Henry A. Kissinger sharply assailed North Vietnam yester day for having "totally violat ed" the Vietnam cease-fire agreement.
While prices of both imports and domestic products have been rising, the price of one choice luxury import--caviar--has yet to be raised because of currency realignments.
The out look for a fast growth in the volume of world trade this year is very good," the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today.
The City Stores Company, which operates both department and specialty stores, announced here yesterday plans to close its Lansburgh store division in Washington because of continued unprofitability.

A former officer of a New Jersey subsidiary of the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Cor poration of America alleged yesterday that he had been asked repeatedly by officers of Equity to illegally transfer assets of the subsidiary to the parent company or its West Coast insurance operation.

Who better qualified to know what appeals to a child than his peers? Crayon sketches by 5- and 6-year-olds have provided the in spiration for a new group of nylon scatter rugs for children's rooms now available on the seventh floor at Bloomingdale's.

It's not often that commercial television presents two major and outstanding dramas in a single week. So naturally enough, given the persistent idiocies of TV scheduling, they are being presented tonight, with the last part of one frustratingly overlapping the first part of the other.
The bodies of two New York City men who drowned over the weekend when their light plane nosedived into nearby Wickham Lake in southern Orange County shortly after take-off have been recovered.
The nation's largest domestic copper producer and the world's second-largest aluminum company reported yesterday gains in first-quarter operations

Consumer attitudes changed radically during the last few months, growing more and more pessimistic as food prices kept rising, George Katona and Jay Schmiedeskamp of the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research reported yesterday.

RAVENNA. By Giuseppe Bovinl. 212 pp. 139 illustrations. Abrams. $45. Erwin Panofsky used to tell about a couple of visitors to the Frick Collection who were examining Van Eyck's "Virgin and Child, with Saints and Donor" following his lecture on that small and precious painting. "It's so disappointing after the lantern slides," one said to the other.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers warned last night that the dramatic progress made in improving relations with the Soviet Union and China was not irreversible.

Henry A. Kissinger said yes terday that the United States planned to build "a new Atlan tic charter" with its European allies this year to overcome the economic, military and diplomatic strains that have de. veloped in the alliance recently.

The Cambodian Gov ernment appeared to be moving today toward satisfying condi tions stipulated by opposition leaders under which they would be willing to join President Lon Nol in collective leadership of the nation.

Richard Wilson, the president of the Oglala Sioux Indian tribe, in a message telephoned to area radio and television stations late last night, urged all able-bodied Oglala Sioux to report to the reservation headquarters here this morning with their rifles.

The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to disapprove a far-reaching school desegregation plan that would merge Richmond's black-majority system with two nearly all-white suburban counties.

There is not much to show for at least $11-million in government funds that Dr. Thomas W. Matthew handled in the last six years: ?? A "hospital" in Queens described in state inspections as "filthy ... deteriorated ... destroyed by addicts."
The State Public Utilities Commis sion toby formally approved and sent Out its much-delayed set of rules to regulate cable television in New Jersey's 567 municipalities.

A sex - discrimination case brought by the State Attorney General's office against the New York Telephone Company will be resolved today when the company enters into an agreement providing that all job categories shall be equally open to qualified candidates regardless of sex or maritalstatus.
The Youth International party, which met here during the weekend, said yesterday that it was planning a series of marijuana "smoke-ins" across the country next weekend.
More than 1,000 Protestant Orangemen, led by blaring bagpipes and booming drums, staged an Eas ter Monday parade through downtown Belfast today to demonstrate their loyalty to Britain.

An accumulation of "small discrep ancies" in accounts offered by the prime suspect in the mur der of 7-year-old Joan D'Ales sandro last Thursday led to his arrest and, the Bergen County Prosecutor's officers said to day, to the solution of a crime that has severely unsettled this normally placid residentialtown of 12,000.

China announced to day that she would soon sign a treaty banning nuclear tests in Latin America. The decision produced elation in the delegation accompanying the Mexican President, Luis Echeverria Alvarez, who is here on a state visit.
George Edward Allen, a Washington lawyer, businessman and poker-playing intimate of three Presidents, died here early today at Eisenhower Medical Center of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.
President Tito forecast to-day that a new Yugoslav Constitution, the country's fourth since 1946, would bring about "revolutionary changes" from top to bottom in economic and social relations.
The Exxon Corporation yesterday reported first-quarter net income of $508-million, or $2.27 a share, a record. This was up 43 per cent from the year-earlier $355-million, or $1.58 a share.

Dr. Joseph T. English, the 39-year-old psychiatrist who has spent nearly three tumultuous years as chief of the city's new public hospital system, announced yesterday that he would leave the post by the end of Mayor Lindsay's term next Dec. 31.

Ruchell Magee will be retried on a charge of aggravated kidnapping in connection with the 1970 Marin County Courthouse shootings that killed a judge and three other persons. Attorney General Evelle J. Younger of California said today.
The Mississippi River's third flood crest of the spring, swollen by weekend rains, kept thousands of persons from their homes and marooned thousands more today.

A Federal appeals court took under consideration today the problem of which group of politicians in Mississippi should be officially called Democrats. The struggle is between the so-called regular Democratic state party, headed by Gov. William Waller, and the civil rights-oriented "loyalist" group.

Thomas J. Mackell resigned yesterday as Queens District Attorney, 12 days after he was indicted on charges of covering up a criminal investigation and five days after Governor Rockefeller said he had begun proceedings to remove him from office.
Ulf Thoressen of Norway easily won trotting's fourth annual driving championship today beating John W. Smolenski of New-Zealand by 25 points.
Arthur W. Woelfie has been named president of the Kraftco Corporation, succeeding William O. Beers, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

The radio talk shows that deal explicitly with sex have been disappearing from the air. In the few weeks since March 28, when Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, attacked what he called "topless radio" for broadcasting "prurient trash," numerous stations have removed the programs or toned them down.

A new battle between parents in Canarsie and East Flatbush over which community will have the majority voice in shaping local school policies is dominating the coming school board elections in Brooklyn's District '18, the scene of recent controversies and boycotts over school zoning practices.

Perhaps tonight, as Coach Emile Francis hopes, his Rangers will have the visiting-team advantage when they face the Black Hawks at Chicago. If the Hawks win, they capture the four-of-seven game Stanley Cup semifinal series; they now have a 3-1 lead.
The Defense Department estimated today that of 300,000 Army enlisted men who served in Vietnam between 1970 and 1972, fewer than 4,000 arecivilian drug addicts.

The city's Board of Ethics ruled yesterday that the activities of an assistant commissioner--a professional engineer--in professional organizations were incompatible with his duties as a city official.

Stockholders of the Howard Johnson Company voted at yesterday's meeting in Boston to approve the acquisition of Tower Grill of Pennsylvania, Inc., a private corporation owned by Howard Johnson, chairman and president of the corporation, and his sister and set up to manage four Howard Johnson restaurants.
Ten more families were evacuated today from an area three miles west of here after the discovery of new eruptions of underground water and gas.

President Nixon telephoned his personal reassurances to his embattled aide John W. Dean 3d yesterday wishing him a "happy Easter" and telling him "You're still my counsel," a source close to Mr. Dean said today.

Much of the comment about the Watergate case centers on retrospective questions: Who knew of the plan? Who approved it? Who covered it up? Definitive answers will not be available for months, until the investigations and trials have been completed, and perhaps not then.
New York University's School of Engineering and the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn were formally merged into a single institution yesterday.

Matt Bolger, the Rutgers base ball coach, has been around a long time and knows that winning a double-header doesn't mean a team has reached perfection and can rest on its laurels. We've been moving people around and we are still developing," Bolger told the New Jersey college baseball writers here today.

A German-born Frenchwoman who investigates Nazi criminals chargedd today that the Nazi commissioner in charge of the Warsaw Ghetto during most of its World War II existence is living comfortably in West Germany and has never been prosecuted.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association opened its 87th annual meeting yesterday with an urgent reminder by its chairman that freedom of the press as guaranteed by the First Amendment was in jeopardy and that newspapers throughout the country "must raise their collective voice and defend the American people's need to know."
Rudy May pitched a five-hitter and Frank Robinson delivered a two-run single tonight in leading the California Angels to a 4.0 victory over Oakland A's. Only one Oakland runner reached third base.

The Dynamics Corporation of America, which has been operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since last August, said yesterday its consolidated losses were about $35.4 million last year, and as a result, its net-worth deficit was about $15.6-million as of last Dec. 31.

Earl Monroe is expected to play when the Knicks meet the Celtics in the fifth game of their National Basketball Association Eastern playoff final in Boston tomorrow night. The Knicks lead the series, 3-1, and need one victory to go on to the championship round.

John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, announced at the annual meeting in Morris Township, N. J., yesterday, that the company had increased the quarterly dividend to 33 cents a share from 30 cents.

" People say that I am a good advocate," Thomas Bradford Curtis observed the other day. "If that is so, it is because I advocate what I believe in." Yesterday, the round-faced, baldish, 62 year-old former United States Representative was advocating a reassertion of its "independence and integrity" by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
After-tax corporate profits surged in the first quarter, the First National City Bank reported yesterday. Earnings reported through last Thursday averaged 24 per cent higher than a year ago.

The stone paths of the univer sity campus are quiet now. In the darkened corridors, a hand ful of teachers and graduate students move slowly Loward empty classrooms to finish research and work silently on term papers.

A Conservative party official said yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi must "vindicate himself thoroughly" when he answers reports that he invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Federal grand jury.
Bernadette Devlin, the firebrand member of the British Parliament who has championed the cause of Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland, was married yesterday on her 26th birthday.

Henry A. Kissinger said yesterday that the United States planned to build "a new Atlantic charter" with its European allies this year to overcome the economic, military and diplomatic strains that have developed in the alliance recently.
The Golden State Warriors struck a blow for self respect and extended their playoff series by fighting off the Los Angeles Lakers in the final quarter tonight and posting a 117-109 victory.

Dr. Joseph T. English, the 39-year-old psychiatrist who ha spent nearly three tumultuous years as chief of the city's new public hospital system, an nounced yesterday that he wou leave the post by the end of Mayor Lindsay's term nextDec. 31.

LOS ANGELES--Can judgment on human conduct be reached, and justice established, by any power other than that of the state? Is it not true, in fact that some of the most dramatic wrongs against humanity have been perpetrated by sovereign states, against which there is today no effective recourse short of war or revolution?

Sooner or later, every designer of repute turns up in New York. A first visit to a store here, to supervise fittings and meet with the customers, is like a finishing school diploma. Subsequent visits are like graduate study: the designer is keeping up with trends in his field.
The 750-ton Navy minesweeper Force, torn by a raging fire that swept out of control, sank to day in the Philippine Sea, a spokesman for the commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet announced.
It was comfortably dark the other night when a young man drove a rented panel truck up to the cattle feeding pen down the road from the Emmett McCormick farm near Waukan, Iowa.
Albert Pass, charged with murder in the Yablonski slaying, was denied a change of venue today. But Erie County Judge Edward Carney said he would consider delaying Mr. Pass's scheduled June 4 trial.
A three-judge Federal court ruled today that $2.13-million in con tracts for auxiliary services to parochial schools in New Jersey could be honored for the rest of the school year.

Steel production for the week ended April 21 backed down from the record of 3,002,000 tons set a week earlier, the American Iron and Stee Instiute reported yesterday. The trade association placed output for the April 21 week at 2,995,000 tons, second highest for any week, but a decline of 0.2 per cent.

Lindy McDaniel, the Yankees' tall, seasoned right-hander, continued to show that he has regained the finesse he exhibited as a relief pitcher in 1971 by turning in a superb rescue job tonight. The handsome 37-year-old pitcher kept the Milwaukee Brewers scoreless during 32/3 innings of relief work as New York beat

Ray DeVoll's song recital Saturday night at Tully Hall didn't attract the screaming millions--in truth, the place looked almost empty. But the bel-canto fans missed a bet, for Mr. DeVoll sings far more beautifully than many of their idols.
The number of companies joining the ranks of those with higher first-quarter profits continued to swell as financial statements of a broad, national cross-section of industries poured in yesterday.

The wife of a rabbi who heads the Bobover Hasidic Jewish sect in the Borough Park district of southwest Brooklyn shook her head sadly, and said: "you walk in the street and someone shouts 'Dirty Jew'."

Recent clashes between Jews and non-Jews in the pleasant, tree-lined neighborhood of Borough Park, Brooklyn. include that of a 49-year-old Jewish lawyer who is charged with assaulting a 16-year-old Italian-American youth.
Heather Greenwood, a 15-year-old California schoolgirl who had never before won a big race, beat Shane Gould of Australia at the International swimming meeting at Crystal Palace today.

Brian Gott fried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won $10,000 and gained 10 points in the World Champion ship Tennis standing today without lifting a racquet when Jaime Fillol of Chile became ill and had to default in the final of the $50,000 South African tournament.
was comfortably dark the other night when a young man drove a rented panel truck up to the cattle feed ing pen down the road from the Emmett McCormick farmnear Waukan Iowa.

An accumulation of "small discrepancies" in accounts offered by the prime suspect in the murder of 7-year-old Joan D'Alessandro last Thursday led to his arrest and, the Bergen County Presecutor's officers said today, to the solution of a crime that has severely unsettled this normally placid residential town of 12,000.

Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won $10,000 and gained 10 points in the World Championship Tennis standing today without lifting a racquet when Jaime Fillol of Chile became ill and had to default in the final of the $50,000 South African tournament.
Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, took his campaign for American trade concessions directly to American Senators today and evidently made some headway.
The "safe" bettors took a beating at Pimlico Race Course today when heavily favored Marian Bender finished out of the money, setting up huge show payoffs in the $30,500 Politely Stakes.

Representative Henry S. Reuss said today that neither Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen nor anyone else from the Justice Department should be in charge of the Watergate investigation, suggesting that an impartial outsider be chosen instead.

The Secretary of Health Education and Welfare said to-day that it. was "in very bad taste" for a Massachusetts school district to lock out 2,300 Army children because of reduced Federal impact-aid spending.

WASHINGTON -- Justice rendered and justice perceived are the indispensable first steps in the journey of a thousand miles back from the political espionage and sabotage understatedly characterized as the Watergate affair, to a plateau of national decency and integrity.

Grain futures prices rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade in the wake of heavy rains over the weekend in the principal growing areas of the Midwest and South. Floods are again delaying spring plantings.
Harold (TNT) Carroll of Syracuse, made his first New York City boxing appearance last night in the Felt Forum, and the result had to be considered a moral victory for Carroll.

A State Department spokesman has compounded the confusion that shrouds everything about military operations in Cambodia by insisting that North Vietnamese troops are actively supporting insurgents fighting around Phnom Penh. Only last week, an American Embassy official in the Cambodian capital asserted that there had been no documentary evidence of Vietnamese troops in combat in Cambodia since the Vietnamese cease-fire.

Henry A. Kissinger said yesterday that the United States planned to build "a new Atlantic charter" with its European allies this year to overcome the economic, mili tary and diplomatic strains that have developed in the alliance recently.

Tom Young, who gained his coaching fame at Ameri can University, was named the Rutgers' basketball coach yesterday. The 40-year-old Young had a 61-37 won-lost record in his four-season stay with the Eagles, including a 21-5 mark last season.
Progress was reported today in the effort to relieve underground gas pressure responsible for more than 100 geyser-like eruptions in this crater-scarred resort area.

Brazil devalued the cruzeiro today, setting the buying rate at 6.06 a United States dollar and the selling rate at 6.1. It was the first devaluation and the second readjustment of the cruzeiro this year.

Gunapala Piyasena Malalasekera, former representative of Sri Lanka (formerly Ceylon) to the United Nations, died last night. He was 73 years old. At Ceriter of Activity Mr. Malalasekera was a wellknown figure at the United Nations in the late nineteenfifties and early sixties.

President Nixon met for an hour here last Thursday with John J. Wilson, a Washington lawyer who is representing two Presidential aides, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, in connection with the Watergate scandal.

The public Broadcasting Service announced yesterday it would make available in prime time its "gavel-togavel" coverage of. the Senate Select Committee's Watergate hearings, which are expected to begin May 15.

Two years after the Indian Government began to crack down on the Maoist guerrilla terrorists known as Naxalites, this uneasy city remains in the grip of a fierce police campaign that has led to charges of violent repression of dissidents.
Frederick G. Uhlmann, one of the country's best-known commodities dealers and the chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, is planning to leave H. Hentz Co., Inc., where he is a senior vice president.

Stock prices dropped sharply in continued slow trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market. One broker commented that the market "needs a catalyst" to snap it out of the doldrums."

Racing fans in New Jersey will have an additional 45 days to place their bets this year under the terms of a bill signed today by Gov. William T. Cahill. The measure adds 15 days to the racing season at each of the three thoroughbred race tracks in the state, Garden State, Atlantic City and Monmouth Park.

Two Army helicopters collided in a driving rainstorm and crashed today, killing eight soldiers flying simulated missions. The crash took place during military war games witnessed by Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson.

The wild fluctuations of form that have marked the National Basketball Association playoffs were still in evidence today following a 117-109 victory by the Golden State Warriors over the Los Angeles Lakers here last night.

The ranking judges of New York State announced yesterday that they were getting ready to open up the inner workings of the courts to the public and that they intended to set up a public relations department to help them do it.

Robert Dain, proprietor of a Madison Avenue art gallery, was found stabbed to death last night in his apartment nearby. He had been reported missing by gallery associates when he failed to appear at a showing earlier yesterday.
The leader of the Congolese guerrilla movement and his deputy were killed early today by security forces, according to an announcement broadcast by the Brazzaville radio.

Governor Rockefeller's package of court-reform proposals continued to draw a mixed response yesterday, with the chief judge of the state praising it as "a positive step forward" and a Democratic contender for the job of chief judge criticizing it as a plan to "make the courts more dependent on politics than ever." . .

Drug-prevention programs in city high schools have shown "a marked degree of effectiveness in changing student behavior," a report made public yesterday by city health and education officials asserts.

The Army has ordered a 10 per cent cutback in the number of basic training companies because of the shrinkage in its strength, a spokesman said today. A total of 30 of the 300 basic training companies will be eliminated at six Army training centers from coast to coast.

Optimism for textbook publishing was exaggerated eight years ago just as the pessimism of investors is exaggerated today, Shelton Fisher, president of McGraw-Hill, Inc., said yesterday at the annual meeting here.

The Montreal Expos erupted for seven runs in the ninth inning to score a 7-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in Riverfront Stadium last night. The defeat dropped the Reds two games behind San Francisco's Western Division leaders in the National League.
In its efforts to set longrange health and medical research policies for the nation, the Nixon Administration clearly feels beleaguered by what it regards as spendthrifts.

Disaster : Major American Catastrophes, by A. A. Hoehling (Hawthorn Books, $6.95). Downhill Lies and Other Falsehoods, or How to Play Dirty Golf, by Rex Lardner, drawings by Roy Schlemme (Hawthorn Books, $4.95).

The Kentucky Colonels, getting 31 points from Dan Issel, never trailed as they registered a 107-96 victory over the Carolina Cougars tonight for the East Division crown and a berth in the playoff finals against the Indiana Pacers for the American Basketball Association championship.

A Frenchman who is general manager of the official Soviet Embassy newsletter in Paris was found guilty today of defamation and "incitement to racial hatred and violence" for publishing an anti-Jewish article.

This predominantly black city, long a bellwether in the civil rights struggle, has adopted a controversial, minimum-desegregation school plan that some race experts think could affect the integration picture all across the United States.

They held a sort of revival meeting at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, with the New York Yankees and Chicago White Sox both trying to recapture something from the past. But the Yankees found it less uplifting than the White Sox,
The stock market suffered one of its worst setbacks in nearly three years yesterday in moderate trading. The Dow-Jones industrial average slid 14.60 points and closed at 940.77.
A bomb explosion in a crowded restaurant yesterday killed five people and wounded 11, the military command reported today. The blast at My Tho in the Mekong Delta, 70 miles south of Saigon,
Cartomancy, or divination with the aid of playing cards, is a dubious art in the fortune-telling field. For the bridge-player it is a vital science, but also one that is little-understood.

Karl Thornton, former University of Pennsylvania track captain, won the first marathan race to be staged at the Penn Relays today. It was the first time Thornton, from Binghamton, N.Y., had run a race of more than 20 miles.
The nation's efforts to ameliorate its air pollution have become so complex administratively that any citizen could be forgiven for being as confused on the subject as a Tibetan at a baseball game.

Hunting remains legal in Morris Township, but members of this community's two gun clubs are aware they may soon have to set their sights in other directions. Late last summer, the township's upland game and deer enthusiasts received a bad scare. The community's fathers-made up of five committeemen-voted in favor of continued hunting by the margin of 3 to 2.

The California Horse Racing Board today unanimously approved Sunday racing for the remainder of Hollywood Park's 15-week season. The three-member board voted favorably on the track's application for Sunday racing days, saying there was nothing prohibiting it.

With his call for "a fresh act of creation" equal to the effort that built the Marshall Plan and the Atlantic Alliance after World War II, Henry A. Kissinger has tried to project the outline of President Nixon's "Year of Europe." if the "new Atlantic Charter" envisioned by Mr. Kissinger in his address to The Associated Press luncheon in New York is still a hazy concept, its general form may be beginning to take shape.

The University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team announced today it had declined an invitation to visit the People's Republic of China. A U.C.L.A. spokesman said the team and coaches had been "favorable" to the idea during a meeting three weeks ago if the timing would not interfere with the academic calendar.
John F. Rich, who founded the fund-raising consulting organization of that name here in 1946, died Saturday while visiting in Athens. He was 70 years old and lived in Haverford.
Icelandic coastguard vessels fired live shells and peppered British fishing trawlers with rifle fire in a flare-up of the long dispute over fishing rights.

The Moet et Chandon champagne firm has bought land in California to make a sparkling wine in the United States, a spokesman said today. The National Committee for Wines of France said Mott's investment would mark the first time a French company has produced wine in the United States.

Arnold Constable, Inc., a Fifth Avenue specialty store with a branch in West Orange, N. J., is conducting a twoweek "experimental" imitation of the current bank premium promotions by offering gifts to customers.
Apparently shocked by what he described as "apartheid at close quarters," Stan Smith, the top ranking United States tennis player, said he would think carefully before returning to South Africa.

The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first quarter of this year. Operating revenues rose to $425.1-million from $369.4-million in the 1972 period.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell testified before a Federal grand jury here yesterday, apparently about a $200,000 cash contribution from Robert L. Vesco to President Nixon's 1972 election campaign.

Henri Richard backhanded in the winning goal at 12 minutes 7 seconds of the third period as the Montreal Canadiens eliminated the Philadelphia Flyers from the Stanley Cup playoffs tonight with a 5-3 victory.

Hamilton Fish Armstrong, an authority on international politics and editor of the quarterly Foreign Affairs for 44 years until his retirement last fall, died yesterday at the New York University Medical Center after a long illness. He was 80 years old on April 7.
The publishers of the four Saturday Review magazines filed bankruptcy proceedings yesterday and announced plans to merge the publications with World magazine to form a single biweekly.
It was 6 P.M. Easter Sunday when Jack Dunn set up his folding chair outside the headquarters of Local 46 of the Metallic Lathers Union, at 1322 Third Avenue.

The availability of John Havlicek for tonight's National Basketball Association playoff game at'Boston between the Knicks and Celties was the nagging question yesterday as the Knicks aimed to end the four-ofseven-game series.
The Athens Jewish community has taken legal action to save this city's only two synagogues from demolition for archeological exploration.

While his slightly tarnished "big horse" relaxed in Kentucky, Ron Turcotte rode four winners at Aqueduct yesterday. "Turcotte's revenge," said a delighted backer as he headed for the windows to cash a ticket on King Ray ($7.60) after the ninth race.
Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira disclosed today that his Government had rejected President Nixon's invitation to Emperor Hirohito to make a state visit to the United States.

The Philadelphia 76ers, selecting first in the National Basketball Association's college draft, picked Doug Collins of Illinois State yesterday even as they were threatening to make the whole draft process illegal. Collins is a 6-foot-6-inch guard who was on the United States Olympic team last year.
The United States made public today a sharply worded reply to Hanoi's charges of ceasefire violations, accusing the North Vietnamese of "direct and inexcusable"

In a flurry of annual meetings, some 145 major corporations confronted their stockholders yesterday in New York and other parts of the country. Today, 103 more annual meetings are scheduled, to be followed by 96 tomorrow and 42 on Friday.

High-ranking Administration officials said today that Henry A. Kissinger's call yesterday for "a new Atlantic charter" was meant to signal Western European leaders that President Nixon wants to sign a major document of agreed principles when he visits their countries later this year.

A Ber gen County executive of a trading stamp and supermarket chain was indicted today on charges that he lied in saying that a $5,000 contribution to Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign fund was a legitimate business expense.

June Hart, the 20-year-old daughter of Mayor William S. Hart of East Orange, was sentenced yesterday to a four-to-six-year term on, a manslaughter conviction for fatally stabbing a girlfriend last October. The sentence was handed down by Superior Court Judge Leon Milmed despite a plea from Miss Hart's lawyer, Raymond Brown, that his client not be imprisoned. He said a prison term "could destroy the fabric within her."

The sun has been shining on Muncie for the last two days and, after a spring plagued by rain, that seems to surprise and interest folks here more than the daily revelations about the Watergate scandal emerging from the nation's capital.

ATHENS-An extensive survey of the Pacific-Asian area leads to one paramount conclusion: the storm center has moved westward. It is no longer Southeast and South Asian regions that threaten world conflict. Now we are back to square one-that Southwest Asian area known as the Middle East.

Rod Laver of Australia went into action today and defeated Rob Maud of South Africa 6-3, 6-4, in the first round of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis Group A tournament. Cliff Richey of Sarasota, Fla., won from Rhodesia's Andrew Pattison. 6-1. 4-6. 6-4.

Racing fans in New Jersey will have an additional 45 days to place their bets this year under the terms of a bill signed today by Gov. William T. Cahill. The measure adds 15 days to the racing season at each of the three thoroughbred race tracks in the state,...

Nine medical educators from the metropolitan area met last week with editors and reporters of The New York Times and warned of a crisis in medical education and research in the years ahead if projected cuts in Federal support in these areas go through.

Shortly after 9 P.M. Perry Smith took a chair in a cramped cell on the fourth floor, the "operating level" of Madison Square Garden. On the wall facing him were 10 television monitors-eight small black-and-white sets and two larger screens in color. Most showed a Roller Derby girl in tile Garden's main arena chopping another girl with karate blows,

Three of the top four auto makers, the General Motors Corporation, the American Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, continued to sell cars at record levels during the period of April 11-20.

The United Rubber Workers Union and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company continued their contract negotiations today past a midnight strike deadline, but there were no reports on how the talks were going.

The Pathet Lao accused the Laotian Government today of delaying the formation of a new provisional government by making unreasonable demands that do not conform to the February cease-fire accord signed by the two parties.

Karl Thornton, former University of Pennsylvania track captain, won the first marathan race to be staged at the Penn Relays today. It was the first time Thornton, from Binghamton, N.Y., had run a race of more than 20 miles.

The Polaroid Corporation and the Eastman Kodak Company told shareholders at their annual meetings yesterday of planned new products and of efforts to advance instant photography.

The Supreme Court ruled today that a criminal defendant cannot contend he has been unfairly trapped by undercover Government agents if they helped him commit the crime but did not give him the idea in the first place.

It was within the last year, the State Deprtment said, that Hertz refused to put Ambassador David K. E. Bruce in the driver's seat of one of its cars at Washington National Airport.
CURTAIN CALL The doctor's house call has gone the way of the trolley car, but it's nice to know they're still available for curtain calls.

A Queens building contractor, who was changing a flat tire near his home at 151-10 84th Drive, Kew Gardens, was shot three times and critically wounded by assailants who made their escape in a green sedan.
Peking announced today that trade-union congresses had been held and union councils formed in Peking and Shanghai, the principal Chinese cities.

The University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team announced today it had declined an invitation to visit the People's Republic of China. A U.C.L.A. spokesman said the team and coaches had been "favorable" to the idea during a meeting three weeks ago if the timing would not interfere with the academic calendar.

Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these short-term securities. The average rate for 12month bills in this month's sale is 6.598 per cent down from last month's 6.615 per cent.

The State Banking Commissioner, Richard F. Schaub, announced today the appointment of Philip A. Kerner as deputy commissioner of the State Department of Banking. Mr. Kerner, 43 years old, of East Anwell Township, Hunterdon County,
Frederick J. Ludwig, the Acting District Attorney of Queens, was questioned at length yesterday by the state's anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari.
The Washington Steel Corporation said today it would comply with a request from the Committee on Interest and Dividends by lowering its next quarterly dividend to 22 cents from 23 cents.

Rudolf Nureyev is back in town, this time with the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House. It may seem a little unfair to mention Mr. Nureyev before mentioning the company, but the two of them do get equal billing in all publicity and while one expects Mr. Nureyev at the Metropolitan it seems possible that the Canadians, who were making their Manhattan debut, might not have made the trip without him.
West German Government spokesman announced in Bonn today that the West German visit of Leonid I. Brezhnev would take place May 18 to May 22, a week later than originally planned.
Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira disclosed today that his Government had rejected President Nixon's invitation to Emperor Hirohito to make a state visit to the United States.
The Chicago North Western Railway announced today that it had ordered 1,200 boxcars costing more than $20-million, equipment that it said was in
Governor Cahill signed a tough campaign disclosure bill into law today even as a Federal investigation of fund-raising activities for the Governor's 1969 campaign produced its first indictment.

Leonard Stein, one of Britain's first Zionists, died here yesterday at the age of 85. Mr. Stein, a lawyer specializing in taxation, was educated at St. Paul's School and Balliol College, Oxford. Early in the century-he first visited Palestine in 1908-he was actively promoting Zionism.
James F. Nugent, retired general foreman of the West Shore division of what is now the Penn Central Railroad, died yesterday at his home in Brielle, N.J. He was 80 years old.

The oil industry delivered its own energy message yesterday: solid, across-the-board profits for the first quarter of 1973. Nine major oil companies announced earnings figures, and all were up. On Monday the world's largest oil company, the Exxon Corporation, and three other big petroleum concerns also reported higher profits.

There are ominous hints of impending new United States military action in Indochina in Henry A. Kissinger's charge before The Associated Press meeting that North Vietnam has "totally violated" the Vietnam ceasefire agreement, an accusation that was backed up yesterday by a formal protest to signatories of the Paris peace accords.

Culminating five years of restructing, the Celanese Corporation annonuced yesterday that it had formed a new threemember corporate office to develop growth strategies. John W. Brooks, the 55-yearold company chairman and chief executive, said the new office would be composed of himself; Peter H. Conze, 52,

Several highly profitable railroads issued earnings statements yesterday in which they complained of a cost-price squeeze that the industry traces to the Interstate Commerce Commission's rejection last February of a 2 per cent emergency freight rate surcharge.

A lone man said to have been wearing a goatee and a large, brimmed hat, entered the Chemical Bank branch at 957 Broadway, Brooklyn, at 9:40 A.M. yesterday. The man was unarmed, according to the police and passed a note to a woman teller demanding money. He was given $1,500 and fled.

Mrs. Frances Emerson Reissig, the wife of the Rev. Dr. Herman R. Reissig, died yesterday at her home, 5 Deepwoods Lane. She was 67 years old. Mrs. Reissig had assisted her husband when he was international relations secretary of the Council for Christian Social Action.

About 100 Oglala Sioux Indians defied the Justice Department this afternoon and set up a new roadblock on the trail to Wounded Knee. A similar roadblock was torn down by Federal agents last night, and eight persons manning it were arrested.

Thirty-seven grants totaling more than $1.1-million to municipalities, planning and environmental groups in 34 states, Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia for City Edges projects have been announced in Washington by Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts.

Vasek Simek is the director and, one assumes, the uncredited compiler of 'A Phantasmagoria Historia of D. Johann Fausten Magister, PhD, MD, DD, DL, Etc.," which opened last night at the Truck and Warehouse Theater.
The release of the first civilian prisoners of war in Vietnam was delayed today by a dispute between the Vietcong and South Vietnamese over their release sites.

The extent of President Nixon's influence over the Watergate investigation is a matter of growing concern among former members of the Justice Department and among legal scholars and lawyers associated with the case.
Former Premier Tanzan Ishibashi died early today. He was 88 years old. Philosopher and politician Mr. Ishibashi was a philosopher and economist; a bon vivant and the son of a Buddhist priest;

The Greyhound Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Russ Togs, Inc., manufacturers of women's and children's apparel. The proposal calls for the exchange of 1.25 share of Greyhound common for each of the approximately 4 million common shares of Russ Togs outstanding.
Julius J. Gans, a retired justice of the State Supreme Court who served in the Assembly from 1936 to 1954, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 44 East 67th Street.

A civilian tow-truck driver for the Police Department, Angel Anzisi, was wounded last night when motorists in a passing car fired at him with a revolver and a shotgun-as he sat in his parked truck on 11th Avenue at 26th Street, the police reported.
Superior Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne, who a Mafia figure in New Jersey once said "couldn't be bought," announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
Paul Miller, chairman and chief executive of the Gannett Company, was re-elected chairman of The Associated Press at its annual meeting yesterday.

Federal investigators have determined that officials of the White House were regularly kept informed last May and June of some of the information obtained through the illegal wiretapping 'of the Democratic National Committee headquarters, sources close to the case said today.

Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, has informed Representative Les Aspin he has not been able to sell 12,028 shares of his stock in Litton Industries, Inc., because it has been held as collateral for a bank loan made to a third party.

The United States' proposal for a "new Atlantic charter" was generally welcomed today in European capitals, where officials said that it provided a new vision of if not new solutions to vexing problems in the alliance.
The new United States liaison mission in Peking is likely to be housed near a park called Altar of the Sun in the eastern part of the city.

A 30-year-old woman was found yesterday morning stabbed to death with a pair of scissors in a quiet residential hotel on the Upper West Side. The victim, identified by the police as Angela Catelano was discovered by a maid on the floor of her $25-a-week single room in the Riverside Studios Hotel at 342 West 71st Street.
A Scottish freighter today rescued all 65 crewmen of a Navy minesweeper eight hours after the woodenhulled ship burned and sank in the Philippine Sea, the Navy announced.

School District 13 in Brooklyn covers all of Brooklyn Heights and Fort Greene, a small part of Park Slope and a large chunk of BedfordStuyvesant. There are 26.000 students in the district's four junior high and 18 elementary schools.
Mrs. Jane Booth, finishing with a hole-in-one, opened a spectacular defense of her North and South amateur golf championship today with an impressive 5-and-3 victory over Nancy Hager.
Chris Bordeleau of Winnipeg scored at 17:49 of the third period to end a Houston rally and give the Jets a 4-2 victory tonight in the World Hockey Association Western Division playoff.
United States District Judge James Lawrence King has refused to grant Meyer Lansky, the reputed underworld financial manipulator, a new trial on charges of criminal contempt.

Dr. Albert B. Sabin, whose vaccine has eliminated polio as a widespread health problem in large areas of the world, claimed proof today that a common virus is a causative factor in nine types of human cancer.
The deluge of first-quarter financial statements continued to flow yesterday from a long, nationwide list of companies, giving further evidence of record - breaking corporate profits for the period.

A Council of Magistrates ruled today that publication of an antiGovernment statement from former Premier Constantine Caramanlis constituted "an act of subversion," and the police tonight were looking for two executives of the Athens newspaper that first printed it.
The executive leadership of Cambodia became a four-man council today under an agreement by which President Lon Nol will share power equally with three leading political opponents.

The Government said today that substantial progress had been made in reducing the number of classified documents in its files.

Swelling toward the greatest flood crest in the recorded history of the Mississippi, that river and its tributaries drove thousands more from their homes today along 1,400 miles of flooded watershed from Iowa to the Deep South.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell testified before a Federal grand jury here yesterday, apparently about a $200,000 cash contribution from Robert L. Vesco to President Nixon's 1972 election campaign.

Former Deputy Attorney General David A. Biederman, who touched off a Federal grandjury investigation that led to the indictment of former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin on extortion and conspiracy charges, heard himself charged with a conflict of interest today in a hearing before the State Supreme Court.
The year that was supposed to belong to the Rangers ended abruptly tonight before a bellowing Chicago Stadium crowd as the Black Hawks crushed another New York dream with a 4-1 victory.

Rapping Jon Matlack, a left-hander, for eight of their nine hits, the Houston Astros stretched their longest winning streak of the season to six games tonight, defeating the New York Mets, 4-2, before a crowd of 12,759 in the Astrodome.

The ranking judges of New York State announced yesterday that they were getting ready to open up the inner workings of the courts to the public and that they intended to set up a public relations department to help them do it.

Kent Leavitt, a past president of the National Association of Soil Conservation Districts, died yesterday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at Fraleigh Hill Farm, where he raised Hereford cattle.

Capt. William V. Bradley president emeritus of the Inter national Longshoremen's Association, died Monday night near his home in Staten 'Island when his auto crashed into a parked car. His age was 70.
The prosecution authorities announced today that a group of nine South Koreans had been arrested on charges of spying for North Korea or collaborating in espionage activities.
Apparently shocked .by what he described as "apartheid at close quarters," Stan Smith, the top ranking United States tennis player, said he would think carefully before returning to South Africa.

British shipbuilding concerns obtained orders for 64 merchant ships of 570,200 compensated tons (1,292,800 gross tons) in the first quarter of 1973, the Shipbuilders and Repairers National Association announced today.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority made public yesterday a long-awaited blueprint from consultants recommending a $1-billion transformation of Stewart Airport near Newburgh into a major facility that, by 1990, would handle almost twice the traffic Kennedy International Airport handles today.
The Vatican appears worried by a series of Arab attacks on the Roman Catholic Church following a declaration by France's bishops upholding the Jewish people's right to nationhood.

Individuals reputedly active in organized crime were among 13 persons indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan in an alleged conspiracy to cheat investors in stock in a concern established to lease luxury automobiles.

The Police Department yesterday announced the,abolition of the words "patrolman" and "policewoman" from its official lexicon. The two titles have been replaced by the sexually neutral term "police officer."

Seven American Senators ended a five-day visit to the Soviet Union today after one of them met secretly with prominent Moscow Jews to get their views on the controversial emigration issue.

The study commission created by Governor Rockefeller and the State Legislature two years ago to investigate the governmental organization and practices of New York City has completed its work without ever succeeding in separating itself from the all-consuming hostility between the Governor and Mayor Lindsay.
Superior Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne, who a Mafia figure in New Jersey once said "couldn't be bought," announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., in a bid for a preferred ballot position in the June 5 primary, intends to run a slate of candidates for county office against Governor Cahill and the Bergen County Republican organization.

Instead of being subjected to a vote of no confidence, Dr. Joseph T. English last night won a pledge from the directors of the city's public-hospital system that they will "cooperate fully" with him as long as he stays in office.

The Nixon re-election organization attempted last May to genrate a favorable public response to the President's decision to mine Haiphong harbor in North Vietnam, The Washington Post reported tonight.

A House Judiciary subcommittee will propose legislation to reorganize the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission in a way similar to an Administration proposal. However, it will seek to retain more Congressional control over the controversial commission's activities, according to informed sources.

The nation's two top steel producers, the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, and several major copper companies reported yesterday higher earnings , sales, production and shipments in the first three months.
Fortified by a 12-day Easter-Passover vacation after completing 15 weeks of desultory sessions more notable for inertia than achievement, the Legislature resumes here tomorrow.
A one-day strike of concretetruck drivers that had blocked most deliveries of cement and concrete to construction sites was settled early yesterday after all-night negotiations.
Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court today tc force the Cost of Living Council to open meetings of its advisory committees to the public.

A state commission studying the salaries of legislators and members of the judiciary met secretly in New York City today and is expected to recommend shortly substantial increases for the state's 210 Senators and Assemblymen.

Ted Garvin was hired today as coach of the National Hockey League's Detroit Red Wings and was expected to become hockey's counterpart of Billy Martin, the volatile manager of baseball's Detroit Tigers.

Torrential rain that has fallen in the last two weeks has forced sharp curtailments of paper manufacturing in an area covering East Texas, Louisiana, Arkansas and Mississippi. The International Paper Company said yesterday that it had ordered curtailments in six of its primary mills in the South, and had put customers on allocations.

High-ranking Administration officials said today that Henry A. Kissinger's call yesterday for "a new Atlantic charter" was meant to signal Western European leaders- that President Nixon wants to sign a major document of agreed principles when he visits their countries later this year.
The Rhodesian security forces lost four men killed and five seriously wounded in operations against black nationalist guerrillas, a Government communique said today.

After five years as president of the 11,000-member Uniformed Firefighters Association, Michael J. Maye has been defeated in a bid for re-election for a two-year term.
The Environmental Protection Agency has been asked to prohibit du Pont industries from dumping 66,000 tons of toxic, chemical wastes into the Gulf of Mexico and off the East Coast every month.

A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent testified today that Morton H. Halperin, a former Defense Department official, had said that he sent the Pentagon papers to the Rand Corporation for storage "acting as an official of the United States Government."

High-ranking Administration officials said yesterday that Henry A. Kissinger's call for "a new Atlantic Charter" was meant to signal Western European leaders that President Nixon wants to sign a major document of agreed principles when he visits their countries later this year. [Page 1, Column 1.]

A 20-year old former custodian of the 123-year-old First Methodist Church here was held today in lieu of $10,000 bail and charged with setting a fire in the build ing last Saturday that heavily damaged the landmark.
The publishers of the four Saturday Review magazines filed bankruptcy proceedings yesterday and announced plans to merge the publications with World magazine to form a single biweekly.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported a net loss of $19.1-million in the first quarter this year, an improvement on the $30.9-million deficit reported in the first quarter of 1972.

"People were always dreaming up backstage feuds among us but there was nothing to it-we got along divinely," said Audrey Christie, a member of the original cast of Clare Boothe Luce's 1936 play, "The Women."

American space experts strongly suspect that a "catastrophic failure" connected with the Soviet Union's Salyut 2 prevented Soviet astronauts from making an attempt to man the large, earth-orbiting space station.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority made public yesterday a long-awaited blueprint from consultants recommending a $1-billion transformation of Stewart Airport near Newburgh into a major facility that, by 1990, would, handle almost twice the traffic Kennedy International Airport handles today.

Chile's leftist Government said today that it would return 125 Soviet tractors that it said proved unsuitable for the country's terrain. Opposition press reports said the $30,000 tractors did not work.

Federal Judge Jacob Mishler ruled in Brooklyn yesterday that Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan was not an American citizen and therefore could be expatriated to West Germany to face charges that she murdered inmates of a Nazi death camp.

The head the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, opposed proposals today for the creation of a bargaining bloc of oil-consuming nations, such as the plan that the Nixon Administration is reported to be preparing.

Strong demand for a new issue of Bell System debentures served to put some spine into parts of the bond market yesterday but prices over-all continued to struggle to hold their own. Treasury securities, anticipating the May refunding terms to be announced. late today,

Cotton futures prices continued to move up yesterday, still responding to talk of flooding in the cotton-growing areas along the Mississippi River. The National Weather Service expects the river to crest at a record high tomorrow.

What is the new Federal policy on secrecy in scientific research? Despite a five-page Executive order dealing with freedom of information that went into effect 10 months ago, the interpretation of the Presidential document's fine print as it pertains to scientific research apparently remains a secret, according to one professor who made a persistent effort to find out.

The behind-the-scenes story of how the almost legendary Carl Akeley collected animals in Africa and started a new art form in displaying the mounted specimens is told in a new exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History.

The Civil Aeronautics Board rejected today a proposal by American Airlines to offer discounts of up to 30 per cent on domestic flights of more than 1,000 miles.

At the end of their annual meeting yesterday the members of the 60-year-old Bureau of Advertising voted to change its name to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. It's only right, since that's the only kind of advertising it's interested in.

The 23,395-ton Holland America cruise liner Volendam arrived here yesterday from European ports to take up station here. The 617-foot steamship was accorded the traditional port welcome for new ships, complete with fireboat salute and surface and aerial escort.
Gasoline allocations to retail dealers are being cut back throughout the Sun Oil Company's 34-state marketing territory, a company spokesman said today.

The malaise oppressing Wall Street deepened yesterday and the stock market suffered. one of its worst setbacks in nearly three years. The Dow Jones industrial average sagged 14.60 points and closed at 940.77 after dropping nearly 7 points in the final 30 minutes of trading.

Ursula Jeans, the British stage and screen actress, died Saturday in a nursing home near here. She was 66 years old. Miss Jeans had been on tour recently in South Africa with her husband, Roger Livesey, the actor, in the P. G. Wodehouse play "Oh Clarence."

Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the Connecticut Republican who has been pressing for a full disclosure of the Watergate case, said today he had no evidence that would indicate President Nixon knew about the bugging in advance or subsequently tried to cover it up.

President Hugo Banzer Suarez of Bolivia today installed a reshuffled cabinet in which the armed forces were given an additional seat to put them on an equal footing with the two main political parties that support his military government.

It has discovered the sales appeal of "hypo allergenic"-a term that simply means a product is less allergenic than something else.

British troops came under fire twice in the Londonderry area today. A patrol in one of the city's Roman Catholic areas, Creggan Estate, clashed with a stonethrowing crowd and a nail bomb went off harmlessly near other soldiers.
Plans to attract increased Japanese manufacturing investment to Puerto Rico were announced yesterday by the island commonwealth's Economic Development Administration.

Ezra Pound is, to put it mildly, not well known as a composer--he even described himself once as an "incompetent amateur" in that regard. But he did have something of a musical background, he did practice music criticism and he did, in fact, compose. Fantasy Records in Berkeley, Calif., has now recorded his opera, "Le Testament de Villon" (12001, $4.98), and it turns out to be an altogether fascinating piece of work.
