WASHINGTON -- Sir Winston Churchill once remarked: "What's the use of being a famous race and nation if, at the end of the week, you can't pay your housekeeping bill?" By most of the usual statistics, the second Nixon Administration is off to an excellent start.

The Health Research Group, a consumer-oriented organization affiliated with Ralph Nader, has petitioned the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to bar from the market one brand of the antibiotic drug erythromycin.

Federal investigators have determined that officials of the White House were regularly kept informed last May and June of some of the information obtained through the illegal wiretapping of the Democratic National Committee headquarters, sources close to the case said today.

Ambassador William D. Eberle, special United States trade negotiator, today invited trade association representatives to pour in data to help the United States trade negotiators build their case.
Representative Herman Badillo charged yesterday that "too many important public interests" had been sacrificed in the city's bargaining with its employes.

HACKENSACK - Joseph McGowan, a 26-year-oldhigh school teacher, was indicted by a Bergen County grand jury today on a charge of murdering 7-year-old Joan D'Allesandro, who had gone to his home to deliver Girl Scout cookies.

A secondary offering of 375,000 shares of Lawson Products, Inc., common at $19 per share was made by underwriters headed by Blyth Eastman Dillon and Bacon, Whipple Co. A group headed by White, Weld Co. plans to sell sometime this week 637,674 shares of Hecla Mining Company.

Two weeks ago, 42 candidates were vying for the nine seats on the school board in Brooklyn's District 13. Yesterday that number was down to 31 as a result of a well-financed legal battle over the validity of nominating petitions that left many of the candidates convinced that the United Federation of Teachers had allied with a local politician to eliminate some candidates in Tuesday's election.

Charles L. McConnell, as president of Lithographers and Photo-Engravers' Union No. l-P, said yesterday that he had filed quit in Supreme Court against the Chemical Bank, seeking a judgment of $100,000 or the applicable interest on an account maintained by the union With the bank.

Nine medical educators from the metropolitan area met last week with editors and reporters of The New York Times and warned of a crisis in medical education and research in the years ahead if projected cuts in Federal support in these areas go through.
The executive leadership of Cambodia became a four-man council today under an agreement by which President Lon Nol will share power equally with three leading political opponents.
An inmate of the Manhattan House of Detention for Men who is the editor of the prison newspaper was stabbed in the chest last night by another Tombs inmate, according to the police.

H. R. Haldeman, who once ran the Nixon White House with stern efficiency, appeared today to have lost much of his power as reports mounted that a shake-up in the staff, including resignations, was being planned.

A new 17-man cabinet was formed here today under Amin Hafez to guide Lebanon in the critical days following the Israeli raid two weeks ago in which three Palestinian guerrilla leaders were assassinated in their homes in this city.
The Union Pacific Corporation, one of the most diversified of the railroad holding companies, reported yesterday a 37 per cent gain in earnings on a 9 per cent increase in gross revenues and sales.

For more than 25 years, the Corps of Engineers had a huge model of the Mississippi River Basin here on which it could study the river's quirks and problems, like those occurring during this year's flooding.
Communist forces bombarded the suburbs of Phnom Penh at dawn today for the first time in seven months. Government positions throughout the country were violently attacked.

Henry Fisk Carlton, a former president of the Radio Writers Guild, who is credited with writing the first dramas for radio broadcast, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 315 East 68th Street.

If, on recent woodland walks, you have felt that crows are particularly brazen this spring, you may be right, for they are now an official game bird, protected by law.

A veteran explorer of gravitation. al theory told members of the National Academy of Sciences today that the collapse of the universe into a single, great "black hole" with the annihilation of all matter and all physical laws seemed ultimately inevitable.

The General American Transportation Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the American Steamship Company for 200,000 shares of General American common stock and $45.4-million in cash and notes.

The value of knitted outerwear at the wholesale level in 1972 was estimated at $1.7billion, or 26 per cent above the level of output in 1971, Sidney Korzenik, executive director of the National Knitted Outerwear Association said yesterday.
General Electric stockholders today defeated proposals sponsored by church groups that challenged the company's policies in South Africa and on production of military weapons.
The Federal Reserve System was asked by Government investigators to trace money carried by the wife of the Watergate conspirator, E. Howard Hunt, at the time of her death last year.
United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern said today that better investigative work rather than stiffer sentences may be the road to better crime prevention.

The New England Whalers, who lead the Cleveland Crusaders 3-1 in the World Hockey Association playoff semifinals, will try to wrap up the four-ofseven-game series tomorrow night without two key players.
Hudson County has again emerged as a key to the fortunes of the Democratic party in this year's gubernatorial elections.
The United Rubber Workers and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reached agreement early today on a new contract calling for wage increases totaling about 16 per cent over three years.

Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, said today that he had agreed to a request by Federal prosecutors to stop publishing excerpts from secret testimony taken by the grand jury investigating the Watergate bugging case.
Vice President Agnew reiterated his faith in President Nixon today but conceded for the first time that some of the speculation on the Watergate scandal might eventually be substantiated.

Eileen Di Tullio is a New York-born soprano who has sung here only intermittently since she made a successful debut in the nineteen-fifties, but she has an enthusiastic following worthy of a prima donna. In her latest recital, in Tully Hall on Tuesday night, she made it apparent why this is so. Her light lyric voice has the kind of sheen that immediately pleases the ear.
Four more states were added today to the growing list of jurisdictions ordered to repay more than $20-million in federal education funds they are accused of misspending.

George T. Senseney, an architect and physicist who was associated with the early phases of the nuclear and space programs, died Monday night at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 66 years old.

Officials of the New York Coliseum presented a plan yesterday for a $274-million expansion of their exhibition hall as an alternative to the exhibition center, which these opponents say would cost upward of $750million.

Commuters who would like to hear a bit of music before heading home at a still early hour may find what they have been looking for in the new 6 o'clock "Encore" series of concerts being presented by Town Hall and Dubonnet. Dubonnet? Yes, the aperitif, which is credited on the program as being a product of the Schenley Imports Company.

Robert T. Carson, a former aide to Senator Hiram L. Fong, Republican of Hawaii, sentenced to 18 months on a conspiracy and perjury conviction, was granted parole today by the United States Board of Parole.

Mrs. Dorothy McGrayne Olney, a producer-manager of stage plays and concerts for 35 years, died Monday in an auto accident in Newtown, Conn., where she had been a resident for the last six months. Her age was 73. Mrs. Olney was the wife of Tulian F. Olney, also a stage producer and was a graduate of Barnard College.

The value of trained retrievers is at a record high. A prospective field trial winner brings from $15,000 to $20,000. Authorities estimate it costs $1,000 a point on the way to a championship. Since it takes 10 points, it's a costly business.

Favorable profit results for the first quarter of this year were plentiful again yesterday for a variety of companies. The number of records and sharply higher sales and earnings exceeded expectation, even though the comparison was made with a less favorable first quarter of last year.

Fuad Chehab, the first commander of the Lebanese Army and former President of this Middle Eastern republic, died today after a heart attack at his country home near here.

The Boston Celtics, inspired by an 18point scoring effort by John Haviicek, who was not expected to play, held off the New York Knicks in the final seconds of play and stayed alive in the National Basketball Association playoff competition with a 98-97 triumph tonight at Boston Garden.

Security at the White House is described as adequate by the two top Secret Service officials. They said it did not seem likely that President Nixon would have to use an available tunnel to escape if a mob attempted to storm his official residence.

One sure victim of Watergate, lying dead with none to mourn, is an institution that has served the nation well for a couple of centuries: the grand jury.

The rival South Vietnamese regimes traded new plans for a political settlement here today, just two days before the end of the 90-day period set by the ceasefire agreement for a solution to their dispute.
The Royal Typewriter division of Litton Industries, Inc., announced yesterday a new compact desk-top office copier, the Royal Citation, aimed at the low-copy volume market.
Two Democrats filed a $100,000 damage suit today against Senator William Brock, a Republican, charging he had slandered 1970 campaigners for the former Democratic Senator, Albert Gore.

Allegations of improper pressure by the White House on the independent Corporation for Public Broadcasting were described as "a phony issue" and as "outrageous" and inaccurate in interviews with three members of the corporation's board.

The Police Department gave its commanders a manual yesterday describing 22 different kinds of police corruption found in New York City telling how to spot such problems in individual commands and offering specific methods to reduce various kinds of graft.

Richard J. Vizzini, who was elected president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association Tuesday night in a surprise victory over Michael J. Maye, the incumbent, yesterday promised aggressive bargaining for a new contract.

Three Soviet urbanologists, on a tour of United States cities, visited this "new town" today as part of their study of the American urban environment. The group is the first of 11 environmental exchange groups to visit the United States under an environmental treaty signed last May by President Nixon.

The neoFascist movement, which won nearly 9 per cent of the vote in the general election last year, is now politically isolated, under strong pressure on several fronts and torn by dissension in its ranks.
New Jersey's first horse meat market in years opened to brisk business here today. Customers lined up well in advance of the 9 A.M. opening, eager to take advantage of the low prices.
John F. Hennessy, chairman of the consulting engineering concern of Syska Hennessy, of which he was a co-founder in 1928, died Tuesday at his Caribbean home in Lyford Cay, Nassau. He was 70 years old
Few players are at their best when playing in an international championship for the first time, since the conditions of play and general atmosphere are unfamiliar.

An offering of 1,300,000 shares of A. H. Robins, Inc., at 33 1/2 per share became effective late yesterday, according to underwriters headed by Goldman Sachs; Smith Barney; Merrill Lynch; and Wheat First Securities Inc. The company's shares, trading on a "when issued" basis, closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 33 5/8, down 1/8.

In what prosecutors believe is the first such case involving college officials, the dean of adult education at Federal City College and his assistant were charged yesterday with stealing $230,000 in Government money and tampering with grand jury witnesses.

The Justice Department said that Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan was sworn in last week as a special deputy United States marshal, which means he may now legally carry a gun across state lines. The swearing-in followed disclosures that Mr. Brennan sometimes carries a gun, a practice acquired during his years as head of the building and construction trades union in New York.

Tonight at 10 C.B.S. News, in a gesture rare for commercial television, rather justly bites the hand that feeds it. The hour-long documentary, produced, directed and written by Irv Drasnin, with Perry Wolff as executive producer, is called "You and the Commercial."

The Public Service Commission has approved a permanent rate increase of $53,356 a year for the Empire Telephone Corporation, it was announced today. The company originally asked for $71,766 and had been granted $25,000 on a temporary basis.
Mother Teresa traveled from the squalor of Calcutta's poorest quarters to the ornate splendor of London's Guildhall to be acclaimed today the first winner of an annual award for progress in religion.
The Treasury, flush with cash, announced today that it would refinance only part of the $4.3-billion of publicly held securities maturing May 15.
If, on recent woodland walks, you have felt that crows are particularly brazen this spring, you may be right, for they are now an official game bird, protected by law.
" Mark Spitz is no longer the pretournament favorite" suggested George Connell, tournament chairman of the Byron Nelson Golf Classic today as the sun caused him to smile.

The Columbia Broadcasting System's presentation of Ingmar Bergman's "The Lie" dominated the ratings for its time slot Tuesday evening in New York. Beginning at 9:30 and running an unusual length of about one hour and 45 minutes,

Government agencies, including the Securities and Exchange Commission, are conducting an investigation of the auditing firms that reviewed the books of the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Corporation of Amerca, according to regulatory sources.

The Mississippi River and its tributaries rolled over more farms, towns and suburbs in this area and elsewhere today as floodcontrol officials termed this spring the "wettest" in mid-America's recorded history and warned of more trouble from north of Rock Island, Ill., to south of. New Orleans.

Gloria Steinem told the American Newspaper Publishers Association here yesterday that the press was failing to report what women really wanted to read and that young women in particular were turning away from the Establishment press and looking for "alternative sources of information."

About 200 outraged residents and some town officials of this quiet suburban community, which cherishes its image of propriety and respectability, demonstrated noisily this evening outside the entrance of Upper Montclair's Bellevue Theater to protest the opening of "Last Tango in Paris."

In another heavy day of annual meetings, stockholders continued to press for added benefits in the form of larger cash or stock dividends, and showed their concern about ecology and the socio-economic aspects of big business.
A Rochester civic group plans to use a billboard advertising campaign to help track down the man who raped and strangled an 11year-old girl.
The Census Bureau estimated today after a new analysis that it had overlooked 5,300,000 Americans in the Census of 1970.
George Lichtheim, social historian and an authority on Marxism, died here Sunday. He was about 60 years old. A native of Germany who settled in Britain with the advent of Hitlerism,
The General Accounting Office will cite the Republicans' 1972 campaign organization for the second time for criminal violations of the financial disclosure law, it was learned today.

Critics of Honeywell, Inc., led by clergymen and church laity, peppered management at the annual meeting today but failed to push through a resolution to get the company out of some of its military business.

" Oh what a tangled web we weave, when first we practice to deceive!" wrote Sir Walter Scott a couple of centuries ago. This truism hasn't lost its validity over the years; it is so vibrantly alive that it can be accurately applied to such disparate things as Watergate and college athletics. The only bond between them is the element of deception.
In 1936 when Clare Boothe Luce's play "The Women" was new and naughty, my predecessor, Brooks Atkinson, wrote: "This reviewer disliked it." Now it is not so

Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., predicted yesterday that a turnaround in Wall Street's present period of drought "will come before long." But he declined to set a specific timetable.

Community Board 8 voted last night to recommend that the city's Board of Standards and Appeals deny the zoning variance requested by the directors of the Guggenheim Museum's for alterations to the structure on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street.
Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., vice chief of staff of the Army and President Nixon's top military troubleshooter, testified today as a surprise Government witness in the Pentagon papers trial.

PLAINFIELD, N. J.-Mei Ling Lee is the hostess at the Shanghai Restaurant here. With a smile, she shows customers to their tables and asks who recommended the patrons to this fairly new establishment, and then passes through a mental inventory of guests, trying to remember her customers.
Leaders of the Connecticut State Medical Society have recommended that people in good health be allowed to write a bill of rights for themselves in the event they contract a terminal disease.

NEWARK, N.Y.-No murders or robberies even, but for the District Attorney, it is still a very big day, starting with an early-morning raid, with seven people, including the son of a town judge, arrested on charges of selling marijuana to an undercover agent.

Representative Mario Biaggi promised yesterday to ask a three-judge panel to look at his secret Federal grand-jury testimony and report "whether or not I took the Fifth Amendment or any other privilege on my personal finances and assets."

The Census Bureau said today after a reanalysis that it had overlooked an estimated 5.3 million Americans in the decennial Census of 1970. Bureau statisticians pointed out that the estimated error -approximately 2.5 per cent of the previously reported total of 203.235.000 people counted
Top-seeded Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., stepped into the $50,000 World Championship Tennis Group A tournament tonight with a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Allan Stone of Australia.
Saturday Review is not the first failure for the publishing team of John J. Veronis and Nicholas H. Charney. Does anyone remember Careers Today?

The Trades Union Congress, the central organization of British labor, conceded the defeat today of its member unions' resistance to limitations on pay raises under the Government's anti-inflation program.
Japan announced a plan today to open most of her industries to wholly-owned foreign subsidiaries starting May 1.

The Mississippi River and its tributaries rolled over more farms, towns and suburbs in this area and elsewhere today as floodcontrol officials termed this spring the "wettest" in midAmerica's recorded history and warned of more trouble from north of Rock Island, Ill., to south of New Orleans.

The New York and American Stock Exchange yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:
Juan Marichal, the 34-yearold San Francisco right-hander, is off to a fine start in his 14th season in a Giant uniform.

A State Supreme Court justice has denied the bail application of one of two men accused of killing a guard during the 1971 Attica prison riot. The justice, Carman F. Ball, gave no reason for the denial.

There was stubble on the faces, but a gleam of hope for high-paying lathers' jobs in the tired eyes of more than 250 men camped yesterday on the sidewalk on 76th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues.

With Wilt Chamberlain igniting fast breaks like a hyperactive launching pad and Gail Goodrich clicking off baskets like a runaway slot machine, the Los Angeles Lakers walloped the Golden State Warriors, 128-118, tonight, and moved into the final round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.
More brokerage firms--including Merrill Lynch, the nation's biggest investment concernhave laid off employes as high costs and low profits continue to plague Wall Street, it was learned yesterday.
The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today challenging the acquisition of the Hayes Company division of Genesco, Inc., by Blue Bell, Inc.
At his own request, Dennis R. McGuire, 18 years old, will pay $1,400 in hospital and funeral expenses incurred by the family of a 19-year-old youth he accidentally shot and killed.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell testified in Federal court here tonight that he knew of no efforts by the Committee for the Re-election of the President to tap telephone conversations by members of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War.

The New Jersey Senate is expected to pass today a legislative package, already approved by the Assembly, that is of extreme importance in the belated effort to save that state's invaluable coast. Since recreation is New Jersey's largest employer, the bills should do as much to protect its economy as its environment.
A criminal contempt hearing scheduled for today on Robert L. Vesco was postponed yesterday, apparently at the request of Mr. Vesco's lawyer, Edward Bennett Williams.

Dr. Vincent J. Fontana, chairman of the Mayor's Task Force on Child Abuse and Neglect, said yesterday that he strongly supported pending state legislation aimed at preventing what he called an "epidemic" of child-abuse deaths and injuries.
The owners of more than 40 per cent of the nonmedallion taxis licensed by the city said yesterday that they would give up their licenses and go back to operating as "gypsy" cabs.

Charles G. Rodman, president of the Grand Union Company, said today that the company was supporting William H. Preis, Grand Union executive who has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on a charge of lying about a $5,000 contribution to Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign fund.

Bernard L. Barker, the convicted watergate burglar, made a concerted effort here last summer to present his break-ins at the Democratic National Committee headquarters in Washington as Central Intelligence Agency operations, Richard E. Gerstein, Dade County state attorney, said today.
Top-seeded Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., stepped into the $50,000 World Championship Tennis Group A tournament tonight with a '6-3, 6-3 victory over Allan Stone of Australia.
American industry has sharply expanded its plans to invest in new plant and equipment during 1973, a comprehensive survey by the McGrawHill Publications Company has concluded.

Prisoners in the state's correctional institutions are entitled to a better grade of education while in jail, particularly an education that is geared to the job market, the State Correction Commissioner, Russell G. Oswald, said yesterday in urging the implementation of the recommendations of a special task force.
The United States dropped nearly 39,000 tons of bombs on Cambodia in March, according to Defense Department tabulations. Since March the United States has accelerated its bombing in Camobdia.
The Air Force announced yesterday that 235 former prisoners of war will begin attending classes at Maxwell Air Force Base April 30 to bring them up to date on world and cultural affairs.
The E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. Inc., said yesterday that it would increase prices for most types of cellophane by three cents a pound, effective with shipments May 28.
The Food and Drug Administration today banned the cattlefattening fattening hormone DES, which is known to cause cancer in some animals. The move is certain to raise beef prices.

The White House announced today that Henry A. Kissinger would return to Paris in midMay for talks with Hanoi's chief negotiator, Le Duc Tho, on ways to achieve "strict implementation" of the much-violated Vietnam cease-fire agreement.
A controversial yoga society that has gained some popularity in the United States was involved in a fierce dispute with the police today over the fiery sacrifice of a 32-year-old leader of the group.
The Food and Drug Administration today banned the cattlefattening hormone DES, which is known to cause cancer in some animals. The move is certain to raise beef prices.
The value of trained retrievers is at a record high. A prospective field trial winner brings from $15,000 to $20,000. Authorities estimate it costs $1,000 a point on the way to a championship. Since

Vidal Sassoon, the master crimper, is doing his hair thing in a new location, Salon No. 3, in the plaza of the General Motors building (Fifth Avenue and 58th Street), opened officially yesterday with a hair fashion show. It had the assistance

The Toronto Argonauts have filed a complaint with Commissioner Jake Gaudaur of the Canadian Football League that involves tampering charges against the Green Bay Packers. The complaint involves Jim Stillwagon, 240-pound defensive lineman, who recently sold his house in Toronto, withdrew from the C.F.L. pension plan and returned to the United States.

All those women who felt unhinged at the thought that they might not be permitted to pay $600 and up for their favorite Norells can relax. Though Norman Norell died six months ago, the house is in the capable hands of Gustave Tassell, who is carrying on the tradition.
A man with a submachine gun killed one opponent of President Makarios and seriously wounded another one early today as they left a night club in the east coast port of Famagusta.

Combustion Engineering, Inc., announced yesterday that it had received an order from the Duke Power Company for the design and fabrication of six nuclear steam supply systems in the 1,200 megawatt class.

New York Coliseum officials presented the city with a plan for a $274-million expansion of the Coliseum as an alternative to the Lindsay administration's proposal for a new convention and exhibition center near the Hudson River.
The final major prep for the Kentucky Derby will take place at the Keeneland course tomorrow with the running of the Blue Grass Stakes.

The State Investigation Commission will begin public hearings here next Tuesday to publicize evidence of alleged corruption in New Jersey's workmen's compensation system that one source said involved lawyers and physicians "by the fistful."
The lean young businessman sauntered into the steamy cafe on the town square, yawned and sat down to wait until the electric current flowed again and he could order his midmorning coffee.

Using the Easter recess to gauge the impact of the Watergate scandal, members of Congress from around the country report a sense of frustration and impotence on' the part of increasingly concerned voters at home.

The odorous assortment of malfeasances known as the "Watergate scandals," committed by Republicans with the morals and methods of the lowest form of private detectives, is a nasty piece of political business.
Shares on the American Stock Exchange and the overthe-counter market declined for the second straight day yesterday in stepped-up trading.
Women working full time on the faculties of the nation's universities are earning an average of $3,500 less than their male counterparts, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.
A British soldier was seriously injured when he was shot by a sniper while on foot patrol today in the Turf Lodge section of Belfast, a Roman Catholic area.

Representative Mario Biaggi promised yesterday to ask a three-judge panel to look at his secret Federal grand-jury testimony and report "whether or not I took the Fifth Amendment or any other privilege on my personal finances and assets."
A Government report showing smaller soybean and grain stocks, issued after the close of markets on Tuesday, sent futures prices of those commodities soaring yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Frank Clearwater, who was critically wounded on April 17 during a daylong rifle fight between United States marshals and Indian insurgents in the village of Wounded Knee, died before dawn today in a Rapid City hospital where he had been airlifted by the Government the day he was shot.
A Government military spokesman said today that Saigon and the Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Vietcong had agreed to an exchange of civilian prisoners beginning Friday.

Local and county governments are spending almost half of their Federal revenue-sharing funds on their police forces, according to the State Community Affairs Department. The Federal Government has allocated $119-million to local governments and $69-million to counties.
Clouds of depression continued to hang heavily over Wall Street yesterday as the stock market absorbed yet another shellacking and skidded to new lows for the year.

Money and security, scarce items in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, will determine whether Mel Davis signs a professional basketball contract or returns to St. John's University for his final collegiate season.

Midway through the season of annual corporate meetings, shareholders of the General Electric Company voted yesterday on an issue that has been placed, in one form or another, before 18 other companies and that both sides concede is complex: investments in white-ruled South Africa.

The New York State Legislature, the legislative boards of Nassau and Westchester Counties, the Connecticut General Assembly, the Governor of Connecticut, the Department of the Interior and the Congress of the United States-all are against the proposed Rye-Oyster Bay bridge across Long Island Sound. Governor Nelson Rockefeller is for it. So plans for the project proceed.
The West Indies and Australia played to a draw today in the fifth and final match of a cricket series the Australians already had won.

Tom Earl snapped a 1-1 tic late in the second period tonight and Brad Sclwood added a third-period goal as the New England Whalers advanced to the final round of the World Hockey Association Playoffs.

Baby chicks sold in one store as Easter gifts have been found to be contaminated with dangerous bacteria, but there have been no reports yet of similar cases across the country, Federal officials said today.

South Carolina today became the 17th state to refuse ratification of the proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution. A ratification proposal was tabled, ending at least for this year, any chance for adoption by the state.

Six members of two youths gangs, the Savage Skulls of the South Bronx and the Satan Souls of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, were arrested on firstdegree murder charges last night in the slaying of an 18year-old youth last week.

The Swedish Government, a persistent critic of American involvement in Indochina, yesterday condemned the United States bombing of Cambodia, which it said "indiscriminately hit the civilian population." The statement was made by Foreign Minister Krister Wickman in response to a question in Parliament, [Page 4, Colunm 1.]
The Mississippi River and its tributaries spread over more land today, and along its 1,500mile length men and equipment fought the battle of the levees.

The San Francisco Giants bunched six singles and a sacrifice fly for a four-run third inning today and posted a 7-3 triumph over the Chicago Cubs. It was the Giants' fourth straight victory and ninth in the last 10 games.
Ron Porambo, an author and a reporter for WNET-TV, was sentenced to three months in jail yesterday for bribing a policeman to get pictures of persons killed in the 1967 riots in Newark.

Speculation that the Nixon Administration was planning new initiatives on the economic front sparked a sudden and dramatic rally in the stock market yesterday on accelerating turnover

That elusive light at the end of so many dark tunnels flashed hopefully last week in South Asia when India and Bangladesh finally offered to release, conditionally, about 90,000 Pakistani prisoners of war.
Woodrow G. Gatehouse, president of the National Horse Show Association of America, Ltd., died last night in Community Hospital after a long illness. He was 46 years old

Until proved otherwise, the Los Angeles Lakers remain champions of the National Basketball Association and they await with interest to learn whether the New York Knicks or the Boston Celtics will make the final challenge.

Matthew Henry McCloskey Jr., builder, Democratic party fundraiser and former Ambassador to Ireland, died today at the age of 80. According to a spokesman for suburban Fitzgerald Mercy Hospital, where he died, Mr. McCloskey had been under treatment for cancer.
A Federal judge told a tense and crowded courtroom yesterday that he planned to disclose much of the grand-jury testimony of Representative Mario Biaggi on Monday.
Richard Moore, a Black Panther, was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to life imprisonment for attempting to kill two policemen here with a machine gun in May, 1971.

With Communist troops occupying a village within sight of Phnom Penh's royal palace and with the suburb of Pochentong mourning the score of civilians killed in this morning's Communist rocket attack, the Cambodian capital was uncomfortably aware today of the proximity of war.
The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced a typewriter with an electronic memory that allows corrections and deletions in copy before it is finally recorded.

The New York Stock Exchange, whose member firms are awash in red ink, is preparing a plan to raise commission rates, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

April is a time of beginning in Japan. The cherry blossoms herald the coming of spring, the Government and businesses get their new budgets for the fiscal year, schools start their first semesters, and university graduates embark on their adult lives.

Jeb Stuart Magruder, the former White House and Nixon campaign official who reportedly accused two high Administration figures of complicity in the Watergate bugging case, has resigned as an Assistant Secretary of Commerce, his lawyer said tonight.
Tom Seaver put his finger on one of the main fears of the Mets. "We're not even out of April yet and already the injuries have started," the pitcher said.

George Theodore, a gangly 6-foot-4inch, 190-pound rookie outfielder, helped the Mets score an earned run and an unearned run off Houston's left-hander, Jerry Reuss, in the sixth inning tonight and take the rubber game of their three-game series, 2-1.

Madison Square Garden will pulsate with playoff pressure tonight as the Knicks and the Boston Celtics-neither of whom can afford to losemeet in the sixth game of the four-of-seven series for the championship of the Natonal Basketball Association's Eastern Conference.

The role of Princess Aurora In "The Sleeping Beauty" is one of the most difficult in the classical ballet repertory. Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the National Ballet of Canada presented the second of its four Auroras of the week,
The United States balance of export-import trade showed its best performance in March and in the first quarter since late 1971, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Republican party chairman, George Bush, reportedly had warned the White House that the handling of the Watergate case threatens to compromise the party organization.

The capital is still buzzing with rumors about who is to blame for the Watergate fiasco, and who will take over after the inevitable house-cleaning; but the main question still is not who was to blame but what was to blame.

Terry Riley's "In C" was composed in 1964 and remains a vastly influential piece of music for that part of the American avant-garde fascinated with hypnotic repetition. Not only was it first, but also it is still one of the best works of its kind, and it is one of the few such pieces that can he played by performers not under the direct supervision of the composer.

On the dot of 10 yesterday morning, the first of a chilled and sodden group of 300 men stepped out of the rain and into the offices of Local 46 of the Wood, Wire and Metal Lathers Union, at Third Avenue and 76th Street.

The Swedish Government, long a critic of American involvement in Indochina, condemned the United States today for its bombing of Cambodia, charging that the raids "indiscriminately hit the civilian population."
Jordan has imposed severe security controls on travelers to keep out Arab terrorists, and the United States Embassy here is being fortified against rocket attack or assault.

Democratic defections and halfhearted Republican support in the State Senate combined this evening to defeat a series of bills aimed at protecting New Jersey's coastline and the ecology of its offshore waters.
President Nixon will visit Japan when a convenient time for the trip can be worked out, a State Department spokesman said today.

L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has told friends that he destroyed documents taken from a central figure in the Watergate case after it was suggested at a White House meeting that the papers "should never see the light of day."
The nation's composite index of leading business indicators advanced 1.4 per cent in March, although some indicators were down slightly, the Commerce Department reported today.

A team of 20 detectives continued their investigation of the murder Tuesday of Angela Catalano, the 30-year-old welfare client who was stabbed with scissors in her room at the Riverside Studios Hotel, 342 West 71st Street.

Nearly a month has elapsed since President Nixon made his nationally televised appeal for support in his budgetary battle with Congress. And while mem bets of Congress are being in undated with mail this year little of it appears to have beer generated by the President's plea.

A pilot study of crime, sponsored by the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, indicates that in some categories the number of crimes committed could run as high as five times the number officially reported by victims.
About 900 relatives, friends and school mates attended a funeral mass today for 7-yearold Joan D'Alessandro, who was slain last week while delivering Girl Scout cookies near her home here.
Three million railway employes and other workers began a spring labor offensive to day with a 72-hour walkout, plunging Japan into one of the worst transport snarls in its history.

South Carolina today became the 17th state to refuse ratification of the proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution. A ratification proposal was tabled, ending at least for this year, any chance for adoption by the state.

The Ampex Corporation announced today it had been chosen to build a huge system for storing computerized information for the United States Government. The company did not disclose what agency or department of the Federal Government was ordering the system or how much it would cost. The system will
Directors of the Chrysler Corporation yesterday raised the quarterly dividend to 35 cents a share, payable June 11 to holders of record May 10. The company had been paying 25 cents quarterly.

France said today that Egypt and Libya had denied that French-built Mirage jets sold to Libya were being transferred to Egypt, as charged by Israel. After a Cabinet meeting, the Government spokesman, Joseph Comiti, said that France was therefore awaiting proof of the charges.

The temperature hovered around 108 today. If hot weather is hardly major news in New Delhi, the sudden April heat wave has nevertheless frayed political tempers, led to a sellout of charpoys, or rope beds for sleeping outdoors, and spurred a wave of ticket sales to the cooler mountain resorts such as Kashmir and Simla.

An offering of 950,000 common shares of Eli Lilly at $81.25 per share was made yesterday by underwriters managed by Morgan Stanley. All of the shares are being sold by Merchants National Bank Trust Co., Indianapolis, as executor of the estate of the late Ruth Allison Lilly and proceeds will be used for Federal and state taxes.
Frank Fullam, a former boxing referee and judge for many major fights, died Wednesday evening at his home, 49-07 39th Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens. He was 64 years old.
The police today dropped murder charges against a Columbia Broadcasting System camera team in connection with the immolation of a Hindu monk.

American swimmers won all but one event at the opening of the Rumanian international swimming meet inBucharest, the Austrian news agency Agerpress reported today. Tom Szuba won the 50-meter free-style in 25.7 seconds, beating the Rumanian champion, Marian Slavic. He then lost the 50-meter butterfly to Ion Milcaus.

Agreeing with a doctor who says that learning to handle alcohol is vital to a man's education, the State Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control upheld the right of Seton Hall University to have a pub on campus. Robert Bower, the division's director, said that "it is apparent from the testimony presented that safeguards will be exercised to guard against this new club license from becoming another gin mill."

The International Coffee Council failed to reach agreement today after two days of intensive debate on the speed of dismantling the operative controls of the 10-year-old international agreement, delegates said. The Council met Tuesday to consider a proposal from the assembly of the diversification fund to speed up the liquidation of the fund. The old international agreement

The bell may not yet be tolling for Greece's military rulers but they now unquestionably face the broadest, most united and most determined opposition they have encountered in the six years since their seizure of power. What makes the current threat far more formidable than any previous anti-junta effort is its positive element:

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains in first-quarter operating revenues and net income. The quarterly report placed operate ing revenues at $680-million compared with $622.8-millior a year earlier.

The United States Justice Department has intensified an 11-month investigation into charges of massive bribery in the Illinois Departement of Insurance in the wake of the Equity Funding scandal, according to Samuel K. Skinner, an Assistant United States Attorney and chief of the special investigations division in Chicago.
A new study shows that volunteer soldiers are more likely to go AWOL than p draftees and predicts that this may mean trouble for the allvolunteer Army.

Businessmen are paying private couriers $5 to take a letter from Milan to Naples, and thousands of old people throughout Italy are asking their grocers for credit because they can't collect their pensions.
Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, made a major foreign policy address today to a semi-annual meeting of the party's Central Committee.

His face flushed with anger, the judge in the Pentagon papers trial sent the jury home today because the Government had again withheld evidence from the court and the defendants.
Emery L. Frazier, who retired as Secretary of the United States Senate in 1966 after 33 years as a Senate officer, died here Tuesday. His age was 76.
Dudley B. Martin of the New York Times was elected president of the Society of the Silurians, an organization of veteran newsmen and newswomen at a meeting at the Players Club last night.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association called yesterday for Federal legislation to protect reporters from having to disclose their news sources.
Governor Rockefeller gave Senator John J. Marchi, Republican of Staten Island, a tepid endorsement today as the party's candidate for Mayor of New York City.
Gov. Milton J. Shapp today unveiled the nation's most comprehensive statewide plan to regulate and administer health care in an effort to contain "skyrocketing medical costs."

New Yorkers, who endured day-long rains many times during the winter, discovered yesterday that spring showers may also be prolonged. Steady rain, varying from fine sprinkles to heavy torrents, caused flooding on highways in several parts of the city, mostly along river fronts and other low-lying areas. "It's hub cap stuff," said a Traffic Department spokesman, reporting that delays were experienced by motorists on scores of main thoroughfares in the morning and evening rush hours.

Roy Boe, unburdened by the conservative behavior inherent in sports ownership, said today he had given Kevin Loughery a five-year contract to coach the New York Nets. That works out to one year for each victory Loughery has amassed in his brief coaching career.

Fearful of sabotage, Douglas Dillon, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has expressed reservations about the Metropolitan's plans to be host to a major Israeli archeological exhibition in connection with the city's commemoration of the 25th anniversary of Israel's independence.

In recent years outdoor magazines have been praising the fighting qualities of the peacock bass, Cichla Ocellaris, a species reputed to be one of the best tasting and hardest fighting lighttackle fish in South America.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, made an urgent appeal today for legislation requiring identical reserve requirements for both member and nonmember banks against demand deposits.,
The oil industry yesterday continued on its way to one of the best quarters in its history as four more major companies reported sharply higher earnings for the first three months of 1973.
C. Lee Walton Jr., who became managing director of McKinsey Co., Inc. four and a half years ago, is planning to step down in June. The 42
The strongest earthquake to strike the island of Hawaii in 23 years damaged several buildings today and injured at least four persons.

George Meany, the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused the Nixon Administration today of using "the big lie technique" to hide its economic failures and declining popular support.

Abraham Kavadlo, a publicschool teacher who founded the Great Society Press, Inc., to provide remedial reading pamphlets for the culturally deprived, died Monday of a heart ailment at St. John's Hospital in Elmhurst, Queens. He was 59 years

WASHINGTON-Just when one was getting used to life's minor irritations -the bomb, strife in the Middle East, the price of beef, Watergate and Jane Fonda-something really serious had to happen. The Great Onion Crisis. Too much rain, too soon, wiped out a large chunk of America's current onion crop.
Richard Moore, a Black Panther, was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to life imprisonment for attempting to kill two policemen here with a machine gun in May, 1971.
The ban on the cattle-fattening hormone, DES, announced by the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, sent prices of live cattle futures up sharply yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Bond prices registered selective advances again yesterday, spurred in part by the Treasury's announcement late Wednesday of plans to pay off securities coming due in midMay.

The courtroom was hushed. For the newsmen and spectators, it was a hearing heavy with tension. For Mario Biaggi, mayoral candidate, it was a proceeding fraught with consequences crucial to his aspirations.

The New York Times won this year's Page One Award for the "best example of a crusading newspaper," it was announced yesterday by the Newspaper Guild of New York. It was the fourth time since 1969 that The Times has won the award in this category.

Top officials of the Asian Development Bank recommended today that a special development fund be set up to which rich countries could regularly contribute. But the United States, instead of endorsing the proposal, sought a review of the bank's procedures.

The young woman who once shared the apartment of Robert Dain, the East Side art dealer who was found stabbed to death Tuesday, "had absolutely nothing to do with the homicide," a police sergeant investigating the case said yesterday. The sergeant,

A pilot study of crime,sponsored by the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, indicates that in some categories the number of crimes committed could run as high as five times the number officially reported by victims.
President Anwar el-Sadat is pushing ahead with a campaign of psychological mobilization in the name of national unity and "total confrontation" with Isreal.

Amid signs of continuing resistance to his proposals for stiffer penalties for drug pushers, Governor Rockefeller today described the legislation he had presented as the "most important" issue facing the Legislature.

In one room: a group of toddlersboys, girls, black, white, Puerto Rican -happily scrambling for toys, dunking in a plastic swimming pool, singing songs. In another room: mothers-well-to-do and welfare, middle-aged and young, from city and suburb - quietly exchanging ideas about the care and raising of their children.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that its directors have approved the membership in the Federal Reserve System of the Depository Trust Company. Depository
A new form of trading in securities was initiated here today on the new Chicago Board Options Exchange with both a slap and a pat from the Federal Government.

The Crocker National Bank said today it was leading a group of 26 banks that has agreed to lend $40-million to the Republic of Peru. The loan is good for seven years, but Crocker refused to reveal the interest rate.

Following are excerpts from statements made in Federal Court here by Whitney North Seymour Jr., the United States Attorney, and Arthur H. Christy, attorney for Mario Biaggi, and from the remarks of Judge Edmund L. Palmieri:

Prices of color television sets appear to be moving upward, although several major manufacturers said they did not intend to match rises announced yesterday by the industry leader the RCA Corporation.

Democratic defections and halfhearted Republican support in the State Senate combined this evening to defeat a series of bills aimed at protecting New Jersey's coastline and the ecology of its offshore waters.

Campaign workers for Representative Mario Biaggi reported to the police that their storefront center at 241 Canal Street, two blocks south of Police Headquarters, was broken into yesterday evening and ransacked.

The 25-?? nation disarmament conference ended a nine-week session here today amid complaints about a lack of progress toward a comprehensive ban on the testing of nuclear weapons and the outlawing of chemical arms.

Joseph Ferdinando, who allegedly ran a get-rich-quick scheme that involved $400-million and almost 400 individuals, and that led to the indictment and resignation of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell, of Queens, pleaded guilty today to two counts of third-degree larceny.

The Swedish Government, long a critic of American involvement in Indochina, condemned the United States today for its bombing of Cambodia, charging that the raids "indiscriminately hit the civilian population."
A Federal judge told a tense and crowded courtroom yesterday that he planned to disclose much of the grand-jury testimony of Representative Mario Biaggi on Monday.

Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, protested to Secretary of State William P. Rogers today against what he called a restrictive attitude on the part of the United States Embassy in Cambodia toward American reporters.

CHARLEVOIX, Mich.-Kamal Nasser, public relations man, spokesman for the Palestinian Liberation Organization, assassinated in his Beirut apartment by Israeli commandos, was the top fedayeen accessible to the Western press.

My Gallant rallied to success in the $58,100 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland today, scoring by a head over Our Native. A field of nine participated in the 1 1/8-mile event for 3-year-olds, a race that has come to be accepted as a gauge for the Kentucky Derby.
The Nixon Administration softened today its final rules on eligibility and payments for social services such as day care that are designed to get or keep people off welfare.
It was standing room only in Judge Edmund L. Palmieri's courtroom yesterday, and if any of the goings-on there had ever happened before, no one could recall it.
A boy was born last night in the muster room of the 81st Precinct station on Ralph Avenue in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

Federal attorneys, went to the Supreme Court this week to help the state of Virginia fight the consolidation of the heavily black Richmond school district with those of two mostly white suburban counties.
Russians are reading their first reports on the American meat boycott, which has provided the controlled Soviet press with a new opportunity to depict economic problems in the United States.

Mrs. Jane Booth, last year's winner, and Beth Barry, last year's runner-up, won semifinal-round matches today in the North and South amateur golf tournament and became the first finalists in 32 years to repeat.
Adm. Frank Jack Fletcher, U.S.N. retired, a task-force commander in the World War II battles of the Coral Sea and Midway, died yesterday at the Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 87 years old.

Large corporations holding annual meetings yesterday emphasized improvements in sales and earnings and plans to expand facilities. With few exceptions, management's reported improved figures for 1972 and the first quarter of 1973 and expressed confidence that business for the balance of the year would continue to rise.
John J. Wilson, a 71-year-old Washington lawyer with a cherubic face and a reputation for combativeness, has emerged as a central if enigmatic figure in the Watergate case.
Governor Rockefeller gave Senator John J. Marchi, Republican of Staten Island, a tepid endorsement today as the party's candidate for Mayor of New York City.
The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends issued clarifications today of its new "dual prime rate" policy, in the form of 11 questions and answers. The clarification
There was a joyous rush of cattlemen, farm workers and young people, and then it happened: The presidential candidate, his committee and the grandstand crashed to the ground.

It is no accident that the Nixon Administration's bill to shut down urban renewal, Model Cities and other urban programs and substitute a share of Federal revenue is entitled the "Better Communities Act." The objective is to shift Federal money and public attention away from the cities where the Administration's political support is weakest and transfer them to the suburbs where its support is greatest. To achieve that shift,

The current business upswing, reflected in the daily flow of favorable first-quarter earnings reports extended yesterday to all sectors of business. As has been the case to date, numerous companies turned in record resuits or substantially larger sales and earnings over the corresponding three months last year.
A peace agreement in women's tennis is expected to be announced here today that would allow Chris Evert to meet Mrs. Billie Jean King and Mrs. Margaret Court in major tournaments, perhaps this year.

An international array of dance stars, from Dame Margot Fonteyn to Twyla Tharp, and ran equally international teaching staff, from Maria Tallchief to Kirsten Ralov and Fred Bjornsson of the Royal Danish Ballet, will be part of a reorganized format at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival this summer.

Brendan T. Byrne's 11th-hour bid for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination picked up important support today as Richard J. Coffee, one of four major announced candidates, withdrew and agreed to serve as Mr. Byrne's campaign chairman.

Mrs. Jvet Synek Love was married here yesterday afternoon to F. Malcolm Graff Jr., a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the home of the bride.

In expressing its concern about what it sees as signs that the Executive branch of the Federal Government might be trying to take over control of public television for its own ends, TV station WGBH in Boston yesterday called on the board of the Corporation of Public Broadcasting to declare publicly its rules for dealing with the White House.
Some television briefs: Wednesday evening, the National Broadcasting Company network carried a 90minute, lavishly produced curiosity called "The Going Up of David Lev."

A routine traffic-accident case in which an out-of-town salesman struck several parked cars while allegedly intoxicated resulted yesterday in the a indictment of two police officers in the Bronx on perjury charges.

Dr. Hector J. Campora, President-elect of Argentina, flew to Madrid tonight to consult with former President Juan D. Peron amid growing signs of dissension within the Peronist coalition and a mounting guerrilla campaign against the incumbent military Government.
A Rockland County Republican official and a Town Supervisor have been indicted on charges of soliciting and receiving $25,000 in bribes to advance the county's purchase of an office building.
Three months after the Vietnam cease-fire, the fundamental issues of the Indochina conflict remain as sharp as ever and the firing has not ceased.

The City Council's General Welfare Committee will vote today on a twice-defeated bill to bar discrimination against homosexuals in housing, employment and public accommodations, The outcome this time is expected to be close.

Mark Van Doren, the poet and longtime teacher at Columbia University who died last December, was warmly recalled by friends and former students last night at the 63d annual dinner of the Poetry Society of America in the Plaza Hotel.

Rutgers University's campus patrol and the New Brunswick Police Department started mounted police protection for the college and the city today with three horses on loan from the New York City Police Department.
About 125 workers who help operate a Skylab tracking station called a strike tonight against the Bendix Field Engineering Division and set up picket lines at Kennedy Space Center gates.
In an effort to soothe the ruffled feelings of Oglala Sioux Indian leaders, the Justice Department agreed tonight to give the tribe a larger voice in handling the Wounded Knee insurrection.

Patricia E. Davis of United Press International was elected president of the New York Press Club last night. Miss Davis, an assistant New York City editor for the wire service, becomes the first woman president in the club's 25-year history. She succeeds
Without really noticing, Bob Alotta has come a long way from the brash days when he was a chubby kid growing up in South Philadelphia 20-odd years ago.

The difficulty when confronting a modem classic is that it is not exactly modern and not precisely classic. Tennessee Williams's "A Streetcar Named Desire," which opened at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center last night, is one of the most celebrated plays of the century.
Directors of the Todd Shipyards Corporation suspended the 20-cent quarterly dividend payment yesterday after a 57year record of successive quarterly disbursements. John T.

The American Trucking Associ nations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 2.9 per cent above the corresponding week of last year Truck tonnage last week was 4.4 per cent below the immediately proceeding week.
Using a sawed-off putter, Don Bies of Seattle fashioned a two-shot lead with a five-under-par 65 today in the opening round of the $150,000 Byron Nelson Classic. Lee Trevino, the favorite, had a 79.

Opponents and supporters of Chile's Marxist-led Government battled each other and the police today in Santiago's streets. Thousands of students began demonstrating in the morning against Government plans to reform education and "prepare pupils for the new Socialist society."
Slater Walker Securities, an aggressive investment firm, and Hill Samuel Co., a merchant bank, today announced plans to merge, forming the biggest private banking complex in Britain.

L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has told friends that he destroyed documents taken from a central figure in the Watergate case after it was suggested at a White House meeting that the papers "should never see the light of day."

Brazil and neighboring Paraguay signed a partnership agreement today to build what is expected to be the world's largest hydroelectric projects on the Parana River, despite the protests of downriver Argentina.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards, Inc., a member firm based in Los Angeles, has been censured in a disciplinary proceeding.
Two days after the break-in at the Democratic headquarters in the Watergate complex, Ronald L. Ziegler, President Nixon's press secretary, called it "a third-rate burglary attempt."
The State Insurance Commissioner, Richard C. McDonough, ordered the fire insurance industry today to revise its procedures so that it could provide better and cheaper service.

A high State Department official, William H. Sullivan, arrived in Paris today to prepare the ground with the North Vietnamese for talks next month between the architects of the Vietnam peace agreement, Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho.

News that President Nixon will meet with his top economic advisers on Saturday spurred a rally on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market yesterday afternoon.
The president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York called on President Nixon today to appoint a special prosecutor in the Watergate case.
If surroundings have an impact upon behavior, then gambling bids should be less in evidence at the Long Island Regional Championships this year than they were last year. The Nassau- Suffolk

The Department of Justice intervened on the side of the PBW Stock Exchange in its effort to have the third circuit Court of Appeals overturn a ruling of the Securities and Exchange Commission restricting institutional membership in national stock exchanges.

The second annual meeting of the Interpublic Group of Companies, the world's largest ad-agency system, began with an excellent first-quarter statement, got into equal opportunity for women, took time out to see its collection of commercials and ended with a standing ovation for Robert E. Healy, the outgoing chairman.

Reggie Blackshear of Metuchen High School takes another stride toward the 1976 Summer Olympic Games tomorrow when he competes against the best high hurdlers in the East at the Penn Relays in Philadelphia.

A general "conceptual" agreement, was reported today on an offtrack betting compromise that, according to legislative sources, would permit New York City to continue to run its OTB system with no immediate crimping of its daily double and other basic betting activities.

Francisco Aybar obviously has the name and the heritage to suit the Latin program he chose for his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night: excerpts from Albeniz's "Iberia," Granados's "Goyescas" and Ginastera's Sonata (1952). But

Heublein, Inc., a major producer of vodka and mixed cocktails, announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Davis Foods Service, Inc., of Atlanta for about 790,000 common shares of Heublein.
James B. Irwin, the retired astronaut, left the Fitzsimmons Army Medical Center in Aurora, Colo., after three weeks of treatment for the heart attack he suffered while playing handball on April 4.

George Meany, the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused the Nixon Administration today of using "the big lie technique" to hide its economic failures and declining popular support.

Hoofs slapped the marshy track with a rhythmic "kaPOK, ka-POK" as the horses. warmed up for the second race at Aqueduct yesterday. Mud-hating handicappers may have winced, but the splashy sound was sweet music to less-dogmatic players in the crowd of 14,018.
An overflow subscription of 16 owners paid the $1,500 starting fee today to enter horses in the rich Realization Pace on Saturday, May 5, at Roosevelt Raceway.

The National Collegiate decathlon champion, Ron Evans, from the University of Connecticut, upset the Olympian, Jeff Bennett, in the Penn Relays decathlon today. Evans totaled 7,821 points, a personal record and a Penn Relays mark.

Dr. Frank Stanton, who retired as vice chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System last month after 38 years with the company, received a tribute from Governor Rockefeller and the annual award of the Four Freedoms Foundation last night at a dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
Sears, Roebuck Co. announced today, it would introduce a nationwide car rental service May 1. The Sears Rent-a-Car service will be linked by a coast-tocoast, toll-free, 244-hour reservation system.

A Brush Prairie, Wash., woman gave birth to quintuplets here today, her 28th birthday. The three boys and two girls, all reported in satisfactory health, were born to Mr. and Mrs. Eric Anderson in Kaiser Hospital.
The Federal Reserve System pressed its policy of monetary restraint during the last two weeks, data published yesterday by the central bank showed. Consider these developments:

General agreement was reported by legislative sources in Albany on an offtrack betting compromise that would permit New York City to retain control of its present operations with no crimping of its daily double and other basic betting activities.
The National League Green Book of records shows that Roberto Clemente led baseball's active hitters at the end of last season with a .317 batting average for 2,433 games.

George Theodore, a gangly 6-foot-4inch, 190-pound rookie outfielder, helped the Mets score an earned run and an unearned run off Houston's left-hander, Jerry Reuss, in the sixth inning tonight and take the rubber game of their three-game series, 2-1.

The Kansas City Royals, who had gone on a run-scoring binge during the first two weeks of the season, fell victim to a big bat themselves last night, losing to the Milwaukee Brewers, 7-3, on a ninth-inning grand slam by Dave May.

The Defense Department today identified the first American killed in Cambodia since the Vietnam cease-fire. He was First Lieut. Joseph Gambino Jr. of the Air Force, son of Joseph Gambino Sr. of the Bronx.
A Connecticut couple tried yesterday to force their daughters to leave a religious group here and return home, but were foiled by neighbors who called the police.
With the approval of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, Congress is considering a plan to include in legislation estimates of how its passage would increase the workload of the Federal court system.

Nixon campaign worker who tired and paid a college stulent $150 to spy on radical groups has been dismissed by he Department of the Interior. An interior Department spokesman confirmed yesteray that George K. Gorton was asked to leave because of adverse publicity" over his ?? in the Nixon campaign last year.

A group of Canadian physicians were confirmed in their determination to press for a program of doctor exchanges with China after taking a firsthand look this week at the work the Chinese are doing in the reattachment of severed limbs, the treatment of severe burns and the refinement of the ancient practice of herbal medicine.
The United States balance of export-import trade showed its best performance in March and in the first quarter since late 1971, the Commerce Department reported today.
Eight men, including the onetime "king of LSD," have been indicted on Federal charges connected with an alleged widespread ring manufacturing and selling hallucinogenic drugs.

Raimo Pihl of Brigham Young set a personal record in the closing event, the 1,500meter run, and held off Carl Wood of the Florida Track Club to capture the decathlon today at the 64th Drake Relays. Pihl, a junior from Tullige, Sweden, led Wood by 70 points going into the final event.
Tom Seaver put his finger on one of the main fears of the Mets. "We're not even out of April yet and already the injuries have started," the pitcher said.

An early-morning crash of a tug and barge into the abutment of the Raritan River drawbridge delayed some 11,000 New York-bound railroad commuters for up to 90 minutes this morning and again this evening.

Roscoe Tanner, a hard-hitting 21-year-old from Lookout Mountain, Tenn., defeated favored Ken Rosewall in straight sets, 6-1, 6-2, tonight in the quarterfinals of the United Bank tournament, the last stop on the World Championship of Tennis Group B tour.

Top Democratic, Republican and Liberal politicians applauded a Federal Court decision yesterday to release substantial parts of the transcript of Representative Mario Biaggi's testimony before a grand jury.
Gen. Giovanni de Lorenzo, Italy's embattled former counterintelligence chief, died of cancer in a hospital here today. He was 65 years old.

MADE IN BRITTEN The English Chamber Orchestra was founded in 1948, an ensemble designed, it was said, for the use of Benjamin Britten, the composer. It is known for its Britten repertory. An avalanche of mud swept down a mountainside in southwestern Quito overnight leaving at least 25 dead and forcing 2,000 people to leave their homes.
Senator Henry M. Jackson, chairman of the Senate Interior Committee, said today that he would open a hearing May 1 on President Nixon's energy message to Congress.
Canada said today that she would end the 20-year-old practice of letting United States Customs agents clear United Statesbound passengers at four large Canadian airports.
The Penn Central Railroad today set a new deadline of June 9 to put into effect a reduction in train crew sizes. that it said would ultimately save the bankrupt line $97.5-million a year.

" I'm hurtin' all over", said John Mendenhall yesterday as the New York Giants' outstanding rookie defensive tackle of 1972 was recuperating in St. Joseph's Hospital in Houston following a boating accident Wednesday night.
The West Indies and Australia played to a draw today in the fifth and final match of a cricket series the Australians already had won.

Three female members of the 1972 United States Olympic gymnastic team and three Japanese men dominated the opening day's competition of the senior national men's and women's Amateur Athletic Union gymnastics championships at Canisius College today.

There are some endorsements a man would rather not have. To mere outsiders, Vice President Agnew's words of praise for President Nixon in the Watergate case look very much as if they might fall in that dubious category. "I want to make it very clear that I have full confidence in the integrity of President Nixon," the Vice President told the press in a brief statement.

For his "outstanding achievement in art history," Meyer Schapiro, the art scholar and critic, was given a bronze replica of an Alexander Calder stabile and a $3,000 check by the Art Dealers Association of America at a dinner on Wednesday evening at the Museum of Modern Art. The Incredible String Band, which filled Philharmonic Hall with its admirers Easter night, is neither a band, insofar as that implies a big band, nor a string band, if one is thinking of swooning, massed violins.
His face flushed with anger, the judge in the Pentagon papers trial sent the jury home today because the Government had again withheld evidence from the court and the defendants.
Irene Ryan, whose 60-year acting career reached a climax when she became a television star in the "Beverly Hillbillies" series, died today at the age of 70.

It was up again, down again for members of the Soviet Union's ruling Politburo as communications apparently became snarled between the Kremlin and at least one work crew putting up the portraits of the nation's leaders on Moscow building fronts.

Few of us ever see the backstage, anthill activity of an art museum as it uncrates, arranges and hangs a priceless painting collection. This earthy, brass-tacks operation is the real novelty of "On Loan From Russia-41 French Masterpieces."

The City Council's General Welfare Committee refused again yesterday to vote out a bill to ban discrimination against homosexuals in housing, employment and public accommodations. The action was the third such setback for the bill in the last two years.

Montedison S. p. A., an Italian industrial giant plagued by losses and a 90-per cent drop in the price of its stock in the last five years, held its annual stockholders meeting today and gave its small shareholders a rare chance to be heard.
The Nixon Administration insisted today that Congress had no right to obtain budget requests from Government agencies until after the President submitted his annual budget message.

To a hitter, the hits are like the minutes of his life. When one is lost, it can't be recaptured. "If I played last year," Tony Oliva was saying yesterday, "I have 1,600 hits now, maybe 1,700." He spoke with the assurance of his reputation as perhaps the purest natural hitter in the major leagues, a three-time American League batting champion.

The judge in the Pentagon papers trial released today a Justice Department memorandum saying that two convicted Watergate conspirators had broken into the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist here with the intention of stealing Dr. Ellsberg's medical records.
North Vietnam appeared to raise doubts today that its chief negotiator, Le Duc Tho, would meet in Paris with Henry A. Kissinger in mid-May, as announced two days ago by the White House.
Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor four triangles to none).

The Connecticut General Assembly has approved a measure that would allow savings banks and building and loan associations to offer personal checking accounts. The bill, which must still be acted on by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill, was one of the most hotly contested issues the Assembly has dealt with in recent years.
The foreign businessman stared out the large picture window in the living room of his comfortable suburban home and gestured to the young man mangling the flower bed in his garden.

A burglary venture that it was thought might produce information on Senator Edmund S. Muskie's Presidential campaign was discussed, but never carried out, by E. Howard Hunt Jr. a former Hunt business associate has told The New York Times.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here has ruled that a corporate director has no duty to provide adverse information to purchasers of the stock of a company of which he is a board member if he personally was not a participant in the transaction. The decision, 6 to 4,
Tom Szuba and Linda Stimpson, American swimmers, won two events each on the second day of an international swimming meet in Bucharest, the Rumanian news agency Agerpres said today.
The trustees for the Institute for Advanced Study today reejected the demand of a majority of the faculty for the early resignation of Dr. Carl Kaysen, director of the institute.

Roper Corporation: Charles M. Hoover, chairman and president, told the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday that 1973 should be another record year. In 1972 the company earned a record $6.9-million, or $2.83 a share.

American jet fighterbombers were screeching over the Cambodian capital all day today, pouring bombs, rockets and napalm onto Communist positions just across the Mekong River.

New Zealand's Deputy Premier, Hugh Watt, said today that he had failed to persuade France to end nuclear tests in the Pacific and that New Zealand would take the matter to the International Court of Justice at The Hague.

A 25-year-old married nurse was shot to death as she lay on her bed alone in her home here while watching television last night or early this morning. Middlesex County Prosecutor's officers sai dthe house, in a quiet residential section, had been broken into and burglarized.

The Rhodesian Appeals Court heard today the appeal of Peter Niesewand, a journalist whose case has aroused an international furor and jeopardized the possibility of a settlement of Rhodesia's lengthy dispute with Britain.
The South Vietnamese Government announced today that it was permitting Saigon journalists to attend press briefings given by the Vietcong.

The proprietor of a grocery store in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn was shot to death by one of two armed men who robbed his store and stole a customer's wallet last nights the police said. The gunmen fled with an undetermined amount of money.

The long-standing discord in the board of directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation has been ??nded, at least temporarily, by the decision of Dr. Joseph T. English to resign as president when a suitable successor is found.

Villanova is not dead yet as an Eastern collegiate track and field power. The Wildcats won the distance medley relay in the 79th annual Penn Relays today for the eighth consecutive year, this time in a chilling rain.

The Environmental Protection Agency issued an interim permit yesterday to the City of Camden, N. J., allowing it to continue dumping its sewage in the Atlantic Ocean, but in a new area 50 miles offshore instead of the current dumping site 12 miles from the coast.
The Celtics moved the ball and shot well; the Celtics played fine team defense; the Celtics showed poise and determination. The Knicks didn't.
A class action suit has been filed against the University Computing Company charging violations of Federal securities laws and fraud.

Dr. Jean Stehelin, who had been Picasso's physician for many years, died Wednesday. He was 70 years old. Jacqueline Picasso had called Dr. Stehelin when the artist was stricken by a heart attack April 8, but the physician was ill and unable to leave his home.
