Workers on Japan's Government run railroads called off a nationwide strike today after winning a large wage increase and Government consideration of their demand for the right to strike.

The Soviet Union yesterday carried out its first major shake-up of the ruling Politburo since the ouster of Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1964 with a series of moves that confirmed the currentt policy of conciliation with the West accompanied by strong defense and firm security measures at home. [Page 1, Columns 2-3.]

El Teatro Campesino the farm workers' theater that grew out of the Delano grape-pickers' strike in 1965 - performs on picket lines, in fields, on streets and sometimes in theaters. Currently, the company is at the Chelsea Theater Center in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Tomorrow it finishes its indoor engagement and then tours city parks.
L. Patrick Gray 3d resigned today in the intensifying Watergate crisis and was immediately replaced as Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation by William D. Ruckelshaus.

A committee of the Security Council recommended today that all governments seize cargoes arriving from Rhodesia in violation of the Council's embargo of 1968 against trading with that whitegoverned country.
UnliKe Rodney Dangerfield, the comedian who "can't get no respect," Tom Seaver of the New York Mets gets plenty of that from his teammates, but he can't get no support.

Despite another strong rise in productivity in the first quarter and unusually small wage increases negotiated by unions during the period, unit labor costs in the United States rose at more than triple the rate of last year, the Labor Department reported today.

President Nixon's principal 1972 re-election committee was formally cited today for a fourth time for violations of the new campaign finance reform act that Mr. Nixon, in signing Last year, had predicted would "restore public confidence in the electoral process."

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumental of Manhattan called yesterday for yearly disclosures of income and assets by members of the Board of Estimate and the City Council and all employes of the city at or above the rank of deputy commissioner.
Daylight saving time will begin at 2 A.M. tomorrow, when clocks and watches should be set forward one hour.

Some 35,000 commuters on the Penn Central's Harlem, Hudson and New Haven lines were up to 67 minutes late getting to New York yesterday when the railroad developed switch trouble at the height of the morning rush.

Arthur Horace James, wh rose from a job as a mine work er to become Pennsylvania' 34th Governor, died today a his home in Plymouth, nea here. He was 89 years old. The cause of death was give as arteriosclerosis.

Polish-born Swietlana P. abruptly departed from her native Dzierzoniow when refused admission to a university. It was never clearly stated, but she is quite sure her application was turned down because she is Jewish.
While teachers at the Walden School in Manhattan fill out their end-of-term report cards, students from the eighth grade on up get together to evaluate the teachers.
Governor Rockefeller vetoed a bill today that would have delayed for one year consideration of a land-use plan for the 3.7 million acres of privately held land in the Adirondack Park.
The Paul Sanasardo Dance Company, which is giving a brief season through Sunday night at the Exchange Theater, presented four works by Mr. Sanasardo, including two premieres, on Thursday night.
Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth Rush of the United States expressed hope today that differences between India and Pakistan could be resolved through negotiations.

Representative Mario Biaggi, who had scheduled the most extensive television campaign of any of the mayoral hopefuls, yesterday canceled a series of TV commercials planned for next week and instead planned to contradt for them on a dayto-day.basis.

Officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art gave assurances yesterday that they would proceed with plans for a major Israeli archeological . exhibition and "not yield to terror or to threats of terror" by backing out.
The Overseas Press Club said yesterday that it had been unable to pay its rent at the Time-Life Building and would move into the Women's National Republican Club at 3 West 51st Street on May 15.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday ordered a special election for members of the City Council in November, 1975, and directed the Council to redraw its district lines in "sufficient" time for that election.

SALINA, Kan.-Who done it? If it weren't for that question, Watergate would be the biggest bore of the year. Out here in Kansas, in the home precincts of Senator Bob Dole, the downpouring of scandal from Washington is a far less concern than the excessive spring rains sending the creeks into flood.
Three of the Anderson quintuplets born here yesterday were reported doing well today. Two of the babies required supplemental oxygen.

Carols Alberto Menditeguy, veteran Argentine racing driver and polo player, died today. He was 58 years old. Carlos Menditeguy was a member, with his brother, Julio, of Argentina's acclaimed Trebol polo team. Both were 10-goal players.

Insurgents holding Wounded Knee reported this afternoon that one of their number had been killed and another wounded in a gunfight in which United States marshals used gas as well as rifles to try to subdue the militants.
Anger over Sikkim's efforts to' loosen ties with India opened the way for New Delhi's swift take-over of the tiny Himalayan protectorate, according to authoritative reports reaching here.

The State Court of Appeals handed down yesterday a unanimous decision that would almost certainly have postponed the school board elections here, but hours later Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Lindsay and legislative leaders in Albany announced plans that would effectively sidestep the court's ruling.

President Nixon's principal 1972 re-election committee was formally cited today for a fourth time for violations of the new campaign finance reform act that Mr. Nixon, in signing last year, had predicted would "restore public confidence in the electoral process."
Sandra Palmer knocked in a 25-foot chip shot for a birdie on the 18th hole today and took a one-shot lead after the first round f the Birmingham Classic.

Ferdinand L. Ketterer, assistant treasurer and a director of the Manhattan Refrigerating Company and Union Terminal Cold Storage Company, Inc., died Thursday at his home, 164 Wildwood Avenue, Upper Montclair, N. J. His age was 80.

A Suffolk County Court judge in Riverhead dismissed all the indictments yesterday against three present and former county officials and a realestate broker charged with land manipulations in connection with the county's purchase of land at Tiana Beach in Hampton Bays.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market dropped sharply yesterday in continued light trading.

The Giant Stores Corporation, one of the discount-retailing industry's dramatic-growth companies that recently ran into financial problems, has discovered possible bookkeeping irregularities involving the last two fiscal years, its president, Jack H. Shapiro, announced yesterday.

The Pentagon's decision to keep open the Army training center here for an indefinite extended time has saved from extinction one of the nation's few debt-free railroad' lines.

Paul L. Hanly Sr., the 59year-old son-in-law of the former Hudson County Democratic boss, John V. Kenny, was indicted today for allegedly putting the harbor master of a Florida yacht club on the Hudson County payroll.

Gen. Yoon Pil Yong, the former commander of the elite Capital Security Command of the South Korean Army, who had ben one of President Park Chung Hee's favorites, was sentenced today to 15 years in prison by an army court-martial on charges of accepting bribes and other misconduct.

The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.6 billion ton-miles, 4.1 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago.

The General Motors Corporation announced today that sales and earnings were at record levels for the first quarter of 1973, but the company expressed disappointment that its profit margin was still less than in the last boom period in the mid-sixties.

It is unfortunate that domestic Japanese politics-a combination of opposition pressures, an oversensitive reaction by the Imperial Household Agency and excessive timidity on the part of an embattled Premier-have forced cancellation of Emperor Hirohito's planned visit to the United States this year, especially since the Emperor wanted to make the trip.

"My friends think I'm a great celebrity, a great detective," said Frank Wills, a 25-year-old security guard from North Augusta, S. C., who works in Washington. "Down home, I'm big stuff," Mr. Wills went on.
Daylight saving time will begin at 2 A.M. tomorrow, when clocks and watches should be set forward one hour. The system of advanced time will be in effect until a return to standard time on Oct. 28.

The South Vietnamese Government and the Vietcong blamed each other yesterday for 12,000 violations of the cease-fire in which more than 25,000 soldiers and civilians are reported to have been killed since Jan. 28.

The Public Service Commission yesterday authorized Consolidated Edison to increase its gas rates by $5,230,000 a year over and above an increase of $14,546,000 that was approved last December. The total increase of $19,776,000 in annual rate increases was short of the $24,051,000 sought by the utility.

NONPROFIT For most of us not in the know, "amateur films" has overtones of a yawning interlude during which you watch a shaky panning of the Grand Canyon ("that's it, over there, lower left") taken on vacation by Uncle Oscar.

An accountant related by marriage to a Watergate conspirator, E. Howart Hunt Jr., quoted Mr. Hunt today as saying the $10,000 his wife was carrying the night she was killed in an airline crash was to buy a Holiday Inn franchise.

A document purporting to be a 10-year-old State Department cable dealing with American policy toward former South Vietnamese President Ngo Dinh Diem was in the possession of E. Howard Hunt Jr., the convicted Watergate conspirator, in the summer of 1971.

For the first time, plant breeders have been granted protection on new varieties produced from seed. Certificates comparable to patents have been issued to four seed companies for six new varieties of lettuce.

A Senate subcommittee today made public previously secret Defense Department information officially confirming that the preponderance of American bombing in Cambodia shifted since last month from striking at North Vietnamese lines, of communication to supporting Cambodian Government forces.
L. Patrick Gray 3d resigned today in the intensifying Watergate crisis and was immediately replaced as Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation by William D. Ruckelshaus.

Andree Gilbert, a stocky black applicant for a lather's work permit, stood near the front of one of two minoritygroup lines on East 76th Street yesterday, his yellow foulweather gear dripping with the wind-whipped rain.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a seat for $86,000-the lowest price in more than 15 years-in the wake of slumping volume and eroding profits in the securities business.

New York and three other states have submitted proposals to impose traffic restrictions, inspection programs and improved exhaust devices for older cars, the Environmental Protection Agency announced today.
Motorola, Inc., announced yesterday that its consumer products division at Franklin Park, II., was ending its manufacturing and marketing of consumer audio products in this country.

A British soldier was killed by a sniper in Londonderry today despite a cease-fire called by the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army. An army spokesman said it was the fourth attack by gunmen on soldiers in the Creggan district of the city since the Provincials called a seven-day truce last Saturday to coincide with a local arts and sports festival.

The Soviet Union yesterday carried out its first major shake-up of the ruling Politburo since the ouster of Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1964 with a series of moves that confirmed the current policy of conciliation with the West, accompanied by strong defense and firm security measures at home. [Page 1, Columns 2-3.]

The Democratic party's ComImission on Delegate Selection and Party Structure began its first meeting tonight, with the aim, according to its chairman, of having a 1976 national convention at which "every Democrat watching on TV" will "feel like he or she,sees somebody like himself . . ."
Anyone with any interest at all in painting should try to get down to the Max Hutchinson Gallery, 127 Greene Street, before John Mandel's new exhibition closes on May 16.

The judge in the Pentagon papers trial released today a Justice Department memorandum saying that two convicted Watergate conspirators had broken into the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist here with the intention of stealing Dr. Ellsberg's medical records.
The Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., inducted five new members yesterday, including Elmer Ripley, the 81-year-old former coach at Georgetown, Yale, Columbia and Army,

Jill Johnston, a columnist for The Village Voice, was arrested late Thursday night outside the Guggenheim Museum at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street on charges of directing obscene language and gestures at a police officer, the police of the 23d Precinct said yesterday.

Warren Steilbel, producer of "Firing Line With William F. Buckley Jr.," said yesterday that the program, which may be withdrawn from public television for lack of funding, had recently been rated by more than 80 per cent of the public network's 237 station managers to be "the most essential" program in their schedule.
After nearly five hours of debate, the Senate tonight passed by a vote of 41 to 14 Governor Rockefeller's modified legislation for dealing with traffickers in dangerous drugs.
The Justice Department filed suit today against Parma Ohio, accusing the city of denying housing opportunities to blacks.

A group of black policemen has filed a $20-million damage suit in United States District Court here against Police Chief John Inman, Mayor Sam Massell and other city officials, accusing them of racial discrimination.
The Administration is considering proposing a bill to bring all commodity futures trading and related services under some form of Federal regulation, a Government official said yesterday.

An unidentified man around 25 or 30 years of age and wearing casual clothes and carrying no personal papers was found dead of a gunshot wound in the chest in a hallway of a West Side brownstone Thursday night, the fifth homicide victim in a week in the central Manhattan detective division.

President Nixon took a respite from his Watergate troubles today and flew to an air naval station near here where he was cheered by a crowd of several thousand and encouraged by Senator John C. Stennis to "tough it out."
The Mayor of Hilo estimated today damage at more than $1-million from yesterday's earthquake that flattened one building, damaged more than 100 homes and left 11 persons injured.
The stock market suffered another sharp setback yesterday in moderate trading. The Dow-Jones industrial average toppled 15.57 points to 922.19, a new closing low for 1973.

David D. Michaels, who became publisher of The New Yorker magazine in 1969 when its advertising revenues were in a serious decline and saw it turn around, resigned yesterday. The official management reason was "differences of views of the company's goals."

A Federal grand jury, which started out about two months ago trying to unravel a tangled securities case and then broadened its investigation to question two former Cabinet members who ran President Nixon's re-election campaign, appears to be nearing completion of its inquiry.

Despite the runaway climb of food prices ana owner living costs, major wage settlements are still being negotiated without strikes at levels close to the anti-inflation guidepost established by the now-dismantled Pay Board. The latest example of this moderation is the three-year agreement between Goodyear and the United Rubber Workers, a union with a long tradition of militancy.
Steve Busby, a right-handed rookie pitcher for the Kansas City Royals who had lasted only one inning in his last start, pitched a no-hitter last night, beating the Detroit Tigers, 3-0.

This has been a week for endorsements that seem more knock than boost. Vice President Agnew started it with his patronizing attestation to President Nixon's integrity in the Watergate case. Now Governor Rockefeller has made his contribution with a half-hearted expression of support for State Senator John J. Marchi, Republican nominee for Mayor of New York City.

Last week when the Watergate thing began getting very bad indeed for President Nixon, establishment thinkers of both parties began talking the line that we should all be cautious about leaning too hard on the President lest we end up by damaging the Presidency.

Kenneth B. Clark, a member of the State Board of Regents, asked the Regents and the State Education Commissioner today to remove the New York City Board of Education and appoint a "receiver or trustee" in its place.

The 11 widows and 36 children of 12 firemen killed when a floor collapsed during a fivealarm blaze here seven years ago were awarded a total of $2,150,000, settling in State Supreme Court a trial that had begun on Monday. One of the widows has died since the fire.

The Government arrested 18 more leaders of the National Awami party in Baluchistan Province today, official sources reported. The sources said the Government of President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto believed that law and order in the province were in jeopardy.

The head of the striking gravediggers' union, asserting that the managements of 4th cemeteries in the city had refused to negotiate for three weeks, warned yesterday that a citywide strike of cemetery workers way imminent.

About 360 soccer teams will play from Old Tappan to Cape May tomorrow in competitions that involve titles, promotions and demotions to lower divisions of their respective leagues. "Things have grown so much that we are having problems coordinating the efforts of all people in soccer within the state," said Edward Kennedy, president of the New Jersey State Soccer Association.

Outplayed, outhustled, outshot and, most surprising of all, outsteadied, the New York Knicks fell before the Boston Celtics, 110-100, at Madison Square Garden last night and allowed the semifinal round of the National Basketball Association championship playoff to be reduced to one game, to be played at Boston tomorrow afternoon.

The British Government tonight described Henry A. Kissinger's proposals for a "new Atlantic charter" as realistic and timely but made it clear that Europe did not intend to link monetary, trade and defense issues in single negotiations.

Both losses were after substantial tax credits.

Robert E. Lauterbach, president of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, has been elected chief executive officer of the nation's ninth largest steel producer, effective June 1. He will succeed Allison R. Maxwell Jr., who continues as chairman.

A local employe of El Al, the Israeli airline, was shot to death this afternoon by an Arab gunman in front of a department store. No. 10 Downing Street was on public view again yesterday. That is, its front door was. The rest of the 18th-century facade of Prime Minister Heath's official residence was covered with corrugated sheet steel, a precaution against bombs or other attacks. Only the door was visible.

The New York Athletic Club won its fifth straight eightoared race of the season today on the Orchard Beach lagoon. The winners, stroked by Joe Caminiti, defeated New York State Maritime College by four and a half lengths in rough conditions to capture the Gen. John Glover Cup.

RIVERHEAD, L. I.-Suffolk County will no longer have to rely on a historically quaint but often entangled system of land description inherited from its villages' forefathers when its new tax map is completed.

RIVERHEAD, L. I. - To make up an estimated deficit of $580,000 in the current county police budget caused by rising retirement costs, Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein has ordered a freeze in the hiring of all clerical and maintenance workers and a delay in the start of future cadet classes.
Ivan Southall is best known in this country for "Hills End," "Ash Road" and "To the Wild Sky." Those are fast-moving action. and suspense novels with spectacular backdrops of Australia's interior.

EXTREME avant -garde ideas proliferated like flies in the sixties. Two tendencies of thought in the background of many of these ideas were reductivism, which wanted to strip art to its essentials, and what might be called "multimedia," which wanted to transcend traditional art categories by hybridizing them.
Cambodia's exiled head of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, said today that his forces were positioned all around Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, but had no intention of assaulting and capturing it.

Miss Marie Jo Foscato, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Foscato, was married here this morning to Philip Frank Spinella, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Spinella of Brooklyn. The Rev. Robert L. Brown performed the ceremony and celebrated a nuptial mass in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.
CHAPPAQUA, N. Y.-For single, widowed or divorced people it can be expensive as well as depressing to live alone in the suburbs.

Leaders of the American Indian Movement said this afternoon that they would defy the Oglala Sioux Indian tribe and the Federal Government and march onto the Pine Ridge Reservation tomorrow to bury a Wounded Knee insurgent who died Wednesday from a gunshot wound.

Sherry Baltimore, 30 years old, is a busy corporate wife who lives in Phoenix, Ariz. She fills in when her husband's secretary is on vacation, travels with her husband on business, helps him entertain customers and talks with him about his work even when she's bored.

LONDON - Big snips under sail will try to beat the times set by the legendary clippers of the last century in an around-the-world race to take place in 1975. The race, from England to Australia and back again, will include, a 15,000-mile leg that is more than four times the maximum distance raced by sailing boats until nOw.

Once the target of Congressional snickers over fancy toe dancers and long-haired fiddlers, the National Endowment for the Arts has discovered that there are perils, too, in being taken seriously.

The nephew of the ruler of Sikkim charged here yesterday that neo-colonialist elements within the Indian Government were responsible for the recent political crisis in the Himalayan protectorate.

One of the most remarkable clutch records in sports is the Boston Celtics' record in seventh games of National Basketball Association playoffs. They have never lost in 10 series that went to the seventh game.

OCEANSIDE, L. I. - Arnie is going into commission again next month on Bedell Creek, proving that his conversion from tee to sea is no fluke. For years, Arnie arose before daybreak on weekends to join the hordes on the public links of Long Island, a ridiculous procedure he attributes solely to the fact that his last name is Hartman, not Palmer.

TRENTON - New Jersey's 1973 gubernatorial races break from the starting gate this week, with Republicans facing a replay of a 1969 grudge match and the Democrats trying to avoid a divisive four-way primary fight.

Dr. Carl Kaysen, director of the Institute for Advanced Study, who has been asked by the institute's trustees to stay on for at least five years, said today that he intended "to stay and serve as long as I can usefully do so."
President Nixon signed into law today a bill providing $872million in student aid for the coming college year even though it was not the kind of aid the President had requested.
Vice President Agnew Is still the favorite of Republican voters for the Presidential nomination in 1976, the Gallup poll reported yesterday.

The Congress of Racial Equality, a long-time foe of racial discrimination, has lined up with the Nixon Administration and the state of Virginia in an attempt to block Supreme Court approval of public school integration across city-suburban lines.

New York University Medical Center yesterday honored the memory of one of its benefactors by naming its new center mall and entrance at 550 First Avenue at 31st Street, the Samuel D. Leidesdorf Plaza.
A Government consultant on energy problems has suggested that all Americans work in their shirtsleeves in summertime to reduce or eliminate air-conditioning demands.

Steam locomotives--with their traditional sounds and aromas that haunt old-time rail fans-are still flourishing in Eastern Europe. But impressive modernization programs will phase them out in just a few more years.

There's a revolution going on--in small boats. Sometimes called "fun boats" or "seamobiles" or just simply "one-man" craft, they come in all sizes, shapes, colors and prices, but with one thing in common: zippiness.

The annual Harvard-Yale crew race, the oldest intercollegiate sports event in the United States, dating to 1852, may be abandoned or modified after this year's contest at New London, Conn., on June 16.

The United States will get another crack at the Soviet Olympic championship wrestling team. The two rivals of the 1972 Olympic, as well as in the world championships of 1969 and 1970, will meet in the Felt Forum, June 1 at 8 p.m.
Dan Sikes, the pro golf tour's only lawyer, overtook Bob Dickson today to share the 54-hole lead at 206, four under par, in the $150,000 Byron Nelson Classic.

WASHINGTON-It was not until 1932 that the Supreme Court first recognized the defense of entrapment, the claim by a defendant that disguised law enforcement agents deceived him into commission of a crime of which he should therefore be judged innocent.

For 10 days now the cheating scandal at the United States Military Academy here has continued to grow. Fifteen cadets have been found in violation of the academy's honor code, and the cadet honor committee gave no sign that its investigation was nearing an end before it recessed its hearings yesterday for the weekend.

A 35-year-old clothing clerk at the state institution for the mentally retarded at 75 Morton Street in Greenwich Village has been charged with raping a 12year-old girl patient at the recently opened facility.
Collegians at several eastern Pennsylvania schools have revived the obscure art of concrete-boat building for tomorrow's first running of the intercollegiate concrete canoe race.

For stout-hearted patrons who had the nerve to back Hobeau Farm's Poker Night against Summer Guest and Numbered Account yesterday at Aqueduct, it didn't take a mirror on the wall to see which filly was the fairest in the land.

HACKENSACK - International folk-dancing appears to be sweeping the state. Every night of the week, at various places and various times, community groups and individuals are stepping to the tunes of foreign dances.

Jacques Maritain, the renowned Roman Catholic philosopher, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in Toulouse at the community house of the Little Brothers of Jesus, where he had lived in retirement since 1960. He was 90 years old.

Two fresh gas eruptions late yesterday have forced the evacuation of another family and the sealing off of another half square mile of this area, which has been beleaguered by the mysterious development of 150 potholes and gas-bearing geysers since April 18.
Paula Rapp, an artist known for her collages in metal and paper, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 42 years old and lived at 216-18 40th Avenue in Bayside, Queens.
Yoshi Hayasaki, YashiakiTakei and Jean Moore Rice were awarded gold medals tonight as the all-round champions at the national Amateur Athletic Union senior gymnastics meet at Canisius College.

When their cramped West Side quarters were gutted' by a fire a few months ago, Bob Berman and Jim Kronen packed up their old scientific and mechanical instruments and their American folk art and moved to a more spacious shop on the East Side.

MOSCOW-Friday was a bad day for those hapless souls who have to hang the massive, stylized portraits of the Soviet leadership on big buildings in Moscow for the annual May Day parade. Work crews struggled in the rain and got them part way upthen paused-then took theme down again.
James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhod of Teamsters, disclosed today that he planned to run for president of his home local in Detroit next year.

The stock market plunged sharply last week and recorded one of its largest weekly declines in history. The Dow-Jones industrial average toppled 41.01 points in the five sessions and closed at a new 1973 low of 922.19, eclipsing the former low of 922.71 reached March 23. The total loss for the Dow was even greater than the 40.05-point nosedive in the climactic week of May 18-22, 1970.

President Nixon has signed a multimillion-dollar bill that revives a rural disaster relief program killed by the White House in December. The law provides disaster relief loans at 5 per cent interest to victims who cannot ob-. tain them from commercial sources.

THE latest planning controversy of major magnitude in London is focused on Piccadilly Circus. North Korea was approved for admission to the Inter-Parliamentary Union today. The resolution for admission, introduced by Italy, was by a vote of 57 to 28, with 20 abstentions. It called for the admission of North Korea at the next session of the council, in Santiago, Chile, in October.

Washington responded by accusing Hanoi of "direct and inexcusable" breaches in the three-months- old accord. American reconnaissance planes again flew over North Vietnam - a none-toosubtle warning of a possible renewal of American bombing.

J., one of the most talented young experts in the metropolitan area, was able to draw an inference from the slow play of an opponent at a different table.

MORRISTOWN - Superior Court Judge Joseph H. Stamler, who has gained wide respect during his seven years on the bench, is retiring this week. For the last three and one-half years, the judge, who has handed down decisions of both statewide and national impact, has served in the Chancery Division in Morris County.

Tina Ramirez's Ballet Hispanico of New York is a company to keep your eye on. The troupe, formed in 1970 by Miss Ramirez, whose performing career until the early nineteen-sixties was in Spanish dancing, is an example of what a communityoriented organization can offer to a wide public.

H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, and John D. Ehrlichman, President Nixon's top domestic adviser, will meet with Federal prosecutors this week to discuss their possible roles in the Watergate break-in and its subsequent cover-up, sources close to the case said today.

Gloria Ehret, a nineyear pro who had not won a Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament since 1966, sank a 15-foot birdie putt today to defeat Clifford Ann Creed and Betty Burfeindt, the defender, in a sudden-death playoff in the Birmingham Classic.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the May Department Stores Company announced yesterday that Metropolitan Life would soon offer a supplementary hospital insurance plan to charge-account customers of the FamousBarr department store in St. Louis.

Robert S. Strauss, chiarman of the Democratic National Committee, sought :support tonight from Democratic Governors for a $75,000 television campaign attacking the Nixon Administration for its handling of the Watergate case.

WASHINGTON-The apparent collapse of the student revolt, which just two years ago threatened to stop the Government, is an abrupt and significant development. Campuses claim they are back at work, newspapers talk inflation, energy shortages, scandal, checks and balances. Revolutionaries have lost their mystique.

Agriculture is one of the most intractable problems confronting the United States and its European allies as they strive for a revitalized partnership in the "Year of Europe." Both President Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger have expressed concern that European Community protectionism would nullify this country's "comparative advantage" in agricultural exports.
More than one million supermarket register tapes will be mailed to the White House starting today to protest soaring food prices.

Miss Lucille Marie Cuccurullo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Cuccurullo of Cold Spring Harbor, was married here this afternoon to James William Wyckoff, son of Mrs. Edward Thomas Wyckoff of Huntington and the late Mr. Wyckoff.

A force of 150 state and local law officers searched today for the remaining 12 convicts who escaped from the Decatur Correctional Institution last night. Twelve others who also escaped were recaptured later.
Two bookstalls at the southeast corner of Central Park opened yesterday for a second season and quickly drew the compulsive readers from among the pedestrians at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street.

Following are excerpts from Mayor Lindsay's transportation message: I am proposing to the Albany Legislature a whole new approach to mass transit financing which will revitalize mass transportation in the New York City metropolitan region and in other regions of the state which may choose to use it.

All it took was the Knicks' finest defensive effort of the National Basketball Association season-82 regular games and 12 playoff contests-to bring chuckles of self-satisfaction to Coach Red Holzman and his team after today's game at Boston Garden.
Speculation as to whether Shecky Greene, conceded to be one of the fastest sprinters of recent years, will race in the Kentucky Derby next Saturday was the main concern at Churchill Downs today.

The Department of Defense over the last 15 years has used emergency authorization to award tens of millions of dollars in outright grants to defense contractors - decisions taken frequently without the ratification or even the knowledge of the Secretary of Defence.

The United States national basketball team, battling to atone for a disputed loss to the Russians in the 1972 Olympic final, defeated the Soviet five by a score of 83-65 today in the opener of a six-game series.

The "El Mole Rachamim," the Hebrew prayer for the dead (God, Full of Mercy)-echoed in Times Square and in Temple Emanu-El yesterday as New York Jews honored those who died in the Warsaw ghetto uprising 30 years ago.
The population of a southern Philippine mountain tribe that still lives in the Stone Age has grown to 28 with the birth of a baby girl, it was reported here today.
The World Cup ski circuit will stay entirely in Europe next year, the International Ski Federation (FIS) announced today.

Physicians may have to write their own cough medicine formulas because the Federal Government has ordered dozens of commercial cough remedies off the market, the Journal of the American Medical Association said today.
Mrs. Louise Munroe Means, widow of Philip Ainsworth Means, an expert on Inca civil??zation, died Saturday at her home, 755 Park Avenue. She was 82 years old.
Silas Spitzer, food editor since 1971 of Travel and Leisure magazine, died yesterday at his winter home in Quogue.

Michael Burke, the man who induced the Columbia Broadcasting System to buy the Yankees in 1964 and then to sell them to the present owners earlier this year, relinquished yesterday his role in the operation of the club.
The three-mile shoreline of Scherwenz Lake just south of here is dotted with more than a hundred vacation cottages-all of them illegal, according to East German property regulations.
Japan's end of April external reserves dropped to $16.83-billion from $18.1-billion at the end of March, the Finance Ministry announced.
Billy Gallagher of Larchmont, N.Y., the top-seeded player, won the Concord Junior invitation tennis tournament today defeating Gary Adelman of Roslyn, L.I., 6-0, 7-6.
Nicaragua is suffering from serious trauma four months after an earthquake destroyed this capital city, killing about 10,000 people. According to mental-health experts,

Shoppers in the New York area continued to fight high meat prices last week by curtailing their purchases, but so far the tactic has produced only some special sales, no lowering of meat prices in general.

Top-seeded Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., overcame a tough challenge from John Alexander in the first set and came back strongly to defeat the sixth-seeded Australian 5-7, 6-4, 6-2, in the final of the $50,000 Swedish pro tennis championships today.

Defense attorneys in the Pentagon papers trial are considering a move tomorrow for dismissal of the case against Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. because of a report that the office of Dr. Ellsberg's former psychiatrist had been broken into by men associated with the Government.

William H. Sullivan, the United States Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, and Nguyen Co Thach, the North Vietnamese Deputy Foreign Minister met for five and a half hours today in their second session of talks here in three days.

" Whiskey," the title of Terrence McNally's new comedy, is the name of the equine star of the "longest-running, most highly rated television series." Onstage at Theater at St. Clements, where the show opened last night, the famous horse is heard but not seen. The play is actually about Whiskey's cowboy family, The Lush Thrushes.

The body of an unidentified woman about 50 years old was take from the East River yesterday afternoon by police who had been sent to the scene after passengers aboard a Circle Line sightseeing boat had spotted her first and informed the crew.

" The effectiveness and merit of properly controlled exercise in the life of a victim of a heart attack could not be better described than what you are witnessing here this morning," declared Dr. Irving M. Levitas, director of rehabilitation medicine at Hackensack Hospital.
Miss Susan Jane Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Davis Jr. of New York, was married here this afternoon to Barry Denenberg. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Denenberg of Dumont, N. J.

Defense attorneys in the Pentagon papers trial are considering a move tomorrow for dismissal of the case against Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. because of a report that the office of Dr. Ellsberg's former psychiatrist had been broken into by men associated with the Government.

A plan to roll back bus and subway fares to 25 cents, cut commuter fares by almost 30 per cent and, at the same time, provide for Jong-range financing of mass transit in the metropolitan area was unveiled

A new concert series entitled "Three by Three," which got under way yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, fitted somewhere between what in art circles is called a group show and what in Olympic circles is called a marathon.
The Head Start program for needy pre-school children has begun charging middl-class parents for enrolling their children in the education program, it became known last week.

The results of a Gallup Poll released today show that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts leads Vice President Agnew by a wide margin in voter popularity. The survey gave the Massachusetts Democrat 51 per cent against 38 per cent for the Vice President.
A statistical researcher with time to spare could draw some conclusions about rubber-bridge play compared with duplicate by surveying a large number of deals in each category.

A vast new co-operative meat market, designed to take wholesalers off the crowded streets of the West Village and Brook Avenue in the Bronx, is nearing completion in Hunts Point. The project, in. which 45 big dealers have already enlisted, is mostly financed by city on lease-back arrangement.
MANILA - An Americanowned company--the Andres Soriano Corporation--has offered the majority of its stock to its Filipino employes.

A battered 3-month-old girl was reported in critical condition at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday after having been rescued by a transit patrolman early Saturday morning from her father, who the police said, was trying to sell the screaming infant on the subway to collect enough money to buy narcotics.
The Committee for Economic Development, a research group supported by industry, is recommending variable-rate mortgages to make housing less vulnerable to swings in the economy.

Connecticut's economy moved forward in the first three months of this year but still lagged behind the national recovery, according to the five-man Connecticut Council of Economic Advisers, which yesterday continued improvement in the coming six months, but warned that greater unemployment could develop toward the end of this year.

The State Assembly, by a vote of 62 to 0, approved and sent to Governor Cahill today a measure authorizing a $25-million bond issue to finance the expansion and construction of day-school educational centers for thousands of New Jersey's severely handicapped children.
Herbert M. Greenberg, a Princeton, N.J., psychologist and pollster, said today that 80 per cent of working Americans were dissatisfied with their jobs.
Laura Dean has the exhilarating tenacity to repeat a step a hundred times so that her audience may clearly see it, and she makes wonderful sense out of insistent repetition.

Ever-increasing numbers of recaptured young bluefin tuna originally tagged in the northwestern Atlantic indicate that this age group of the species is being overfished by commercial interests, says Frank J. Mather 3d, a scientist at the Woods Hole (Mass.) Oceanographic Institute.

The New York Knickerbockers were generally conceded to have not too bright a chance of defeating the Celtics in the seventh and deciding game of their playoff series at Boston on Sunday. This was obvious to even the most backward of the experts. The Celtics had rallied with Irresistible surge to force this showdown as they displayed the hottest hands since the guy broke the bank at Monte Carlo.

A non-registered secondary of 62,350 shares of Southern Railway at $36 a share was made yesterday by Paine Webber Jackson CurtiS. The company's stock was up 1/2 at 36 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Thousands of plants, shrubs and saplings, some in blossom, were banked on the steps of the Federal Hall National Memorial at Broad and Wall Streets yesterday to mark the 184th anniversary of George Washington's Presidential inauguration at that site.

The president of the United Nations Economic and Social Council said today the Nixon Administration plan to sell part of the United States stockpile of metals and other commodities would harm the economies of poor nations.

When the Yugoslav grandmaster Milan Matulovic suffers a rare pasting from a less-favored opponent, he insists on playing through to the end of the regular fivehour session, no matter how awful his position.

Charging the Record Club of America with false and deceptive advertising, the office of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, obtained in State Supreme Court yesterday an order requiring the club to justify its business practices or return $288,000 to New Yorkers who were induced by ads for free tapes to records to enroll in the club.
The Nixon Administration proposed today changes in the tax laws and tax forms that would mike it easier for millions, of individuals to figure out their Federal income taxes.
The resignations of H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman from President Nixon's senior staff clearly mark the end of one era of the Nixon Presidency and the beginning of another.
The state's Public Health Council voted unanimously yesterday to deny an application to certify Dr. Thomas W. Mathew's Interfaith Hospital in Queens as a health-related facility.

The State Department acknowledged today that Charles W. Colson secretly arranged for copies of a praiseful letter about President Nixon, over the signature of Walter Annenberg, the United States Ambassador to Britain, to be sent to American citizens at Government expense.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ordered today implementation of a lower court plan for desegregation of public schools in Chattanooga, Tenn.

The strike of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen again PATH, the Porth Aruthority Trans-Hudson commuter railroad, entered its second month today with the deadlock over wage increases and the length of a new contract still unresolvped.

The president of one of the nation's foremost groups of young medical scientists charged today that the Nixon Administration's policies on health research and training were producing "unacceptable" risks with the lives and destinies of Americans.

Lincoln's country, the America of innocence, the America before Vietnam, before Watergate-this is the special image conjured up by Edgar; Lee Masters's "Spoon River Anthology," which was revived last night at Stage 73. It wears well.

The Government's investigation of the Watergate affair will remain in the hands of Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen until Elliot L. Richardson is confirmed as Attorney General, a Justice Department spokesman said today.

The Assembly gave final passage today to a bill that eliminates the "all-or-nothing" concept in New Jersey laws covering accident insurance and enables accident victims to collect damages even if they contribute to an accident.

After waiting in line to open an account at a savings bank in New York, the man was impatient. "I'm in a hurry," he said to the young woman signing up newcomers. "Open an account for $1,000. My wife--she won't do this, says it's silly.

The General Telephone Electronics Corporation's unit, GTE Information Systems, said today it had received a communications network contract from the Social Security Administration, Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

After having served four years of an 11-year sentence, Robert Bolivar DePugh, founder of the right-wing Minutemen organization, was released from Federal prison in Atlanta. DePugh was convicted of weapons-law violations and failing to appear in court.
The floodwaters receded slightly in the northern part of the Mississippi Valley yesterday, but the danger was far from over and the damage was still mounting.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today he did not believe that the Watergate scandal would damage American foreign relations so long as there was "full and complete disclosure" of the facts, prosecution of all those guilty and remedial action to prevent such affairs in the future.
A reputed Mafia member, his son and three other men were charged yesterday with having forced a Long Island dairy concern out of business through robbery and extortion demands.

While enjoying a full day in first place in the National League's East Division, the New York Mets played an exhibition game here and made some medical decisions. John Milner, the Mets, first baseman, who suffered a pulled hamstring in Houston last week, saw Dr. Peter LaMotte and the team physician recommended Milner not play for two weeks.
Yields on United States Treasury bills were mixed in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.
The Tenneco Oil Company, drilling offshore in the Gulf of Thailand, has struck crude oil, mining sources said today.

Amid today's school board elections and preparations for the June 4 primaries, the Board of Elections is losing its administrator-manager. Alexander Bassett, 58 years old, is resigning today after 34 years with the board.

Standing in the coastal shallows, its head and neck tilted at a sharp angle, the great blue heron appears to be listening to the wind or merely listing for want of anything better to do with a neck so long.
The trial of Vincent Pacelli, who is accused of murdering a 28-year-old Manhattan model to prevent her from testifying against him in a narcotics trial, opened yesterday in Federal court here.
Lesser-known players made a clean sweep at the Long Island Regional tournament held at Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I., last weekend.
Farm Ministers of the nine European Common Market Nations moved toward a compromise today on establishing new farm prices for the 1973-74 season.
The Ford Motor Company reported record earnings today of $361million, or $3.59 a share, in the first quarter of 1973 on peak sales of $6.1-billion.

Newsmen gathered here over the weekend for the northeastern regional conference of Sigma Delta Chi, national journalistic society, hailed the achievements of Washington reporters sifting through evidence surrounding the Watergate scandal.

The discovery of the Watergate scandal so early in the second Administration of President Nixon is a fortunate circumstance for the nation. It is likely to slow down' and may reverse related and equally ominous developments.

A Federal Court judge ordered the Irvington police today not to seize sex books and films from a book store, and ordered the bookstore's harassment suit combined with two other Federal cases attacking New Jersey's antiobscenity procedures.

Members of Congress joined in widespread, bipartisan praise today for President Nixon's shake-up of his Administration's high command.
Four top Nixon Administration officials resigned today as a consequence of the Watergate case, one of the most widespread scandals in American Presidential history.
A Federal judge yesterday ordered the release of Mario Biaggi's testimony before a grand jury but held up the order when the mayoral candidate's lawyer. said he would appeal to block disclosure.
The State of Maryland has submitted a plan for meeting Federal air quality standards that its officials admit would take "nothing short of martial law" to enforce.

WASHINGTON-Almost fifty years ago, Mr. Justice Brandeis, dissenting in the famous wiretapping case, Olmstead v. United States, said: "Our Government is the potent, the omnipresent teacher. For good or evil, it teaches the whole people by its example."
Policemen firing teargas and plastic riot bullets battied thousands of youths who fought back with rocks, bottles and bricks yesterday during a rock music concert at a baseball field.

The Harness Tracks of America executive committee has recom-. mended that "appropriate disciplinary action" should be taken against Monticello Raceway for "statements and conduct not in the best interests of harness racing."

Eight recent immigrants from the Soviet Union tried today to gain entrance to the weekly meeting of the Israeli Cabinet to protest the Government's refusal to endorse the proposed Jackson amendment to United States legislation on Soviet trade.
The design for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt memorial planned for Welfare Island, scheduled to be released last week; has run into snags of time and taste.

The first systematic enforcement of the restrictions on blowing vehicular horns since the city's new noise code went into effect last year will begin on May 14, the Environmental Protection Administration said yesterday.

Police Officer Thomas J. Shea who is accused of having fatally shot Clifford Glover, a 10-year-old Queens youth, in the back early Saturday, was a member of the 103d Precinct's neighborhood police team-and one of about 1,00 policemen who comb the streets of New York in plainclothes and a variety of disguises.

Prices received by farmers for raw products dropped 1.5 per cent in April, the first decline in 12 months, the Department of Agriculture said today. But they still averaged 32 per cent higher than the year-earlier level.
Five local Churehes refused yesterday to 'follow the return of daylight savings time and held services at standard time. Attendance was better than last year.
The state police in this Chemung County community, seven miles northwest of Elmira, said that when they, answered a burglar alarm at Black's Feed Mill, all they found inside was a confused dog.

The City Council's Housing Committee voted yesterday to repeal the rent control law's controversial maximum base rent formula, which permits rent increases up to 7.5 per cent a year in many controlled apartments.
The size of the field for Saturday's 99th running of the Kentucky Derby may be affected by the outcome of the Derby Trial, the one-mile event that will head tomorrow's Churchill Downs program.

President Nixon told the nation tonight that he accepted the responsibility for what happened in the Watergate case even though he had had no knowledge of political espionage or attempts to cover it up.
A sexton was injured today in a general alarm fire that caused Heavy damage to St. George's Greek Orthodox Church. Christos Tsolios, 85
Five members of the United States Senate Commerce Committee arrived today for talks with European Common Market officials on European-American trade disputes.
The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it had scheduled May 17 as the date for an underground nuclear gas-stimulation test, near Meeker, Colo.

There hasn't been much time for poetry in Billy Reay's check. ered and long career as coach of the Chicago Black Hawks. But today he had a ready, unrhymed answer when asked whether yesterday's 8-3 loss to the Canadiens was worse than, say, a 3-1 defeat.
Members of Congress joined in widespread, bipartisan praise today for President Nixon's shake-up of his Administration's high command.
Jacob A. Rubenstein, a retired textile executive, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 40 East 83d street.

The military government tonight declared a state of emeragency in Argentina's five largest cities in the wake of the assassination by left-wing guerrillas of the former Chief of Staff of the armed forces.

A Manhattan fur brokerage concern that pleaded guilty last February to having traded illegally in the pelts of endangered species was fined $500,000 in Federal Court in Brooklyn. Judge Jack B. Weinstein suspended, all but $10,000 of the fine against Vesley-Forte, Inc., of 259 West 30th Street, warning that he would impose the entire fine if there were further violations.
The nation's Democratic Governors joined today in the call for appointment of a special prosecutor in the Watergate case;
Two former officers of the K Securities Corporation, an over-the-counter brokerage house, were sentenced yesterday in New York Supreme Court to up to five years each in prison.

The last legal snag that might have delayed community school board elections in New York City was cleared away here today as the Legislature passed by an overwhelming vote a bill to allow the use of print-out lists for identification of voters at polling places tomorrow.

New York's Offtrack Betting Corporation will handle wagering on the 3-year-old Triple Crown of thoroughbred racing -- the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes-for the third straight year, according to an announcement yesterday by Howard Samuels, the president of OTB.

The Southern Pacific Company reported yesterday a $5.5-million drop in its net income in the first quarter to $14.1-million, or 53 cents a share, from $19.6-million, or 74 cents a share, in the same 1972 period.

The Lloyan Government has banned entry to all foreigners except those with Arabic-language passports, effectively stopping travel into the country by all but other Arabs, diplomats here reported today.
The bond market, virtually unaffected by the resignation of some top Administration aides, traded in a narrow range yesterday in uneventful dealings.
The American Broadcasting Company will televise all but one of the National Basketball Association playoff games between the NewYork Knicks and Los Angeles Lakers.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the continued American bombing in Cambodia was legally justified by the Constitution and was "a meaningful interim action" to force the communist-backed insurgents there to agree to a cease-fire.
The Knitwear Employers Association and District 65 of the Distributive Workers have reached a tentative contract settlement, Harold Korzenik, counsel for the association, said yesterday.

The 18-year-old son of Alan King, the comedian, pleaded not guilty yesterday to unauthorized possession of his father's car. The case drew attention when Mr. King reported the car missing and had his son Andrew arrested on the misdemeanor charge.

Bruce D. Voorhees has been appointed general merchandise manager for Gimbels East, the new Manhattan store opened by Gimbel Brothers in February, 1972. Mr. Voorhees was previously merchandising vice president of women's and junior apparel at H S Pogue Co., Cincinnati.

The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission called on state regulatory and enforcement authorities today to plug any holes in their supervision of the insurance industry so that "swindles like the Equity Funding matter cannot recur."

Only four days before he pitched an 11-0 no-hitter against Colgate University two weeks ago, Roger Kreutzer thought his Fairleigh Dickinson University baseball career had ended at age 19 because of a lingering arm ailment.
Two men, one armed with a sawed-off shotgun, held up the Pelham branch of the First Westchester National Bank today and fled with an undetermined amount of cash, the police reported.

Trial Skylab countdowns moved smoothly today but striking tracking - station workers said that they and the Benedix Field Engineering Corporation were far apart in a pay dispute that threatened the scheduled launching of the orbiting laboratory in two weeks.

A new flag, bearing the number 75, was raised over City Hall yesterday as the city began a year-long celebration of the 75th anniversary of the consolidation of the five boroughs into Greater New York.

Teen-agers and college students in metropolitan New York can spend this summer as telephone operators, maids, vegetable pickers or as actors playing such cartoon characters as Bugs Bunny.

The executive committee of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting held a closed meeting yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to consider, among other things, the question of who will succeed Thomas B. Curtis as board chairman. Mr. Curtis, a former Republican Representative from Missouri, resigned as C.P.B. chairman and as a board member April 18.
The judge in the Pentagon papers trial today ordered four figures connected to the Watergate affair to produce affidavits concerning any link between that break-in and the trial here.
Jiro Osaragi, novelist and historian, whose writings on postwar Japan won him an international audience, died today at the National cancer center here. He was 75 years old.
The Tennessee legislature sent to Gov. Winfield Dunn today a proposed law restricting the teaching of evolution in the state's public schools, effective in 1975.

Spurred by the resignation of four leading aides of Pres'ident Nixon who are involved in the Watergate scandal, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in over-thecounter trading yesterday managed to erase some of their earlier losses.
The Assembly gave final passage tonight to legislation delaying for six months the controversial program to curb exhaust pollution from automobiles. The vote was 44 to 10.
A former Foreign Minister has condemned the continued presence of American forces in Thailand, saying it was never intended that they should remain after a Vietnam cease-fire.
Jim Brewer of the University of Minnesota, the second player selected in the recent National Basketball Association college draft, signed yesterday with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

An agreement between the United States Lawn Tennis Association and the Virginia Slims tennis circuit was announced today by Mrs. Billie Jean King, president of the Women's International Tennis Federation.
Dr. Israel J. Baron, a retired Brooklyn urologist, died Sunday of a heart attack in Hallandale, Fla., where he lived. He was 74 years old and also had a home in Far Rockaway, Queens.
The renovation of Yankee Stadium and the Yankees' continued presence there won't be affected by the change in the club's high command, city and team officials said yesterday.

Pat McNeill of Durham, N. C., held the lead after 12 games today in the $30,000 United States women's open bowling championship at Garden City Bowl. Her score was 2,544.
