Two Palestinian guerrilla leaders have attacked the President of Libya, Col Muammar el-Qaddafi, and challenged him to nationalize United States oil interests in his country.

The United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that widespread segregated neighborhoods resulted from official action of Federal, state and local governments in conjunction with the private housing industry.

Directors of the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) voted yesterday to increase from 1 to 3 per cent the maximum percentage of Series 1 outstanding shares of common stock that may be owned by any one person.

United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. dedared tonight that "in the memories of most of us there has probably never been a time when public confidence in the integrity of government has been so low."
Henry A. Kissinger will fly to Moscow this week for talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, on plans for Mr. Brezhnev's expected visit to the United States late in June.
The body of a Patchogue man, missing since April 8, When he went clamming in his motorboat, has washed ashore on Fire Island, the Suffolk County Police reported.
For a woman alone to take on a brownstone and renovate it or to buy a house in the suburbs just for herself sounds like a pretty formidable undertaking.

Roughly half of the country's 298 women's colleges became coeducational or went out of business between 1960 and 1972 according to a study released yesterday by the Educational Testing Service's College Research Center.

Another road block arose in the New York Giants' road to the Yale Bowl yesterday as the National Football League released the 1973 schedule without citing that the Giants have no place to play the final five of their seven home games.

The Buffalo Evening News began operations in a new fivestory building in downtown Buffalo today. The evening daily moved into the new building Saturday and yesterday after publishing its weekend edition in the old building a few blocks away.
A pint of some of the rarest blood in the world was on the way from Thailand to the Franklin County Public Hospital today to aid an elderly woman suffering from severe anemia.

Raymond L. Dirks, the stockmarket 'expert who uncovered the insurance fraud at the Equity Funding Corporation of America and then ran into difficulty with the New York Stock Exchange for telling his customers about it, disclosed yesterday that his legal bills were mounting so rapidly that he was planning to conduct a seminar and to write a book on his discovery to help defray his costs.
L. Patrick Gray spent the weekend in seclusion at his home, conferring with former associates at a New London law firm.

Brig. Gen. Lon Non, the controversial and powerful younger brother of Cambodia's President, Lon Nol, departed from Cambodia with his family today, but he denied that American pressure had forced him into temporary exile.

After a four-week run at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the show "On Loan From Russia-4l Fredch Masterpieces" will open Thursday at 10 A.M. at the Knoedler Gallery, 21 East 70th Street, and continue through May 26.
A grand jury today handed up Judge John O. Henderson indictments charging 24 men with various crimes.
Moments after President Nixon completed his television speech tonight, he walked into the room where the White House press briefings are held each morning.
Esmark, Inc., a holding company formed to handle the major business of Swift Co., began trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange on a when-issued basis and closed down 3/8 at 24 5/8.
Following is a sketch of Elliot L. Richardson, who today was named Attorney Generalof the United States:

Ladies and gentlemen, the Great Paver of the UnitedStates: "Good motoring, everybody. I have nothing very major to announce today. Three towns in eastern, Pennsylvania were successfully covered with asphalt during the night and no longer present an obstacle to highspeed traffic.

Leaving his office at 20 Broad Street in lower Manhattan yesterday, former Attorney General John N. Mitchell was asked to comment on developments in the Watergate case and on the resignation of four of President Nixon's top White House aides.
Computer Automation, Inc., introduced here yesterday two minicomputers, one of which can actually fit into a standard pizza box.
Harry Markson, who recently retired as president of Madison Square Garden Boxing, Inc., became the 90th member of the Garden's Hall of Fame at a special induction ceremony yesterday.

Vito Antuofermo, the Italianborn Brooklyn-based middleweight, remained unbeaten as a pro, winning a split decision over Art Kettles of Asbury Park, N. J., in 10-round bout last night at the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden. Antuofermo has 16 victories and a draw.
The judge in the Pentagon papers trial today ordered four figures connected to the Watergate affair to produce affidavits concerning any link between that break-in and the trial here.
The Federal Trade Commis sion announced today that it was, making formal complaints that four manufacturers of toys, gifts and hobby items were marketing products in deceptively oversized packages.
The Lebanese security police reported today that they had foiled an attempt by Palestinian guerrillas to attack the United States Embassy, the latest of several commando incidents.
Poland has withdrawn from the annual women's Federation Cup tennis competition in protest over the participation of South Africa, the defending champion, organizers of the event said today.
The New York Stock Exchange is circulating to accountants and executives a draft of a white paper outlining new guidelines for financial reporting to shareholders of listed corporations.

The Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist, who is a close friend of President Nixon, said yesterday that the Watergate scandal was a symptom of the "permissiveness, corruption and crime" permeating much of American life.
The Cleveland coup that captured the New York Yankees appeared complete yesterday after the withdrawal of Michael Burke as chief executive officer of the team.

Howard Kohn, a reporter for The Detroit Free Press, has won Columbia University's 1973 Paul Tobenkin award for "outstanding achievement in the cent field of newspaper writing in were the fight against racial and re- jobs. ligious hatred, intolerance, discrimination and every form of bigotry."

In his drive for a new Atlantic Charter and a "revitalized Atlantic partnership," President Nixon has scheduled no more important preliminary than his talks today andtomorrow with West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. In every respect, Mr. Brandt will be, a key figure for the success or failure of the Administration's ambitious objectives for the "Year of Europe."
A Federal judge yesterday ordered the release of Mario Biaggi's testimony before a grand jury but held up the order when the mayoral candidate's lawyer said he would appeal to block disclosure.

An explosion demolished an Irish Republican Army meeting hall in Belfast today, the army said. It also reported that soldiers had defused two bombs in taverns in Roman Catholic areas of the border town of Strabane in a renewal of strife that has claimed the lives of three British soldiers in as many days:

" Bird Lives!" is the first full-scale biography of the jazz musician Charlie Parker to appear in the 18 years since his death. It has already received much praise. The author, Ross Russell, is a jazz critic, magazine writer, novelist and former record producer who teaches jazz at the university of California at San Diego.

The New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, an influential Jewish congregational group, has rejected President Nixon's appeal to use "quiet diplomacy concerning the applications of Jews in the Soviet Union for exit visas.
A state court jury convicted nine Black Muslims today of inciting to riot in connection with a January, 1972, shooting confrontation in which five persons were killed.
Agriculture Department statistics, on soybeans inspected for export last week, disclose the first shipment to China.

A corporate realignment at the Control Data Corporation has created three functional subsidiaries, each headed by a president. The subsidiaries' presidents, the head of Control Data's Commercial Credit Company and three senior vice presidents have been named to a newly established management committee, which will have operating responsibility for the computer corporation.

To the Editor: While the recent boycott has not' had its desired effect in reducing meat prices, I believe the boycott is of monumental importance in indicating the willingness of a mass segment of Americans to self-discipline themselves regarding a growing menace-inflationwhich threatens to undermine our country.
A 53-year-old Spring Valley lawyer pleaded not guilty today to a charge of having lied to a grand jury investigating official corruption and organized crime in Rockland County.
Henry A. Kissinger will fly to Moscow this week for talks with Leonid I. Biezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, on plans for Mr. Brezhnev's expected visit to the United States late in June.

The $445.6-million suit brought by Life-Time Industries Inc., against Winnebago Industries, Inc., in 1970 has been settled for $4-million, the amount of the judgment previously rendered against the company, John K. Hanson, chairman of Winnebago, announced yesterday.

Shareholders of the Marinduque Mining and Industrial Corporation, meeting yesterday in Manila, the Philippines, approved a six-for-one split of the capital stock and a classification of this stock into Class A and Class B shares.

Alice Rice Cook, educator and management consultant, who directed the Human Relations Centers at the New School for Social Research from 1951 to 1966 and at City College from 1951 to 1957, died yesterday at her home, 220 Madison Avenue. She was 73 years old.

Following is the text of a State Department memorandum presented to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today by Secretary of State William P. Rogers, setting forth the basis of Presidential authority to continue bombing in Cambodia:

Following are excerpts from the proceedings yesterday in the Biaggi case. The partici pants were United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr.; Mr. Biaggi's lawyer, Arthur H. Christy, and the Court Judge Edmund L. Palmieri.

Into a job made vacant by scandal and into the conservative-oriented power core of the White House' comes Leonard Garment, an anxiously brilliant, iconoclastic liberal for whom variety has always been not just the spice but the absolute joy of life.
Although both dealt with charges of scandal, President Nixon's Watergate speech tonight bore more contrasts than similarities to his famous checkers speech of Sept, 23. 1952.

CHATILLON - SUR- SEINE, France - This little northern Burgundy town on the banks of what the guidebook calls "the Young Seine" is reasonably typical of modern France - some picturesque but crumbling stone houses in the old, poor quarters, a lot of concrete and glass boxes with full conveniences spreading out around them, and signs pointing the way to the superhighwav.
An international organization charged here yesterday that the use of torture by governments against political prisoners was growing and had reached "epidemic" proportions.

Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri angrily removed yesterday the mask that Representative Mario Biaggi has donned so cynically to keep the public from knowing whether he did or did not refuse to answer questions put to him by a recent grand jury.

President Nixon's draft of Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson to be Attorney General, while sending a shock wave of surprise through the top ranks of the Pentagon, was not expected to disrupt the management of a defense program that has a momentum of its own.
Protesting the state's failure to ratify a new contract, Essex County's 1,200 welfare workers stayed off the job yesterday, shutting down six of eight field offices serving 45,000 welfare clients.

" The war has come home," said Joe Garcia of Seattle, a member of the steering committee of the National Planning Conference on Emotional Needs of Vietnam Veterans. The group met here last weekend under the sponsorship of th National Council of Churches.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that 1,000 workers who walked off their jobs last Thursday had returned to work at plants at Decatur and Bloomington, Ill.

Ten members of the Gay activists Alliance-five men and five women-were taken into custody by the police late yesterday afternoon, after they had been accused of disrupting a City Council meeting by blowing tin whistles and shouting "bigots" and "justtice."

Ever-increasing numbers of recaptured young bluefin tuna originally tagged in the northwestern Atlantic indicate that this age group of the species is being overfished by commercial interests, says Frank J. Mather 3d, a scientist at the Woods Hole (Mass.) Oceanographic Institute.

WHO WILL BE ELECTED -- Nine-member boards for each of the 32 community school districts in the city. The 288 members chosen from among the 834 candidates will serve two-year terms, without salary, starting July 1. VOTING HOURS -- Polls will be open today from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.
" The 51st State," the local nightly news and public-affairs program on public television that had been threatened with cancellation, will definitely return in the fall, it was learned yesterday.

Following is a transcript of President Nixon's broadcast address in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times: Good evening. I want to talk to you tonight from my heart on a subject of deep concern to every American.
The acting District Attorney of Queens, Frederick J. Ludwig, reversed his position yesterday and said he would not seek to reduce the murder charge against Police Officer Thomas J. Shea.
Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, who is promoting improved relations with the United States, was awarded the Lenin Peace Prize today.

Following are the texts of a statement by President Nixon today announcing staff resignations and other changes and of letters of resignation to the President from H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, White House aides, and Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst:

The Foreign Minister of Southern Yemen and 24 of his country's diplomats died in an air crash here today. An official announcement said that those killed along with Foreign Minister Mohammed Saleh Aulaqi included the Southern Yemeni ambassadors to Britain, the Soviet Union, Iraq, Somali and Lebanon.
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson and her associates on the Town Lake Beautification Committee
The Finance houses Association said today that it had cut its base leading rate for May to 10 1/2 per cent from the record 11 per cent set in April.
Two correspondents for Newsweek and a French woman, arrested when they returned from a stay of 11 days in Vietcong territory, were brought back to Saigon and released from Government custody tonight.
Senior officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation urged President Nixon unanimously today to appoint a man from the bureau's ranks to be permanent new director of the FBI.

Charges and countercharges marked the last day of campaigning yesterday as voters prepared to go to the polls to elect members of their community school boards. While the controversy over candidates persisted in several of the city's 32 school districts, a challenge was raised to the method of safeguarding ballot boxes at polling places in public schools.
Earnings for the first quarter of this year continued to make pleasant reading, with most companies posting large gains over last year's period and records in a number of cases.

Kenneth Gartner took a musically sound approach to the piano works on his Town Hall recital program Sunday afternoon. His playing was uncluttered with extraneous detail, yet always solidly proportioned and usually alive to the essential character of each piece.

Representative Mario Biaggi's quest for the Democratic Mayoral nomination was thrown into turmoil yesterday as he dismissed City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. as his campaign manager just as the Queens Democrat was preparing to quit because Mr. Biaggi had not agreed to full disclosure of his grand jury testimony.
American and North Vietnamese delegates today concluded three sessions of talks to "prepare a review" of the Indochina ceasefire.

Diplomatic sources report that ground equipment has been installed at some Egyptian air bases for French-built fighterbombers from Libya and British-built planes from other Arab countries, and that it has been tested by the aircraft during brief visits.
At the age of 22, Alan Marcus had struck it rich as owner and president of a Texas dress company dedicated, to putting "Marcus Originals" on the backs of young women.

Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen labeled as "spurious" today an article in The New York Times yesterday that quoted Government sources as saying that he and Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst had refused to continue electronic surveillance of West Coast Mafia figures involved with the teamsters' union.
A window washer, a delivery man and assorted New Yorkers stopped and stared at Arnold Constable's Fifth Avenue window yesterday. A group of out-of-towners, cameras at the ready, snapped pictures.

PREMIERE Karl Weigl was a Viennese composer, teacher, associate of 'Mahler and refugee from Hitler, who pied here in 1949. In his Austrian years, he,wrote the score for an opera, "The Pied Piper," with. libretto by Helene Scheu-Riesz and Rudolf S. Hoffman. It has never been done here, until this Week.

Investigators for the State Public Service Commission charged in a report yesterday that the New York Telephone Company was requiring customers to pay "unfair," "excessive" and "illegal" deposits for telephone installations.

For the third time in four years, the New York Knicks and the Los Angeles Lakers will meet at the summit of the basketball world, starting a four-of-seven game series for the National Basketball Association championship at the Forum here tomorrow night.
The Food and Drug Administration joined the Justice Department's Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs today in recommending tighter controls over nine barbiturate drug products.

The politics of this lovely New England state, long a source of puzzlement and amusement to outsiders, has taken a bizarre new twist in recent weeks with a series of exposures and controversies that local wags have dubbed Watergate North.

President Nixon told the nation tonight that he accepted the responsibility for what happened in the Watergate case even though he had had no knowledge of political espionage or attempts to cover it up.
The Civil Aeronautics Board approved international airline agreements today that increase a number of fares and cargo rates across the Pacific and to the Caribbean and South America.
If new music is not as new as newer music, then there was better new music than newer music at the New and Newer Music concert Sunday afternoon at Tully Hall.

A surge of buying moved into the market yesterday morning shortly after reports circulated that several highlevel figures in the Nixon Administration were resigning in connection with the Watergate affair.

The General Electric Company, denying widespread newspaper reports, said yesterday that it had not discussed any "across-the-board link or partnership" with Rolls-Royce, Ltd., the British concern. However, G.E.'s spokesman acknowledged that the two companies are working together on several engine programs.
Stockholders of the International Business Machines Corporation approved a 5-for-4 stock split at the annual meeting here today after Frank T. Cary chairman, voiced optimism for 1973 business.
The Nixon Administration proposed today changes in the tax laws and tax forms that would make it easier for millions of individuals to figure out their Federal income taxes.

The strike of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen against PATH, the Port Authority Trans-Hudson commuter railroad, entered its second month today with the deadlock over wage increases and the length of a new contract still unresolved.
The GAF Corporation filed an antitrust suit against the Eastman Kodak Company yesterday, asking that the photographic and chemical concern be divided into 10 separate businesses.

The Assembly today passed and sent to the Senate a bill that would speed the destruction of seized narcotics to avert situations such as have occurred in New York City, where 398 pounds of drugs with a street-sale value of $73-million have been stolen from the Police Department.
Steel production in the week ended April 28 fell for the second consecutive week, accrding to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

With the reluctant support of the Administration, both houses of Congress approved today, and President Nixon signed, a compromise bill extending for another year the President's authority to regulate wages and prices.
The nation's first program of mass medical tests for high blood pressure -- often called the nation's No. 1 killer -- has found more than onethird of those tested suffering from the disease.

A large-scale Soviet industrial exhibition designed to promote trade with-the West got off to a subdued start here today-its first in West Berlin. In a last-minute compromise bridging conflicting views on West Berlin's links with the West German Republic, the Mayor of West Berlin, the Soviet Ambassador to East Berlin, and a high-ranking West German official attended.
Today marks the beginning of the United Fund of Greater New York's fifth annual UNITED FUND campaign to

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner denied yesterday in State Supreme Court that his recent abortive mayoral candidacy had been part of a Liberal party scheme to have him stand in for Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal.
Mayor Lindsay, his wife and several aides will leave next Wednesday, on a seven-day visit to the Soviet Union for a discussion of public administration and urban problems.

Fred Astaire--or "the greatest dancer in the world," as George Balanchine has called him-came back to town last night. In a special gala it Philharmonic Hall, the Film Society of Lincoln Center saluted him through the medium that cartried him to international stardom.
The Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government released 322 South Vietnamese civilians yesterday, Saigon high command sources reported today.
Robert W. Fri took office today as acting administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency upon the departure of William D. Ruckelshaus to head the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Vermont's ,pollution suit against the International Paper Company and the State of New York was bolstered during the weekend by one of the people who control the state's pursestrings.

The recent decision of the Ford Foundation to continue spending one-quarter of its budget-$50 million annually--to help developing nations is an encouraging reaffirnation of American idealism and, humanitarian concern on the part of a private institution at a time when Congress seems to be turning the other way.
The Labor Department issued emergency rules today to protect farm workers from the toxic effects of pesticides, which kill or sicken thousands of workers each year.
While enjoying a full day in first place in the National League's East Division, the New York Mets played an exhibition game here and made some medical decisions.

Until now, "Teapot Dome" has been the phrase most often used to define the extent of Executive-Branch scadal. But the taint of impropriety -- of money and influence misused, of public trust betrayed for private advantage--has soiled many other Administrations of both parties over the years.
Kazuo Uehara, a 23-year-old Japanese composer working at the Manhattan School of Music's Electronic Laboratory, offered a sensitive nonconcert Sunday night at the Kitchen, 240 Mercer Street.

A fire broke out before noon yesterday on the 13th floor of the new Police Headquarters, which is still under construction, trapping two workmen inside an office as flames raced through the hall outside.

Basketball, hockey and baseball players were rewarded with new contracts and a bonus yesterday. Bob Lantier of the Detroit Pistons and John Bucyk, the elder statesman of the Boston Bruins, received new contracts and Steve Busby, the Kansas City Royals' rookie pitcher, was promised a bonus for his no-hitter last Friday against the Detroit Tigers.
William E. Caldwell, president of the St. Regis Paper Company for the last two years, died yesterday. He was 56 years old and lived at 38 Turtle Back Road.

Putting thousands or welfare recipients to work at tasks ordinarily done by Civil Service employes is not unconstitutional and cannot be called peonage, Justice Samuel J. Silverman ruled yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
Thousands of Catholic parochial school students jammed into Trenton today to protest a Federal court decision declaring the state's program of aid to private schools unconstitutional.

Putting thousands of welfare recipients to work at tasks ordinarily done by Civil Service employes is not unconstitutional and cannot be called peonage, Justice Samuel J. Silyerman ruled yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
Offers of money, adoption, mothering and clothes have poured into St. Vincent's Hospital for Kim Cruz, the 3month-old baby who was admitted there on Saturday in critical condition after being beaten.

The special counsel for the State Commission of Investigation charged today that there was widespread collusion among physicians, lawyers and compensation judges settling claims for injuries or disabilities under New Jersey's Workmen's Compensation system.

The Exxon Corporation has made a matching grant of $1million, to be added to the same sum allocated by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, to WNET/Channel 13 for production of a major drama series for the country's public television stations.

N. Baxter Jackson, who retired in 1956 as chairman of the board of Chemical Bank but a continued as a director until 1968, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 82, and he lived at 19 East 72d Street.

Aerial photographs of the results, of the heavy United States bombing of Hanoi last December show damage to military targets, to a hospital near a military airfield and to a commercial and residential area close to the main railroad station and yards.
Details of a planned community of $100,000 homes that would provide residents with inducements not to own an automobile were announced today.
Jeb S. Magruder's lawyer said to day that his client, a former White House aide and Nixon official, had appeared before a Federal grand jury investigating the Watergate scandal.
Workers in wholesale fabric establishments struck 400 shops in New York and New Jersey yesterday after rejecting contract proposals made by two textile employer associations.
Richard G. Kleindienst, who resigned yesterday as Attorney General, said today that a national wave of lawlessness has been broken during the Nixon Administration.
Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Rich. ardson was nominated formally today as Attorney General while moving into over-all control of the Justice Department's investigation of the Watergate scandal.

Premier Fidel Castro said tonight that Cuba was willing to join an organization of Western Hemisphere nations that excluded the United States. In a May Day speech in Havana, monitored here on the Havana radio, Mr. Castro repeated his view that Cuba would never return to the Organization of American States as it is now constituted.
It was a big day yesterday for Dr. Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel Prize-winning economist and professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The 57-year-old
Amtrak, the National Railroad Passengers Corporation, celebrated its second anniversary today with a birthday statement saying that rail travel was regaining public favor.

Tickets for the triple-header world championship of Roller Derby for the Gold Cup at Shea Stadium on Saturday, May 26, 'will be available through all Ticketron outlets and the Shea Stadium box office.
Bobby Murcer's fourth home run of the season and Sparky Lyle's first save helped the New York Yankees defeat the Kansas Royals, 6-1, last night at Yankee Stadium.

Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein disclosed today that he would seek to acquire 9,000 acres of prime Suffolk farmland at a cost of $45-million over the next three years in his program to prevent the destruction of the agricultural industry on Long Island.

Thousands of carpenters, supported by other craftsmen, struck construction sites throughout New Jersey's 21 counties yesterday, an action that could shut down major projects in the state by the end of the week.
Incumbents won easily in most suburban school-board elections held yesterday in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties.
E Systems, Inc., said yesterday that it had a contract from GTE International Systems Corporation of Waltham, Mass., to provide a satellite communications antenna to be built in China near Peking.

Although mathematics and bridge have some features in common, notably the need for their practitioners to have analytical ability, few academic mathematicians reach the highest ranks as card-players.

In the wake of controversy over the Metropolitan Museum of Art's sale of 345 Roman gold coins last year at auction and the purchase of the $1-million Euphronios krater Dietrich von Bothmer, the Metropolitan's curator of Greek art, has resigned from the New York chapter of the Archeological Institute of America, it was learned yesterday.

A fire broke out before noon yesterday on the 13th, floor of the new Police Headquarters, which is still under construction, trapping two workmen inside an office as flames raced through the hall outside.
A new prepaid group health insurance plan that will offer physician house calls and psychiatric care, in addition to the standard health services, will open in downtown Brooklyn this fall.
Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, apologized to The 'Washington Post today for his earlier criticisms of the newspaper's coverage of the Watergate case.
Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, today reaffirmed the Kremlin's desire for further improvement in Soviet-American relations.

Two years ago the Blassport collection by Bill Blass was a neat assemblage of classic jackets, sweaters, pants - and all that. Now it's fur-bearing sweaters, strapless evening dresses, fox boas-just about everything.

Conservative party leaders declared yesterday that they would seek to deprive Representative Mario Biaggi of the Conservative mayoral designation either through the courts or the Legislature "if it is determined that he has lied to us."

Before the start of the 1973 major league baseball season, Henry Aaron of the Atlanta Braves said he hoped he would remain healthy the next two years so that he might have a better chance to break Babe Ruth's homerun mark of 714.
President Nixon intends to issue an economic policy statement tomorrow that is expected to include selective tightening of his wage-price stabilization program.

One of the most conspicuous developments at antiques shows in the last several years has been the growing interest in paintings, a trend amply reflected in the fair that opened here yesterday at the Westchester County Center off the Bronx River Parkway.

Basketball, hockey and baseball players were rewarded with new contracts and a bonus yesterday. Bob Lantier of the Detroit Pistons. and John Bucyk, the elder statesman of the Boston Bruins, received new contracts and Steve Busby, the Kansas City Royals'rookie pitcher, was promised a bonus for his no-hitter last Friday against the 'Detroit Tigers.

President Nixon today asked Congress to authorize $2.9-billion in foreign economic and military aid in the fiscal year beginning July 1, including $632-million for rebuilding all countries of Indochina except North Vietnam.

Going with the lowest bidder is an unusual way to select an advertising agency. But, according to more than one source, that is how the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company consolidated its three agencies and in the process dumped Gardner Advertising, which had served it for more than 30 years.

Joseph Welsaglass, president of the Weissglass Gold Seal Dairy Corporation on Staten Island, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 8 Buttonwood Road, in the Dongan Hills area of Staen Island.

Frederick Sessions Beebe, chairman of the board of the Washington Post Company and overseer of a communications concern that includes The Washington Post, Newsweek magazine, a chain of radio and television stations and a partial interest- in The International Herald Tribune, died yesterday of cancer 'at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center.

Joseph Monty, the former chief rackets investigator in the Queens District Attorney's office, asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to quash a subpoena requiring him to testify in public before the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.
WASHINGTON--The stunningg succession with which Watergate events bombarded this city heightened some of its characteristic reactions to upheaval.

PARIS--An aspect of the Watergate mess more considered abroad than in the United States was summarized in The London Observer, which editorialized: "The way this scandal is now being relentlessly exposed should ... strengthen America's claim to be the most open society: political skulduggery has happened in many countries but in few could it have been exposed as publicly as now in the U.S."
The House striking back at President Nixon's widespread Impoundment of appropriated funds, voted today to require Senate confirmation of his top White House budget officials.

Governor Rockefeller has picked Michael F. Amstrong, the chief counsel of the Knapp Commission, as the likely replacement for Thomas J. Mackell of Queens, according to! sources in New York and Albany.

Three gunmen dressed in work clothes escaped with an estimated total of $500,000 in jewels in a robbery at the AirIndia cargo terminal at Kennedy International Airport Monday night, the police reported yesterday.
A neck, a head and a nose were all that separated. the first four horses at the wire yesterday in the Relic, the featured allowance race at Aqueduct.
Compagnie de Saint-GobainPont-a-Mousson announced yesterday that it planned to make a cash tender offer for common stock and Series A convertible preferred stock of the Certain-Teed Corporation.

PITTSBURGH -- In addressing the Massachusetts Legislature in July, 1951, after his return -from the Far East, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur drew a distinction, as he then seemed to view it, between the loyalty and obedience owed by a soldier to his Commander in Chief and the loyalty owed "to country and Constitution."

A sharp decline in the stock market was arrested yesterday when the White House announced that President Nixon would make a statement today on the economy following a meeting with his economic advisers.

Voters, candidates and poll inspectors complained of administrative confusion and charged some deliberate irregularities at scattered polling places throughout the city yesterday during the light voting for the city's 32 community school boards.

After one of the bitterest and most protracted sessions in the history of the Common Market, agriculture ministers of the nine member states agreed today on a new level of farm prices for the coming 12 months and instituted a 'radical new policy of consumer subsidies to bring down the cost of butter.
Establishment of a $100,000 scientific research prize, one of the largest medical awards ever offered in American history, was announced today by the National Multiple Sclerosis Socity.

Dr. Bruce Frome, the Los Angeles physician who was to provide medical services to teamsters union members under a prepaid health plan, said today that six weeks ago the Federal Bureau of Investigation told him the persons who presented the plan to the union on his behalf were members of the Mafia.

Lawrence C. Baker, California's deputy insurance commissioner, charged today that the conduct of the First National City Bank indicated that the bank had "a very friendly relationship with the principal perpetrators of the fraud" in the Equity Funding Corporation of America scandal.

Charlotte Ford, who has spent most of her adult life as one of the world's most eligible women, took herself out of the ranking last night. the 32-year-old elder daughter of Henry Ford 2d, board chairman and chief executive officer of the Ford Motor Company, was married in a
Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation moved into position today to guard the files of three senior Presidential assistants who are leaving because of the Watergate case.
Congress, prodded by Republican members, pressed today for the appointment of an independent prosecutor to take charge of the Nixon Administration's Watergate investigation.

A 65-year-old night watchman struck a pistol-wielding robber on the head with his heavy watchman's clock early today, but still lost $19. Joseph Colosimo of Utica told the police here he had been making his rounds on a bridge construction project on Route 28 when he was confronted by a man carrying a gun and a rubber hose.
E. Howard Hunt Jr., convicted Watergate spy, billed the White House for a consultant's fee for the day of the break-in at the Beverly Hills, Calif., office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting has told the Federal Communications Commission that the F.C.C. lacks legal "jurisdiction over the operations and activities" of the independent corporation.
President Nguyen Van Thieu plans a "reform of the national structure" in an effort to streamline and decentralize the South Vietnamese Government, a Government spokesman said today.
A New Jersey state trooper was shot and wounded in an exchange of gunfire, early today when he stopped a car for a routine check on the New Jersey, Turnpike near here, the state police reported.

The Kremlin orchestrators of Soviet propaganda have gone to great pains to minimize the significance of these historic new shifts, and particularly to protect Leonid I. Brezhnev's public image from injury.

The RCA Corporation expects to spend a record $200-million on expansion this year, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman, said after the annual meeting in Convention Center here today.
The Connecticut Liquor Control Commission suspended today for 90 days the state liquor shipping permit of the Schenley Affiliated Brands Corporation of New York, a major liquor distiller.
The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it was suspending trading in the stock of the Investors Funding Corporation of New York for 10 days.

Dr. T. Campbell Goodwin, a pioneer in the use of a computerized "talking typewriter" to teach children who were considered hopelessly autistic, died yesterday in Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital, of which he was emeritus chief of pediatrics. He was 71 years old, and was also emeritus professor of pediatrics at Columbia University.

President Nixon's energy policies underwent strong criticism here yesterday at a conference on energy and environment in an unusual accord by environ- ti mentalists, industrialists and state and local officials.
Robert Coles, a 43-year-old Harvard psychiatrist, was awarded a $10,000 prize today "for his research into the effects of poverty and racism on the mental health of children."
The Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association signed Swen Nater of the University of California, Los Angeles, to a multiyear contract today, a spokesman for the Squires said.
The securities brokerage house of Drexel Burnham Co., Inc., has formally entered the domestic and foreign commodities business, Robert E. Linton, executive vice president, announced yesterday.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation sees no hope of any amicable settlement with the Chilean Government over expropriation of its copper mining properties in that country.
Three gunmen held gradeschool children hostage today until the police killed one gunman and the two others surrendered without harming their captives.
Manufacturers' new orders and inventories both surged in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Watergate scandal has become a crisis of Presidential authority. In his address to the nation Monday evening, President Nixon tried but failed to resolve that crisis. The whole trend of future events remains in doubt. Although he has dismissed three of his senior aides and formally accepted responsibility for whatever misdeeds may have been committed without his knowledge, Mr. Nixon basically has conceded nothing except what events have wrenched from him.
Congress, prodded by Republican members, pressed today for the appointment of an independent prosecutor to take charge of the Nixon Administration's Watergate investigation.
Governor Rockefeller presented Society of Silurians' medallions last night to 13 members of the news media honored by the association for outstanding journalistic achievement in 1972.
In response to the developing Watergate affair, Republican lawmakers in Connecticut have shelved legislation that would have eased restrictions on wiretapping.

American General Insurance Company reported its tender offer for 2.5 million of its own common shares at $19.50 (net to seller) per share was. oversubscribed and that it will acquire on a prorated basis only the .2.5 million shares sought. The company's stock was down 3/4 at 163/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

In a highly unusual labormanagement move, two teamster locals and the F. Schaefer Brewing Company announced yesterday they had signed a new three-year contract that provides for no increase in the wage rate.

The chairman of the Senate Securities subcommittee told a cross section of the securities industry today that James J. Needham no longer spoke for the New York Stock Exchange on the issues of fixed commission rates and institutional membership.

In launching the celebration of New York City's first 75 years as a consolidated unit formed through fusing its five boroughs, Mayor Lindsay has helped point the way for the 75 to come. On the eve of the official festivities, Mr. Lindsay unveiled a plan for the integration and regionalization of mass transit facilities serving the central city and its suburbs.
A fire killed five elderly persons and destroyed the 74-year-old Manhattan Hotel in this resort town early this morning.

Settecento, who competes for a New York investment banker, Martin Wygod, beat the Aisco Stable's Mr. Prospector in the Derby Trial today. The outcome was a surprise as Larry Adams rode Settecento to a 1 1/4-length triumph.

Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally will announce at a news conference in Houston tomorrow his long-expected switch from the Democratic to the Republican party.

New York has chosen an approach different from Chicago's in the use of computers to speed traffic, Transportation Administrator Constantine SidamonEristoff said yesterday, but he praised Chicago's as "a beautiful system."

Gov. George C. Wallace made a public speech tonight from a standing position for the first time since he was paralyzed from the waist down in an attempt on his life one year ago.
Declines outnumbered advances again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market. It was the seventh consecutive session that prices ended lower in both markets.

The California Legislature has started planning a celebration of the 400th anniversary of Sir Francis Drake's landing in the state. The Assembly approved creation yesterday of a joint committee on Sir Francis Drake to oversee celebrations scheduled for 1979.

The body of Frank Clearwater, one of the two Indians killed by gunfire during the siege of Wounded Knee, was taken through a police blockade this afternoon to burial place on the neighboring Rosebud Sioux Reservation.

Robert H. Finch, aformer Presidential counselor, has offered to help President Nixon reorganize the White House staff, a spokesman for Mr. Finch said today. "He's willing and anxious to do anything to help," the spokesman, Zan Thompson, said of Mr. Finch.

The Los Angeles Lakers clearly outplayed the New York Knicks for three quarters, then just did hold off a fourth-period rally for a 115-112 victory tonight, and took a 1-0 lead in the fourof-seven-game series for the championship of the National Basketball Association.

Three years after a pack of impudent colonists declared their independence of George III and thus blazed a trail that would lead to Watergate, Lord Derby and his friend Sir Charles Bumbury laid plans to run a race for 3-year-olds at Epsom Downs, a new course southwest of London. Montreal and New York were bridged today by the first international air-shuttle service, a reflection of the fastgrowing community of interests between the two cities.

Tens of thousands of workers sloshed through central Paris, today under a drenching rain in a May Day parade that was different from those that have gone on here since 1890.

The Henry R. Luce Hall of News Reporting opened today at the Smithsonian Institution, but to most of the visitors the lure appeared to be nostalgic rather than journalistic.

Tickets for. the triple-header world championship of Roller Derby for the Gold Cup at Shea Stadium on Saturday, May 26, will be available through all Ticketron outlets and the Shea Stadium box office. Reserved seats are priced at $5, $6 and $7. The Pioneers face the Jolters in the opening game, and New York Chiefs battle the Bombers in the second game. The winners will meet in the third game for the cup.

Senator Henry Bellmon, Republican of Oklahoma, said today that the Watergate disclosures showed the necessity for replacing the Electoral College system of electing Presidents with a national primary and their direct election.

The Philadelphia Phillies traded 33-year-old Deron Johnson, first baseman who has played in the majors 10 years, to the Oakland A's today for Jack Bastable, a minor league outfielder-third baseman.

Common Cause said yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi had not responded to its request for early volunteer disclosure of his campaign finances. The citizens' lobbying group said he was the only one of five mayoral candidates here to ignore its request.

Linda Costanza, clad only in a black leotard, stepped onto a belt vibrating machine at the Better Business Bureau yesterday and flipped on the switch. The belt went jiggle-jiggle-jiggle against her slender, 105-pound body.

The police charged six young beach transients with first-degree murder today in the witchcraft slaying last Friday of a 17-year-old amusement park worker.

Patty Costello of New Carrellton, Md., the 1972 woman bowler of the year, held the lead at the halfway mark of the 24-game finals in the $30,000 United States women's bowling championship last night at Garden City Bowl.

To the Editor: In his April 3 letter to The Times, A. Jarrell Raper deplored what he saw as a slowing down, a drawing back from the nation's commitment to racial integration. Citing a national leadership that appeared unwilling to sustain and continue the momentum toward a total amalgam of the races, Mr. Raper lamented the consequences which would follow an abandonment of this social experiment.

The New England Whalers scored five goals in the third period tonight to post a 7-4 victory over the Winnipeg I Jets and take a 2-0 lead in their four-of-seven-game World Hockey Association playoff final.

The Kansas City left-hander, Paul Splittorff, scattered 10 hits and the right-handed reliever, Gene Garber, came in the ninth inning to pick up his fourth save of the season as the Royals defeated the New York Yankees, 4-3, before a crowd of 7,604 at Yankee Stadium last night.

Christy walked down the steps of the United States Court House yesterday to the microphones and television cameras and reporters' questions about the latest developments in the case of his client, Mario Biaggi, a television reporter suddenly s t o o d squarely Man in front of Mr. in the Christy and asked him about News his own integrity.

Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that they expected Elliot L. Richardson to appoint a special prosecutor in the Watergate case before Mr. Richardson's nomination as Attorney General came before the committee.

Ed Wilson, a freshman who wants as much work as he can get in track and field, won the long jump and triple jump, had a pair of second place finishes and set a meet record as he led Princeton to the team title in the 11th annual New Jersey college, track and field championships today at Rider College.

Smuggling has been a style of life in Colombia for centuries and has generally been tolerated as long as it was confined to cigarettes, electrical appliances and emeralds. But now smugglers have turned to narcotics, and the country is alarmed.

With the initiative coming from the Republican side of the aisle, a new challenge is being mounted in the Senate to President Nixon's constitutional authority to continue bombing in Cambodia.

A raucous overflow crowd shouting "Smoke that Joint," disrupted the Berkeley City Council meeting last night after council members called for an investigation into the legality of the city's new marijuana ordinance.

In a decision likely to provoke angry protests from young people and some Congressmen, the Civil Aeronautics Board ordered the nation's airlines yesterday to begin phasing out domestic youth and family-fare discounts June 1. It said the discounts must be abolished by June 1, 1974.

An editor of The Record of Hackensack, two members of his family and four of their friends have been indicted by a Bergen County grand jury on charges including possession of marijuana and hashish with intent to distribute them.

President Nixon tightened the Government's regulation of price increases today. Nevertheless, he warned the American people that "price increases will probably be higher than we would like for some months."
The Health Department turned yesterday to Chubby the Hip Cherub, an animated cartoon character, as a lighthearted, attention-getting device to help combat venereal disease.
Oregonians, voting in a referendum that attracted national attention, have decided by a heavy margin to keep the local property tax as the major source of funds for their public schools.

Police Officer Thomas J. Shea was arraigned yesterday in Queens Criminal Court in the killing of 10-year-old Clifford Glover at dawn Saturday. The charge was murder despite the efforts of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to get it reduced.

All of the patients who are admitted toCalvary Hospital in the Highbridge section of the Bronx have three things in common: They are medically indigent; they have cancer; they have a life expectancy of three to six weeks.

New Hampshire's dual enrollment program of parochial school aid has been ruled unconstitutional by a threejudge Federal panel. The judges enjoined the state against spending any funds to maintain such programs in the 1973-74 school year.

Federal District Judge Charles A. Moye has approved an antidiscrimination agreement between the Government and Delta Air Lines, Inc., that could cost Delta hundreds of thousands of dollars in back pay to minority and female employes.

Investor anticipation ot action by President Nixon to tighten Phase 3 controls to stem runaway prices enabled the American Stock Exchange and-the over-the-counter market;to register their first advances yesterday in eight sessions.

A controversial black author and leader of the Malcolm X Foundation here was shot to death last night in his home in the city's Roxbury section by black gunmen brandishing pistols and automatic rifles, according to the police.

A state trooper and a former information minister for a New York faction of the Black Panthers were killed and the woman leader of the so-called Black Liberation Army was wounded and captured today in a shoot-out and chase on the New Jersey Turnpike. A second trooper also was wounded.
Organizers of a $1,000-a plate Republican Congressional fund-raising affair say the Secret Service has restricted news coverage to reporters with White House credentials.
BITUSH reserves rose $82-milion to $6.11-billion in April, the Treasury reported today. This was after receipts of $75-million from publicsector foreign currency borrowing.

A rematch between Ken Norton and Muhammad Ali will be announced in New York tomorrow, a local promoter said today. C. E. (Lee) Fruin made the statement shortly after a Federal court had refused to restrain him from arranging the heavyweight fight.

Chrysler Corporation recalled today 50,717 Dodge compact trucks produced in the 1971 model year because of a steering defect that in one case resulted in an accident traced to the loss of vehicle control.
J. Edward Crabiel, the Senate minority leader, pulled out of the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor today.

After breaking attendance records at the National Galery in Washington, a collection of 41 impressionist and postimpressionist paintings from the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad and the Pushkin Museum In Moscow came to New York this week in heavily guarded trucks and went on display last night in a Special benefit exhibition at the Knoedler Gallery.

Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., was upset in Federation Cup tennis competition today, but the United States pulled out a 2-1 victory over South Korea to move into the quarterfinals against West Germany.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation ignored today the first anniversary bf the death of J. Edgar Hoover, but Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, took the occasion to urge President Nixon to name a permanent successor to the late director of the bureau.

American Export Industries, a financially troubled shipping and trucking concern, has filed a recapitalization plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it described as an alternative to bankruptcy.

It is more than two years since Martha Graham created a new work, but for her company's season at the Alvin Theater she is scheduled to offer two world premieres. The first, "Mendicants of Evening," made its bow last night.

The Manhattan offices of two physicians who treated former President John F. Kennedy were burglarized shortly before the 1960 Democratic National Convention, Dr. Eugene J. Cohen, one of the two physicians, said last night.

Republicans and Justice Department officials defended the Nixon Administration's proposed new criminal code today as Congress began grappling with the slippery issue of government control of information that touches on national security.

Ron Behagen and Bobby Jones sparked an explosive offense that carried the United States national basketball team to an 83-67 victory over the Soviet Union tonight, giving the Americans a 2-1 lead in the series.

The Center on Corporate Responsibility, Inc., an organization that does research and litigation on public issues involving business, filed a lawsuit today aimed at forcing the Internal Revenue Service to act on its application for tax-exempt status.

WASHINGTON-The Nixon Administration has embarked on a new propaganda campaign designed to hide the facts of soaring inflation, continued high unemployment, mounting budget deficits and a shocking drop in public confidence.
Libya has refused to allow an American diplomat to enter because his passport was not in the Arabic language, the State Department said today.

Soviet authorities have increased pressures on the civil-rights advocate Andrei D. Sakharov by delivering to him a letter purportedly from Pyotr I. Yakir, a jailed dissident leader, asserting that dissident activities are illegal and play into the hands of Western propagandists.

Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the former Attorney General, is scheduled to give a deposition here today in a civil damage suit by the Democratic National Committee arising from the bugging of the party's Watergate headquarters last June.

Joanne Chesimard, who was wounded and captured after a shoot-out on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday, has been described by the police here as a central figure in an amalgam of black militants who have been linked to the murders and attempted murders of policemen.

Asger Jorn, painter and writer, died during the night in a hospital in Aarhus. He was 59 years old. Mr. Jorn was a founder of the Cobra group of French, Dutch, Belgian and Danish arttists. The Museum-of Modern Art in New York has a number of his works.

Mrs. Margaret Court had a head cold, but it was Francoise Durr and Lesley Hunt who felt sicker after opening-round matches in the $100,000 Family Circle Cup women's tennis tournament today.
Forty fraternity men were questioned today about the rape and slaying of a teen-ager whose body was found in an orchard after an all-night party.
At least a dozen crew members of B-52 bombers used in raids in Cambodia have written members of Congress protesting against the bombing, it was disclosed today.

Russell Means, a leader of the American Indian Movement, and four others affiliated with the organization were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of conspiring to illegally transport arms to Wounded Knee, S.D., and to cross state lines with intent to incite a riot.

The city is making big strides in filling its multitude of potholes and collecting fees for parking violations, according to a third productivity report made public yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton.

The lines of visitors waiting to tour the White House were as long as usual for a balmy May morning. Checking their cameras and adjusting their sunglasses, schoolchildren, retirees and middle aged vacationers filed steadily through the President's residence and symbol of government.

An assistant staff accountant of The New York Times and two other men were arrested yesterday in the Manhattan District Attorney's office on charges of second-degree grand larceny in the alleged theft of more than $25,000 from The Times.

The cost of sending a son or daughter to college will rise sharply again next fall, as it has every year for the last decade, and campus administrators are warning parents and students to expect the price of higher education to continue climbing in the years ahead.
The Soviet Union has demonstrated a growing interest in entering the world uranium market to help meet an expected shortage of nuclear-fuel supplies starting in the late nineteen-seventies.

David Young, one of the men in charge of the Presidential investigation into the Pentagon papers case, has resigned from the staff of the National Security Council, a White House spokesman said today.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Novel-Prize-winning author, has married Natalya Svetlova, who bore him two of his sons during the threeand-a-half years he was separated from his first wife. Unofficial sources said the 55-year-old writer and the 33-year-old mathematician were married about three weeks ago.
The strongest rally in three weeks lifted the stock market out of the doldrums yesterday, as Wall Street awaited President Nixon's statement on economic policy.

Dr. Max Wolff, professor of educational sociology at Long Island University and a sponsor of the educational park concept, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 179 Woodlawn Ave, New Rochelle, N. Y. Dr. Wolff was stricken at 82d Street and Broadway as he drove from the university in Brooklyn to his home.
Several million-dollar-plus accounts have found new homes this week. They are always easier to place than orphans.
Foreign Minister Michel Jobert raised the possibility today that Libyan jets might have been in Egypt, as Israel has claimed, but said Libya had not violated the terms of her arms deal with France.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has contributed more than $150,000 to a tax-exempt foundation established by former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens, according to sources within the company, and public hearings on the matter are to begin today.
The House Banking Committee today approved legislation to make formal the devaluation of the dollar, by about 10 per cent against the price of gold, which took effect in mid-February.

Torrential new rains are heightening the damage caused in the Midwest by the rampaging Mississippi and its tributaries. In a normal March and April, the Mississippi Valley gets eight to nine inches of rain; this year much of the area got fifteen to twenty inches while in the north early melting snows were making their own substantial contribution to the floods that threaten to drown mid-America.
The American Motors Corporation today reported net earnings of $49.2-million in the JanuaryMarch period compared with $6.3-million in the same period a year ago.

Dr. Hector J. Campora, Presidentelect of Argentina, returned here from Spain today to confer with military leaders in the wake of a series of Troskyite guerrilla attacks that have brought most of the country under martial law.

The current shortage of gasoline could force a cut-off of bulk sales to New York's taxi fleets and force 800 or more cabs off the city's streets next month, a spokesman for the taxi industry said yesterday.

The General Dynamics Corporation indicated that it expected improvements in sales and earnings in 1973. The Phelps Dodge Corporation increased its quarterly dividend, and the Control Data Corporation discussed the "preliminary" talks it has been holding with the Soviet Union on cooperative programs.
Profit taking in cattle, hog, soybean and grain futures resulted in mostly lower prices yesterday in the Chicago trading pits. The prices had been rising for some time previously.
Dr. Joseph A. Freiberg, a former president of the American Orthopedic Association and a former vice president of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, died here yesterday. He was 74 years old.

The straight-marked furrows in the vegetable garden behind a cluster of houses on Marlboro Road here today awaited the young plants that were to have been placed there. But the man who was to 'plant them could not do so because he was dead.
Samuel R. Pierce Jr., general counsel to the Treasury Department and the Administration's topranking black official, has resigned, it was announced today.

Darby Dan's Java Moon, who got to the races only once last year-an outing in late November in which she finished second-and who triumphed in her three previous races this season, beat 10 much more experienced 3-year-old fillies in yesterday's 24th running of the Comely at Aqueduct.
If Phnom Penh is under siege, as a number of recent headlines have suggested, then it is surely among the most bizarre military sieges in history.

A former White House publicity aide, who until recently was director of administration for President Nixon's re-election campaign committee, has been hired as a temporary management consultant by the Agriculture department, officials confirmed today.
Two Roman Catholic churches and a school were blasted by explosives and a man was found dead of gunshot wounds today amid a fresh upsurge of violence in Northern Ireland.

Two four-story, century-old tenement' buildings being renovated by a pentecostal church on the Lower East Side collapsed yesterday morning, injuring 10 workmen, none seriously.

The marriage of Miss Louise Appleby, daughter of Dr. Basil Appleby and Mrs. Lila Steele of London, to Roger M. Deitz, a special counsel with the Securities and Exchange Commission, took place here yesterday morning.

Arthur Milliken, retired headmaster of the Westminster School at Simsbury, Conn., died yesterday at the New England Baptist Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Hyannisport and Sea Island, Ga.
Bruce Jay Friedman's "Steambath" had a respectable run at an Off Broadway theater a couple of years ago.

Robert S. Gerstell, retired chairman of the Alpha Portland Cement Company died here yesterday. He was 79 years old. Mr. Gerstell graduated from Princeton University in 1917. After a year in the Army in World War I he joined Alpha, which was founded by his father, and rose to president in 1957 and chairman in 1963.

Since walls are rapidly becoming the background for a great many art and decorative media other than painting these days, it seems appropriate that a gallery has opened where what hangs on the wall is done, not with a brush, but with needle or loom.

Opposition to a proposed $200-million convention center in the Clinton Area of the WestSide was reaffirmed last night by Community Planning Board 4. North Vietnam's Defense Minister, Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, has called for the urgent buildup and modernization of Hanoi's armed forces, the North Vietnam press agency reported today.

A Federal District Court judge ruled here today that all of the plants of the United States Steel Company in Alabama must end their racially separated seniority systems.

State Insurance Commissioner Richard C. McDonough proposed regulations to require insurance companies to plain to motorists how their charges were figured. A workmen's compensation judge was accused before the State Commission of Investigation today of accepting theater tickets and cash from a North Jersey physician who. allegedly received illegally excessive fees after appearances in the judge's court on behalf of injured clients.

Mrs. Lucille Wang Liu, widow of Dr. J. Heng Liu, who was China's Minister of Health and later president of the Red Cross Society and vice president of the American Bureau for Medical Aid to China, died here yesterday. She was 81 years old.

The draw for the 99th Kentucky Derby will take place tomorrow, and it is expected that 15 names will be submitted for the 1 1/4-mile glamour event, on payment of $2,500 each.

An editor of The Record of Hackensack, two members of his family and several of their friends have been indicted by a Bergen County grand jury on charges including possession of marijuana and hashish with intent to distribute them.
An inventory of 55,000 handguns at the Police Department's Property Clerk Division has shown that 13 weapons "could not be located and must be considered missing."
Another cadet has been declared in violation of the West Point honor code in the continuing investigation of a cheating scandal that has implicated 16 so far.

The judge in the Pentagon papers trial confirmed today that twice during this trial he met directly with John D. Ehrlichman to discuss the possibility of becoming director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

President Nixon nominated today former Repretentative Howard H. Callaway, an unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor of Georgia in 1966, to be Secretary of the Army.

The American Stock Exchange took sharp exception yesterday to key provisions of a bill introduced in Congress for restructuring the securities industry. It called for a reshaping of the proposed legislation.

Vice President Agnew, acknowledging that past criticism of the press was excessively abrasive, said tonight that the Nixon Administration would like to begin talks with the media to reduce the "unfortunate hostility."
In a secluded house on the fringe of Bombay, an intense, bespectacled cartoonist has founded a militant party whose impact has jolted the Government and caused disquiet among moderates.

Henry A. Kissinger met with three prominent Jewish leaders at the White House last night to discuss in detail the conditions of Jews in the Soviet Union. Mr. Kissinger leaves tomorrow for a visit to Moscow.
The bond market continued to tread lightly yesterday as many investors awaited the Administration's statement on economic controls and the outcome of the Treasury's auction of 25-year bonds.

Students demonstrating against the threatened. end of free tuition in the City University and against state-mandated budget cuts kept most of City College administrative personnel from entering their offices yesterday.

American Phantom jets today bombed Communist positions beyond the Mekong River three miles east of Phnom Penh.

Lawyers representing candidates from several community school districts started legal action yesterday against the Board of Elections in an effort to nullify the results of the Tuesday elections in the city's 32 community school districts.

Lawyers who specialize in class-action litigation said a ruling by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals here Tuesday could have a sharp effect on consumer suits - possibly ending them.

An offering of 650,000 shares of beneficial interest of Mortgage Investors of Washington at $15 a share was made yesterday by Goldman, Sachs; Loeb Rhoades; and Johnston, Lemon Co., joint managers of the underwriting group. The real estate investment trust's shares, traded over-thecounter, closed at 14 7/8 bid, 15 1/4 asked, down 1/8.
An antipoverty agency in Jackson, Miss., asked President Nixon today to release a Federal grant that it said was being unaccountably held up by one of the President's appointees.

The National Orchestral Association has been having a reunion with some of its alumni this season, and on Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall, it was the turn of Charles Blackman, a former assistant conductor of this training ensemble.

Having settled very little in last night's game, which the Los Angeles Lakers won, 115-112, the New York Knicks and Lakers will go at each other again tomorrow night in the second game of the four-of-seven-game series for the National Basketball Association championship.
A Roman Catholic priest charged yesterday that the police had ignored assaults by Hasidic Jews against Hispanics in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

The Senate voted today to authorize $840-million in Federal aid to the arts and humanities during the next three years. The bill cleared the Senate by a vote of 76 to 14 after supporters had defeated an attempt by Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, to trim the total authorization by about half.

President Nixon plans to expand his European trip this fall in quest of "a new Atlantic charter" to include meetings with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Common Market-possibly at the summit level-at their headquarters in Brussels.
Senator George McGovern accused President Nixon today of implying that the Watergate case was typical of American politics and called it the worst campaign scandal in modern times.

Andy Dinko, a 48-year-old seaman who was shot in the right arm in Queens on Tuesday night, said yesterday that he had been threatened earlier and told to drop his campaign for the presidency of the National Maritime Union.

As the city celebrates its 75th anniversary, one key to its future health will be decent housing for its people, The vote of the City Council's housing committee to kill the computerized formula for establishing fair rents in 1.2 million rent-controlled apartments represents a demagogic step toward wrecking an important preservative of the housing the city now has.

At the age of 26, Art Carrington has given up his job as a high school teacher and is making his bid to get to the top in tennis. Tomorrow the muscular 6-footer leaves for England to play in tournaments leading up to the Wimbledon championship. He may not make the draw for Wimbledon, but he feels he has a chance and "everything in me tells me to take it."

Lord Clark of Saltwood, better known to his American audience as Kenneth Clark of "Civilisation," his book and television series outlining the history of art, is giving the finest volumes in his private library to an American institution as "a small-a very small-sign of recognition of what we owe to the United States."

The United Transportation Union signed yesterday thetentative contract agreement reached in March between the nation's railroads and 15 railway workers' unions.

The South Vietnamese and Japanese Governments began investigations today into the possibility that United States defoliants used in the Vietnam war are still contaminating marine life in Vietnamese waters.

Nelson T. Evans, a suspended narcotics detective here, was sentenced today to six years in federal prison for conspiracy and for distributing heroin that disappeared from the Monroe County laboratory.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make a list available this, week.

Henry A. Kissinger insisted today that "there is an agreement" for him to meet with Le Duc Tho, Hanoi's chief negotiator, in Paris later this month, but that the two sides had not yet agreed on when to announce it.

The United States basketball team, in dire need of rebounders and brute strength for its series with the Soviet Union, yesterday called on two college strongmen, Mary Barnes of Providence and Len Elmore of Maryland.

America's Skylab space station passed its final ground test today for launching May 14 on an ambitious mission to keep men in orbit for 140 days this year.

The timing of John B. Connally's formal jump to the Republicans is hardly accidental. By coming to the aid of the Grand Old Party in its time of trouble he puts its leaders, especially President Nixon, heavily in his debt. At this stage it was the best way to keep alive his prospects for obtaining, with Mr. Nixon's backing, theRepublican Presidential nomination in 1976.

Farm products, feed and processed food components dropped 0.8 per cent to 147.9.

WASHINGTON-The Nixon Administration seemed uncertain last week about its intentions in Indochina. Walter W. Foskett, a lawyer here for 52 years, died Thursday at the age of 87. David put on his soccer boots today and slew Goliath. That is to say that Sunderland, a once-derided soccer team in the Second Division of the English League, beat Leeds, one ot the best in Europe, 1-0, to win the cherished Football Association Cup.

When "Oklahoma" opened on Broadway 30 years ago this spring, it became a bright marker a1ong the often wayward path of the musical theater. One reason was that thousands of uncouth types learned that properly administered ballet could be fun, not just exercises indulged in by effeminate young men and masculine young ladies for their private amusement. Credit this to Agnes de Mille, the choreographer.

An appeals court yesterday overturned the murder and manslaughter convictions against Mrs. Alice Crimmins in the deaths of her two children nearly eight years ago and ordered her retried again, but this time only for manslaughter.
Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward, investigative reporters for The Washington Post, have named recipients of the 23d annual Sidney Hillman awards for their coverage of the Watergate affair.

A 22-year veteran of the Fire Department performed an acrobatic rescue of three children and three adults from a Harlem tenement yesterday morning, straddling an air-shaft five stories above the ground to pull to safety the occupants of a burning apartment.

Schuyler G. Chapin, who has been acting general manager of the Metropolitan Opera since Goeran Gentele's death last July, is virtually a. certainty to be named today as general manager, with a three-year contract.

The White House has come to grips with some of the energy problems which faced the nation in the 1960's. What still seems to elude the capabilities of the Federal Government is the crisis now building for the 1970's and 1980's.

A proposal to construct a $30-million industrial park in Roosevelt, L. I., was all but dropped yesterday after nearly 300 residents of the community protested bitterly at the weekly Nassau County Board of Supervisors meeting. A building contractor's spokesman said today that Federal intervention might speed up a settlement in the statewide carpenters strike, which enters its second week tomorrow.
When William B. Randall emerges from his new-product think tank in Irvine, Calif., and. heads for the office of a manufacturer, he is armed with far more than an idea. He has the product.

Restrictions that New Jersey plans to put into effect this summer on the dumping of New York City's garbage there could force the city into short-term disposal alternatives costing up to three times the present disposal costs, city officials said yesterday.
The State Supreme Court today upheld by a 4-to-3 vote the constitutionality of the 1968 law that created the Hackensack Meadowlands Development District.

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal said yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi was now "irrelevant" as a mayoral candidate, and that some of Mr. Biaggi's former supporters had switched their allegiance to his own campaign in recent days.

Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson told the Senate Appropriations Committee today that the bombing of Cambodia would continue even if Congress refused to provide the Pentagon with additional spending authority.

Brown University has received a $900,000 grant from the Kresge Foundation for the reconstruction of several of the university buildings in Providence, R. I., as facilities for the performing arts, The university, however, must raise an additional $1.8-million by June, 1976, to receive the grant.

Amid charges by seven dissenting a Democrats that it was a "fraud" aimed at deluding the public, the Senate completed legislative action today on the final version of Governor Rockefeller's legislation providing for harsher penalties for traffickers in dangerous drugs.

Eudora Welty, who received a Pulitzer Prize today, was honored last week by her home state as "the nation's foremost lady of letters."
Most interest rates continued to rise yesterday in a capitalmarket session marked by some significant financing announcements.

When, the Franco-Polish player David Janowski referred to rooks doubled on the seventh rank as "blind pigs," he knew whereof he spoke. Such rooks will devour everything in range and, worse yet, constrict the enemy position so badly that countermeasures are futile.

The Soviet Union is hoping to borrow $1billion from a group of banks in Europe but is seeking to hold the interest rate to a point where the lenders would barely cover their costs, international banking sources said today.
The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today the relaxation of Federal standards on the emission of sulphur oxides from smokestacks.

SAIGON, South Vietnam - A Canadian secretary misses mountains and snow. A Hungarian misses goulash. And the female Polish interpreter misses her husband. Apart from that, the women (about 20 of them) working for the four-party International Commission for Control and Supervision - Canadians, Poles, Hungarians and Indonesians - are steadily adapting to life in Saigon.
