Sir Ernest MacMillan, composerconductor who directed the Toronto Symphony Orchestra From 1931 to 1956, died yesterlay in Toronto General Hospital. He was 79 years old.

In a respite from his sometimes provocative; sometimes merely curious, preoccupation with the criminal, Truman Capote is taking a look at the other side of the lawand-order coin. In "Crimewatch,", on the 'American Broadcasting Company network tonight from 11:30 to, 1 A.M., Mr. Capote conducts a series of interviews on the policeman or, more precisely, the "Super Cop."

Godfred Fred Fugger, 54 years old, part owner of a business in New Jersey, was sentenced yesterday to serve two and a half years in prison for conspiring to sell $1.5million in stolen securities through a Bahamanian bank.

The Coalition for Human Needs and Budget Priorities warned today that a major reform of the Congressional spending system could limit the opportunities to allocate more Federal funds to social programs.

The malaria-carrying mosquito was honored-in Sierra Leone today for making the country the "whiteman's grave" in past years and preventing Europeans from settling here and setting up "another Rhodesia."

Military headquarters yesterday reported a four-hour gun battle during the weekend with a 20man group of rebels near the town of San Antonio in Neuva Ecija Province 70 miles north of here. Five of the rebels were reported killed and one captured.

American and South Vietnamese officials are making detailed charges of a substantial North Vietnamese military build-up in the northern provinces of South Vietnam. The most important developments alleged seem to be the construction of a major logistics base at Khe Sanh and a new road from there through the Ashau Valley to the vicinity of Da Nang.

American scientists have picked a site near the end of the Martian "Grand Canyon' and another near the, fringe of that planet's northern polar cap for the first United States attempts to land instruments on Mars.

The steel industry "appears to be heating up to get increases," Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation told newsmen prior to its annual meeting here today.

The Republican party is something else. Last summer when the Republican party held a convention in Florida it nearly died of treacle poisoning brought on by self-inflicted sycophancy, but next time will probably be different.

Government scientists said today that immense solar flares bombarded the earth with such unprecedented levels of energy last August that they disrupted some defense communications and may have caused homing pigeons to become lost.

The four-man ruling council formed two weeks ago has still not been able to agree on a premier an a cabinet. "Strife is still the word to describe their deliberations," an informed Western diplomat said.
United Rubber Workers Local 5 struck the B. F. Goodrich Company plant in Akron at 10 o'clock tonight while negotiations continued in Columbus inman effort to forestall a nationwide strike.

Livingston County Judge Joseph S. Montesano of Mount Morris died today in Strong Memorial Hospital after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 62 years old.

A New Jersey father has identified the bodies of two girls found slain last week as those of his daughters. Thomas John Jenkins of Gloucester City, N. J., identified the bodies yesterday as Margureit Jenkins, 18 years old, and Mary Jenkins, 16, the police said.

The South Platte River receded here today, but down river the crest of its floodwaters, swollen by day-long rains and 20 inches of snow in the mountains, swept through small farming towns in northern Colorado, battering earthen dikes and trapping livestock.

The Supreme Court today overturned a Treasury Department regulation that required mutual fund shares to be valued for estate tax purposes at the "asked" price rather than the lower "bid" price.

Production, of steel in the week ended 'Saturday declined for the third consecutive week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade group placed output for the latest period at 2,981,000 tons, down 0.2 per cent from the 2,987,000 tons poured the preceding week.
President Nixon said today that he would soon ask Congress 'to finance continued operation of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, which broadcast to European Communist countries.

The new state commission created to enforce New Jersey's tough campaign financial disclosure law declared today that it would require a full accounting of all funds collected and spent in the June 5 primary election campaign.

Taxpayers are spending between $50,000 and $100,000 a day in subsidies for at least 20 huge tankers waiting in United States ports, often for weeks, to be loaded with wheat and corn for the Soviet Union.

Jordan and Thomas Gangemi Jr., the son of a former mayor, will affect not only the course ef city government here for the next four years but also the Democratic gubernatorial primary.

Ted Patrick, key figure in a controversy involving alleged abductions by parents of young people in religious groups, was released on $5,000 bail yesterday after having spent the night in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men.
Vincent J. Burke, a senior member of the Washington staff of The Los Angeles Times, died today of cancer. He was 53 years old.

Legislative agreement to supplement state aid to schools this year by an additional $25-millionwhile shelving controversial proposals for basic reform of school financing - was reported today by the head of the Assembly Education Committee.
The City of New York drafted a formal apology yesterday to the Liberian diplomat hospitalized after he was beaten early Sunday by a group of white youths in the Marble Hill section of Manhattan.

A Boeing 707 flew six times over the lush rolling hills south of Dulles International Airport today and, while more than 100 people strained their ears in a green pasture beneath, brought a billion-dollar dispute nearer to a climax.
The spirited recovery that carried stocks ahead late last week stalled early yesterday. Prices declined in the slowest trading in three weeks.

Despite a moderate statistical gain, department-store business in New York during March and April showed The relatively little real advance over last year.

To the Editor: Authorities on carcinogenesis (cancer formation) tell us that most human cancers are caused by man-made, avoidable environmental agents. Nevertheless, when the Food and Drug Administration recently banned the treatment of beef cattle with DES, a known carcinogen, the F.D.A. was criticized with unfounded charges that meat prices would rise and that the quantities of DES in beef were "infinitesimal" anyway [Editorial April 30].
North Vietnam plans to invite relatives of some of the Americans who died in prison camps or plane crashes there to visit the servicemen's graves, a spokesman from Hanoi said today.
Nine self - proclaimed Black Muslims convicted of inciting a riot in which two sheriff's deputies and three blacks were killed were sentenced today to maximum prison terms of 21 years.

The Senate passed legislation today authorizing funds for two years for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. The Senate approved the measure only after reducing by $10-million the amount of money that would be available for' the second year.

A Scotch whisky company and the New York Racing Association are making it cheaper to lose money on the horses. From now until June 30, racing fans will be admitted to Aqueduct and later Belmont for 50 cents instead of the usual $2 grandstand admission if they present a coupon distributed by the W. A. Taylor Company, makers of Old Smuggler Scotch.

Four Black Panthers charged with killing a member of a rival faction of the party went on trial yesterday for the second time in State Supreme Court in Queens.

The 1973 Pulitzer Prize for public service in journalism was awarded yesterday to The Washington Post for its investigation of the Watergate case, the affair that began with an attempt to bug Democratic National Headquarters last June and grew into a national scandal last month.

A group of old people watched yesterday as 11 elderly men and women 'rehearsed the song "Mathilda" for a variety show to be presented in the Andrew Jackson Senior Center at 125 East 156th Street in the Bronx.

More than 20 youths were arrested yesterday afternoon when they were allegedly found looting a supermarket in South Jamaica, Queens, that had been closed for a week because of neighborhood disturbances following the police shooting of a 10-year-old boy.

Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., and Harris, Upham Co., Inc., two major member firms of the -New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that they were considering the formation of a jointly owned operations company to reduce costs.

John Kennedy, president of Stereotypers Local 1, said yesterday that the union's membership had authorized the scale committee "to go back to the bargaining table with the city's newspapers and make one more try to reach an agreement."

Mayor Lindsay's office announced yesterday the completion of the installation of highintensity street lighting along the entire length of Central Park West and on 125th Street from the Hudson River to the East River.
Dr. Harmon M. Chapman, professor emeritus of philosophy at New York University, died Sunday at his home on Cow Hill Road in Clinton, Conn. He was 72 years old.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has entered into a "settlement agreement" with the New York regional office of the National Labor Relations Board regarding charges of unfair labor practices filed by employes of the museum.

In 1917, members of the Alaska Engineering Commission survey team that was building the Alaska railroad began wagering about when the ice on the Tanana River would break. Since then the Nenana Ice Classic has been the greatest game of chance in the 49th state and has led to direct involvement by the Internal Revenue Service.
The liner Queen Elizabeth 2 steamed homeward through the Mediterranean today, half her cruise completed without any Arab terrorist attacks against her Jewish passengers.

" It was the key play of the game," said Jerry West of the Lakers last. night, looking back on Dave DeBusschere's 3-point-play rebound that stopped a late Los Angeles rally and helped the Knicks to a 103-98 victory last night.
Charles Grayson, novelist and screenwriter who wrote more than 20 screenplays including "Beau Geste," "Battle Hymn" and "The Barbarian and the Geisha," died Friday. He was 69 years old.

Northeastern, the defending champion, was seeded first yesterday for Saturday's Eastern sprint championships at Worcester, Mass. The Huskie crew, undefeated after four races, was place atop the list of 15 heavyweight eights ahead of Harvard, also unbeaten.
The outgoing Secretary of Defense, Elliot L. Richardson, asked Congress today for $1.2billion in military aid for Cambodia, Korea, Thailand and other areas.

The Food and Drug Admninistration is about to ban the use of plastic liquor bottles because of suspicions that toxic materials are seeping from the containers into their alcoholic contents.

James W. McCord Jr. has charged that he was pressured on two occasions before his trial early this year to assert that he and his colleagues were working on a covert operation for the Central Intelligence Agency at the time of their arrest in the Watergate breakin.
A new cease-fire between Government forces and Palestinian guerrillas was announced last night after a day marked by heavy rocket attacks by Lebanese jets on guerrilla positions.
Textile workers yesterday ended a seven-day strike here and in New Jersey and returned to work after ratifying a threeyear contract with two employer groups.

Government purchasing officlals in the metropolitan area and in other parts of the country have begun to look into contingency plans for rationing gasoline for official cars because oil companies have not been eager to bid on contracts for future gasoline supplies.
Gus Lampo and Mike Orlovsky, of Endicott, N. Y., bowled 1.279 yesterday and took second place in the Classic Division doubles of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

With panoply and fanfare and some caustic words for his critics, Governor Rockefeller signed into law today the final version of his bills providing harsher penalties for traffickers in dangerous drugs.

The Cerro Corporation's annual meeting in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday got off on a high note-an announcement that the quarterly dividend was being doubled from 10 to 20 cents' a share-and the tone continued for the duration of the one-hour-and-55minute session.
Edward J. Powers, president and general manager of the Boston Garden Arena, died today in Winchester Hospital. He was 66 years old.
Jordan protested here today against the military parade that Israel staged yesterday in Jerusalem, partly through the former Jordanian sector, in celebration of her 25th anniversary of independence.
The Senate ignored the threat of another Presidential veto to. day as it approved a $362.5million, one-year extension of programs to aid economically depressed areas of the nation.
Vice President Agnew said tonight that while he applauded the role of the media in the Watergate scandal, some reporting techniques used have been "a very short jump from McCarthvism."
Tennessee's new version of the state's once-famous monkey law went into the lawbooks at midnight without Gov. Winfield Dunn's signature.
Silent Majority,. the outstanding 4-year-old pacer named Canadian horse of the year for 1972, will not race again.
President Nixon proposed today legislation designed to consolidate Federal disaster-assistance programs and give the states a larger responsibility.

A public offering of 650,000 units of Hamilton Investment Trust, a real estate trust, at $19.50 per unit (consisting of one share of beneficial interest and a warrant to purchase one additional share at $20, subject to adjustment in certain events) was made yesterday by underwriters managed by Blyth Eastman Dillon and Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc.

Like a lot of other people, Vladimir Kondrashin, the coach of the Soviet Union basketball team, doesn't want to antagonize Wilt Chamberlain. Apparently he is having second thoughts about his widely quoted observation in New York the other day that Chamberlain "is not good."
Dr. Veniamin G. Levich, an internationally known physical chemist who applied last year for permission to emigrate to Israel, was threatened today with expulsion from the Soviet Academy of Sciences.

An Assistant Attorney General testified today that President Nixon could invoke executive privilege even in a proceeding involving his own impeachment.

Top-seeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania breezed through his two opening matches today in the $65,000 British clay court tennis chamin pionships. Three seeded players were eliminated.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos tonight described new perspectives in Philippine foreign policy, including a reorganization of relations with the United States.

Watergate and immunity: The Senate committee investigating Watergate will hold its first public hearings May 17 and will move to compel testimony by John W. Dean 3d, the deposed White House counsel, by granting him immunity. President Nixon, the White House said, will no longer advise prosecutors to withhold immunity from current or former members of the Administration.

An agreement to give the Indian protectorate of Sikkim a more democratic form of government was reportedly signed tonight, resolving the crisis that led India to take over the kingdom's administration last month.
Campers and trailers will be barred from the infield of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway for the 500-mile race May 28 because they "encourage vice," according to the Speedway Traffic Committee.

The deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency met at the agency with E. Howard Hunt Jr. in July, 1971, and ordered that Hunt be supplied with false identity papers and such disguises as a wig, glasses and a voice alteration device, the Government confirmed today at the Pentagon papers trial.

LIHUE, KAUAI, Hawaii The scene seemed to be repeated endlessly. The young man placed the young woman so she had her back to the white foam on the surf, whipped up by the strong trade winds. He held a light meter to her smiling face.

KANSAS CITY--Optioned Tom Burgmeler, left-handed relief pitcher, to Omaha of the American Association. Recalled Jim Wohlford, outfielder, from Omaha. OAKLAND--Placed on disabled list Billy Conigllaro, outfielder. Recalled Tim Hosley catcher, from Tucson of the Pacific Coast League.

George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., describing the Nixon Administration as "steeped in scandal and twisted by privilege," called today for a "vigorous and impartial investigation" of the Watergate conspiracy.

SPANISH GIFT If your budget doesn't allow a trip this year, or even if it does, drop into the Donnell Library Center at 20 West 53d Street (near Fifth) (790-6447) between now and May 30 for a delightful look at Old and New Spain. The library, in
Maj. Gen. Mordecai Hod, commandant of the Israel Air Force during the Arab-Israeli War of June, 1967, is retiring. He will be succeeded on Thursday by his long-time second-in-command, Brig. Gen.

In a speech on the floor of the United States Senate, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, has accused the press of being "grossly unfair" in reporting secret charges that President Nixon knew about the cover-up in the Watergate case.
President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan has dismissed his 16-member Cabinet in preparation for the "real administrative revolution" he has promised.
Directors of The Washington Post Company are scheduled t name Mrs. Katharine Graham today as chairman and chief executive officer and Larry H. Israel as president and chief operating officer.

Ralph Darwin Miller, believed to be the oldest living former major league baseball player, died at a rest home here yesterday. He was 100 years old. Mr. Miller, a pitcher, broke into the National League with Brooklyn in 1898 after playing four years in the minors.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation holds its annual meeting here Wednesday amid indications that the big conglomerate's management could face a stormy session.

Ken Singleton, the ex-Met who went to Montreal as part of the deal for Rusty Staub in April of last season, had a hand in two rallies last night as the Expos snapped Houston's nine-game winning streak, 4-3, on Jim York's wild throw to the plate in the ninth.
Lady Scatterley's Lovers, by Gene Fowler, edited and introduced by H. Allen Smith (Lyle Stuart, Secaucus, N. J., $5.95). Posthumous edition of a spoof written in the late nineteen-thirties.

The trustees of the bankrupt Penr Central Railroad cautioned Con. gress today that it must ac quickly on a plan that would include substantial cash aid from the Federal Government or accept the likelihood that the trains will stop running before October.

The Federal Appeals Court here set the week of June 4 to hear an appeal by Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner. Ryan on a decision to extradite her to West Germany on charges that she murdered inmates in a Nazi concentration camp.
The Pentagon said today that 28 marines and 18 navy personnel had been taken off duty at Camp David, Md., President Nixon's mountain retreat, following an investigation into alleged marijuana use.
The Onondaga County Legislature has adopted a modified consumer protection code and created an office of consumer affairs.

A fire that the authorities said had been set by an arsonist yesterday killed a woman and her three children and two grandchildren in Brooklyn. The early-morning blaze trapped the victims on the top floor of a three-story tenement in a rundown section of Brownsville.

There's nothing wrong with the Yankees that the Minnesota Twins can't cure. Even Rod Carew, no physician he, recognized the get-well symptoms. "Don't worry," the Twins' second baseman said before tonight's game, "we'll help them get their averages up again." For Minnesota, the prognosis Proved painfully perfect,

The Senate Watergate committee announced today that it would begin public hearings on May 17 and would move to compel testimony by John W. Dean 3d, the deposed White House counsel, by granting him immunity from prosecution.
The United Fund of Greater New York's 425 affiliated agencies in the five boroughs make up the largest network of local hospitals and health and social service agencies in the world.
The value of the United States dolJar fell in Europe today. It suffered its worst day on the London foreign-exchange market since the crisis surrounding the February dollar devaluation.
The Federal Rome Loan Bank Board acted today to increase the availability of mortgage loans at savings and loan associations by as much as $1billion.
Warner Communications, Inc., has reached an agreement to acquire the cable-television systems of Time Inc., it was learned yesterday. Announcement of the transaction is expected to he made today.

Charles E. Canfield, board chairman of the Canfield Paper Company of New York; died Sunday at Putnam Memorial Hospital, Bennington. He was 72 years old and had lived here since his retirement in 1963.
Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals set a major league record tonight by starting his 242d straight game, and he later passed Cy Young on the career strike-out list.

A committee of the Euro pean Parliament warned today of an energy crisis by 1980 in which "quite literally" the lights would go out all over Europe unless the member countries of the Common Market agreed on a comprehensive energy policy.

" Can't you feel it? Can't you feel it? Evita is present," chanted a frenzied crowd gathered in front of the General Labor Union headquarters here to celebrate the 54th birthday anniversary of Eva Duarte Peron.

Citing the deaths of 24,000 people each year because of bad reactions to medication, a state appeals court upheld yesterday a rule requiring druggists to keep a profile record on their customers. The Appellate Division of the Superior Court rejected a challenge by Rite Aid of New Jersey, Inc., and nine, other retail pharmacies to the rule adopted last year by the State Board of Pharmacy. The military Government of Gen. Juan Velasco Alvarado said today that it was expropriating the country's fishing industry, once the biggest in the world, because of a twoyear economic crisis.

Three-month-old Kim Cruz was taken off the critical list at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday, and a spokesman there said she was now in "fair condition." The baby had been in critical condition with cerebral hemorrhaging since May 8, when she was rescued from her father, James Layne, who allegedly tried to sell her on the IRT subway to get money for narcotics.
The New York Press Club, which will mark its silver anniversary in July, inducted its first woman. president last night at its annual installation and awards dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel.

The annual convention of the Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday urged "pardon and/or clemency to persons currently incarcerated for mere possession and use of marijuana," and amnesty for all who refused service in Vietnam for reasons of conscience.
Cambodian military sources reported the recapture of two towns near Phnom Penh today.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the recovery of the entire $303,000 in extortion money paid to the hijacker of an Eastern Air Lines jet airline who bailed out over Honduras last May.

Amzy B. Steed, a retired vice president and general counsel of Texaco, Inc., died yesterday. He was 59 years. old and lived here. Mr. Steed was a 1936 law graduate of the University of Tennessee.
Henry A. Kissinger met again today with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, for continued planning of Mr. Brezhnev's trip to Washineton.
Controller Abraham D. Beame vowed yesterday to "go into the ring," if necessary, to prove he was as vigorous as his younger opponents in the primary race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.
Icelandic. Airlines was struck by its pilots last night, stranding 249 passengers booked on the airline's only evening flight from Kennedy Airport.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell was quoted by the American Broadcasting Company yesterday as saying that he never knew the White House was conducting its own investigation of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's release of the Pentagon papers, and that the case might not have been prosecuted if he had.

Every morning, Harry Feldman trundles his mail cart past the flowering cherry trees and the chattering squirrels of Stuyvesant Town. In the red brick buildings, he is greeted by retired oldsters waiting for Social Security checks or letters from faraway sons and daughters. If he is late, they worry.
Seventy-seven of the known 114 surviving black males involved in the Tuskegee; Ala., syphilis study have accepted an offer of medical care at Government expense for the rest of their lives.

By the time he was 13 years old, Schuyler Garrison Chapin was quite sure that he wanted to be "involved in music." Yesterday, in his 51st year, he was made the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera.

A ringerpint taken from a glass of whisky was shown in court here yesterday in an effort to identify a reputed member of the crime family of the late Joseph Gallo as the killer of a West Side-bar manager last March.

It is a great relief that the United States Consul General in Guadalajara has been released unharmed after his kidnapping and imprisonment for three days by a left-wing Mexican guerrilla organization.

About 150 members of senior citizen centers braved a chill drizzle yesterday to dance and clap to Dixieland music blaring from the gazebo of Poe Park as the celebration of Bronx Week continued with a salute to the elderly.

Yesterday's peaceful denouement of the ten - week occupation of Wounded Knee by militant Indians and concurrent siege by Federal marshals was a credit to cooler heads on both sides. This "tragic event," as an Indian leader described it, was a lesser tragedy by far than it might have been because of the restraint shown by the Government and of the ultimate wisdom of tribal leaders in agreeing to move from confrontation to dialogue.

Police sources today described pottery fragments found in Italy and linked to the Euphronios vase in New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art as "of the length of an average package of cigarettes and rather narrower."
Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, said today that as a result of the Watergate scandal disclosures, he would not rule out running for President in 1976.

Watergate and immunity: The Senate committee investigating Watergate will hold its first public hearing May 17 and will move to compel testimony by John W. Dean 3d, the deposed White House counsel, by granting him immunity. President Nixon, the White House said, will no longer advise prosecutors to withhold immunity from current or former members of the Administration.
Egil Krogh Jr., former White House aide, was reported under intense pressure today to resign as Under Secretary of Transportation because of his admitted role in the Ellsberg case.
A new cease-fire between Government forces and Palestinian guerrillas was announced last night after a day marked by heavy rocket attacks by Lebanese jets on guerrilla positions.
Today's schedule of Bronx Week events include: A lecture on the "Indian Heritage of the Bronx" at the Wave Hill Center in Riverdale at 8 P.M.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former chief of state of Cambodia, flew to Dakar, Senegal, to begin a tour of African and European countries to promote the prestige of his government-in-exile, which is based in Peking.
David J. Witmer, who helped design the Pentagon as co-chief and chief architect for the War Department in 1941-43, died Saturday at the age of 84.

Simple little dresses. Whoever thought Rudi Gernreich would be lauded for his pretty dresses? They're short tentsand long ones, too. Some are based, more or less faithfully, on the cheongsam, the classic Chinese dress.

A Federal judge signed an order here last night delaying the transfer of $3,675,000 from Florida to the Bahamas by an consider associate of Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who is being sought in connection with the funding of President Nixon's re-election campaign, until a Government challenge to the transfer can be heard.
A top assistant to President Nixon termed "blatant nonsense" today the allegation that the President was seeking "unprecedented power" in.his proDosed trade bill.

Candidates for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals and for New York City Controller have become the first to avail themselves of free time on a new cable television channel serving upper Manhattan.

Top-seeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania breezed through his two opening Brown matches today in the $65,000 British clay court tennis chain. Total pionships. Three seeded players were eliminated.
About 40 per cent of all colleges and universities now offer what educators sometimes call "nontraditional" courses - courses that adults may take without necessarily working for a degree.
Eleven persons were arrested today in what Morris County Prosecutor Donald Collester Jr. said was a major drive against prostitution, drug and gambling offenses.

Some sectors of the bond market snapped back from a string of declines yesterday and posted moderate gains in relatively brisk trading. Many corporate issues, after some early weakness, had climbed by 1/4 point--$2.50 per bond--by the close of the session, and Treasury securities rose by 2 to 8/32ds of a point.

Dr. James Killian Jr. was expected to be elected chairian of the board of the Cororation for Public Broadcastng today in what informed sources said would be an atempt to give the impression hat the board is "independent" If White House control.

The Vietcong charged today that Saigon troops fighting in a Communist-held area had sprayed toxic chemicals that "ruined" more than 1,500 acres of land and caused serious illness to "large numbers of persons."
A Federal court ordered the Government today to make available $6-billion to the states for water pollution control, bringing Federal funding up to the full amount authorized by Congress last year.
Mayor Paul T. Jordan won a lopsided re-election victory tonight over Thomas Gangemi Jr. and the remnants of the once-powerful Democratic organization of John V. Kenny.

Joseph M. McCrane Jr., the former State Treasurer, plans to sell his household effects, including some valuable antiques June 2. According to the auctioneer, B. G. Coats of Rumson, Mr. McCrane asked him about two weeks ago to handle the sale.

The State Department acknowledged today that E. Howard Hunt Jr., a Watergate conspirator, was given access to secret Vietnam diplomatic cables in 1971 at the request of David R. Young Jr., then a White House aide.

The United States Court of Appeals, in a 4-to-2 decision, upheld here yesterday a Federal District Court order for the International Business Machines Corporation to produce some 1,200 business documents that L.B.M. says are confidential.
Frederick M. Adams, a commissioner of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority and a former Mayor of Woodbridge, died today in Elizabeth General Hospital. His age was 53 and he lived at Colonia.

Net' profit of the Coca-Cola Company for the first quarter this year increased 15.3 per cent to a record $40.6-million, or 68 cents a share, from $35.2million, or 59 cents, in the initial three months last year, it was reported yesterday.
Norm Van Lier, on trial with six other men in connection with an altercation with the police last August, denied under oath today that he led the alleged assault.

Adelphi University suspended yesterday its outstanding quarter-miler, Dennis Walker, from intercollegiate competition in the face of threats by the Eastern College Athletic Conference and National Collegiate Athletic Association to penalize Adelphi if the senior track star continued to run.

The deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency met at the agency with E. Howard Hunt Jr. in July, 1971, and ordered that Hunt be supplied with false identity papers and such disguises as a wig, glasses and a voice alteration device, the Government confirmed today at the Pentagon papers trial.
Herbert J. Brean, a novelist, mystery-story writer and editor, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 500 East 77th Street.
The strike that has shut down Goodrich rubber plants in six states is the first somber warning that union moderation on the wage front may be cracking under the squeeze of resurgent inflation.

The volume of trading in stock options reached a cumulative total of one million shares at midsession yesterday on the Chicago Board Options Exchange. Trading in stock call options there began on April 26.

The State Pension Commission today contradicted Governor Rockefeller and warned that the state's new contract with its employes would "effectively doom" any chance of meaningful reform of the increasingly costly public pension system.

The Connecticut Civil Liberties Union has called upon the United States Attorney in Connecticut to investigate a series of recent efforts by parents to "rescue" their children from religious groups they regard as dangerous.

The second Battle of Wounded Knee ended today. After 70 days, two deaths, numerous injuries, countless meetings, bureaucratic bickering and a last-minute gunfight, more than 100 militants lay down their arms and surrendered this occupied reservation town to wary Federal officials.
" We propose to work like hell to break even" this year, William T. Seawell, Pan American World Airways' chairman and chief executive officer, said at the annual meeting here today.

Isadore Bookstein, a retired Supreme Court justice, died today at his home here. He was 82 years old. Admitted to the bar in 1912, Mr. Bookstein served as assistand district attorney for Albany County in 1920-21, later being appointed a county judge.

Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that "I don't think there will be any general or substantial tightening of the [wage-price] control system." Then he added, "We can't keep changing the rules of the game."

Henry A. Kissinger's visit to Moscow may advance the valuable but limited progress toward Soviet-American detente made since President Nixon's visit a year ago. Rather, I think it is time to concentrate on the disadvantages of a bicycle and try to find ways of overcoming those disadvantazes.

In its passion for secrecy and centralized control, the Nixon Administration originally put forward an enormously swollen doctrine of executive privilege. Under the pressure of the Watergate revelations, the Administration has begun to shrink its interpretation somewhat. Yet it is still bloated beyond what previous Presidents have claimed and still looks suspiciously like an effort to cover up improper behavior.

A spectacularly beautiful exhibition of ancient art treasures never before seen outside China had its world premiere here tonight. Tomorrow it goes on view to the public at the Petit Palais museum just off the Champs-Elysees.
An anonymous Long Island collector paid $27,500 yesterday for a letter written by George Washington, the highest auction price ever paid for a Washington letter.

Reflecting the booming economy, the effects of inflation, inventory revaluation and dollar devaluation, firstquarter profits of 1,545 United States corporations rose 26 per cent to $11-billion from $8.79-billion in the'first three months of last year. The gain was but three per cent from t the 1972 fourth-quarter net of $10.7-billion.

Thirteen cars of a 137car Penn Central freight train derailed here early today near the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. Penn Central officials could not say when service on the railroad's West Shore branch, its main north-south freight line between Albany and New York, would be restored.

Ross A. Lasley, an industrial consultant who was the first editor of Parade magazine after its founding in the early nineteen-forties, died last evening, apparently. of pneumonia, in Norwalk Hospital. He was 74
More than 10,000 rubber workers struck the B. F. Goodrich Company today, halting all production at plants in six states. Contract talks were recessed, and no time for their resumption was announced.
Federal court ordered the Government today to make available $6-billion to the states for water pollution control, bringing Federal funding up to the full amount authorized by Congress last year.

Australian workers were awarded substantial raises today by the National Arbitration Commission, the five-man body that periodically reviews and adjusts pay levels for employes governed by federal labor standards. The action added

The State Supreme Court tried to determine today whether William B. Colsey 3d, a Mount Holly lawyer and a figure in Republican fund- raising investigations, had once disguided the extortion of $15,000 as a political contribution.
Financial officials of the West German Government met this evening to complete a tough program to curb inflation. A flood of new industrial orders and large wage increases

Advances narrowly outnumhered declines yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market in slightly stepped-up trading.
Nine men and nine women clap their hands, sway their hips and dance triumphantly down to the footlights to the shouts of the spiritual "Rocka My Soul in the Bosom of Abraham."

Pounding her guitar as much as strumming it-her rich, deep voice singing about men in jail and men fighting for survival - an impressive black woman in flowing robes performed in badly lit auditoriums and coffee houses during the nineteen-fifties and established her name as one synonymous with American folk music.

Adelphi University suspended yesterday its outstanding quarter-miler, Dennis Walker, from intercollegiate competition in the face of threats by the Eastern College Athletic Conference and National Collegiate Athletic Association to penalize Adelphi if the senior track star continued to run.
The White House said today that President Nixon was no longer advising prosecutors in the Watergate case not to grant immunity to present or former members of the Administration.

Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, the assistant floor leader, joined the United Mine Workers Union today in demanding the resignation of Donald P. Schlick as the Government's chief enforcer of strict new Federal safety regulations in the nation's coal mines.

Wenda Smorra, the only trainer at Roosevelt Raceway, was almost in tears last night after having seen Matt Coats, one of the four horses in her public stable, go off stride just as the field of trooters was approaching the starting line for the first race.

George McGinnis stole an inbounds pass and drove under for stuff shot in the final 23 sec- he onds tonight to clinch Indiana's 89-86 victory over the Kentucky Colonels and give the Pacers a 3-2 lead in the American Basketball Association championship playoff.

PARIS--American politics, on the whole shown to be considerably less dirty over the years than those of France, Italy or Spain (to name but a few examples), have managed to acquire a particularly sordid reputation now. Perhaps our original Puritan heritage inspires a special orgy of shame over Watergate.

A fire in an electrical transformer on the top floor of the 30-story Xerox Corporation tower today forced a virtual shutdown of the building for about one and a half hours. The structure houses about 1,800 employes.

A Everette MacIntyre has ended a controversy over his possible vulnerability to White House influence by resigning from the Federal Trade Commission.

At noon yesterday, the lights Went out in the Hunts Point branch of the New York Public Library. In fact, lights were dimmed or turned off in libraries throughout the country, thought not from a loss of power.

Postal authorities in the city of brotherly love across the Delaware from this friendly hamlet seem to exhibit a disdain from time to time toward Stanton's third-class post office that offends the sensibilities of its 104 boxholders.
An anonymous appeal to the International Red Cross and world opinion alleged tonight that security authorities had arrested student leaders and were torturing them.

The ravenous American appetite for minerals will lead to severe shortages in the next few decades unless the nation stops wasting resources and starts employing better ways of finding and exploiting low-grade ores, according to a report from the United States Geological Survey.
One of these days, Tom Campanelli and Diane Heiss are going to get to ride a horse with a chance of winning.

Harry S. Truman's hometown and representatives from Washington joined today in marking the 89th birthday anniversary of the 33d President.

Cesar Charlone, economist, politician and lawyer, died today of a heart attack. He was 77 years old. Mr. Charlone's last Government position was in 1970, when he became Finance Minister in the Government of then President Jorge Pacheco Areco.
Australia is lifting her embargo on trade with Communist nations, including North Vietnam--four months after withdrawal of the last Australian soldiers from the Vietnam war.
Lord Carrington, the British Defense Secretary, said today that British soldiers had tried to blackmail a Belfast teen-ager into spying for the army.

In the fourth straight wild finish of a weird series for them championship of the National Basketball Association, the NewYork Knicks held on for a 10398 decision over the Los Angeles Lakers at Madison Square: Garden last night and left for:
A settlement may be near in the nine-week-old Writers Guild strike that has brought large segments of the motion picture and television industries to a standstill.

WASHINGTON-A recent Gallup Poll shows that 50 per cent of the 456 people polled think that President Nixon has been covering up facts in the Watergate case. Yet 58 per cent say they see little difference with respect to corruption between the Nixon Administration and others over the last 25 years.

The use of a single religious building by the congregations of the three branches of Judaism -- Orthodox, Conservative and Reform-that would cut expenses and help cope with other pressures was advocated today before 500 Conservative rabbis.

To the Editor: The current proposal in a "taxreform" package by President Nixon to provide tax credits for parents of parochial-school students is unwise by any reasonable public standard, primarily because it would entail, like the more direct attempts to obtain

The reversal of the murder and manslaughter convictions against Mrs. Alice Crimmins in the death of her two children almost eight years ago will be appealed, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

A 16-year-old girl about to graduate from a Lower East Side preparatory school for children of disadvantaged families was found dead with her 23-year-old fiance in an East Village apartment yesterday.

The Agriculture Department officially acknowledged today that for 1973 as a whole the rate of increase in retail food prices could be about 50 per cent above its earlier estimates and approximately twice the rise in 1972.

The Phoenix Suns signed Gary Melchionni, former Duke University star, to a multi-yea: contract yesterday. Melchionni, a 6-foot-3 guard, was chosen by the Suns of the National Basketball Associa. tion in the second round of the 1973 draft.

Four former Army sergeants who organized a ring that systematically defrauded noncommissioned officers' clubs in Vietnam told Senate investigators today that the Army was incapable of uncovering such wrongdoing by Itself.
The New York Mets suffered a double loss last night, when Jon Matlack was struck on the forehead by a line drive while pitching against the Atlanta Braves, who then scored seven cus in the inning.

The second Battle of Wounded Knee ended today. After 70 days, two deaths, numerous injuries, countless meetings, bureaucratic bickering and a last-minute gunfight, more than 100 militants lay down their arms and surrendered the occupied reservation town to wary Federal officials.

The ravenous American appetite minerals will lead to severe shortages in the next few decades unless the nation stops wasting resources and starts employing better ways of finding and exploiting low-grade ores, according to a report from the United States Geological Survey.
I don't want to read one more column or editorial expressing the belief that Watergate should be resolved in a way that enables us to keep on trusting in the Presidency.

John W. Bristol Co., Inc., the Boston Company, Inc., and Boston Company Institutional investors, Inc., advisors to a number of major investors in the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Corporation of America, filed a $16-million counterclaim yesterday in United States District Court here against Salomon Brothers, the Wall Street investment-banking house.

A jury of nine women and three men in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday heard how Garrett B. Trapnell, a confessed hijacker, had been induced to permit 93 passengers of a Trans World Airlines jet to debark at Kennedy International Airport.

A young woman injured in an automobile accident in 1969 testified before the State Commission of Investigation today that she had been referred to a physician who "treated" her six times by putting her in a closet with a heat lamp and dark glasses and then billed her law firm for 39 treatments.
Improbably, yet irresistibly, the Chicago Black Hawks kept hockey's longest season alive tonight with an 8-7 victory over the mighty Canadiens.

American industry is embarked upon a huge capital spending boom. The latest McGraw-Hill survey reports companies are planning to increase their outlays on new plant and equipment by $17-billion this year to a total of $105.5-billion
A compromise agreement was reached today that is expected to clear the way for passage if legislation to control development of the 3.7 million acres of private land in the Adironlack Park.

Charles W. Colson, the former White House aide whose name has increasingly been linked to the Watergate-Pentagon papers case, played a behind-the-scenes role in Administration efforts to defeat a key Democratic Senator during the 1970 elections.

The Senate Watergate committee announced today that it would begin public hearings on May 17 and would move to compel testimony by John W. Dean 3d, the deposed White House coun sel, by granting him immunity from prosecution.

Senator William Proxmire took to the floor of the Senate today to denounce the press for being "grossly unfair" to President Nixon, only a day after he had told a friend that he believed the President was "involved in Watergate up to his ears."

Mrs. Marguerite Wales Norton, who was general director of nurses of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, now the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, from 1923 to 1936, died Tuesday in Joshua Tree, Calif.
Algoma Steel Corporation, Ltd., announced yesterday that it would raise structural steel prices by $5 a ton beginning June 1. The company, a major Canadian producer of structural steel,
A series of crew errors led to the crash of a British airliner with the loss of 118 lives near London last June, according to the findings of a court of inquiry published today.

Spending on television and radio advertising in the 1972 election campaign increased hardly at all from 1968, largely because a new law forced broadcasters to charge their lowest rate for political ads last year, the Federal Communications Commission reported today.
Thirteen states have enacted laws to bring back the death penalty and measures reinstating capital punishment are awaiting action by the Governors of two other states.

Four Justice Department officials, including Henry E. Petersen, an Assistant Attorney General, swore today that they did not know about the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist until April 16 this year.

The House voted overwhelmingly today to prohibit mutual savings banks from opening interest-bearing checking accounts. The House vote, if upheld by the Senate, would force banks in Massachusetts and New Hampshire to abandon their negotiable order of withdrawal (NOW) accounts and would prohibit mutual savings banks in other states from opening any NOW accounts.

An indictment is expected here today against former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans and Robert L. Vesco, a missing financier, according to sources close: to the investigation.

A Nixon Administration official told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that despite the Vietnam and Laos cease-fires, 15,000 to 20,000 Thai "irregular" troops-financed by the United Stateswere now based in Laos.

Three judges and a successful trial lawyer are campaigning for the privilege of running on the Democratic ticket for the highest judicial post in the state - chief judge of the Court of Appeals-in the first primary race for the office since 1916.

Branding Governor Rockefeller's new narcotics law as "cruel" and "regressive," the Lindsay administration predicted yesterday that it would cost the courts in the city an additional $127-million in the first year and said it would promptly ask the state to appropriate that amount.
The United States dollar fell sharply on Europe's main money markets today and the price of free-market gold rose to new highs. The main factors behind the dollar's decline, dealers said,
The Senate voted today to reduce the terms of members of the Board of Regents from 15 years to seven. Present board members would be affected by the change.

President Nguyen Van Thieu is giving "favorable" consideration to a petition from Tran Ngoc Chau, a former member of the National Assembly and respected friend of many American officials, re questing that he not be released to the Communists, along with other civilian prisoners, a Government spokesman said today. .

Noel A. Rhys, executive vice president of the Keystone Broadcasting System, which includes radio stations in many parts of the country, died yesterday in Knickerbocker. Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 350 East 52d Street.

Half the reporting staff was dismissed last week. The current season, set to end next week, has been cut short by a couple of weeks. And the budget remains an object for juggling. But "The 51st State" has been committed to another season by the management of WNET/13.

Alarmed at the growing resort to weapons by criminals, the British Government today proposed a series of measures including tight curbs on shotguns and a ban on all mail-order sales of firearms and ammunition.
A stronger stand against violators of inside information regulations of the securities laws was promised yesterday by G. Bradford Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Rod Laver survived a shaky start and defeated his fellow Australian Roy Emerson, 7-5, 6-2, 7-5, in the opening match of, the $100,000 World Championship of Tennis circuit finals tonight.

James T. Flexner, whose four-volume biography of George Washington won a Pulitzer Prize this week, happened to pass through the mall of the Graduate Center of the City University of New York yesterday. He stopped to listen to one of four special noontime fund-raising concerts sponsored by the Bowery Savings Bank on behalf of the Research Library of the New York Public Library.

H. Rap Brown was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison for his role in the armed robbery of a West Side bar and a gun battle with the police a year and a half ago. He could have drawn 25 years.
Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally said today that President Nixon had not offered him a post in Washington, but he indicated that he might accept a position if requested by the President.

An offering of 110,000 shares of the Combanks Corporation common stock at $32 a share was made yesterday by underwriters managed by Dean Witter Co. The company's stock, traded overthe-counter, closed at 32 bid, up 1/2 from the previous bid price.
Nobody's talking much about the drop in hemlines for fall. Victor Joris showed some calf-length styles in his collection for Cuddlecoat. And now Ralph Lauren shows some for Polo.

MINNEAPOLIS--The damage of the Watergate affair is done. Under the circumstances the best the President could do was assign the responsibility for uncovering the truth to Elliot Richardson. A loyal and committed Nixon partisan, the new Attorney General is a man of unquestioned integrity, intelligence and ability. He is the right man for the job.
To the Editor: The Administration's handling of the Watergate affair does nothing to challenge the general belief that governments do a poor job of policing themselves.

Negotiations on the price of crude oil between Western oil companies and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries ended today in failure, an OPEC statement said. The statement said the'OPEC negotiating team had called special meeting of the 11-member organization for May 21 in Vienna to discuss the talks.

Total loans of the 4,614 national banks rose 18.7 per cent to a record $230.46-billion at the end of 1972, the Office of the Controller of the Currency reported. Total capital accounts of $30.35-million were 12.1 per cent higher than the year-earlier figure.
Mayor Lindsay told Russians today that they had a "beautiful and remarkable country" and should stop being afraid of foreigners.
The New York Mets lost Jon Matlack yesterday for an indefinite time, but they apparently regained Jerry Koosman-who stopped the Atlanta Braves, 8-1, on five hits last night in Shea Stadium.

The Media Access Project, a publicinterest law group, has written to each of the three major networks demanding information on how much if anything, the networks have broadcast concerning current controversies over children's programs and advertising aimed at children.

Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz told the House Ways and Means Committee today that the forthcoming trade negotiations with other leading nations probably should not be "reciprocal," adding that "there may have to be more giving than taking as far as other people are concerned."

A Newark law firm that has sued to halt an inquiry by the State Commission of Investigation into alleged fraud and misconduct in workmen's compensation cases was linked by an agency investigator today with a physician accused of padding bills and altering medical records.
The Yankees bade good-by to the Minnesota Twins with mixed emotions tonight. They were happy to be going home, but they were sad because they 'wouldn't see the Twins again until July 6.

General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, the country's only living five-star officer and one of the last surviving and most honored heroes of World War II, today received the honor he said he prized "above all others"

A six-point program to deal with an "alarming growth" in the abuse of such prescription drugs as barbiturates, sedatives and tranquilizers was announced yesterday by Gordon Chase, head of the city's Health Services Administration. "While we've seen evidence of a decline in heroin

The medical director and three other officials of Meadowview Hospital in Hudson County were indicted today on charges of having conspired to permit the morgue custodian to collect payments for burials he did not perform.

Mrs. Miles Valentine's 4-year old gelding, Babamist, raced to victory today in the feature hurdles race as Fair Hill opened a two-day spring meeting. The event is the only hunt meeting with pari-mutuel betting.

The rape and robbery of Dominican nun Tuesday night in Brooklyn was disclosed yesterday by the police. Detectives said that the nun, who is 38 years old, had been wearing secular garb, as permitted by her order.

The head of the New York Stock Exchange urged the Financial Analysts Federation today to adopt "severe" disciplinary sanctions against members who advise investor clients on the basis of inside information.
The Northrop Corporation received a $50.7-million addition to a previously awarded Air Force contract for F5E aircraft and support equipment for sale to foreign allies, it was announced yesterday.

The head of the Central Intelligence Agency said today that the agency had been "insufficiently cautious" in providing materials to a White House aide involved in the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.
President Nixon assured Republican leaders and contributors tonight that his appointees would "get to the bottom of this very deplorable"

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market lost earlier gains and finished lower yesterday. The lists opened higher and remained that way until about 2 P.M. when selling pressure increased.

The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation is "going slow" on liquefied natural gas and synthetic natural gas projects because they are "too risky at this stage," W. M. Elmer, chairman, told about 70 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at 20 Pine Street.

Earnings of the nation's 10 domestic trunklines-the major carriers-should rise this year to about $250-million from the 1972 level of $215-million, according to George W. James, senior vice president economics and finance of the Air Transport Association.

Soybean futures prices reached new highs on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.. The prices of the May soybean option rose 57 cents a bushel to $9.05 and that for Mivay soybean meal futures broke the $30d-a-ton mark for the first time ever, closing at $305 a ton. In sympathy, prices of soybean oil also rose but their increases were only in fractions of a cent a pound.

The medical director and three other officials of Meadowview Hospital in Hudson County were indicted today on charges of having conspired to permit the morgue custodian to collect payments for burials he did not perform.
The Illinois Department of insurance expects to know by July 1 how many of the Equity Funding Life Insurance company's policies are bogus, Fred A. Mauck, director of the agency, said today.

The Senate Agriculture Committee, rejecting Nixon Administration demands, approved today a farm bill providing a subsidy mechanism designed to main. tain farmer's incomes at levels close to the record set last year.

A merchant marine officer, Stanley Novak, lost his pants, and as a result the New York State Legislature recently passed a new banking law, effective immediately. It protects savings-account depositors more effectively against forgery.

" I'm out to prove that a guy 55 years old, with one foot in the grave, can play with the best woman in the world and maybe beat her," said Bobby Riggs as he prepared for his two-of-three set, winner-take-all $10,000 tennis match on Sunday with Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia in Ramona, Calif.

Senate and Federal investigators say that, on the basis of extended interviews with John W. Dean 3d, they believe he has no evidence to link President Nixon either to prior knowledge of the Watergate bugging or to any subsequent cover-up, reliable sources said today.

Today's schedule of Bronx Week events includes the following; A street festival with a parade and music at Crames Square Park, Hunts Point and Bruckner Boulevard, noon to 4.P.M.
North and Scuth Korea opened the sixth session of heir Red Cross talks here tolay in an attempt to break a deadlock over basic principles in arranging family contacts between the two Koreas.
Elliot L. Richardson told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that, if he became Attorney General, he would maintain "ultimate responsibility" for the Watergate investigation and prosecution.

An indictment is expected here today against former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans and Robert L. Vesco, a missing financier, according to sources close to the investigation.
Tentam of the Cragwood Stable won the $27,850 Toboggan Handicap at foggy Aque. duct yesterday, to the satisfaction of the form players in the crowd of 17,163 as well as to his rider, Jorge Velasquez.

In the seven previous seasons Johnny Bench has worn the uniform of the Cincinnati Reds, he has garnered one superlative after another. He has been' the National League's All-Star Game catcher four times.

The Board of Education was criticized caustically yesterday by the Health and Education Committee of the City Council for what the committee said was "inaction" that contributed "to the increase in school crime."

The Mets and Yankees will hold their annual reunion for the Mayor's Trophy and for sandlot baseball tonight at Shea Stadium. It will be the 11th game in the series, which the Yankees have deadlocked at five apiece bI winning the last three.

Richardson hearing: On the first day of confirmation hearings, Attorney General-designate Elliot L. Richardson told the Senate Judiciary Committee that although he planned to delegate considerable authority to a special Watergate prosecutor for whom he had begun a search, he would maintain "ultimate responsibility." His' position was challenged amid indications his confirmation was in doubt.

The Chicago Board Options Exchange reported yesterday that a record volume of 2,153 contracts of 100 shares each were traded. Some 500 contracts of 100 shares each were traded. Some 500 contracts changed hands in the first hour, a spokesman added.
The Mexican police held five men in Guadalajara today in connection with the kidnapping of the United States Consul General, Terrance G. Leonhardy, authorities said here.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art's "Odalisque" painting by Ingres, which stirred a controversy last January when it was believed that the museum had secretly sold the canvas, went back on display in Gallery 16 of the museum on Monday.

The City Housing Authority said yesterday that an investigation had been begun into allegations that painting companies working under contract to the authority had withheld sizable contributions they were required to make to the painters' union welfare fund.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters presented today a contract proposal calling for wage increases totaling $1.50 an hour over the next three years, an increase of about 8 per cent a year, union and industry sources said. Substan.
Clayton Snyder, who at the age of 94 continued to maintain his membership in the New York Stock Exchange, died Sunday at his home, 830 Park Avenue.
The original arrests in the Watergate break-in occurred on June 17, 1972. Two weeks later, to the day, John Mitchell resigned as manager of President Nixon's re-election campaign.
F.T.D., which used to be the Florists' Telegraph Delivery Association, has become Florists Transworld Delivery because the 13,000 members now telephone their orders to each other.
A Republican booster club barred two reporters from its meeting today on the ground that their presence would inhibit questions the members wanted to ask Governor Cahill, the organization's guest.

A 42-year-old deaf man lost his memory and his ability to speak when he was mugged on wandering through the Bronx Sunday and had apparently been for more than three days before he was brought into a hospital by a friend last night, hospital officials reported.
A heavily armed force of Palestinian guerrillas has crossed from Syria into the mountainous Rasheiya region of southeastern Lebanon and set up gun emplacements commanding a main highway.

Anthony M. Mauro, suspended president of the Uniformed Bridge and Tunnel Officers, announced yesterday that 420 of the.482 Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority Employes he represented had quit the union and designated him as their choice for bargaining agent.

" We have had our differences in the past, and I hope you give me hell every time you think I'm wrong. I hope I'm worthy of your trust," President Nixon told a few members of the White House press corps after he concluded his Watergate speech.

Another bizarre instance of what can happen when man disturbs nature's delicate checks and balances involves the gecko, a nearly transparent little lizard of tropical Asia. In an effort to eradicate malaria in the jungle village of Malaysin in Borneo,

Ray Leonard of Washington and Dale Grant of Tacoma, Wash., a couple of 17-year-old national Golden Gloves champions, posted impressive victories today at the 85th National Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships.

The Assembly passed last week a regressive little bill that would cripple efforts to expand voter registration in New York City. Three of the city's boroughs now have such poor voter participation as to be technically subject to provisions of Federal voting laws designed to prevent discrimination against minority groups in the Deep South.

A Newark law firm that has sued to halt an inquiry by the State Commission of Investigation into alleged fraud and misconduct in workmen's compensation cases was linked by an agency investigator today with a physician accused of padding bills and altering medical records.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans are expected to be indicted today in connection with a secret $200,000 conrtribution to President Nixon's 1972 campaign, sources close to the investigation said yesterday.
Unknown to Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson, the Army has ordered several thousand new nuclear shells for its large cannons in Europe.

Governor Rockefeller proposed today that the state take over 90 per cent of New York City's local sales tax as well as all of its stocktransfer tax, as a means of financing the proposed assumption by the state of welfare and Medicaid administration.

The extent to which improvisation has returned to serious music, after an eclipse that lasted about a century, was demonstrated in an odd way on Tuesday night when Composers Theater began its fourth annual May Festival of Contemporary American Music at the New School.

Rainer Barzel resigned today as the Opposition leader in Parliament after a majority of his followers rejected his strategy for opposing ratification of the treaty to establish formal relations between the two Germanys.

David L. Benstock, board chairman of the Superior Surgical Manufacturing Company, Inc., of Huntington, L. I., a manufacturer of hospital uni- cc forms and allied products, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Miami Beach on Wednesday.

Badger-dog history was made last Friday when the Dachshund Club of New Jersey held its specialty at the Holiday Inn in Bordentown. It was the club's first independent show since it was organized 30 years ago by 10 fanciers.

In an unrelated case yesterday, Nguyen Tan Doi, another member of the National Assembly and the head of South Vietnam's largest bank, was sent to prison despite his immunity because of charges that he had embezzled millions of dollars in investors' funds.
The City administration is receiving assistance from art experts in Florida and New York in its efforts to authenticate paintings in the controversial John Bass Art Museum which it closed last week.

Bond prices worKed a bit higher on balance yesterday for the second consecutive session, aided by some easier money rates and strong demand for $2-billion of Federal agency financing to be formally offered this morning to yield 7.05 per cent.

A consumer advocacy group petitioned the Food and Drug Administration today to revise its regulations on drug testing to prevent potentially dangerous drugs from being given to humans before animal safety testing is complete.

The Grumman Corporation reported today net operating aernings for the first quarter nearly one third higher than for the comparable quarter a year ago. Thus reflecting a more than $30-million increase in sales and a greater contribution to that figure by the company's non-aerospace business.

The Health Department has named 11 more fodd-processing establishments as second offenders against the health code. If a third inspection later this month finds the violations still uncorrected, closing orders could result.

Mayor Paul T. Jordan's overwhelming victory in yesterday's city election was viewed by political leaders here today as proof of a lasting desire for reform by city voters and as projecting the new county Democratic Coalition into a potent force in state party councils.
Governor Rockefeller joined other Republican Governors here yesterday in saying that Republicans in general would not or should not be considered guilty of the Watergate scandal.

In an early-morning blitzkrieg, burglars broke into the loft of a Canal Street diamond merchant yesterday, dragged a 4,000-pound safe across the room and slammed it through a window and the surrounding

Senate and Federal investigators say that, on the basis of extended interviews which John W. Dean 3d, they believe he has no evidence to link President Nixon either to prior knowledge of the Watergate bugging or to any subsequent cover-up, reliable sources said today.

The Soviet Union, making judicious use of fouls under international rules, defeated the United States, 72-64, tonight in a rough-and-tumble finale of its six-game series. The United States won four of the six games in the American tour.

The general court-martial of S Sgt. John D. Layton, a drill instructor accused of mistreating a trainee who died shortly afterward, began here today when two soldiers testified thai they saw the sergeant kick the trainee after he had collapsed.

The Agriculture Department has ordered the dismissal of about 3,000 employes of state and county farm programs in a cutback caused mainly by elimination of a popular conservation subsidy program, officials confirmed today.

Court approval of a new rule requiring druggists to keep medical profiles of their customers was described as a great victory today by Millicent H. Fenwick, director of the state's Division of Consumer Affairs.
A 24-hour search at Elmira State Correctional Facility turned up 170 handmade weapons and 700 items of contraband including whisky, officials said today.

The New York City Ballet has announced that its two premieres of the season will be "Cortege Hongrois," set to Glazunov music by George Balanchine, on May 17, and "An Evening's Waltzes," to five Prokofiev waltzes, by Jerome Robbins, on May 24.

In an early-morning blitzkrieg, burglars broke into the loft of a Canal Street diamond merchant yesterday, dragged a 4,000-pound safe across the room and slammed it through a window and the surrounding brick wall to the street 20 feet below.

Not enough has ever been said about sunset in the city. Little enough has been said about sunrise, either; few are up to see the sun rise except in the dead of winter. But sunset is there, visible, sometimes insistent, every day of the year. Just turn your head and look down the street or across the roofs to the west, and there it is, over there beyond the river, beyond the Jersey shore,
The blackbirds were back in Wounded Knee today, singing in the grass. The bunkers were bulldozed over. The prairie winds were smoothing down the dusty soil over a new grave up on the hill.

" I'm out to prove that a guy 55 years old, with one foot in the grave, can play with the best woman in the world and maybe beat her," said Bobby Riggs as he prepared for his two-of-three set, winner-take-all $10,000 tennis match on Sunday with Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia in Ramona, Calif.

Willis B. Boyer, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, was named chairman yesterday and William J. De Lancey, executive vice president, succeeded him as president. The appointment of Mr. Boyer, who is 58, fills a post vacant since Thomas Patton retired as chairman in 1971.

The overwhelming support that voters in Jersey City have given their young reform mayor, Paul T. Jordan, signals an important turn in political outlook for the whole Garden State. A bastion of corruption and reaction for years, the "old" Jersey City was the home of the Hague and Kenny machines which controlled Hudson County and extended their influence into statewide political activities.
A heavily armed force of Palestinian guerrillas has crossed from Syria into the mountainous Rasheiya region of southeastern Lebanon and set up gun emplacements commanding a main highway.

There are two works that have for years and years dominated the repertory of the Alvin Ailey Dance Company -- "Revelations" and "Blues Suite." It is rare, indeed, to find an Ailey program without one of them on the bill, and quite often both are in attendance.

Residents of the Bronx, celebrating their borough as the center of a many-sidedculture, learned last night that the area was a center of succeeding rich cultures long before Europeans opened it up to modern settlement.

For 17 of his 43 years, Robert Deal started - and ended - each day with bad stuff: narcotics. But for the last year, he has made it possible for a growing number of people, mostly in the Greater Los Angeles area,
Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal charged yesterday that Controller Abraham D. Beame lacked the energy and stamina "absolutely necessary to survive as Mayor."
The Ralston Purina Company said today that all tests it had conducted on i s Chicken of the Sea tuna indicated the tuna had no connection with the death of an Illinois woman last Thursday.

Rainer Barzel's fate as leader of the Christian Democratic Union and candidate for West German Chancellor was probably sealed last November when Willy Brandt's coalition of Social and Free Democrats won an unexpectedly decisive election victory. Though Mr. Barzel was later re-elected leader of the Christian Union opposition in the Bundestag, his displacement well in advance of the next federal election was regarded as inevitable.
The Army said today it would investigate charges that Gen. William C. Westmoreland and other high Army officers had sought to cover up frauds committed in South Vietnam.

Voters rejected a property tax proposal here yesterday for operation of this city's public schools, 53,456 to 25,395. The two-year levy would have been $4.80 per $100,000 assessed value of real estate and had been expected to yield a total of $18.7-million.

The Duke Power Company, which operates in the Piedmont section of North and South Carolina, where the textile industry is the dominant business, realized a 37.8 per cent increase in earnings on a revenue gain of 23 per cent in the first quarter this year, it was reported yesterday.

Neil Hellman said today there was a possibility he would enter Linda's Chief in the Preakness on May 19 as a challenge to Secretariat's bid for the second leg of the Triple Crown. Linda's Chief suffered a foot bruise while winning the California Derby, but the bruise has healed, Hellman said by phone from Miami.
