Cornmunist forces have launched attacks along two major highways and infiltrated a string of villages northeast of Phnom Penh, shifting the emphasis of their offensive well away from the Cambodian capital, military sources said today.

Henry Kissinger today concluded four days of intensive private talks with the Soviet leadership with the surprise assertion that the date for the visit to the United States of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the party leader, had not yet been set.
North Vietnam today broadcast its first posttruce charge that Americans had tortured Communist prisoners, alleging atrocities that ranged from "brutal beatings" to "surgical experiments."

With winners announced in all but one of the 32 districts, the May 1 local school-board elections show a weak voter turnout-about 11 per cent of the 3.5 million eligible voters--and a large measure of success by candidates backed by the United Federation of Teachers or by parents' groups, or both.
United States Savings Bond are tailor-made for people who find it difficult to save money.

Four mayoral candidates and most of the other primary aspirants for citywide office answered questions last night at a forum focused on what the sponsors, the Manhattan Women's Political Caucus, defined as the city's "crisis areas for women"-employment discrimnation, child care and welfare.
Stocks of big worldwide oil companies declined sharply late yesterday after their negotiations in Libya with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were reported to have ended in failure.

" Who knows what will happen Thursday night?" asked Stan Mikita, savoring the question. It was a fair query. For last night in Montreal the Chicago Black Hawks remained alive in the Stanley Cup finals by outlasting the Canadiens, 8-7,

The Cost of Living Council has drafted a proposed corporate disclosure regulation that would effectively defeat the intent of controversial legislation enacted by Congress last week. The agency expects to make the draft regulation public tomorrow.

As the United States Army in Europe tries to rebuild itself after years of neglect during the Vietnam war, its biggest problem is still morale. To the long-standing irritants of drug abuse and racial tension a new problem has been added-devalued dollars that do not go far in the inflated West German economy.
A high-ranking official of the American Psychiatric Association urged the organization today to stop labeling homosexuality as a mental illness.

A former White House aide, Egil Krogh Jr., resigned today as Under Secretary of Transportation, saying that his "overriding desire" was "to accept full responsibility for my acts and decisions and to assist in bringing all the facts and circumstances into the open."

The New York State Banking Board, acting on the recommendation of Harry W. Albright Jr., the Superintendent of Banks denied yesterday the application of Barclays Bank, Ltd., of London to acquire the $508-million Long Island Trust Company of Garden City.
The Food and Drug Administration proposed today the first Federal bicycle safety standards designed to reduce the annual average of 800 deaths resulting from an estimated one million accidents.
Milton Gross, the nationally syndicated sports columnist of The New York Post, died today at Mercy Hospital of cardiac arrest. He was 61 years old and lived at 410 Westminster Road.

The board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting elected Dr. James Killian Jr. its new chairman yesterday and proposed what he called a fourpoint "declaration of peace" with the Public Broadcasting Service.

Proposals now awaiting action in Albany to boost the salaries of members of the State Legislature are excessive under present conditions and should be scaled down sharply. For what is essentially a part-time job, the lawmakers now receive a basic annual salary of $15,000 plus $5,000 in expense allotments for which no accounting is required, plus additional amounts ranging from $1,500 to $21,000 if they hold certain committee or leadership positions.

Senator Walter F. Mondale de nounced today a plan for al overhaul of the Congressiona spending system, contending that it would turn most Sena tors and Representatives into mere "petitioners" on moneJ matters.

Senate Democrats unanimous ly adopted today a policy resolution calling for public financling of all Federal elections. Sponsors of the resolution said that they intended it to bar any private campaign do nations of more than $500 to candidates for either the Presi dency or seats in the Senate and House of Representatives.
President Nixon assured Republican leaders and contributors tonight that his appointees would "get to the bottom of this very deplorable" Watergate

George M. Steinbrenner 3d, who has avoided discussing the Michael Burke situation in the Yankee front office ever since Burke resigned as chief executive officer April 29, now says Burke is remaining with the club in a public relations role.

With winners announced in all but one of the 32 districts, the May 1 local school-board elections in New York City showed a weak voter turnout of about 11 per cent of the 3.5 million eligible voters and a large measure of success by candidates backed by the United Federation of Teachers or parents' groups, or both.

Governor Cahill urged municipalities and property owners yesterday to purchase special flood insurance to protect themselves against a severe threat of flooding in New Jersey. "Abnormally heavy rainfall throughout our state over the past 12 months has filled our lakes and reservoirs, saturated our soil and raised ground water tables to an all-time high," Mr. Cahill said.

" The Agency shall have no police, subpoena, lawenforcement powers, or internal-security functions," states the National Security Act of 1947 creating the nation's Central Intelligence institutions. Scarcely having lived down the unsavory image of running an "invisible government," officials of the Central Intelligence Agency have now allowed the organization to be used as a sort of secret police for the Nixon Administration.

After more than a day of silence, the White House sought today to put down reports that President Nixon had tried to prevent the Justice Department from providing to the Pentagon-papers trial in Los Angeles information on the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.
Australia and New Zealand instituted legal proceedings at the World Court today against France's planned nuclear tests in the South Pacific.

The Very Rev. Donald M. O'Callaghan, father provincial from 1955 to 1961 of the local Camelite community and for 12 years the director of Carmelite foreign missions, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home,
The General Electric Company's way of marketing household light bulbs, a method head that survived two antitrust challenges in the past, was held yesterday to violate the Sherman Antitrust Act.

Bennie G. Thompson, a social worker, was elected in yesterday's primary Mississippi's second black Mayor of a biracial community. Blacks als won all five spots on the Board of Aldermen and the City Clerk's office.

Following is the text of a letter of resignation submitted this morning to President Nixon by Egil Krogh Jr., Under Secretary of Transportation and former White House aide who has become implicated in the 1971 burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist:
An administrative law judge of the Federal Trade Commission ruled today that the Standard Oil Company of California had not falsely advertised its gasoline additive, F-310.
A three-year labor agreement reached yesterday between Rheingold Breweries, Inc., and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Locals 3 and 46 calls for no increase in the wage rate.

The trial of a class action suit against the General Electric Company on behalf of all its female workers has been set for July 24. The suit seeks to have the company extend sickness insurance payments to cover Dregnancies.

Like almonds and raisins, ironies and hypocrisies go well with each other. The most obvious hypocrisy .in the Watergate case is that men who have preached "law and order" appear to have broken the law.

Eugene O'Neill, the playwright, hired his literary agent over a meal at a Greenwich Village restaurant, Christine's, in 1919, and the man went home and told his wife, "I saw this gentle, clear-eyed man and I fell in love with him."

The Eastern College Athletic Conference and the National Collegiate Athletic Association modified their stand yesterday against two track athletes who competed for the United Statets against the Soviet Union last March 16.

Col. Edmund B. Edmondson, the retired Air Force officer who directs the United States Chess Federation, firmly believes that, had Bobby Fischer never learned chess, he would have been world champion of something else.
Lieut. Comdr. Earl R. Miller, U.S.N., retired, who was a bodyguard to Alfred E. Smith and Franklin D. Roosevelt when they were Governors of New York, died here last Wednesday. He was 75 years old.
When 49 youngsters filed into the Goddard-Riverside Community Center the other morning, not one knew what printmaking was. One hour later, all held up their completed vivid purple prints.

A Nixon Administration official told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that despite the Vietnam and Laos cease-fires, 15,000 to 20,000 Thai regular" troops--financed by the United Stateswere now based in Laos.

The Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs warned today of a new illegally produced amphetamine that has caused at least 18 deaths since it first appeared in Canada and the United States a month ago.

The management of Forest Hills Gardens, an affluent residential community in Queens, was charged yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz with chargoing excessive fees for cars towed away from private property.

One expression that athletes favor for explaining spectacular performances is this: "My hands felt thin." Although golfers use it more often than most of the others, it is meant to denote an extra-sensitivity of touch that also applies to manipulating a basketball, handling a football, throwing a baseball, swinging a bat or stroking a tennis racquet.

The head of the Central Intelligence Agency said today that the agency had been "insufficiently cautious" in providing materials to a White House aide involved in the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

A staff report prepared for the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City says the panel has received suggestions from some commissions, civic organizations and study groups that the Controller's term of office differs from the Mayor's.

Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the International Telephone- and Telegraph Corporation, was [sharply attacked here today by stockholders questioning the company's use of its power and influence in the United States and overseas.

A Federal grand jury in Philadelphia is investigating Justice Department charges that several major stores in New York, Philadelphia and other cities conspired to fix prices on women's dresses and other apparel items.
Three leaders of major American Jewish organizations Expressed general agreement today that the needs and demands of youths must be the top priority of all Jewish communnal agencies.
A Penn Central commuter train was derailed at Topstone Curve near here today, killing one man and injuring three others. Only 10 passengers were aboard the 10-car train.

In an unusual ruling in which a jurist sharply criticized a state law while invoking its provisions, Judge Joseph J. Kunzeman of the State Supreme Court in Queens County yesterday levied a total fine of $250 against the Jamaica Gas and Electric Company of Great Neck, L.I., for violations of the state's Feld-Crawford fair-trade law.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that he had received so little cooperation from major oil companies in his investigation into gasoline shortages that he might be forced to subpoena

Court approval of a new rule requiring druggists to keep medical profiles of their customers was described as a great victory today by Millicent H. Fenwick, director of the state's Division of Consumer Affairs.

To start off its final week at the Alvin Theater, the Martha Graham Dance Company presented Mary Hinkson on Tuesday night in her first appearance as Medea in "Cave of the Heart," Miss Graham's well-known study of jealousy in the guise of Greek myth.
About 7 o'clock every night this week, 23-year-old Jim Schmitt of East Sayville, L. I., will start gathering rosebuds--perhaps 60,000 of them, in all colors and stemlengths, and crated with ice.
Wellington Associates announced yesterday it was offering to purchase for cash up to. one million common shares of the Sonesta International Hotels Corporation at $7 net a share.

Associate Justice Potter Stewart of the Supreme Court credited today the "dedication and persistence" of two newspaper reporters in bringing to light aspects of the Watergate scandal.
Unknown to Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson, the Army has ordered several thousand new nuclear shells for its large cannons in Europe.

Boxing, one of the reasons there are more television sets than bathtubs in the United States, returns to the tube nationally on a weekly basis this summer-July 7 through Sept. --over the American Broadcasting Company, it was announced yesterday.

Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, today asked Graham A. Martin, former Ambassador to Italy, whether he had recommended the use of secret United States Government funds to influence Italian politics.
The Vietcong proposed today a three-point plan for a new cease-fire to put an end to the fighting throughout South Vietnam. It was immediately rejected by Saigon.
The Securities Industries Association said today that most brokerage firms that favor an increase in commission rates believe, however, that fees should not be raised on trades under $5,000.
Three persons in 10 are less likely than before to vote for Republican candidates in the 1974 Congressional election because of the Watergate conspiracy case, the Gallup Poll reported today.
Despite cumbersome and time-consuming procedures, the process of declassifying millions of secret Government papers is proceeding on schedule, the project supervisor said today.

The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization voted today to give Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers $1.6-million over the next three months.

Even having attended American Youth Performs concerts in past years and knowing what remarkable standards these high school musicians achieve, it came as a fresh surprise to hear such an astounding display of professionalism.

After breaking a month-long filibuster, the Senate passed day and sent to the House a bill that would allow eligible voters in Presidential and Congressional elections to register simply by filling out and mailing a postcard form.

Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, has left the law firm of Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton Garrison "to devote all my time to matters that I thought were important, and that's a little incompatible with the general practice of law."
The film "Hitler: The Last Ten Days," was banned by one of Britain's biggest movie chains today because its chairman considered it too sympathetic to the Nazi leader.

Carnegie Lake, which is owned by Princeton University, should soon be the center of intercollegiate and international rowing for the East Coast, according to Peter Sparhawk, the Princeton rowing coach. Princeton ,crew alumni have raised money to construct a permanently buoyed Olympic race course on the lake.

A new and significant idea in the presentation of exhibition matches was introduced into this hemisphere here Monday by the Mexican Bridge Federation, and is likely to find imitators in the United States.

One more victory is all the New York Knicks need to win the National Basketball Association championship and to overcome finally the effects of a shock they suffered two years three Weeks ago.
Elliot L. Richardson told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that, if he became Attorney General, he would maintain "ultimate responsibility" for the Watergate investigation and prosecution.
The sky is wide and high over Teapot Dome, a rolling, even choppy, stretch of brown prairie about five miles south of the twin hamlets of Midwest and Edgerton in northeastern Wyoming.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday appointed Michael F. Armstrong, the former counsel of the Knapp Commission, as the new District Attorney of Queens.

Jack E. Leonard whose trademark as a nightclub comedian was the one-line insult, died yesterday of diabetic complications. He was 62 years old and had been hospitalized since he collapsed last March while doing a show at the Rainbow Grill.

The jockey room at Aqueduct yesterday was a happy place after the second race. Lee Moon, a cheerful, animated 26-year-old jockey of JapaneseKorean extraction, had just scored the first victory of his Career.

"I don't want to be typed as a jazz musician anymore--my music is my music," Herbie Mann said the other day. Being classified as a jazzman, he explained, seems to turn off many potential listeners, thus limiting his exposure.
The Senate confirmed today the nomination of former Representative Howard H. Calla, way of Georgia as Secretary of the Army, succeeding Robert F. Froehlke, who resigned.

Egil Krogh Jr., the Nixon Administration official who has resigned in the WatergatePentagon papers scandal, once threatened to "destroy" anyone who opposed President Nixon's policies, according to a prominent physician.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and five of his neighbors have 20 days to appeal a court decision allowing two Marlboro developers to subdivide land on Squaw Island off Cape Cod, where the Senator maintains a summer home.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).
The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission told the mutual-fund industry today that the agency was considering a number of proposals that would make it easier to sell mutual funds.

William Egan Colby, named today as the new chief of the Central Intelligence Agency, is one of the few professionals to rise to the top of a major Government department: He is a career clandestine operative.
Multiple sclerosis is called the "great crippler," usually afflicting those between the the ages of 20 and 40, still in the prime of career and family building.

Eldredge Co., Inc., municipal bond dealer, announced last night that it would file a petition under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Law in United States Federal District Court here and that it temporarily halted its business activities.

The Mets and the Yankees took time out from their other problems last night to stage their 11th annual game for the Mayor's Trophy and the Mets won it, 8-4, with five runs in the second inning.

Representative Herman Badillo was endorsed for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday by The New York Amsterdam News, the black weekly, and said that he believed the backing would turn out to be the first of a series of endorsements of him in the black community.

Frank Berle, from 1930 to 1965 personal manager and road manager for his brother Milton Berle, the comedian, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 27 West 72d Street.

As part of a broad investigation into the city's criminal justice system, the State Commission of Investigation has been examining the extent to which Richard R. Aurelio has played a part in the selection of city judges since he left his job as Deputy Mayor in November, 1971, according to sources close to the investigation.

One of the most superb impressions of a Rembrandt print, "The Agony in the Garden," brought a stellar price of $70,000 yesterday in a sale of Old Master prints at Sotheby Park Bernet, 980 Madison Avenue.

Most players are rather too cautious in attempting grand-slam contracts. They feel that a seven-bid should be attempted only if it appears to be a near-certainty. This is a sensible policy for a beginner, whose judgment of partnership assets is likely to be shaky, but not for an experienced player.

Retail sales declined slightly in April but remained far above the same month a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported today. Based on preliminary figures, April sales were put at $41.33-billion,

Steve Dunning got his wish and the Cleveland Indians added an experienced right-handed pitcher today in a trade that sent Dunning to the Texas Rangers for Dick Bosman and a minor league outfielder, Ted Ford.
Bruce Crampton of Australia scrambled to a four-under-par 6 and a two-stroke lead today in the first round of the $150,000 Colonial invitation golf tournament.
Roberta Albers scored a holein-one on the 17th hole today at Pine Ridge Golf Course during the pro-amateur round of the Lady Carling open.

A special Federal grand jury yesterday indicted John N. Mitchell, former United States Attorney General; Maurice H. Stans, former Secretary of Commerce; Harry L. Sears, former majority leader of the New Jersey Senate, and Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier.
The Alabama Legis lature, under the last of several Federal court ultimatums, has passed a reapportionment bill today and sent it to Gov. George C. Wallace for his signature.

The first American to manage a British symphony orchestra, Harold Lawrence, is returning home to be manager of the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Lawrence, who has been manager of the London Symphony Orchestra since 1967, is expected to take his new post at the Philharmonic in the fall. He is succeeding Helen M. Thompson as manager.

The full-scale United States bombing in Cambodia is being conducted with the assistance of the American Embassy in Phnom Penh under circumstances that raise questions about the safeguards against striking civilian targets and about possible violations of the Congressional act under which the embassy functions.
The four United States auto companies said today that they would not appeal the Government's controversial interim pollution control standards for 1975 cars.

Governor Rockefeller, with Governor Cahill of New Jersey at his side, signed legislation yesterday that will permit the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to undertake a $650-million construction program for mass-transportation facilities.

The state Insurance Department rejected today as insufficient proposals by Blue Cross and Blue Shield for open enrollment and liberalized health coverage.
Thirty-five major Australian trade unions agreed today to boycott all French aircraft, ships, goods and communications as a protest against French nuclear tests in the south Pacific.

The House has taken a historic step toward restoring Congressional authority over war-making and toward ending once and for all the United States military involvement in Indochina with its vote yesterday denying President Nixon the authority to transfer defense funds to pay for the bombing of Cambodia and for other Indochina activities.

Two medical officials of the Central Intelligence Agency told a Senate subcommittee today that a "personality assessment" made on Dr. Daniel Ellsberg was the first that the agency had ever made on an American citizen.

After months of repeated denials, Mario Biaggi admitted last night that he had refused to answer questions when he appeared in 1971 before a Federal grand jury. Political leaders said the admission would damage his mayoral candidacy.
Donald H. Segretti will be arraigned in United States District Court in Tampa, Fla.. next Thursday on charges of mailing fictitious campaign literature, his lawyer here said yesterday.

AIKEN, S.C. --Strange things are happening in the dark swamps and deep lakes around the Atomic Energy Commission's Savannah River plant near here. Vapors rise off the swamp waters, wrapping their eerie spell about tht lifeless cypress trunks.

Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz has designated 447 counties in 19 states where the Farmers Home Administration can begin making emergency loans to help farmers recover from natural disasters, including drought and floods.

Bail for Alice Crimmins was reduced yesterday from $25,000 to $15,000 by State Supreme Court Justice Williams Groat in Queens. The action was seen as paving the way for her release soon from the Correctional Facility for Women in Bedford Hills. She was convicted for murder in 1971 in the death of her 5-year-old son and manslaughter in the death of her 4-year-old daughter.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market registered their second consecutive losses yesterday in slow trading. Prices in both markets opened off and finished at or near their lows for the session.

The track coach, Daniel Wickenheisser, aware of the potentially blinding, whiplike capabilities of Farrell's shoulder-length, straight brown hair, feared for the 18-year-old senior's safety while embraced in the hairraising swirl of competition.

DOWNTOWN The Bronx is in the middle of a week of celebrating itself and, to spread the good word, the Bronx Opera Company makes its first foray into Manhattan tonight and tomorrow at 7:30.

Albert Shanker, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, yesterday expressed "great satisfaction" in the results of the May 1 local school board elections and said that the defeat of supporters of Luis Fuentes, the controversial District 1 superintendent, showed that the parents had rejected the politics of "separatism and confrontation."

Two special envoys from President Nixon told the nation's Republican Governors here yesterday that the President would make his Administration "more open, accessible and communicative" to them and to the press.

Artis Gilmore popped in 28 points and pulled down 21 rebounds to lead the Kentucky Colonels to a 109-93 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight, sending the American Basketball Association championship playoff into a decisive seventh game.

A combination public offering of 460,000 shares of the Hesston Corporation common at $21.25 per share was made yesterday by underwriters managed by Merrill Lynch. The company is selling 350,000 shares and certain shareholders 110,000 shares. The company's stock, traded over-thecounter, closed at 21 1/4 bid, unchanged from the previous close.

After rising 70 cents to a new high of $9.75 a bushel, prices of the May soybean futures dropped under heavy local and commercial selling yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

The civic pride of the Bronx in general and the Hunts Point neighborhood in particular were on parade yesterday. And because present Hunts Point residents are mostly of Puerto Rican origin, the flag of the Caribbean island flew next to the Stars and Stripes as Cub Scouts, Sea Cadets and others marched on the peninsula in the Southeast Bronx.
Harold Goldstein, former president of Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc., a large commodity option dealer, was indicted today on charges of mail fraud and perjury.

Public television station WNET/Channel 13 will carry gavel-to-gavel coverage of the Senate hearings into the Watergate affair live as well as on a nighttime delayed basis, beginning at 10 A.M. next Thursday.

Five teen-agers riding bicycles trailed a holdup suspect aboard a bus for 12 blocks on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday, hailed a passing police car and helped in the suspect's arrest and the recovery of $77.66 reported stolen from a milk bar.

In an effort to obtaini corporate support for the neighborhood arts in New York this summer, the Arts and Business Council yesterday presented a 60-minute show, "Summerfare," at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Street.
Suburban and country homeowners whose trees are damaged each year by leafeating gypsy moth larvae may gain some satisfaction by luring a few thousand of the male adults to their demise this summer.
The four United States auto companies said today that they would not appeal the Government's controversial interim pollution control standards for 1975 cars.

The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority today gave approval to the sale later this month of $268-million in revenue bonds to finance land acquisition, construction and initial operation costs of the Hackensack Meadowlands sports complex.

The price of gold rose today above $95 an ounce to a new high in Europe. As gold climbed earlier this week, the value of the dollar declined a little against the major European currencies, but today the dollar strengthened.

Although it may be difficult to bear in mind when so many sensational developments swirl into view each day, the essential fact remains that individuals-including those at the highest levels of government-are properly convicted only in a court of law and not in the press or on television.

Charges of conspiring to defraud the United States and to obstruct justice were handed up by a Federal grand jury against former Attorney General John M. Mitchell; former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans; Harry L. Sears, former majority leader of the New Jersey Senate, and Robert L. Vesco, a New Jersey financier.

Wall Street speculators stand to lose upwards of $2.5-million as a result of the rejection by a sharply divided New York State Banking Board of the proposed acquisition of the Long Island Trust Company by the giant Barclays Bank, Ltd., of London.

John Wesley Dean 3d, once the chief investigator of the Watergate scandals for the White House, has emerged as a central figure of suspicion himself. Few outsiders knew Mr. Dean in the days before Watergate.

Frank Wills, the $80a-week Watergate security guard who discovered the break-in last June 17, has taken a job at another downtown Washington building and is making $85 a week and getting up to $300 for interviews.

As part of a broad investigation into the city's criminal justice system, the State Commission of Investigation has been examining the extent to which Richard R. Aurelio has played a part in the selection of city judges since he left his job as Deputy Mayor in November, 1971, according to sources close to the investigation.

The Boston Red Sox, unable to get either a hit or a base runner for 51/3 innings from Dick Tidrow of Cleveland, rallied for three runs against Jerry Johnson in the eighth and beat the Indians, 4-3, at Fenway Park last night.
The House of Representatives in a rebuke to President Nixon's Indochina policies, voted 219 to 188 today to block the trans fer of defense funds to finance the continued bombing of Cambodia.

A shot from a passing automobile narrowly missed the Rockland County District Attorney, Robert R. Meehan, as he drove alone on a foggy county road early this morning. The 42-year-old Democratic Prosecutor, whose investigation of official corruption and organized crime has already led to several indictments,
The city is studying plans to divert heavy truck traffic in the West Village area in an attempt to prevent damage to historic homes in what has been designated a landmark neighborhood.

Representative Mario Biaggi's admission that he had refused to answer questions before a Federal grand jury, despite his repeated denials, has severely damaged his mayoral candidacy, Democratic politicians widely agreed yesterday.

An 18-year-old former football-star at Far Rockaway High School, arrested Wednesday night on charges of having taken part with other youths in a robbery-beating spree, died in the Queens Criminal Court detention pen yesterday afternoon after being subdued by correction officers, who said he had "gone berserk."
John Z. DeLorean, who resigned last month as a vice president of the General Motors Corporation, has married Christina Ferrare, a movie actress.
The British-born photographer Eadweard Muybridge (1830-1904) is one of the legendary figures in the early history of the medium.

Charges of conspiring to defraud the United States and to obstruct justice were handed up by a Federal grand jury against former Attorney General John N. Mitchell; former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans; Harry L. Sears, former majority leader of the New Jersey Senate, and Robert L. Vesco, a New Jersey financier.
Suburban and country homeowners whose trees are damaged each year by leafeating gypsy moth larvae may gain some satisfaction by luring a few thousand of the male adults to their demise this summer.
Bob Cousy doesn't quite know how the American rules of basketball were changed when they reached the international arena, but he thinks the United States had better learn to adjust.
The Collegiate Chorale, the amateur chorus organized some 30 years ago by Robert Shaw, has a history of such distinguished achievement behind it that it is sad to find it in a state of decline.

Bored shareholders have been asking for something new in annual meetings and yesterday they got it. At Burlington Northern's meeting in St. Paul, Minn., Norton Simon, one of 18 directors nominated for re-election to the big railroad conglomerate's board, voted against himself and his fellow directors.

Tom Bogs of Denmark, the European middleweight champion, outpointed Mike Quarry of San Luis Obispo, Calif., in a 10-round bout tonight. Bogs was awarded a unanimous decision over Quarry, who is a light heavyweight.

Henry Ford 2d, board chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said today the auto concern planned to seek a sizable increase in prices on its 1974 models. "I can tell you it's going to be substantial," he said at the company's annual meeting.
Elliot L. Richardson said today that he felt "betrayed by the shoddy standards of morals" of those Nixon Administration officials who have been involved in the Watergate affair.

The House passed a $1-billiona-year rural electric and telephone loan bill today after Congress worked out a compromise with the Administration. The measure was promptly sent to the White House for President Nixon's signature, hopefully tomorrow the 38th anniversary of the Rural Electrification Administration.

The House of Representatives, in a rebuke to President Nixon's Indochina policies, voted 219 to 188 today to block the use of defense funds for the continued bombing of Cambodia. The action marked the first time in six years that the House has supported an end-the-war amendment.

The Federal Reserve System's monetary policy is tightening slowly, banking data published yesterday showed. This increasing tightness, combined with the central bank's action yesterday in raising its discount rate to 6 per cent, bankers said yesterday.

The Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos has embarked on a peace offensive among the rebellious Mindanao Moslems, offering them the choice of peace and an economic windfall or a final confrontation with Government forces.
President Nixon's latest reorganization of his Administration completes the demolition of the so-called "Berlin wall" that surrounded him during his first term.

A Communist member of Parliament demanded today that the Government arrest and deport an American Embassy political officer, whom he described as a "known C.I.A. agent," unless Washington recalled him immediately.
A county court here yesterday struck down out-ofstate tuition payments for some 7,500 University of Michigan students. It could cost the university more than $5-million a year.

A former New Jersey physician who has surrendered his professional license told the State Commission of Investigation today that 99 per cent of the state's doctors and lawyers padded their bills in a practice that represents "the American way of life."

Attorney General George F. Kugler announced the appointment of Stephen Skillman of Princeton as the first assistant attorney general. Mr. Skillman has been assistant attorney general in charge of appellate matters in the Division of Law since 1969. As first assistant to the attorney general he will succeed Mrs. Marylin Loftus Schauer, who is soon to be sworn in as a judge of the Essex County Court.

Full of holes in every other respect, the Watergate seems to be thoroughly effective in damming up the flow of new talent into President Nixon's Washington. It could, of course, be argued that on a day when two of his former Cabinet members were indicted for consplracy and perjury, any new appointments would be improvements.
The Vancouver Canucks finished seventh this season in the eight-team East Division of the National Hockey League. Yesterday their coach, Vic Stasiuk, was dismissed.

The Cost of Living Council, reflecting Government concern over rising prices of scrap iron and steel, said today that it would conduct a fact-finding survey of the nation's largest producers and brokers of the items.

In addition to his Watergate misfortunes, President Nixon has been taking his lumps from the courts on another issue. Although he had seemed to be winning politically in his spending fight with Congress, his impoundment strategy has been thrice denied by Federal judges--which leaves some important problems up in the air.
The Israeli Army began extensive infantry maneuvers on the occupied Golan heights today, apparently in an effort to discourage Syria from sending substantial forces Into southern Lebanon.

Mrs. Ruby Smith, 58 years old arrived home from her job as shipping clerk to find her husband dead of a heart attack. As she telephoned for an ambulance, the switchboard operator who took the call said the telephone suddenly went silent.

Four persons were killed and more than 100 injured tonight as tornadoes ripped through the northwestern section of Ohio. An Ohio National Guard spokesman said three persons were killed and at least 100 injured in Willard.

The Orthodox Church of Greece today overruled its primate, Archbishop Ieronymos, and elected an "old guard" church government, to satisfy the wishes of the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, its "mother" church.
The group sponsoring a national homecoming celebration for all Vietnam veterans sent out its invitations yesterday. The guest list was impressive for the numbers alone.
A Federal District court judge in Brooklyn yesterday enjoined the "overburdened" Legal Aid Society from accepting the assignment of more criminal cases in State Supreme Court than it can handle.

A Cambodian Air Force T-28 fighter plane mistakenly bombed and strafed a Government position near the besieged provincial capital of Takeo yesterday, wounding at least 17 soldiers, military sources said today.

The East-West deadlock that has blocked preparations for a conference on mutual reduction of military forces In Central Eu rope for nearly three and a half months has been broker with an agreement to seat Hun gary as less than a full participant.
New York City officials today began their annual fiscal efforts in search of extra state funds to balance the Mayor's 1973 budget, which is scheduled to be made public next Tuesday.
The House of Representatives in a rebuke to President Nixon's Indochina policies, voted 219 to 188 today to block the trans fer of defense funds to finance the continued bombing of Cambodia.
Governor Cahill signed legislation today designed to protect the pensions of workers employed by companies that shut down operations or move out of New Jersey.
A Federal grand jury in Houston opened today a secret investigation into the $89,000 in Mexican checks that allegedly went into the Nixon campaign's hidden Watergate fund.

Assemblyman Peter R. Biondo, Republican of Westchester, said today that he had received several telephone calls threatening his life because he was sponsoring a bill to define and regulate the practice of psychology in the state.

Henry A. Kissinger took an optimistic line tonight on his talks with the Soviet leadership and suggested that an announcement would come soon on the visit to the United States of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.
The James Cotton Blues Band, at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street, through Monday, gives audiences a chance to see and hear a blues veteran who is still very much in his prime.

The Nastase of Rumania, punctuating the match with verbal barbs and complaints, defeated Geoff Masters of Australia, 6-1, 8-6, today and advanced to the semifinals of the $67,500 British clay court tennis championships.
An autopsy report issued to night said the late Senator Ed ward V. Long, Democrat of Mis souri, was not poisoned-a pos sibility raised four months after his death by his long-time sec retary.

The skill, the expertise, yes, even the genius, of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater, is partly contained within its ability to give old songs new lyrics. This is, admittedly, a familiar technique. Yet it almost always works.

Earnings or the Singer Company are expected to continue the upward trend of the first quarter during the balance of the year, which would 'mean an increase of about 12 per cent over the record 1972 net of $87.5-million,
The House of Representatives in a rebuke to President Nixon's Indochina policies, voted 219 to 188 today to block the trans fer of defense funds to finance the continued bombing of Cambodia.
The PBW Stock Exchange said today that two major life-insurance companies were expected shortly to place capital into two specialist units of the exchange.
A 34-year-old mental patient was shot and killed by the police early yesterday in the Floral Park section of Queens after he allegedly attacked his mother and stepfather with a hammer as they slept.

Ruckelhaus, acting director of the F.B.I., on electronic surveillance of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and excerpts from an F.B.I. report on an interview with Charles W. Colson, a former White House counsel, and from a C.I.A. report released by the judge in the Pentagon papers trial:
Charles Blyth, a 32year-old British sports car driver, died today of injuries suffered in a collision yesterday on the circuit for Sunday's Targa Florio race.
Farmers are expected to harvest a record 1,281,999,000 bushels of winter wheat this year, up 8 per cent from 1972, the Agriculture Department announced today.

The OTB horseplayer's Aqueduct daily double has gone down the drain, and his exactas haven't been close. His confidence is falling apart. He steps up to the window for one last try, and the ticket-seller says cheerfully: "You can't always win, you know. You'll be luckier next time."

Genesco, Inc., the Nashvillebased major apparel producer and retailer, said yesterday that preliminary figures indicated sales. for the third fiscal quarter ended April 30 would show an approximate 3 per cent rise while earnings-per-share would be slightly less than last year due to higher taxes.

COLUMBIA, S. C.-The first term of the Nixon Administration saw the South change considerably and the South's image Improve immeasurably. As the press-christened "Southern Strategist" in residence at the White House, I saw the changes and experienced the increased Southern acceptance first hand.
A police officer accused of sexually abusing a woman he was questioning about narcotics was suspended from the force and arrested yesterday and a policeman with him at the time was also suspended.
Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the military Jewish Defense League, went on trial with three others today on charges of attempting to export military firearms to the United States without authorization.

William H. Sullivan, a senior American negotiator with North Vietnam, said today that while Hanoi officials strongly desired foreign economic aid, they were suspicious of any multinational programs because "they don't trust the Russians or Chinese any more than they do us."

A television poll of the New York metropolitan region shows that citizens strongly favor a broad range of public programs to alleviate poverty.
The New Jersey Federation of Republican Women opened a convention here today at which it will decide the first contest for 20 years for president of the organization.

Cuban real estate broker, in a deposition here today, said that he and two Watergate burglars, Bernard L. Barker and Eugenio R. Martinez, broke into the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist in September, 1971, and photographed Dr. Ellsberg's and "other files."

The full-scale United States bombing in Cambodia is being conducted with the assistance of the American Embassy in Phnom Penh under circumstances that raise questions about the safeguards against striking civilian targets and about possible violations of the Congressional act under which the embassy functions.

When Henry Kissinger flew off to Moscow last week, the general assumption-which neither the White House nor the Kremlin discouraged-was that he was going to complete arrangements for Mr. Brezhnev's planned visit here next month. In fact, the usual "informed sources" were pinpointing June 25 as the day Mr. Brezhnev would arrive in this country.

A RUSSIAN BEAUTY AND OTHER STORIES. By Vladimir Nabokov. Translated from the Russian by Dmitri Nabokov in collaboration with the author and by Simon Krlinsky. 268 pages. McGraw-Hill. $7.95. It is surprising, when you consider his fame, how few of Vladimir Nabokov's books are read in this country.

The Royal Dutch - Shell Group, continuing its improved earnings pattern of the end of last year, had a 46 per cent increase in first-quarter earnings on a revenue gain of 14.4 per cent, the group reported yesterday.

For more than 10 months, investigators and reporters have been searching for a connection between Charles W. Colson and the Watergate affair through his friendship with E. Howard Hunt Jr., one of the Watergate conspirators, who pleaded guilty.

Spent 32 years building up a lucrative Wall Street law practice with national recognition as specialist in municipal and state financing ... Had known Richard Nixon only a year or so before their law firms merged in 1967....
Sueyuki Wakasugi, president of Mitsui Co., Ltd., one of Japan's largest trading concerns, died yesterday in Mitsui Memorial Hospital in Tokyo. He was 70 years old and lived in Tokyo.
It's advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to the show. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

Brendan T. Byrne, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, said today that he opposed the traditional system of financing elections with political campaign contributions and that, if elected,

The National Clearing Corporation, a concern that clears over-the-counter securities transactions for 300 broker-dealers, has established a working relationship with the Central Certificate Service of the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday.

The Fassler family of Middletown, Conn., which numbered three on Tuesday, numbered seven a days later. At Women's Hospital, part of St. Luke's Hospital in New York City, Mrs. Andrea Fassler, who has a 4-year-old son, gave birth to quadruplets.

Eric Sevareid, a news commentator for the Columbia Broadcasting System, said on the CBS-TV evening news tonight that early in 1969, the then Attorney General, John N. Mitchell, sought improper influence through an unidentified emissary, on two Supreme Court Justices in connection with a wire-tapping case.
The Senate has passed a bill authorizing the expenditure of $300-million over the next four years to combat effects of leadbased paint poisoning in children.
Premier Thanom Kittikachorn told the National Assembly today that United States military forces were still necessary in Thailand for the security of nations in Indochina and of Thailand as well.

Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., has received a second gift of $10-million from Mr. and Mrs. Foster G. McGaw, who gave $10-million to the institution in 1969. All $20-million is to be used in the development of the McGaw Medical Center.
The Public Service Commission today authorized the Long Island Lighting Company to increase its electric and gas rates by a total of $15,066,000 a year.
Georgia asked the Supreme Court today to order President Nixon to release Federal funds earmarked by Congress for highways, education and pollution control.

A special Federal grand jury yesterday indicted John N. Mitchell, former United States Attorney General; Maurice H. Stans, former Secretary of Commerce; Harry L. Sears, former majority leader of the New Jersey Senate, and Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier.
Winston Lord, one of Henry Kissinger's closest aides, said today that he was leaving the White House to "read, reflect and recharge my batteries."

Johnson Johnson announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire from private Swiss interests a majority position in the Dr. Carl Hahn Company of Dusseldorf, West Germany, manufacturers of feminine hygiene products.
The United States Steel Corportion said yesterday that if would raise prices of sheet and strip products by an average of 4.8 per cent, effective with shipments of June 15.

Ralph C. Wilson Jr., president of the Buffalo Bills, who has offered Erie County $1.5-million to name its new stadium Erie County Stadium rather than sell the stadium name to the Rich Products Corporation, which makes synthetic dairy products, said today he "felt from the beginning" the stadium should bear a name connected with the community and not with a commercial product.

The Federal Reserve Board announced today the second quarter-point increase in the discount rate in three weeks. The rise, from 5 3/4 to 6 per cent, was approved for 11 of the 12 Federal Reserve banks.
The Atomic Energy Commission said today that President Nixon had authorized the detonation 6,000 feet underground of a nuclear device on May 17 in Colorado.
F. Donald Nixon denied today that the Marriott Corporation got a $10-million loan from the Greek Government because he was President Nixon's brother.
Last winter, Patty Swiassolit purchased Blimpie Base #39 at Broadway and 71st Street, hoping to make her fortune selling the combination sandwiches on French bread that are standard Blimpie fare.

The new consumer movement that grew out of last month's meat boycott and the militant farmers' group that fought it have negotiated an alliance for an attack on the "middlemen," the big food processors and chain stores, through legislative and antitrust programs.

An unexpected $2.4-million savings to the city because of unanticipated lower bids for high-intensity street lighting will result in illumination by the new lights on an additional 800 miles of city streets by the end of this year, the Lindsay administration announced yesterday.

Worldwide distribution of the Bible and Scripture selections last year exceeded 200 million copies for the first time in the history of the United Bible Societies, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the board of managers of the American Bible Society in the Pierre Hotel.

One year after the trial judge ordered that all information on wiretaps be handed over to the court, the Government disclosed today at the Pentagon papers trial that telephone calls of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg were picked up by F.B.I. wiretaps in late 1969 and in early 1970.
John W. Dean 3d, the deposed White House counsel, charged today that there "is an ongoing effort to limit or prevent my testifying fully and freely" in the Watergate investigation.

Governor Rockefeller, with Governor Cahill of New Jersey at his side, signed legislation yesterday that will permit the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to undertake a $650-million construction program for mass-transportation facilities.

The Senate, for the second time in five weeks, voted today to set a $268-billion ceiling on spending in the next budget year and to insist that President Nixon follow Congressional directions on how the funds are to be used.

Abel Green, who as the editor of Variety knew and reported the news of the great, the near-great and the unknowns of Broadway and Hollywood, died of a heart attack last evening at his home, 55 Central Park West. He was 72 years old.

Vernon Bellecourt, national coordinator of the American Indian Movement, charged yesterday that most of the property damage during the occupation of Wounded Knee, S. D., was caused by either the "violence" or the tactics of Federal forces.
The 20,000-member New Jersey Nonresident Taxpayers Association lost its plea today in the United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals against payment of the city's wage tax here.

President Nixon, who has never been noted for understatement, now describes the Watergate scandal as a "deplorable incident." This is the mildest use of the English language since somebody referred to the San Francisco earthquake as "an unfortunate occurrence," and it suggests that Mr. Nixon still hasn't identified the source or measured the magnitude of the tragedy.

President Nixon yesterday announced a major reorganization brought on by Watergate. Among the changes: James R. Schlesinger is to move from director of the Central Intelligence Agency to Secretary of Defense; former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally will become a part-time White House adviser and the President's "super Cabinet," set up to centralize control of the bureaucracy, will be dismantled.

Stanley Goldblum, former chief executive of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, has been sued for damages of more than $1-million in what the trustee of the bankrupt company said today was probably the first of a series of similar suits against former Equity officers.
When the school bells sound for the last time next month, Mildred West would just like to collect her things and quietly go home. But she doubts if she can get away that easily.

The largest spaceship ever built, Skylab, stands atop a rocket here, ready for launching next Monday. Less than a mile away an Apollo spacecraft, much like the ones that took men to the moon, is being prepared for lift-off Tuesday.

The defense for S. Sgt. John D. Layton, a drill instructor accused of kicking a collapsed basic trainee who died shortlyafterward, attempted to in-, dicate today that one or more prosecution witnesses harbored ill feelings toward the defend-' ant because they believed he was prejudiced against blacks.

A variety of proposals for reducing energy consumption in large buildings by as much as 50 per cent, including tax incentives and revision of public utility rates, have been submitted to Governor Rockefeller by a state task force.

A service for Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, retired, a member of General Dwight D. Eisenhower's staff in World War II and director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administra tion in 1947-48, will be held Monday at 11 A.M. in Arlington National Cemetery.
Credito Italiano of Milan, one of Italy's largest banks, an nounced yesterday that it had been authorized by the New york State Banking Board to open a branch in New YorkCity. The new office,

President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan has decided to postpone indefinitely the trial of the eight Palestinian guerrillas who killed three diplomats, two Americans and a Belgian, while holding the Saudi Embassy in Khartoum last March 2, informed Sudanese sources said here today.

The International Track Association's only remaining undefeated athlete lost his vic tory string at the ninth stop of the indoor pro tour tonight. Leon Coleman had to settle for the runner-up spot behind Lance Babb in the 50-yard highhurdles.

With the farmer's share of the consumer food dollar reaching the highest level in 18 years the cost of a typical household market basket in the first quarter of 1973 reached a record annual rate of $1.414, the Agriculture Department said today.

The bodies of 20 Americans who died in captivity have been removed from Hanoi's municipal cemetery to a location about 35 miles away, in accordance with local tradition, a United States military group visiting Hanoi was toldtoday.

George Steinbrenner, the managing partner of the New York Yankees, will be represented by the favorite in the feature race at Aqueduct today. Steinbrenner owns the Kinship Farm, in whose silks Belle Marie campaigns, and she heads the field of 13 for the Acorn Stakes.
Mrs. Nelson Gross of Saddle River defeated Mrs. Nancy Schluter of Pennington today in the first contested election for president of the New Jersey Federation of Republican Women in 20 years.
The Secretary of Labor, Peter J. Brennan, told Congress to day that the "facts do not support" the assertion of or ganized labor that "imports cause large-scale unemployment."

Beset on all sides by traffic and com merce and other signs of en croaching population, the peo ple on Newfield Avenue here have taken a stand against the steady march of institutions uptheir gracious old street.

The winners in the last of the 32 local school-board elections were announced yesterday. Lucas, Viginia Bell, Benjamin Watkins, Valerie Jordan, Louise Baither and Jose M.Espinosa.

Harrie E. Hart Jr., a 26 year-old Los Angeles person nel consultant, took a chance on Thursday night and found out yesterday that he had lost. But he believes that itwas all for a worthy cause.

Luis Tiant, a 32-year-old Cuban refugee, has had his up and downs in baseball. A 20-game winner with Cleve land in 1968 and a 20-game loser a year later, Tiant broke a shoulder blade and ulti mately was given his outrightrelease by Minnesota in 1971.
Davidow, Inc., a manufaclur er of women's coats and suits established in 1880, has closed its doors and is in the processof being liquidated.

Grigory Kozintsev, a Soviet director known for his Shakespearean movies, died today in Leningrad. He was 68 years old.

The New York Mets defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3, tonight in what may have been their most costly victory in years: Rusty Staub, Cleon Jones and Jerry Grote all were hit by pitched balls and Willie Mays was back home apparentlysneaking up on retirement.
Three prisoners, two of them handcuffed together, leaped from the back of a police van yesterday and ran off along West 86th Streetto freedom.
Radio and television newsmen went on strike today against WTOP, the Washington Post-Newsweek broadcast outlet here.

You won't find Dickensian ambiance at the newly opened New York Antiques Centre, 962 Third Avenue (at 58th Street). Anonymous cubicles stuffed with wares so crowd the interiors that there is no room for the sort of quaint charm that once characterized such Gotham curio centers as Ardlea Court.

Palestinian guerrillas who entered Lebanon from Syria earlier this week were reported pulling back toward the frontier yesterday as the cease-fire between guerrilla and Lebanese forces appeared to beholding.

Corning Glass Works an nounced yesterday that its sub sidiary, Corning International Corporation, had acquired all of the equity interest in James A. Jobling Co., Ltd., and in Electrosil, Ltd., both of Sunder land, England, through a cash transaction with Thomas Tilling, Ltd., of London.
Assemblyman Albert H. Blu menthal yesterday declared his support for a statewide tax to support education, but said the educational system should remain under local control.
The United States dollar dropped sharply in Europe's key monetary centers today as the price of gold in the open market soared to new peaks for the second time in twodays in active trading.

L. Patrick Gray 3d has told Senate investigators that he talked by telephone with President Nixon about three weeks after the Watergate burglary last June 17 to express concern over White House obstacles in his path and confusion that was hampering his investigation,committee sources said today.

The dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at the State Uni versity of New York at Albany, who has been under fire this week from students protesting his role in the dismissal of several teachers, announced last night that he was resign ing to accept a post in Oklahomo.
Representative Mario Biaggi, who appeared twice before a Federal grand jury in 1971, will be called before another jury for further questioning, authoritative sources said yes.terday.
An accountant pleaded guilty here today to charges of dis tributing during the Florida Presidential campaign a bogus letter charging two Presidential candidates with sexual misconduct.

The White House said today that the United States would continue with "the right policy" of bombing in Cambodia in sup port of President Lon Nol's government, despite the vote yesterday in the House of Rep resentatives blocking the trans fer of military funds for suchraids.
Mike Hess of Albany, Ore., scored a stunning upset tonight by de feating Tim Dement of Lafay ette, La., an Olympic boxer, in the 85th national Amateur Ath letic Union boxing championships.

A 16-member Cabinet headed by Premier Joop den Uyl took office today, ending a 163-day political crisis-the longest in the Netherlands' history. Mr. den Uyl and the other members of the five-party coalition Government were sworn by Queen Juliana andassumed their posts.

Her tears of joy had dried, but cheers still filled the courtroom when Patricia Ellsberg embraced one of many friends and said: "I could never believe the scene of waiting for the jury to come in. I just knew it would never happen."

The Securities and Exchange Commission asked the Federal District Court here today to enjoin the Allegheny Beverage Corporation, its two subsidiaries and 22 other defendants from continued violation of the registration and fraud provisions of securities laws.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos to day decreed the lifting of di rect Government supervision of all local and foreign informationoutlets.

Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker, who has presided for six contentious years as the paramount American authority in South Vietnam and has become the last major symbol of United States involvement here,left Saigon today.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, leader of the Soviet Communist party, arrived today to show the Soviet Union's solidarity with Poland before he meets next week in Bonn with Chancellor Willy Brandt. From here Mr. Brezhnev will go to East Berlin tomorrow in a similar gesture ofsolidarity.
Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, mak ing his first appearance at a public hearing of the Board of Education, yesterday accused the five members of fostering segregation in the guise of integration.
Texas Southern University jumped ahead today after the first three events in the Southwestern Athletic Conferencetrack meet.

Brig. Gen. Lon Non, brother of the Cambodian President, Marshal Lon Nol, has called for the United States to "use stronger measures, renew bombing of North Vietnam more intensively if necessary," to force the North Vietnamese to withdraw fromCambodia.

A pay television system that is being patented offers a home box office. Patrons in their living rooms or motel, quarters can insert printed tickets and get selected movies or special programs such as prizefights.

Israel and the United States are standing by and watching with more nervousness than either cares to admit as the beleaguered President Franjieh of Lebanonstruggles to hold his schismatic nation together.
William G. Wells, a re tired Air Force colonel and the owner of radio station WTAN here, died today. He was 69years old.

Dr. Wil liam C. Rasmussen, a promi nent American geologist and hydrologist working under contract in Vietnam for the Agency for International De velopment, was killed yester day when his jeep triggered a land mine on a highway 85 miles east of Saigon, the United States Embassy announced today.

Tony Colon will seek his first sub-4-minute mile while Man hattan bids to unseat C. W. Post for team honors in the 40th annual Metropolitan Intercol legiate outdoor track and field championships today at Rutgers Stadium in New Brunswick,N. J.

A., the Brazilian air line, announced yesterday that it had signed purchase con tracts totaling $92-million for a fleet of eight American-built aircraft, including two new Mc Donnell-Douglas DC-10 series 30 wide body three-engine jets, a flight simulator and ground support and line station equipment.
Three prisoners, two of them handcuffed together, leaped from the back of a police van yesterday and ran off along West 86th Streetto freedom.

Norton Simon, the West Coast industrialist and art col lector, said yesterday that he had paid $1-million for a bronze sculpture of a Hindu deity that Indian Government officials say was stolen from a South Indian temple and smuggled out of India.

Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore proposed today that the United States, Japan, Australia and Asian nations form a joint air-naval task force to keep the Indian Ocean and the western Pacific open to thecommerce of all countries.

The Internal Revenue Service has filed income tax liens against a former show girl, Lillian Reis, and her long time companion, Ralph Staino Jr. A $12,743 lien was filed on Thursday against Miss Reis and $10,276 against Staino, both ofPhiladelphia.

Two fires believed to have been started by an arson ist swept through a row of crowded three-story frame ten ements here today, killing four persons, including three chil dren, and injuring one fire captain.

James L. Fri, former president of the Upholstery and Drapery Fabric Manufacturing Association and the author of books on retail merchandising, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital. His age was 81 andhe lived here

Bruce Crampton shot a 69 to day to go with his opening round 66 and maintained a two-stroke lead in the $150 000 Colonial national invitationgolf tournament.

There were eight finalists in the 100-meter free-style last July in Park Ridge, Ill., when the starter called the swimmers to the starting blocks. Mark Spitz was among them, so almost nobody noticed Kenny Knox, the fastest free-styler in New Jersey history. The top six finishers would make the United States Olympic team, and for Knox, that meant swimming fasterthan he had swum in his life.

The rate of inflation is expected to increase between 4.5 and 5 per cent this year, but should taper off to about 3.5 per cent in 1974, econo-, mists advising the BusinessCouncil said today.

Osterhout, died Thursday at Columbia Presbyterian Med ical Center. She was 84 years old and lived at 160 East 65thStreet.

Top seeded Stan Smith survived a poor start and advanced to the final of the $100,000 World Championship of Tennis with a 4-6, 6-4, 7-6, 7-5 victory overRod Laver tonight.

Japan believes that the formation of a group of oil-consuming nations would constitute a " chal lenge" to the interests of oil-producing countries, the Japa nese Trade Minister said today. Yasuhiro Nakasone, Minister of International Trade and Industry, said at a news conference that the proposal would heighten tension between oil-producing and oil-importing countries. He emphasized his belief that Japan should notjoin such a group, even if it was formed.

Jim Palmer, who was battered for five runs on seven hits in less than two innings when the Yankees faced him in Baltimore last month, was an Oriole of a different hue last night at Yankee Stadium.

A modified "death with dignity" bill cleared the State Senate Health and Rehabilita tive Services Committee today. It provides that a mentally competent person may author ize doctors to let him die with out taking "extraordinary," artificial steps to preserve life, if he is stricken with an incur.able disease or injury.
The Soviet national bas ketball team, stung by a 4-2 loss in its six-game series with the United States all-stars, routed Marathon Oil, the Ama teur Athletic Union champion,109-87, tonight.

After the sixth race ended at Aqueduct yesterday, with Granny's Darling leading Sassy Cyane over the finish line in one, two order, the brothers Marco and Kelly Castaneda found themselves in a rare situation. Marco had ridden Granny's Darling and his brother was on therunner-up.

Atter a week of rises, many of them spectacular, soybean futures prices fell the 20-cent a-bushel limit yesterday in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. At the close, they hadregained only part of the loss.

LONDON-It takes time and a keen eye to find 33 Lombard Street in the heart of the City of London. Despite its imposing address, the London headquarters of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company is tucked away in a narrow alleyway called Plough Court-discreet to the point of near invisibility.

WASHINGTON--The numbers are not comforting. National gasoline stocks in the week ended May 4 totaled 201 million barrels, 20 million below a year earlier. More than 560 gasoline stations have closed because of short supplies; another 1,370 are threatened.

The trial is over and the defendant convicted; he stands before the judge; head bent, shoulders slumped, awaiting his sentence. The defense counsel pleads for mercy. The prosecutor is silent. And then, without so much as a moment's pause, the judge announces the man's fate: Life in prison, he says.

PHILADELPHIA - Under normal circumstances, the civet, or civet cat, manages to attract very little attention. Retiring, nocturnal, shy but with a reputation for sharp teeth and sharper anger, the civet spends most of its time either burrowed beneath the ground in Asia and Africa by day or in search of a rabbit or chicken to sink its teeth into by night.

KABUL, Afghanistan-Eighty riders jostle hard against each other, spur forward and begin to move across the field. Kettle drums beat tensely, as if to forcibly restrain the horses' pace.

SOLOMON ISAIEVICH HUROK, the last of the red hot showmen, is 85 years old and still letting off as much heat as ever. The undisputed champion impresario of the world, the man affectionately known as Papa Hurok, is of sound mind and body as well. But it all comes to naught when the loneliness sets in. Hurok tell's of his solitary evenings.

President Nixon was joined at Camp David by his wife today for a quiet celebration of Mother's Day. The President was reportedly combining a rest at the mountain retreat with work on a proposal to curb future campaign abuses by any political party.

As President Nixon struggled with the Watergate scandal that has wracked his administration, Governor Rockefeller planted the first seeds of a possible Presidential candidacy in 1976 at the Republican Governors' conference here last week.
France has sold missiles with a range of four miles to Libya for mounting on three launches built by Britain for the Libyan Navy, the French armed forces magazine says.

JERUSALEM-It was a tumultuous celebration. With 24 hours of non-stop street dancing, song festivals, bonfires, fireworks and a massive military parade on Monday morning, Israel last week celebrated its 25th anniversary as an independent nation.

Black Panther Zayd Malik Shakur was buried in Long Island National Cemetery early last week. He had been killed a few days before in a shootout with police on the New Jersey turnpike that also left a trooper dead. A former Minister of Information for the Eldridge Cleaver faction of the Panthers, Mr. Shakur had died, in his father's words, as "a struggle . . . a revolutionary."

No one was taking bribes in return for governmental favors.

The New York Stock Exchange's Central Certificate Service, the computerized securities depository formed five years ago, will be taken over by the recently formed Depository Trust Company, Big Board officials announced over the weekend.

Scientists at the California Institute of Technology report that an experimental technique for giving early warning of small earthquakes also proved applicable to a major quake on the West Coast and gives promise of wider application for controls as well as warning.

Governor Rockefeller is expected to ask the Legislature for authority to appoint up to 100 permanent Court of Claims judges - not the "six-month" criminal justices originally mentioned - to handle the increase in case loads expected to result from the state's toughened drug penalties.

Mrs. Frances Shaw Newmark, a leader in Hadassah and a past, vice president of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, died Friday at her home, 1865 East 19th Street, Brooklyn. She was 76 years old, and the wife of Ralph Newmark, a jewelry importer.
One year after he was shot in a Maryland parking lot, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama has apparently overcome the despair that marked much of his convalescence.

David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, chargedd yesterday that some of the tax reforms currently being debated in Congress, if adopted, could "seriously undermine" business and economic growth in the country.

Relief pitching, in the form of Sparky Lyle, helped save the Yankees in the first game of yesterday's double-header at the Stadium, but it failed them in the second and prevented New York from gaining a rare distinction-playing .500 baseball in the American League's Eastern Division.

Conservative party leaders read copies of Mario Biaggi's now-public grand jury testimony yesterday and, badly split, were to meet this evening to decide whether they should try to oust him as their mayoral candidate.

Governor Rockefeller is expected to ask the Legislature for authority to appoint up to 100 permanent Court of Claims judges - not the "six-month" criminal justices originally mentioned - to handle the increase in case loads expected to result from the state's toughened drug penalties.

Neil Simon, perhaps Broadway's most successful playwright, has completed his 14th theater work. It is called "The Good Doctor" and is scheduled to be presented at the Eugene O'Neill Theater late in November by Emanuel Azenberg and Eugene V. Wolks.

If the farm bill approved last week by the Senate Agriculture Committee wins the support of Congress, American housewives can say good-by to any hopes they may have of ever seeing food prices return to levels that-as recently as a year ago-they thought of as high but bearable.

Fighting a brisk and gusty head wind, more than 4,000 marchers and two score brightly uniformed bands and fife and drum corps paraded up Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Streets yesterday in a memorial tribute to the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
For the six years that Robert L. Vesco has lived in this small rural town, he had remained as elusive to his neighbors as he has been to Federal investigators over the last six months.

Miss Manuele Alice Delbourgo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward D. Delbourgo of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday morning to Richard Leo Wasserman, who expects to graduate this month from the Columbia University Law School. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack B. Wasserman of Baltimore.

After weeks of disagreement, during which Cambodia has had no constitutional government outside of the almost absolute power of President Lon Nol, a step has been taken toward formation of a new cabinet.

Michael Burke and George Steinbrenner 3d, Yankee chiefs past and present, ended several months of fighting and two weeks of silence yesterday in a public reconciliation that featured a tale of a brief courtship, a sudden marriage and an even quicker divorce.

Miss Merrie Marcia Spaeth, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip G. Spaeth, was married at the Philadelphia Cricket Club in Chestnut Hill this afternoon to Robert S. Thanhauser Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thanhauser.

The Columbia-Princeton axis in contemporary American music has long been noted for its stern refusal to be seduced by the blandishments of sound for its own sake. Such rigorous intellectuality would seem to persist no matter what the medium.
A memorable documentary of the life of Joseph Stalin will be telecast nationally tonight at 8 by the Public Broadcasting Service, locally over WNET/Channel 13.
Compliments of the Toronto Metros, the Cosmos returned to New York last night with four points, two badly injured players and the discovery of a star midfielder.

For the fourth time in its 15 years of spacefaring, the United States is ready to launch a new man-in-space project. It is Skylab, an eightmonth, $2.5-billion effort to determine man's ability to live and work for long periods in the gravity-free conditions of space flight.

Eighty Mexican-American convicts at Soledad state prison were watching a Spanish-language movie, "La Mascadera" (The Mask), recently when scuffling, curses and screams of pain suddenly drowned out the film's dialogue.
Mrs. Judy Rankin posted a fourstroke victory today in the $30,000 Lady Carling open at Pine Ridge Golf Course by shooting par 73. Her 54-hole total was 215.

Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, predicted today that the time would come when oil would be used as a "weapon of Arab self-defense" and asserted the "sacred right of a nation to nationalize the resources in its soil."

Public broadcasting may yet come to fruition despite the pressures from the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy and the internal dispute between the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, a Government agency that finances programing, and the Public Broadcasting Service, which interconnects the major programs for the 235 stations.
Frances Marion, who won two Oscars and wrote most of the screenplays for Mary pickford and Rudolph Valentino during her half-century in films, died yesterday at the age of 86.
The estimates were for Hank Aaron to break Babe Ruth's career home run record sometime next season. The Atlanta Braves' slugger is acting like he has moved the schedule to sometime this season.

Bobby Riggs let his tennis racquet do the talking today. After having softened up Mrs. Margaret Court with a Mothers Day bouquet of roses, the ebullient 55-year-old former national champion routed the current queen of the women's professional tour, 6-2, 6-1, in their $10,000 winnertake-all challenge match.
Miss Maryanna Dickey, daughter of John Dickey of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Dickey, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Paul Litton Fletcher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher of Kinston, N.C.

Following a week of determined, twice-a-day workouts and the return of Charlotte Crane to stroke, the Radcliffe College crew won the New England women's collegiate rowing championship today and avenged an earlier defeat by Princeton.

In selecting Michael F. Armstrong as acting District Attorney of Queens, Governor Rockefeller has made an excellent start toward cleaning up that scandal-scarred office. The former counsel to the Knapp Commission brings to his new assignment outstanding qualities of integrity and prosecutorial skill. More important still, he has demonstrated a zeal for enforcing high standards of public morality.

If President Nixon understood the large meaning of the events labeled Watergate, if he sought to respond to the public yearning they have evoked, if he wished to cleanse himself and his country of their stain, he would have to begin by rededicating his Government to one principle: respect for law.

Richard Helms, the United States Ambassador, who is the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, left Teheran for Washington today to testify about the C.I.A. 's involvement in the Pentagon papers case.
The Nixon Administration has promised to grant gasoline import licenses to independent wholesalers and retailers with comparative liberality to keep them in business.
