Overamplification buried both Woody Herman's orchestra and the singer Shirley Bassey at Carnegie Hall on Friday night. The noise produced by Mr. Herman's band reverberated through the hall as though it was playing in a barrel of mush.

The Suffolk County police have positively identified a skeleton found in an overgrown lot in the Fire Island community of Saltaire as that of a 25-year-old Bay Shore woman who disappeared May 28, 1972. The woman, Francine Tuminello, was identified through dental records. She had disappeared after a party with friends at an inn only a few hundred yards from where her skeleton was found last Saturday. Miss Tuminello's death remains under investigation.

From 10:30 P.M. to midnight on Friday, WNET/13 carried a "mixed media video consciousness-raising event" called "The Television Show." Transmission of the program was live. Much of the result, however, was not.

David K. E. Bruce entered China today to establish the first American diplomatic mission since the Communists took over in 1949. The veteran diplomat, who is 75 years old, said his assignment was "very intriguing."

At 77, my mother can still turn out a respectable plate of chicken soup, so I came up from Washington to pay her a Mother's Day visit. "I'm sorry for the President," she said, ladling it out, "but I'm more worried about you. When you worked in the White House, were you involved in the Watergate?"

A Federal grand jury empanelled by the Juttice Department to investigate alleged price fixing by at least six New York stores has reportedly expanded its scrutiny to cover a wide range of apparel pricing practices as well as social gettogethers of leading merchants and the reasons behind some recent iob switching.

Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson announced today that he would seek re-election in 1974. The mayor, elected in 1970, told a crowd gathered for a political celebration of his 41st birthday: "Four years is not enough."

The Rev. Dr. Clarence Carroll Clark, former rector of the Episcopal Chapel of the Comforter in New York, died here today at the age of 97. Dr. Clark retired in 1949 as rector of the chapel, entered the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples in New York,
A seventh member of a Brooklyn youth gang called the War Gods was arrested yesterday on charges in connection with a fire last Tuesday in which a woman, her three children and two grandchildren died.

Mrs. John N. Mitchell was reportedly secreted in a mental hospital last week, but yesterday, sounding as ebullient as ever, she denied it. "Anybody who says that, why they're just as crazy as can be," she said by telephone. "I'm right here at home.

A study of local legal services projects has concluded that the entire program has been disrupted by continued harassment by the Office of Economic Opportunity, the antipoverty agency being dismantled by the Nixon Administration.

Renewed fighting in the southern part of the Centrial African nation of Burundi, in which at least 50 persons have been killed, has produced a heavy movement of refugees, many of them wounded, into Tanzania.
For Mrs. Naomi Lepselter, Mother's Day had a special meaning. Her 11-month-old daughter, missing from her home in Woodmere, L. I., since Friday, was returned unharmed yesterday.
The Ford Foundation has announced that it will spend $75million over the next five years to help build the capacity of local community development corporations, according to The Associated Press.

Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz called Senator Sam Ervin, Democrat of North Carolina, a "publicity seeking Senator" today. Senator Ervin heads the Select Senate Committee to Investigate Conduct of the 1972 Presidential Election.

The seven largest power companies in New York State have announced that they are considering forming a separate "generation corporation" whose sole function would be to build power plants supplying electricity to all seven companies.
Two of the three prisoners who leaped to freedom from the back of a police van taking them to Criminal Court Friday morning were back in custody yesterday, facing an additional charge of escape.

Royal Blue, a foxchaser with a world of potential, left the field far behind today and won the second-year green working hunter championship at the closing session of the three-day Children's Services Horse Show.
Suffolk County, still fighting against unemployment from aerospace-contract cutbacks and diversions, is getting a new industry, the processing of tax returns by sophisticated computer systems.

New York City invited its citizens to a birthday party yesterday to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the city's consolidation of its five boroughs into Greater New York.

Thousands of food faddists, 142 Congressmen and a health lobby, which the Federal Government has linked to uaceruackery, are backing an obscure bill a that would allow Americans to obtain as many vitamins as ber an they want.

President Nixon and members of his family spent a quiet day here today at the Camp David retreat. He and Mrs. Nixon returned to the White House tonight by heli copter.

The Federal Government has told about 150 single-sex colleges or colleges that are in the process of becoming coeducational that they must file reports by early summer explaining their plans to eliminate all sex discrimination in their admissions policies.

Gijs Van Lennep of the Netherlands and Herbert Muller of West Germany won the 57th Targa Florio in a Porsche Carrera today as three favorites were forced to withdraw before completing four laps of the world's oldest auto race.

This is the time of year when many men and women are looking for the magic number 631 to appear on their paycheck stubs. The amount-$631.80 to be exact-is the maximum that must be withheld from paychecks for Social Security.

The honeymoon - or, perhaps, the moneymoon - is over for Americans in France. There are 18,000 Americans living here, most of them in or near Paris.
Governor Cahill has issued a list of 43 sewage systems in the state that will be built or upgraded with help from an additional $231-million in Federal funds that a judge has ordered released.

When Henry A. Kissinger flies back to Paris this Thursday to try to patch up the crumbling Paris peace accords with Hanoi's Le Duc Tho, he won't be alone with his Administration aides and Presidential instructions. Congress will be there too. For the first time in years, the President will have to take seriously the will of the people as expressed through Congress in formulating Indochina policy.
Admissions counselors who work with black students at the country's most selective institutions of higher education are voicing concern that the commitment to expand nonwhite enrollments is waning.

Mrs. Elisabeth Logan Davis, an author and former community leader in Rahway, N. J., where her husband, the Rev. Dr. Chester M. Davis, was pastor of the First Presbyterian Church for 35 years, died yesterday in a Chester, N. J., nursing home. She was 87 years old.

Dr. Jack J. Blinn, a past president of the New York Cardiological Society, died yesterday in Long Beach Memorial Hospital, of which he was a former director of medicine and medical board president. He was 73 years old and lived at 65 West Beech Street.

To the Editor: Excessive criticism has been heaped on American car makers for insisting they could not meet Federal emission standards on 1975 models. Actually, Detroit had gone far toward meeting these standards on new cars with development of the catalytic converter and other modifications.

Francis S. Bensel, a senior partner in the law firm of Kelley, Drye, Warren, Clark, Carr Ellis, 350 Park Avenue, died Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

John W. Dean 3d, the former White House counsel, actively attempted to set up an undercover espionage and intelligence ring to infiltrate antiwar protest groups before the Democratic and Republican National Conventions last year, Government sources said today.

Are business and consumer interests antithetical? While most consumer groups are skittish about aligning themselves with business interests, the Consumer Bureau of 152 Alexander Street, here, is an interesting exception.
Lightning killed one baseball player and injured seven others today during an amateur game at Lake Havasu High School. The victim was John Wade, 19 years old, of Lake Havasu City, who was pitching.
The Lebanese Parliament has been called to meet tomorrow to consider an extension of the state of emergency established as a result of fighting between the army and Palestinian guerrillas.

Running at respectable speeds of 190 to 194 miles an hour, six drivers qualified today for the 57th Indianapolis 500 auto race. They joined the 24 who made the field yesterday in the first of four scheduled days of time trials. The race will be run Monday, May 28.

Bruce Crampton, needing only a par 4 on the final hole for his fourth victory of the season, today made a doublebogey 6 instead, permitting Tom Weiskopf to win the $150,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament.

The four candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination met in a televised debate for the first time last night and became embroiled in dispute over the controversial Forest Hills lowincome housing project-the same topic that three of them had argued at a B'nai B'rith Forum in Queens earlier in the day.

Royal Blue, a foxchaser with a world of potential, left the field far behind today and won the second-year green working hunter championship at the closing session of the three day Children's Services Horse Show.

Pablo Picasso's personal collection of paintings by other great artists, given to the Louvre museum at his express wish by his widow and legitimate son a month ago, includes some dazzling masterworks by Matisse Cezanne, Degas, Braque, Le Main and Henri Rousseau.

They came from southern India in the 19th century to clear the jungles and work in the coffee and tea plantations opened by the British. "We transformed this counttry," said Savumiamoordhy Thondaman, president of the powerful Ceylon Workers Congress, representing nearly 400,000 workers.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, ended a one-day visit to East Germany today by presenting to Erich Honecker, the East German party leader, the Order of Lenin and by praising all Germans who took part in the wartime resistance against Hitler.
The Supreme Court declined today to review the bribery and perjury conviction of Irving Kahn, former president of the Teleprompter corporation.

Elmer Snowden, the jazz band leader who introduced Duke Ellington in Harlem 50 years ago, died here today at the age of 72. Mr. Snowden learned banjo from Eubie Blake and formed his own group in Washington.

PALERMO; Sicily--Whenever the Mafia shoots, Sicilians say, it is in trouble. Judging by the volume of shooting that has been going on recently and by the nature of its targets, the "honored society" must be in big trouble.

To the Editor: News stories heralding the desire of the New. York State Judicial Conference for a professionally run office of public information point up the uneasiness all judges feel about the barrage of unfavorable coverage of court problems in the press.

The price of gold rose above $100 an ounce in Europe for the first time today and the dollar weakened sharply, ushering in what could be another period of monetary tension even after the two recent devaluations of the dollar.

The International Automobile Federation today granted organizers of the May 20 Belgian Grand Prix race an extra 32 hours to make the Zolder racing circuit safer. Drivers had said loose gravel made the track dangerous.
Martin J. McNally, the convicted hijacker of an American Airlines jet here last summer, was sentenced to two life prison terms in Federal District Court today.

OWNERS, a play by Caryl Churchill. Directed by Terese Hayden; setting by Fred Kolocuch; production stage manager, John Branon. Presented by Terese Hayden. At the Mercer-Show Theater, 240 Mercer Street.

The New York Stock Exchange wants to boost its minimum fixed commission charges by $300 millionan increase that will require approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Simultaneously, the Justice Department has asked a Federal district court to wipe out the Stock Exchange's system of fixed commission charges altogether on the ground that the price-fixing violates the antitrust laws.

Skylab, the nation's first space station, was rocketed into orbit today, but a deployment failure of its solar-power wings forced a five-day delay and serious curtailment of manned operations aboard the massive research spaceship.

Last May, as the 18th anniversary of the 1954 Supreme Court decision against segregated schools was observed, the nation was still embroiled in a bitter battle over separate schools, and busing of pupils had become the symbol of that straggle.

Green and white Pakistani flags fluttered on Pahlevi Avenue today. Photographs of President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto were displayed in store windows. By noon heavily guarded 'limousines. began moving to the airport.

Brian Gottfried, one of the many bright American newcomers on the international tennis circuit, whipped Clark Graebner, 6-4, 6-7, 6-2, today in the opening round of the $150,000 Alan King-Caesars Palace tennis tournament.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange suffered their sharpest drop in more than a year yesterday. The Amex index was off 0.22, to 23.31. The decline was the severest since March 22, 1972, when the index fell 0.24.
Miles F. York, who retired in 1969 as chairman of the Atlantic Companies (Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company and Centennial Insurance Company died Saturday in Berkeley, Calif. He was 71 years old.

On a blustery afternoon in Chicago, the New York Mets finally did some mending today - their game with the division-leading Cubs was postponed by cold weather, no new injuries were reported and they bought Jerry May from Kansas City as a second-string catcher.
Dr. Frances P. Hoffman, professor emeritus of health and physical education at Queens College, died Friday of cancer in a Silver Spring, Md., nursing home. She was 66 years old.
Edward V. McCann, a proofreader in the composing room of The New York Times, died Sunday night after a brief illness. He lived at 549 East 234th Street, the Bronx, and was 60 years old.
Theater Strategy, an organization of 23 of America's leading experimental playwrights, is dedicated to the care, preservation and propagation of playwrights.

The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that municipalities could not enact a local curfew on jet flights at their airports in an effort to control noise.

William D. Ruckelshaus, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said that records of 17 wiretaps placed on newsmen and Government officials, including one in which Dr. Daniel Ellsberg was overheard, were discovered last week in a White House safe belonging to a former Presidential assistant, John D. Ehrlichman.

An Irish Republican Army member sought as a gunman Was killed in a shootout with British troops today. In other incidents, a man was killed in a bomb explosion in an abandoned house and masked gunmen invaded a nursery school and 'wounded a young Roman Catholic house painter working there.

Billy Martin, the peppery Detroit manager, coached at third base last night for the first time this season and emerged from the part-time job with mixed results. He got a closer view of the Tigers' 8-0 victory over the Yankees, but he also got too close a view of Ike Brown's bat.
About 500 Cambodian soldiers, hungry and unpaid, marched through Phnom Penh today, firing their guns into the air. They promptly got a month's pay and some bread.
Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. asked the Cost of Living Council today to reject the increase in sales commissions on stock transactions that had been requested by the New York Stock Exchange.

Zhores A. Medvedev said today that he did not expect problems in returning to the Soviet Union because of what he called his "factual tribute" to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn.

Eli Broad, chairman of Kaufman Broad, Inc., said today that the company had "completely resolved" a rash of rumors that had produced a "bear raid" on the stock and kept the stock from trading today on the New York Stock Exchange because buy and sell orders could not be matched.

Dave Cowens of the Boston th Celtics, the most valuable player of the National Basketball Association and also the most valuable in the All-Star game, had to be satisfied with a second-team berth in the all-league selections yesterday.

After a five-month investigation into the city's use of provisional employes, a Manhattar grand jury yesterday accused a former high-ranking Lindsay administration official of "gross abuse" of his authority and recommended disciplinary action against him.

The Government of South Africa has recently offered concessions in its dispute with the United Nations over the territory of SouthWest Africa, and their scope has surprised, and generally pleased, white moderates and diplomats here.

The rubber bridge player leads a simple life. He tries to make his contract, and if in the process he fails by two or three tricks he does not care. The problems of the declarer in a duplicate game are somewhat more complex: it may be right for him to resign himself to a one-trick defeat and abandon a chance to make his contract.

Orlando Cepeda, the first man many American League managers thought about when the designated-hitter rule was adopted, proved again last night that he could fill the role. He delivered an 11thinning single to give Boston a 1-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

The Executive Club of the Republican party of New Jersey, a fund-raising organization to which at least 149 members of the state's business elite contributed $1,000 each, has come under the scrutiny of state and Federal investigators.

The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Wilbur D. Mills, said yesterday he did not believe that growing opposition in Congress to Presidential powers would have "too much effect" on the pending bill to give the President broad new authority over tariffs and trade policy.
A 23-year-old Brooklyn man was found shot to death in his apartment late last night, the apparent victim of a robbery, the police reported.
Elliot L. Richardson said today that two ranking members of the new White House staff had suggested to him candidates for special prosecutor in the Watergate case.

Fourteen major New York City galleries, all members of the Art Dealers' Association, will stage simultaneous shows next month to discover "new and exciting talents." Artists of any age or nationality and working in any medium are eligible for selection by each gallery.

A group of 31 nutritionists and 10 citizens' organizations, fearing a trend away from "real foods," announced their opposition today to proposed regulations of the Department of Agriculture that would formally allow "alternate foods" in the nation's school lunch program.

Round Two of the Sporting Battle of the Sexes. Lou Nova, a 58-year-old former heavyweight boxer, said yesterday in Los Angeles, "I would fight any woman in the world for $100,000." Nova, was who knocked out by Joe Louis in a championship fight in 1941, issued the challenge for a bout in Las Vegas, Nev., saying, "I think it would be a good idea. don't you?"
Roger Hawthorne, a newsman for whom Rear Adm. Richard E. Byrd named a mountain in the Antarctic, died Saturday at Barnstable County Hospital. He was 68 years old.

Nobuko Imai led off Carnegie Hall's third and final Three by Three concert on Sunday afternoon with three works for solo viola: a Sonata by Hindemith, a Suite by Reger and Bach's Chaconne. Miss Imai's playing was just this side of spectacular as she drew long, clean, sonorous lines, triumphantly surmounted every technical difficulty and made superb musical sense of each niece.

After half a dozen mannequins swept down the runway of Calvin Klein's showroom just off Seventh Avenue, the last was joined by a male model wearing an identical outfit. Well, almost identical. He wore checked pants; she had on a long checked skirt. They both wore brown sweater jackets and ivory shirts. They linked arms and walked off together.

The National General Corporation reported yesterday net income of $9.8-million, equal to $1.91 a share for the first quarter this year, down from $18.2million, or $3.47 a share, for the corresponding quarter a year ago.

Staff Sgt. John D. Layton, an Army basic training drill instructor here, was acquitted by a court-martial at noon today of charges that he had physically and verbally abused a recruit under his command.
The funeral of Lex Barker, the film actor who died here on Friday, will take place at 11:30 A.M. today at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

More than the $35,000 worth of prizes are dancing through the minds of the contestants in the three-day Dodge open golf tournament that will start here tomorrow over the Rockaway River Country Club's course. The river in the club's name is for real and presents a dreaded water hazard on the 18th hole.

Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court here took possession today of papers purportedly relating to the Watergate case despite a request by the White House that they be returned.

Making a strong closing rush under the guidance of Marco Castaneda, Harold I. Snyder's Krislin captured the $28,075 Vagrancy Handicap, the sevenfurlong feature for fillies and mares at Belmont Park yesterday.

A completely automated typesetting system, developed and put into operation with the cooperation of the typographical union, was demonstrated yesterday by The Composing Room, Inc., a printing company at 387 Park Avenue.

Air coordinators directing the United States bombing of Cambodia received orders yesterday from Seventh Air Force headquarters in Thailand to switch to special secret frequencies to prevent monitoring, military sources said today.
The presiding officer of the Senate, the former Premier Amintore Fanfani, denied today that he had requested secret United States Government funds to sway Italian politics.

E. Paul Gangewere, retired president and board chairman of the Reading Company, died yesterday. He was 72 years old. Mr. Gangewere, a graduate of Lehigh University, began his career in 1922 as an apprentice in the locomotive and car shops, rising to the presidency from 1960 to 1964.
A Federal judge today prohibited the State Commission of Investigation from making public the names of targets of its investigation of the state workmen's compensation system.

The president of the American Statistical Association has :protested the appointment of two men with strong Republican political ties but no professional background to head two of the most important statistical agencies in the Federal Government.

Three Conservative party state leaders last night repudiated Representative Mario Biaggi, their party's mayoral nominee, while five other Conservative leaders reaffirmed their support of the candidate.

Maryland will be seeded No.1 in the national lacrosse championship tournament beginning on Saturday. The Terrapins swamped Johns Hopkins, 17-4, last weekend to finish their season unbeaten, in seven games. The Terps also were ranked atop the weekly lacrosse coaches poll announced yesterday.
Top-seeded Marcelo de la Serna, who comes from Bolivia, made a belated start in the Eastern men's hardcourt tennis championship today and reached the fourth round at the Woodbury Country Club.
The East-West talks to arrange for negotiations on a reduction of armed forces in central Europe opened here today with a nine-minute meeting.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, and Senator Abraham Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, both deplored here yesterday any talk of impeachment of President Nixon in the wake of the Watergate disclosures, while endorsing measures "to get to the bottom of the matter."

American Motor Inns yesterday announced a proposed secondary offering of 153,723 common shares, to be sold for certain selling shareholders, had been withdrawn on grounds that prospective selling shareholders had no desire to sell their shares at present market levels. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, closed unchanged at 9.

Senator Stuart Symington said today that three high-level White House aides had been deeply involved in trying to enlist the help of the Cenrtal Intelligence Agency in domestic undercover activities other than the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

Governor Rockefeller, standing in the White House briefing room, outlined plans today for a bipartisan national commission to seek "a clearer sense of national purpose" for the nation's third century.

Following is a statement of William D. Ruckelshaus, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the results of an inquiry about missing records relating to electronic surveillance on certain in individuals:
The fournation peacekeeping commission voted unanimously today to investigate Communist chargess that the United States had resumed bombing in South Vietnam in violation of the cease-fire.

A City Hall reception for the whole team and presentation of a sports car to Willis Reed are the remaining orders of business for the New York Knicks today, as the aura of success continued to surround them.
PALERMO, Sicily - Of Sicily's three most notorious mafiosi, one is in retirement, another is in jail and the third is in hiding. The "godfather of godfathers" is Giuseppe Genco Russo, 80 years old.
The Nixon Administration, rebuffed on its Indochina policies by the House last week, was rebuffed further today in the Senate by two moves aimed at cutting off funds for bombing in Cambodia.

Mrs. Billie Jean King arrived from Japan today and immediately challenged Bobby Riggs to a tennis match. Mrs. King said in a telephone news conference from Hilton Head Island, S.C., that she would put up $5,000 and her sponsor,

For America's first space station, Skylab 1, the crowds were most noticeable by their absence. When the last of the moon missions, Apollo 17, was launched Dec. 7, the police estimated that a crowd of more than one million packed the Cape Kennedy area to see the blastoff.

The trials for Saturday night's. $119,732 Messenger Stakes will be paced tonight in the fourth and sixth races at Roosevelt Raceway. fifteen owners have posted $2,000 starting fees in hopes of qualfying for the 18th edition of the race for 3-year olds.

When John Martin eyes his tachometer while running at high speed, he sees not only revolutions per minute, but dollar signs. The name of his McLaren is the Unsponsored Special, and it means exactly that.
Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of thes short-term securities. The average rate for 3month bills in this week's sale is 6.179 per cent,

After a five-month investigation into the city's use of provisional employes, a Manhattan grand jury yesterday accused a former high-ranking Lindsay administration official of "gross abuse" of his authority and recommended disciplinary action against him.
Bernard Cornfeld, the American financier who created the Investors Overseas Services mutual fund empire, was jailed here today.

Frank Rose, vice president and treasurer of the Eden Transportation System and a leader in the taxicab industry, died Saturday of cancer in Nassau Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived at 62 Tobin Avenue, Great Neck, L.I.

The apparatus whose inability to deploy properly has partly disrupted the Skylab space mission Is a solar-cell array whose job is to convert rays from the sun into electricity for the astronauts' main quarters in orbit.

Two years after a dramatic management shakeup and bruising proxy fight, the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation appears close to settling millions of dollars of outstanding claims and emerging from the limbo of a quiet Federal securities investigation and a fraud case.

A new investigation has been started by the Bronx District Attorney's office into the event that won Mario Biaggi recognition as a police hero, the 1959 shooting case in which he killed an apparent holdup man n the rear seat of a parked car.
Two new moons were injected into orbit around the earth today, and both of them should sooner or later-depending primarily on weather conditions--be visible to 90 per cent of the world's inhabitants.
The Secretary of the Army, Robert F. Froehike, turned down today parole board recommendations that he trim three years from the 20-year sentence of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.

Dave Cowens of the Boston Celtics, the most valuable player of the National Basketball Association and also the most valuable in the All-Star game, had to be satisfied with a second-team berth in the all-league selections yesterday.
At a time when he fancies himself as a "55-year-old player with one foot in the grave," Bobby Riggs'is finding a magic second wind in his competitive career.

There are some pieces that the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater company performs with special verve. One is Donald McKayle's "Rainbow Rouhd My Shoulder," which was seen Sunday evening for the firt time this season.

President Nixon nominated Kenneth B. Keating, former Ambassador to India, as Ambassador to Israel. The Israeli Government has already reportedly told the United States that the 72-year - old former Senator would be acceptable.

Ehrlichman, President Nixon's former chief adviser on domestic affairs, produced the records of 17 wiretaps placed on newsmen and Government officials. during a 21-month effort to halt "leaks" of secret information to the press. Mr. Ruckelshaus said he and an F.B.I.

The late Martin Tananbaum, president of Yonkers Raceway and a controversial figure in New York politics before his death in 1970, paid about $40,000 in legal fees to the law firm of Assemblyman Alfred H. Blumenthal in 1965 and 1966.

The proposed Gateway National Recreation Area, a series of parks and beaches stretching from Jamaica in Queens to Sandy Hook in New Jersey, will serve the nearly twenty million residents jammed into the most densely populated urban area in the nation. The City of New York, the states of New York and New Jersey, and the Federal Government have a rare opportunity to preserve these invaluable' stretches of shoreline for the enjoyment of future generations.
The Suffolk County police charged today that a 45-yearold widow stabbed her three children, killing one of them, early this morning as they were asleep in their small house here.

The first Soviet-written literary biography of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel Prize-winning novelists has emerged with an inside story of- the uneven struggle to publish his works in the Soviet Union.

Jimmy Wright, who has won the Long Island open golf championship in three of the last four years, shot a 70 today to take the first-round lead. The slim defending champion from Inwood was the only contestant in a field of 147 to break the par-71 of the Pine Hollow Country Club.
Indians in New Mexico and Arizona are being denied job and education opportunities, health care and access to water, the United States Commission on Civil Rights said today.

The Vietcong have replaced one of their top fighting generals as head of their delegation to the Vietnam cease-fire military negotiations in Saigon and assigned him back to duty with military units in the field.
Staff Sgt. John D. Layton, an Army basic training drill instructor here, was acquitted by a court-martial today of charges that he had physically and verbally abused a recruit under his command:
The trouble with Wilhelm Steinitz's conception of positional play was that it put far too much emphasis on pawn structure free from weaknesses.

Two civilian aides who answer the telephones when people dial 911 for police help were arrested yesterday in Manhattan Police Headquarters on charges of possessing and selling marijuana to undercover narcotics patrolmen. The suspects were identified as Frank Hernandez, 23 years old, of 465 West 152d Street, who has been employed in the communications room since 1971, and Henry Romero, 22, of 1305 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn, who has been in communications since March.
Nicolas Mordvinoff, an artist and prize-winning illustrator of children's books, committed suicide on the night of May 5 at his home in Hampton, N. J. He was 61 years old.

Sigmund Sommer's Sham, the powerful son of Pretense who was second to Secretariat in the Kenucky Derby, came out for his final Preakness workout this morning at Pimlico Race Course and impressed clockers and his trainer, Frank (Pancho) Martin, as he went rive furlongs in 0:58 2-5.

Skylab, the nation's first space station, was rocketed into orbit today but a deployment failure of its solar-power wings forced a five-day delay and serious curtailment of manned operations aboard the massive research spaceship.

New evidence from outside the Federal Government has become available in the last few days that helps to explain both the extraordinary pace of the economic boom in the early months of 1973 and the accompanying high rate of inflation.
ROAD TO LEARNING Amsterdam Avenue is scarcely a cultural Appian Way at first glance, but it does run past Lincoln Center, Columnbia University,

The Supreme Court ruled today that female members of the armed services were entitled to the same dependency benefits for their husbands as servicemen have always received for their wives. The vote was 8 to 1.

The Minnesota Vikings reacquired Bob Berry, a quarterback, from Atlanta today as partial compensation when their reserve quarterback, Bob Lee, and middle linebacker, Lonnie Warwick, signed with the Falcons.
Count Leonardo Vitetti, Italian representative to the United Nations from 1956 to 1958, died yesterday in Rome. He was 78 years old. Count Vitetti was the husband of the former Natalie Coe,

The price of gold rose above $100 an ounce in Europe for the first time today and the dollar weakened sharply, ushering in what could be another period of monetary tension even after the two recent devaluations of the dollar.
UNIONDALE, L. I.-He was smoking something exotic from a home-made tinfoil pipe and swaying in the aisle of the Nassau Coliseum, grooving on Rod Stewart and The Faces.

The city's Consumer Affairs Department yesterday sued Grolier, Inc., accusing the encyclopedia and teaching materials company of having tricked the parents of hundreds of parochial school children into paying $300 to $500 for "flimsy plastic teaching machines" and sets of books.
Cornelius Brett Boocock Sr., dean of men at Rutgers University from 1948 until his retirement in 1963, died today in: Point Pleasant Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Mantoloking.

C.B.S. News reported' last night that John D. Ehrlichman and others whose names have been connected to White House investigations of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg will be the subject of "a new grand jury investigation expected to open in Los Angeles," according to the Associated Press.

What are the chances of finding a respectable performance of a rarely performed opera in the meeting room of a Manhattan church? Very good, provided you go to the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at 30 East 31st Street, where a doughty group called the Bel Canto Opera has put on a surprising number of such performances in recent seasons, the most recent being Poulenc's "Dialogues of the Carmelites," in English.

The Minnesota Fighting Saints of the World Hockey Association today signed Coach Harry Neale to a two-year contract. Terms were not disclosed. Neale joined the Saints last August as an assistant to Glen Sonmor, then coach and general manager.

Oil industry sources today categorically denied charges made yesterday by Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, that seven Israeli agents had been discovered on the staff of an American oil company operating in Libya.
The Minnesota Fighting Saints of the World Hockey Association today signed Coach Harry Neale to a two-year contract. Terms were not disclosed.
Ed Remmick owned 217 cattle one recent night. The next morning he owned 220. "All winter long," he said, "you just wait and wait and wait and wait not doing much of anything.

When Bobby Riggs was 11 years old, he played his first tennis game with a borrowed racquet and immediately began scheming for some way he could get a racquet he could call his own. Not long thereafter, he was wander'ing wistfully around the court when he noticed a man amusing himself by scaling away an old tennis bat and having his dog retrieve it.

The nation moved a step closer toward what Senate Majority Leader Mansfield has warned could become "a true constitutional crisis" when a Senate Appropriations subcommittee yesterday accepted a House-approved prohibition on the transfer of funds for bombing in Cambodla. The Administration has already indicated it will ignore such a ban even if it is endorsed by Congress.
Television News, Inc., a new supplier of news film to TV stations, yesterday began a daily, line-fed service to about 30 stations across the country on a two-weeks, no-charge basis.
Eric H. Hager, a senior partner- in the law firm of Shearman Sterling, 53 Wall Street, died Sunday of a heart attack on a vacation in Bermuda. He was 54 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

Drug abuse and narcotics traffic are many-headed phenomena that tough law-enforcement and "glamourous" international crackdowns may drive into new forms, a Senate subcommittee hearing on the Federal Government's new narcotics super agency was told here yesterday.
The Government said today that its troops had halted Burundian insurgents who had entered the country from Rwanda in the north and from Tanzania in the south..
Anthony Lewis, a columnist for The New York Times and twice a Pulitzer Prize winner, will be awarded an honorary doctorate by Rutgers University, the university announced today.

Senator Stuart Symington said today that three high-level White House aides had been deeply involved in trying to enlist the help of the Central Intelligence Agency in domestic undercover activities other than the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

Confronted with a surging incidence of botulism toxin in commercially canned food, theo Government today ordered certain canners to register their processes and face a shutdown if they do not measure up.

A City Hall reception for the whole team and presentation of a sports car to Willis Reed are the remaining orders of business for the New York Knicks today, as the aura of success continued to surround them.

Guinea and Yugoslavia criticized the United States today in the Security Council for permitting the import of chrome and nickel from Rhodesia despite the Council's embargo on trading with that white-ruled country.

Federal Bureau of Investigation agents killed a distraught father with a barrage of gunshots today when he began climbing down a ladder on a 40-foot fuel tank, where he had held a hostage at gunpoint for nearly eight hours.

Henry A. Kissinger confirmed today that he had seen summaries from several wiretaps, placed in 1969 and 1970, but said that he had not asked they be installed nor had he specifically approved them in advance.
Governor Cahill announced today that the State Senate would return here May 21 for a special session to reconsider a sharply revised package of controversial coastal protection legislation.

SAN FRANCISCO- At a time when certain critics are questioning the value of a true repertory system in which a company performs several different plays in nightly alternation, San Francisco's American Conservatory Theater is providing a stirring demonstration of how effective and joyous the repertory way of life can be.

Total business inventories rose less in March than in the two previous months, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase for manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers combined was $1.4-billion in March, compared with $1.8billion in February and $2.2billion in January.
Mrs. James Augustus Thomas lives surrounded by two centuries of exotic fruits and flowers, a reflection both of her love of gardens and of the happier times of her younger years.
The Erie Lackawanna Railway Company's financial reorganization under! the Federal bankruptcy law probably has been as successful as is

The Environmental Protection Agency registered its opposition today to any substantial expansion of Federal efforts to develop a low-pollution alternative to the conventional internal combustion engine.
A key defendant in the Federal investigation of alleged fraud in the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign pleaded guilty to

During a packed ceremony in the Blue Room of City Hall, Mayor Lindsay yesterday pinned the Police Commissioner's gold badge on Donald F. Cawley and praised the 43-year-old former chief of patrol as an "innovator"
Antique jewelry, old gold coins, a shotgun and three rifles valued at from $30,000 to $50,000 were stolen from a store in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.
Edwin T. Meredith 3d, a 40-year-old grandson of the founder of the Meredith Corporation, was named chairman yesterday. He will continue as chief executive officer.

Only one of the four Democratic candidates for New York's chief judicial post was found "well qualified" by the State Bar Association yesterday, prompting two men it found "not qualified" to denounce the ratings as politically motivated.
Governor Rockefeller submitted a pension bill to the Legislature today with a hint that unless it was passed most of the 147,000 state employes might go on strike.

The formal preparatory discussions between NATO and the Warsaw Pact on- mutual force reductions in Central Europe is finally under way in Vienna; but the prospects for solid, rapid progress seem dim. Though details of the agreement that broke a fourteen-week impasse have not been announced, it is clear that the West has yielded to the Soviet Union's refusal to accept full participation by Hungary.

Paul Recard, a former member of the board of directors of a Harlem day-care center, was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing about $900 from the Area 145 Day Care Center at 510 West 145th Street.

The White House described as "a total fabrication" today a newspaper article that said Senate investigators believed President Nixon might have used leftover 1968 campaign funds to buy his California estate.

Directors of the New York Public Library and the Harvard, Yale ard Columbia University libraries, feeling the squeeze of Federal budget cuts, rising costs and the need to cope with an ever-growing mountain of books, met here yesterday to explore coordination and cooperation.

North Vietnam today reiterated its charge that United States planes had struck Communist-held areas of South Vietnam and warned that forthcoming talks with Henry A. Kissinger would be canceled if raids continued.
The Lebanese Parliament failed today to obtain a quorum to vote on extension of the state of emergency declared a week ago when there was fighting between the army and Palestinian guerrillas..

The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, G. Bradford Cook, testified under oath for nearly five hours today before a Senate subcommittee about the agency's investigation of Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier.

Greece's most recent Premier in a constitutional government accused the nation's military-backed regime today of violating elementary principles of justice by making large-scale secret arrests of dissenting students and intellectuals.

Raymond L. Dirks, the stockmarket analyst who ran into trouble with the New York Stock Exchange for telling his clients about what he had uncovered concerning the insurance fraud at the Equity Funding Corporation of America, officially petitioned the exchange yesterday to postpone its findings in his case until several lawsuits now pending are decided in court.
The Nixon Administration, rebuffed on its Indochina policies by the House last week, was rebuffed further today in the Senate by two moves aimed at cutting off funds for bombing in Cambodia.

The acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that records of 17 wiretaps placed on newsmen and Government officials were discovered last week in a White House safe belonging to John D. Ehrlichman, one of the Presidential assistants who resigned over the Watergate scandal.

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal defended public education, legalized abortion and the need for New York City's communities to survive as separate entities, as he campaigned yesterday for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

Donald L. Kaminski, who had been the world's second-longest living heart transplant patient, died today. Officials at the University of Michigan Hospital in Ann Arbor said that Mr. Kaminski, 43 years old, had been ill lately.

Senator John L. McClellan, that thunderous pillar of ostensible virtue, recently said that the statistics on two and a half years of court-authorized wiretapping "should do a great deal to relieve the fears of some citizens. of an excessive use of these techniques by legitimate law-enforcement agents...."
Britain's biggest automobile manufacturer, the British Leyland Motor Corporation, announced today an expansion program that would cost around $1.2-billion over the next five years.

All day yesterday the parishioners of St. Bonaventure's Roman Catholic Church went to the red-tiled rectory in the St. Alban's section of Queens to share their grief over the murder of their priest, the Rev. John Conlon.
The Health Department yesterday listed eight more foodprocessing establishments in New York City where Health Code violations were found to persist on reinspection.

Volkswagen, the financially ailing auto maker, reported today a 40 per cent gain in net profit for 1972, but Rudolf Leiding, the company's chairman, said earnings were still far from satisfactory. Presenting the company's 1972 annual report, Mr. Leiding said that Volkswagen's worldwide profits last year were $63.6-million, up from $45.5-million in 1972. He noted that the earnings increase came despite a 3 per cent drop in 1972 sales.
The steel industry made it virtually unanimous yesterday in following price increases for sheet and strip steel announced last Thursday by the United States Steel Corporation.

While expressing sentiments of "disgust" and "revulsion" over the Watergate scandal, Republican members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation say they still support President Nixon and have faith in his ability to lead the nation effectively.

The Watergate commercial and apartment complex, which is becoming as well-known as the national monuments here because of the break-in last June 17, is Washington's most valuable piece of taxable commercial property, according to assessment records.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, outlined some proposals today, including stricter campaign spending laws, that he said could prevent future Watergate scandals in government.

A quarter century ago the nations of the West perceived a common danger to their security-Stalin's armed divisions in Central Europe - and united into a structure of political and military institutions to meet that threat.

The stock market plunged yesterday in stepped-up trading. The Dow-Jones industrial average registered its biggest loss for a day in almost three years. The index tumbled 18.29 points to finish the session at 909.69.

Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court here took possession today of papers purportedly relating to the Watergate case despite a request by the White House that they be returned.
Finding himself in a country where politicians fear the pen, Heinrich Boll feels perfectly at home. "You have all sceneries here," said West Germany's 1972 Nobel laureate in literature.
A soldier absent without leave since Jan. 8 has pleaded not guilty to charges that he raped and murdered a girl and killed two men over the weekend on the city's East Side.
Philco-Ford will move its account Aug. 13 to Kenyon Eckhardt, an ad agency for the Ford. Motor Company since 1948.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions today approved a ban on the handling of all French goods as a protest against France's planned nuclear tests in the South Pacific.

In summertime following 59 days in court, defense lawyers for the "Camden 28" asserted today that the Government had gone too far in "manufacturing" the crime 'the defendants were charged with committing.

YONKERS -In Paris, at Christian Dior's, there is an air of barely repressed panic before each fashion showing. But you should have seen the nervousness in Yonkers at the Jewish Guild Home for the Aged Blind.
The April meat boycott, whose sults disappointed the housewives who led it, will put "downward pressure" on prices after all, a Department of Agriculture advisory for May has indicated.
A year ago P. J. Johnson was a plump Houston schoolgirl who liked to dance up a storm to rock music in her home after school. It was her only "theatrical experience," she says.
The Senate Appropriations Committee, in a further Congressional rebuff to President Nixon's Indochina policies, voted 24 to 0 today to cut off all funds for bombing in Cambodia.

Tom Nieporte regained the Long Island open golf title to,day despite a closing round of 76 for a 54-hole total of 216. Although he led by four strokes after the morning session, the 44-year-old Piping Rock Club professional scored his fourth victory in this event by only one stroke.
Mayor Lindsay submitted yesterday a $10.595-billion expense budget for the 1973-74 fiscal year, containing a real-estate tax increase that is the largest for any year in the city's history.
Former State Treasurer Joseph M. Mc' Crane Jr. was indicted by the state today on bribery and misconduct charges.
The skylab workshop has been ap?earing on schedule, in its appointed rounds of the earth, observerss reported today, with at least five pieces visible from the ground.

Planting of grains is overcoming a late start caused by heavy spring rains and flooding, the Department of Agriculture said today, and there is still time to get enough seed in the ground to produce big crops.

The price of gold roared up to $128.50 in Paris yesterday-an utterly unprecedented leap away from the dollar. Just the day before the gold price had climbed above $100'an ounce for the first time in history. In European money markets, gold buying-and the unloading of United States dollars-took on panic proportions. The message coming from everywhere, as one dealer put it, was "get out of dollars at all costs."

Independent gasoline dealers told a legislative hearing here today that major oil companies were systematically choking off their supplies in an effort to stifle competition and that they would be out of business unless a law was enacted soon to assure supplies.

A less hazardous cigarette should be on the market within five years, says Dr. Frank Rauscher Jr., head of the National Cancer Institute at Bethesda, Md.
Two bills designed to reform the City Tax Commission and its method of setting realestate tax assessments met with a favorable reception yesterday at a brief hearing before a City Council committee.

Economics is often regarded--especially by economistsas the most advanced and successful of the social sciences, the only one that is privileged to confer a Nobel Prize on its star practitioners.

Governor, Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay have been at swords' points for so long that any Rockefeller proposal to "help out" New York City is naturally bound to be received with considerable initial reserve at City Hall. Warranted as that reserve usually proves, it would not seem to be the right response to the plan just advanced by the Governor for state takeover of public welfare and Medicaid administration.

The Lindsay administration's often-delaycd plan to create a Madison Avenue pedestrian mall was dealt another blow yesterday when an appeals court unanimously upheld a ruling that the city's Transportation Administration did not have the authority to create the mall.

Don Massengale of Elmwood, N.Y., last year's winner, scored a six-under-par 33, 33-66 today to take a three-stroke lead in the first round of the $35,000 Dodge open at the Rockaway River Country Club.

One by-product of the current ragtime renaissance has been the appearance of instrumental ensembles devoted to arrangements, primarily of. rags, that were played by dance orchestras during the ragtime era more than half century ago.
Governor Rockefeller today sent the Legislature a bill to implement his new program for dealing with narcotics traffickers.

" It was fascinating how they got out," Sheriff Ralph Oriscello said of three prisoners who escaped from the Union County jail. The three inmates used rods from their beds to pry open a fire door attached to the end of their eight-prisoner cell tier, and let out a makeshift rope of bedsheets from a seventh floor window. From there, Sheriff Oriscello said, they dropped to the third floor and then to the street.

The American Revolution Bicentennial Commission killed it bicentennial parks plan today with Government officials voting heavily against spending the money.

The gislature today adopted a resolution to adjourn for the year this Friday, but the realists in the House agreed that, historically, they must ration their patience and laundry to go beyond that date to the traditional torpor of whereases and where-am-I's.

The Sacred Heart Grammar School's fencing team held its Trophy Night on May 5 and that program officially marked the end of the season for the sword wielders. But the awards dinner did not conclude the fencing activity for Bill Petrucci. Proud to be coach of one of the few elementary school fencing teams in the state, Petrucci is planning next season's schedule and also is attempting to recruit more youngsters for his favorite sport.
The principal gold dealer of a big Swiss bank described trading today, in which the total again soared to record prices, as among the most active he could remember.

David and Julie Eisenhower, son-in-law and daughter of the President, have taken up residence in their rented home in nearby Bethesda, Md., the White House said today. The young couple moved in Friday night. The $125,000 home
' The price of gold jewelry, you ask? We don't know what quotes to give our customers. Everything is going through the roof."

A vote by the House of Representatives on a bill to devalue the United States dollar by 10 per cent, which was scheduled for tomorrow, has been delayed for at least a week, House Democratic leader Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., of Massachusetts announced today.
A 50-year-old man's refusal to follow the precepts of Hasidic divorce resulted in his being kidnapped, beaten and detained by five other Hasidic Jews, a Brooklyn grand jury charged yesterday.

The Houston Oilers announced today they had traded Ken Houston, an all-pro strong safety, to the Washington Redskins for five players. The five coming from Washington are Jim Snowden, an offensive tackle; Mac Alston.

Tony Perez slugged a pair of home runs and accounted for all of Cincinnati's runs tonight as the Reds downed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-1. Don Gullett gained his fourth victory, getting relief help from Pedro Borbon, who recorded his fifth save of the season.
A Portland woman who says she spent $17.50 to have two packages of ground beef analyzed has sued a supermarket chain for $100,719. She contends the ground beef contrained too much fat.
A hard winter has made their White River .Valley wetter, greener and more beautifulthis spring than usual, and ranchers are driving cattle and sheep north through town to the high summer range.

The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted unanimously at its February meet ing to seek slower growth of the nation's money supply and other monetary "aggregates, a summary of the meeting disclosed today.
The Institute for Public Interest Representation sued the Internal Revenue Service today to gain access to files on the new $1 checkoff on tax returns for political-campaign contributions.

Contributions and grants totaling $4.2-million to the Associated Y.M.-Y.W.HA.'s of Greater New York were 'announced last night by Sidney J. Silberman, president of the group. He said the grants would be used for building projects, including the Block Vacation Center for the Aged at Poyntelle, Pa., which will serve 750 New/York residents in its initial summer season beginning in July.

The Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corporation-will permit the United Auto Workers to hold local elections on company property to "allow larger numbers of employes to participate in the selection of their union representatives."

Detectives from the Bronx District Attorney's office pressed their investigation yesterday of the 1959 shooting incident, in which Mario Biaggi, then a police lieutenant, killed a 23-yearold apparent holdup man.

Denis Potvin, a fast, aggressive, high-scoring defenseman in the mold of Boston's Bobby Orr, was chosen by the New York Islanders today as the No. pick in the National Hockey League's draft of amateur players.
Willis Reed received a 1973 Dodge Charger from Sport magazine yesterday as the most valuable player of the National Basketball Association's championship playoff series. His 11 teammates on

The International Business Machines Corporation, the giant makers of computers, decided in 1970 to compete against small manufacturers of peripheral computer equipment rather than "do nothing" and lose more of the market, Frank T. Cary, I.B.M.'s president and chairman, testified today in Federal court here.

A light rainfall in the afternoon and a gloomy forecast for last night caused an early postponement of the finale of the two-game series between the New York Yankees and the Detroit Tigers at the Yanke Stadium.
John Craddick, a 24-year-old Vietnam war veteran, has a job as a bus driver. Recently at the end of his run he spotted a manila envelope left in one of the seats.

Count Leonardo Vitetti, Italian representative to the United Nations from 1956 to 1958, died Monday in Rome. He was 78 years old. Count Vitetti was the husband of the former Natalie Coe, granddaughter of Henry H. Rogers, Standard Oil financier. At his house in Vigna del
A Portland woman who says she spent $17.50 to have two packages of ground beef analyzed has sued a supermarket chain for $100,719. She contends the ground beef contained too much fat.
A single Issue has slowly come to dominate activity at the low gray Brussels headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization: money.
There seems to be little question that institutional traders can have an undue impact on the stock market.

The sound of black, protest in white-ruled South Africa has grown louder ho and more' persistent in recent days, 'as . traditional African leaders condemn 'the racial system they were expected-to help sustain.
Rhode Islana's law against abortions, adopted two months ago, was declared unconstitutional today by Chief Judge Raymond J. Pettine in United States District Court.

Prof. William Von Minder, founder and former director of the division of professional accounting at Rutgers University's Graduate School of Business, died yesterday at the Allendale Nursing Home. He was 71 years old and lived here.
The faculty union at Rutgers University has filed suit to upset state guidelines allocating, funds for various levels of study on the basis of student-faculty ratios.

Six Army officers and a military civilian employee were found dead today in the wreckage of a "Huey" helicopter that crashed while on a night mission to evaluate newly developed goggles for magnifying moonlight visibility.

Mayor Peter J. Bonastia of Montclair issued an order Tuesday declaring two apartment buildings-long troubled by housing violations and tenant protests-as "unfit for human habitation." His order directs the owners to repair the buildings within 120 days or the town will do the job itself or "demolish said buildings."

With seven first-time starters in the field, Frank Blois didn't want any part of yesterday's third race at Belmont Park. "You're just stumbling around in the dark," grumbled Blois, a 47-year-old retired Staten Islander who says he makes a living playing horses. "They should never allow betting on a race that has first-time starters."

John L. Loeb, a Wall Street d investment banker whose" philanthropic gifts measure in the millions of dollars, was accused by the Federal Government yesterday of having disguised a $48,000 contribution to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's unsuccessful 1972 campaign for the Presidency.

With the opening of the Ervin committee hearings today, the nation carries forward the task-already under way in several grand jury rooms-of sorting out truth from rumor about the interlocking crimes and conspiracies known as Watergate. Public testimony by many witnesses over the coming weeks may illuminate the role of one man not likely to be called as a witness, President Nixon.

The Brazilian Government has formally canceled an agreement to supply American makers of instant coffee with 560,000 bags of coffee beans, the raw material for the instant product, per year free of export taxes. The price of coffee seemed likely today to provide a topic of conversation when the United States Secretary of State, William P. Rogers, meets with Brazilian authorities in Brasilia next week.

The Senate Banking Committee approved today legislation that would permit brokers who are affiliated with institutional inVestors to continue to be members of stock exchanges-and to Join them-so long as sales commissions on stock transactions continue to be price-fixed.
The United States said in the Security Council today that United Nations sanctions were having an economic .impact on the white-minority Government in Rhodesia and should be made more effective.

Gubernational candidates of both parties, speaking at one of the state's most important political forums, raised the issue of corruption in government today but concentrated their remarks on such close-to-home problems as crime, taxes, education and transportation.

The Most Rev. Francis J. Mugavero, bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, last night received the human relations award of the Anti - Defamation League of B'nai B'rith at a dinner in theGrand Ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel.

A consumer group said today that two years of operation of the nation's passenger trains by Amtrak had been a disappointment and that some of the railroads that operated Amtrak trains were deliberately trying to kill passenger service.
Ar organization of building contractors accused 17 building trades unions today of waging a campaign of violence in attempting to force them out of business.

Garrett Brock Trapnell, who admitted hijacking a Trans World Airlines Boeing 707 on Jan. 29, 1972, but contended that he was insane at the time, was found guilty last night of air piracy, unlawful interference with a flight crew and Possession of a gun.

Battle fatigue continued to take its. toll of top players in the $150,000 Alan King tennis tournament today. The latest seeded figures to wilt from the 93-degree heat, soft Australian balls, postDallas blues and some hungry young pro rivals were Ken Rosewall, Marty Riessen and John Newcombe, the defending champion.
Seven out of 10 Americans are satisfied with the taste, color, smell and quality of their water, according to a public opinion official. John Davies, vice president of the Gallup Poll, Inc., told

Piercing through a couple of floors of the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of History and Technology in Washington is a great pendulum. To tourists and' scientists, its long, slow swings demonstrate the motion of the earth, but to politicians it symbolizes the inexorability of change in public opinion.
A South Viet- Vietnamese antiwar leader will be turned over to the Communists because she had "close liaison with the Communists," a Government spokesman said today.
The Federal Reserve Board took a series of steps today to slow the huge growth in bank lending to business and, thus, to cool the inflationary

Representative Mario Biaggi appeared yesterday before a special state grand jury investigating the possible manipulation of the court system in a case in which Mr. Biaggi received $240,000 in legal fees.
The Children's Mass," which opened last night at the Theater de Lys, is a mixture of good and bad, but as a first play it can be regarded as at least promising. It has

The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission resigned following allegations that he had deleted a reference to Robert L. Vesco's secret $200,000 political contribution from a S.E.C. complaint against the financier. In quitting after 74 days as chairman, G. Bradford Cook became the 13th Administration official to resign since late. February. [Page 1, Column 8.]

" I used to be a slave on the hacienda but now I can work for my family and get an education-thanks to Monsefior," a young Indian said passionately at a meeting of the Juan Diego farm cooperative, and the 10 other members nodded in assent.

The Watergate hearings that begin tomorrow in the marblecolumned caucus room of the Old Senate Office Building may be vital to the progress of Richard Nixon's Presidency. Another set of Congressional hearings, 25 years ago, propelled him from the obscurity of a Representative's first term onto the path to the White House.

To the Editor: Senator Proxmire's equating of press and television reporting of Watergate and related subversive activities with McCarthyism reveals fundamental confusion on his part regarding what is involved and what is at stake.

The latest seeded figures to wilt from the 93-degree heat, soft Australian balls, postDallas blues and some hungry young pro rivals were Ken Rosewall, Marty' Riessen and John Newcombe, the defending champion.

John Hart and Nelson Benton will leave "The C.B.S. Morning News" by midsummer and the entire hour-long daily show will be revamped, Richard S. Salant, president of the news for the Columbia Broadcasting System, said yesterday.

The Federal Trade Commission, in an extraordinary action, reopened today an antitrust case it had already decided against Litton Industries, Inc. The reopening was for the purpose of reconsidering the penalty the commission had imposed on the company for violation of the antitrust laws with its acquisition of Triumph-Adler, a German typewriter company.

In the lighthearted play "The Teahouse of the August Moon," the wily Sakini noted philosophically that Okinawans had managed to survive the coming of the Chinese and Japanese in the past and would somehow do the same with the Americans who had just arrived.

Italy's great Blue Team beat its chief rivals, the Aces, in a first-round match here last night. Giorgio Belladonna, Benito Garozzo and Pietro Forquet, who among them have won 36 world titles, were assisted in the victory by a talented newcomer, Benito Bianchi.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark called on the city's Borough Presidents yesterday to remove the five members of the Board of Education because of their recent decision in the Tilden Houses school zoning controversy.

The Billy Graham, the evangelist, was described by one of his daughters as a stern, but loving father who spent more 'time preaching than he did with his five children as they grew up. His 22-year-old. daughter Mrs.

Our Native, third in the Kentucky Derby, arrived at Pimlico Race Course early this morning, relaxed for a few hours, then walked around the shedrow as line. he began preparations for another meeting with Secretariat and Sham in Saturday's 98th Preakness.

Space agency engineers, in their desperate struggle to invent a way out of the orbiting Skylab's troubles, are considering a plan to send up astronauts to spread a thin awning over much of the overheated space station.

John C. Burton, chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said here yesterday that its investigation of the Insurance scandal at the Equity Funding Corporation of America would lead to disciplinary action.

Warren M. Christopher, one of the men on Elliot L. Richardson's final list of possible special prosecutors in the Watergate case, turned down the job today because, he said, he would not have been given enough independence.

Nearly one-third of American consumers plan to-fight the cost of meat by eating less of it, in addition to 26 per cent who actively joined the fight by participating in the recent meat boycott, a Gallup survey shows.
The decline in housing starts and permits for new housing continued in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

Outstanding claims by the United States and China over funds frozen when the two countries broke diplomatic relations in 1949 will be settled soon, sources at the new United States liaison office here said today.
Uruguay's armed forces, in a challenge to the Senate, refused today to lay aside a demand for the removal of a leftist senator's parliamentary immunity, a pro-Government newspaper reported.

Kip Keino has left his homeland to rejoin the International Track Association pro tour after missing several meets. The distance runner, who had returned to Kenya to rest and attend to business interests, said he learned of last week's meets too late to enter. He had expected to resume competition later this month. He indicated he

Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell-again yesterday in slow trading. It was the fifth decline in a row. The Amex index fell 0.07 to close at 23.17 on volume of 2,658,915 shares, compared with 3,424,000 shares Tuesday.
The proCommunist newspaper Paese Sera reported today that the Italian state-owned oil corporation, E.N.I., had reached an accord with North Vietnam on offshore prospecting in the Gulf of Tonkin.
For the next six months at least, a trailer will be parked in the garment district on the west side of Eighth Avenue at 40th Street.
The Kansas City Royals conceded today they had no chance to win their protest against Nolan Ryan's no hitter, so they decided to forget about it.

Dorothy E. Miner, a leading scholar in medieval arts and keeper of manuscripts at the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore since 1934, died Tuesday at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. She was 68 years old.

Using angry questions and fist pounding, Senator Hubert H. Humpbrey wrung from top Federal officials today an admission that most national health programs would not get-more funds in the next budget, despite Nixon Administration reports to the contrary.

Representative Mario Biaggi appeared yesterday before a special state grand jury investigating the possible manipulation of the court system in a case in which Mr. Biaggi re ceived $240,000 in legal fees.

They squeezed the lettuce, examined the labeling on the white bread, tasted the American cheese, drank some apple juice and found out why supermarkets pack strawberries in cardboard containers.

Relatives of the wife of a wealthy builder and her pregnant daughter who were found hanged in their home here said today that they had been murdered, but investigators in the bizarre case refused to say whether the deaths were murder or suicide.
For the first time in nearly a decade, Columbia University held a commencement yesterday that was virtually unshadowned by war protest or reference to war.
Mayor John Reading, helped by a record voter turnOut, won an easy re-election victory yesterday over Bobby G. Seale, the Black Panther leader.

The New York Cosmos had to fight hard tonight to earn a 1-1 tie against a revitalized Miami team. Miami is under new ownership and the team name has been changed from Gatos to Toros. The Toros also have

The Career Center for Social Services yesterday cited Peter Kihss, a reporter for The New York Times, for his "contribution to public understanding of social problems." The citation was made at the organization's 17th annual meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Community Board 8 voted last night after an acrimonious two-hour debate to approve the revised plan of the New York City Educational Construction Fund for a combined public school and high-rise housing on the site of the abandoned Municipal Asphalt Plant in Yorkville.
Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leaders agreed today on additional state aid to schools, totaling $48-million.

Relatives of the wife of a wealthy builder and her pregnant daughter who were found in their home here said today that they had been murderer, but investigators in the bizarre case refused to say whether the deaths were mur der or suicide.
Must the City of New York maintain the confidentiality of applications by property owners for tax reductions, to protect what the real estate industry alleges are "trade secrets"?
A Bahamian trust, described at the holder of $1-billion in real estate in 35 states in this country, today was named a defendant in a $40-million damagesuitfiled in Federal District Court here.

A former Justice Department official said yesterday that he was asked in 1969 by John N. Mitchell, then the Attorney General, to deliver secret information about Government wiretaps to the Supreme Court shortly before the Justice Department asked the Court to reconsider its decision in an important wiretapping case.

It was honor time for the ballerina Melissa-Hayden at the New York State Theater last night. The occasion was a gala evening given by the New York City Ballet, which offered the previews of two new works, "Cortege Hongrois," by George
A hero returned to an estate under sunny skies today in a reunion that brought back memories of glorious times, as Long Island's Gold Coast glittered as brightly as ever.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan suggested yesterday that the United States Attorney General be stripped of his power to prosecute and that this power be transferred to a new office of Prosecutor General of the United States, which would be "above politics."
Two kegs of roofing nails fell from a truck and tied up southbound traffic for nearly three hours on the BrooklynQueens Expressway yesterday afternoon.

Governor Rockefeller has asked the State Task Force on Organized Crime to submit a full report on its inquiry into an incident in which Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo visited the State Dormitory Authority in behalf of a friend whose bid was rebuffed and then later accepted in a contract competition.

REMBRANDT'S HAT. By Bernard Malamud. 204 pages. Farrar, Straus Giroux. $6.95. How much of a story does an author have to give a reader before asking him to imagine the rest? I think this is one of the crucial questions of contemporary fiction.

The stock market was on a seesaw during most of the session yesterday and finished slightly lower in much slower trading. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange opened higher on news that the dollar had firmed in trading abroad following its recent weakness.

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal said yesterday that an analysis of $90,996 contributed to Controller Abraham D. Beame's campaign for Mayor showed that more than half came from real-estate interests that would, therefore, dominate Mr. Beame, should he be elected Mayor.
Mrs. Ridgely W. Cook, proprietor with her husband of the Princeton real-estate concern of Abbott Cook, died at her home here on Monday. She was 42 years old and lived at 58 Princeton Avenue.

Edward Fisher Brown, an executive in health and welfare causes and a retired vice president of National Dairy Products Corporation, died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 1158 Fifth Avenue.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers held an unannounced two-hour meeting today with Gen. Juan Velasco Alvarado, leader of Peru's revolutionary government.
Touro College, a tiny, threeyear-old institution under Jewish auspices, announced yesterday that it plans in 1974 to open New York City's first new law school in almost a halfcentury.

Although the Watergate scandals have raised doubts among some officials about President Nixon's ability to conduct a vigorous foreign policy, overseas criticism of the Administration has been light, and American foreign relations so far do not appear to have suffered significant damage.
No one knows how many self-employed persons such as artists and writers who earn money free-lancing are losing important tax advantages. One estimate puts the number at more than five million.

A widening Federal grand jury investigation of alleged price-fixing by prominent New York stores as far back as 1935, has resulted in the subpoenaing of the records and minutes of the Uptown Retail Guild-a former trade association grouping most of the upper Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue stores.
The Legislature today overwhelmingly approved a bill that would suspend for one year the 2.5 per cent income-tax surcharge authorized during the 1971-72 fiscal crisis.
A group that calls itself Pennies for the President is encouraging citizens to send one-cent pieces to the White House as a means of pretesting "the inequities in President Nixon's proposed budget."
A 25-year-old woman on a bicycle was critically injured yesterday when she collided with another cyclist in Central Park.

The dollar firmed today and the price of gold fell sharply as somewhat calmer conditions returned to Europe's money centers following the steep speculative losses for the currency and gains for the metal of the last couple of days.
A wide-ranging and potentially epic investigation of the reported effort last year to subvert the Presidential election campaign begins tomorrow on Capitol Hill.
President Nixon accused Congress today of "action that could severely undermine" the chances of restoring peace to Cambodia and all of Indochina.

When Manny Sanguillen became Pittsburgh's regular catcher in 1969, he made mistakes behind the plate and mistakes running the bases, but he overcame it all to become, some say, the second best all-round catcher in baseball-after Johnny Bench.
Following is the text, of Representative Mario Biaggi's statement concerning the investigation begun by Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari.
Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, tears in his eyes, said today that he was going to give up the big, new stone house he was building because he could not afford it.

Max Zuckerman, controller and secretary of the Israel Development Corporation and controller of Ampal-American Israel Corporation, died apparently of a heart attack Tuesday evening. He was 57 years old and lived at 69-07 174th Street, Flushing, Queens.

President Nixon set a precedent today by appointing Robert C. Holland, a career staff official of the Federal Reserve System, to fill the vacancy on the Re. serve Board created by the resignation of J. L. Robertson.

A new cabinet under Premier In Tam took off ice today and pledged itself to "independence, neutrality and peace." It also promised reorganization of the armed forces to strengthen "discipline, patriotism and combat value."
