G. Bradford Cook has shown good judgment in resigning as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Though he may be totally innocent of any wrongdoing, the reputation of this highly sensitive agency for integrity and thoroughness could have been undermined by Mr. Cook's present continuance in service and its highly regarded staff further demoralized-as he himself recognized.

President Nixon's handling of the Watergate scandal was strongly criticized today by leading Republicans, who warned that dwindling confidence in the Government was damaging both the country and the party.

Frederick Bryant Ashplant, Founder of the New York investment banking firm of F. B. Ashplant Co., died Tuesday at his home in Villefranche-surMer in Southern France. He was 77 years old and lived also at 605 Ewing Avenue, Franklin Lakes, N. J.
If the New York jockey colony had any notions about taking liberties at the Belmont Park meeting, it lost them yesterday.
The Nixon Administration plans to recommend a fiveyear phasing-out of ceilings that limit the interest con. sumers can earn on their savy. ings accounts, It was learned today.
Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, declaring that "secrecy corrupts just as power corrupts," urged Congress today to enact laws sharply restricting secrecy in the executive branch.

When the editorial design seniors at the Parsons School of Design met last winter to plan the 1973 yearbook, they were agreed on one thing. They didn't want the usual collection of graduating class portraits smiling individually into the camera, or even the clowning group shots recent yearbooks are full of.
The Kansas City Royals conceded today they had no chance to win their protest against Nolan Ryan's no-hitter, so they decided to forget about it.

The Senate passed today a bill to permit free use of certain Federal outdoor recreation facilities. The bill, sent to the House, would authorize special recreation use fees for the use of some federally developed sites, facilities equipment and services.

The Chinese Government protested strongly and formally to The New York Times yesterday against the paper's acceptance of political advertisements from anti-Peking Chinese groups and the Chiang Kai-shek Government on Taiwan.
The New York Mets managed a coupie of minor miracles again tonight, when they defeated the Montreal Expos, 8-3, with one of their most patched-together teams in a season of patchwork.
About 2,600 public school citstodians and service employes ended a three-day strike today, and teachers who had refused to cross their picket lines also went back to work.

The F. W. Woolworth Company realized a 39 per cent increase in earnings in the new first fiscal quarter this year on a sales gain of 17 per cent, shareholders were told at the annual meeting yesterday in Minneapolis.

Mrs. Frances Lange, who retired in 1968 as assistant secretary of the Bronx Savings Bank, died yesterday in Hilton Head Island, S. C., where she had been on vacation. She was 69 years old and lived at 485 Bronx River Road.

Henry A. Kissinger personally provided the Federal Bureau of Investigation with the names of a number of his aides on the National Security Council whom he wanted wiretapped, Justice Department sources said today.

In the first substantial sale of high-grade city bonds in a week, Dallas awarded $21-million of bonds to a syndicate of underwriters managed by the Republic National Bank of Dallas.

Walter W. Hitesman, 54 years old, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of The Reader's Digest. As president, he succeeds Hobart Lewis, 63, who was named chairman and who continues as chief executive officer and editor-inchief.

Weather conditions have improved in the nation's major growing areas for soybeans, corn and wheat. This, plus the fact that prices have made increases lately, combined to bring lower closing prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Vesco, a New Jersey financier.

Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight for a new series of talks with Le Duc Tho to "strengthen the peace in Indochina" and to improve the enforcement of the Vietnam cease-fire agreement that they completed here last January.

The commander of WrightPatterson Air Force Base, Brig. Gen. Irby B.- Jarvis Jr., has rescinded the jail sentence of a Kentucky doctor who was court-martialed because he refused to practice medicine in the Air Force.

Government, business and civic leaders in the city joined yesterday in a flood of condemnation of the record realestate tax increase proposed by Mayor Lindsay in his $10.595billion expense budget for fiscal 1974.

The trigger that will detonate three 30-kiloton nuclear devices more than a mile beneath western Colorado rangeland got a final check to day, and test officials predicted that. tomorrow's experiment to release natural gas would be flawless.

Jack Davis, Canada's Minister of the Environment and Fisheries, was named Conservationist of the Year at a recent meeting of the International Atlantic Salmon Foundation (ISAF) held at the American Museum of Natural History.

A visit to this country by Leonid I. Brezhnev has been a strong probability since President Nixon's own visit to the Soviet Union a year ago. But the timing of the Soviet leader's trip next month for eight days of talks in Washington and San Clemente is decidedly inopportune. It would be in the country's best interest to postpone these talks until late fall or next year.

The Senate passed yesterday, an $805-million bill authorizing Federal funds to encourage group health plans. These plans generally provide comprehensive care to members who pay a fixed monthly charge rather than a fee for service.

Mayor Peter F. Flaherty won a primary election yesterday that made it certain he will be re-elected without opposition in the general election next November.

A symphony orchestra that manages to approach the age of 10 in New York City is something of a miracle. One that has a high turnover among its youthful personnel and has no permanent conductor deserves even more praise for such longevity.

A Philadelphia grand jury recommended yesterday that Isadore H. Bellis, a city councilman, be indicted for receiving bribes in connection with services he allegedly provided for ARA Services, Inc., and some of its subsidiaries. Such a recommendation is normally turned over to a second grand jury that is empowered to return indictments.
The Offtrack Betting Corporation starts accepting bets today on Saturday's Preakness, with Secretariat the 3-5 early favorite.

Space agency engineers, in their desperate struggle to invent a way out of the orbiting Skylab's troubles, are considering a plan to send up astronauts to spread a thin awning over much of the overheated space station.
Don Massengale, who won the tournament and two automobiles last year, led the Dodge open golf tourney today with a 36-hole total of 141.

President Nixon's handling of the Watergate scandal' was strongly criticized today by leading Republicans, who warned that, dwindling confidence in the Government was damaging both the country and the party.

Governor .Rockefeller tonight submitted a much-negotiated proposal to restructure off track betting that would create a centralized State Racing and Wagering Board to oversee betting both at the track and in the parlors. His bill would also allow Sunday racing.

John L. Loeb, a Wall Street investment banker whose philanthropic gifts measure in the millions of dollars, was accused by the Fed, eral Government yesterday of having disguised a $48,000 contribution to Senator Hubert H Humnphrey's unsuccessful 1972 campaign for the Presidency.

Vesco, a New Jersey financier.

Communications Satellite Corp (Comsat) filed with the S.E.C. in connection with a public offering by a prospectus of 2,895,750 of its common shares by American Telephone Telegraph Co. Fans of the New York Philharmonic's Promenades will be delighted to know that the cafe tables and chairs are back in place on the orchestra level of Philharmonic Hall, that Andre Kostelanetz is back on the podium and, in short, that the 11th season of the orchestra's easy-listening soirees is now under way.

Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, charged today that the pulp and paper industry had turned Maine into a paper plantation that imposed "a one crop economy with a onecrop politics which exploits the water, air, soil and people of a beautiful state."

The Assembly today approved a variety of bills designed to help the aged, and Senate Republican leaders introduced legislation that would authorize a $100million program of new housing for the elderly.

An underground nuclear explosion equal to 90,000 tons of TNT sent gentle seismic ripples through the northwestern Colorado mountains this morning, causing small rock slides and a few cracked plaster walls but doing far less damage than had been expected.

Elliot L. Richardson, in the continuingg search for a special Prosecutor for the Watergate investigation, issued a detailed set of guidelines today that apparently would give wide discretion and power to whoever takes up the task.

Oil wells in Texas will run at full capacity for the 15th straight month in June, the Texas Railroad Commission said today. State wells have been producing under a 100 per cent allowable since April, 1972.

The next summer Olympic Games, to be staged here in 1976, received an endorsement of confidence this week following a visit to the city by Willi Daume of West Germany, a vice president of the International Olympic Committee and a most influential person in these matters.

Elliot L. Richardson, in the continuing search for a special prosecutor for the Watergate investigation, issued a detailed set of guidelines today that apparently would give wide discretion and power to whoever takes up the task.
The launching of the Skylab 1 astronauts was postponed again today until next Friday, May 25, to give them time to train for the necessary repair job on the overheated space station.

Precisely at 10 A.M., Sam J. Ervin Jr. hefted the new gavel carved for him by a Cherokee Indian, then rapped it on a long table cloaked in green felt, and the 1972 Presidential campaign went on trial today in the Senate.

To the Editor: Criticism of the President's energy message has tended to fault its virtues and neglect the real defects. The President seems to have correctly concluded that the basic immediate energy problem is to correct some of the many ill-conceived past efforts to develop energy policies.

Thoughtfully rather than noisily, George McGinnis of the Indiana Pacers predicted yesterday that the American Basketball Association champions "would have a chance" in a four-of-seven-game playoff series with the New York Knicks of the National Basketball Association.

The United States Attorney for the Virgin Islands, Joel Sacks, testified yesterday at a hearing that he thought a policeman had admitted to him that torture had been used to obtain confessions from the five defendants awaiting trial in the Fountain Valley murder case.

The deputy director of President Nixon's campaign organization ordered a file that apparently contained political intelligence removed from his desk hours after the Watergate burglary, a Senate select committee was told today as it began public hearings on the case.

A gambling case that the Federal Bureau of Investigation once called potentially the most crippling strike ever against the Mafia in upstate New York was in effect tossed out of Federal Court here today.

The Public Broadcasting Service proposed today its own "agreement for partnership" to counter a "declaration of peace" offered last week by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting in the continuing struggle over who will control the public television network.

Capt. Laurance F. Safford, U.S.N., retired, who was assistant director of naval communications for cryptographic research in World War II, died Tuesday in Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in this area.

Paul W. Gast, professor of geology at Columbia University and chief of the Division of Planetary and Earth Sciences at the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center here, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 43 years old.

Governor Rockefeller's attempt to pack the state courts with scores of new judges-named by himselfto handle drug penalties downgrades his larger effort to restructure and reform the court system. Surely the State Legislature will not allow the Court of Claims to be used as a funnel for slipping through judges without proper appointive or elective safeguards.

Representative Mario Biaggi picked up the campaign trail yesterday in his quest for the Democratic mayoral nomination, shaking hands briskly with morning rush-hour subway riders and getting a generally cordial greeting in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

A re-examination of the 1959 incident that won Mario Biaggi the Police Department's highest honor-his shooting to death an alleged holdup man-will be presented to a Bronx gandd jury after the June 4 primary, according to sources close to the investigtion.
Some of the descendants of the Teton Sioux, in eagle-feather headdress and beaded buckskin, met with five White House negotiators today in an attempt to regain some of their land and power.

Donald H. Segretti, a California lawyer who allegedly headed a political sabotage operation for the Republican party in last year's campaign, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he helped to prepare and distribute a fictitious letter in the Florida primary election.

The country's intellectual establishment celebrated the 75th anniversary of the founding of its official fraternity Wednesday by honoring mostly mien and by promising women a bigger share of honors in the future.

Ed Famula, who three years ago never thought he'd be able to play golf again, Won the Dodge open today by one stroke. With a final-round 71 over the Rockaway River Country Club course, the 37-year-old professional from the East Orange Golf Club, a municipal layout, had a two-over-par 290.

The scene was a palatial Plaza Hotel suite, littered with cocktail glasses and uneaten hors d'oeuvres. The cast included Irving Wallace, the best-selling novelist, and a group of powerful publishing executives who were there to negotiate a $2.3-million contract for Mr. Wallace's next
Gaylord Perry, who won the Cy Young Award as the American League's best pitcher last year, failed to impress the Baltimore Orioles with his talent last night in Cleveland's Municipal Stadium.

Police Chief George A. Johnson of Salem was arrested today on an indictment charging him with misconduct in office and gambling. The two-count indictment was handed up by a state grand jury yesterday but sealed until his arrest today by the state police.
George W. Mitchell, a member of the Federal Reserve Board since 1961, has been designated vice chairman by President Nixon. He succeeds J. L Robertson, who retired last month.

The Government confirmed today what private surveys had already shown--a big increase in corporate profits in the first quarter of this year. Before-tax profits were estimated by the Commerce Deapartment at an annual rate of $113.1-billion in the first quarter, up 28 per cent from a year earlier.

Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia began the 10th anniversary meeting of the Organization of African Unity, in Addis Ababa, with a declaration that all of Africa would be liberated from foreign domination in the next 10 years.

A special offering of 75,000 common shares of Harte-Hanks Newspapers at $11 a share was completed yesterday by Bear Stearns. The company's stock closed at 10 3/4, down l on the New York Stock Exchange.
Scott Eaton, of the New York Giants, still suffering double. vision from an injury he suffered in a scrimmage last year, announced yesterday his retirement from pro football.
The nation's largest banks may find themselves in a pain?? ful squeeze as a result of the Federal Reserve System's latest moves to tighten credit, key banking officials said yesterday.

Gov. David Hall and Secretary of State John Rogers said today that they and other elected Democratic officials in several states were under investigation by the Internal Revenue Service in what Mr. Rogers called "a giant polticial espionage" by the Nixon Administration that is "just like Watergate."
A custody battle has developed within the last few weeks between the Bronx Zoo and the Central- Park Zoo over the future of Patty Cake, the baby gorilla.

The board of directors of the East Side Airlines Terminal, a joint operation of 10 domestic airlines, decided yesterday not to renew a 20-year lease that expires on Oct. 31. As a result, according to a spokesman for the company, the terminal is scheduled to close then unless the city or a public agency, such as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, can be persuaded to step in and keep it going.

Bobby Riggs, who apparently has found a new career in women's tennis at the age of 55, yesterday agreed to play Chris, Evert in a $50,000 winner - take - all match at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Sept. 22.
Turbans are expendable and the platform-shoe craze is on the wane. But to keep in step with fashion it is absolutely essential that you acquire at least one big, long bulky sweater next fall.

A car bomb killed at least three persons and injured two others today in an upsurge of Northern Ireland violence. Two men were shot dead in other incidents.

ON THE CARPET Until about 15 years ago, about 80 per cent of American rug dealers were of Armenian provenance - with the boom in oriental rugs, the percentage may have diminished but the Armenian stamp is still strong.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped again yesterday for the sixth consecutive session. The Amex index fell 0.09 to 23.08, with declines outnumbering gains by 542 to 241. A total of 360 issues to unchanged as eight large blocks changed hands compared with 12 the day before.

In the midst of a leadership crisis, Germany's Opposition today elected Dr. Karl Carstens, a man who has been in Parliament only six months, as its parliamentary floor leader, replacing Dr. Rainer Barzel.

An underground nuclear explosion equal to 90,000 tons of TNT sent gentle seismic ripples through the northwestern Colorado mountains this morning, causing small rock slides and a few cracked plaster walls but doing far less damage than had been expected.

The Federal Reserve's moves designed to check the rapid expansion of bank credit that were announced late Wednesday had a broad impact on interest rates yesterday. From short-term loans to 40-year bonds, rates moved upward.

Tight supply conditions continued in the cocoa market yesterday, giving impetus to another round of price increases by the available limit for all except the current May contract on the New York CoCoa Exchange.

A high-level Swiss banker close to the gold market said today that the Soviet Union and South Africa, he world's two biggest gold producers , had stepped up heir sales in the open market to take advantage of what he calledd "very nice prices."

Baltimore-Buddy Boggs, Baltimore, knocked out Kid Bassey, Jamaica, 8 rounds, welterweights. Stockton, Calif.-Jack O'Halloran, 256 pounds, San Diego, outpointed Charley Reno, 243, Seattle, 12; Boone Kirkman, 208, Renton, Wash., outpointed Steve (Iceman) Carter, 201, Oakland, 10.
The "Camden 28" trial went to the jury this afternoon after 15 weeks in Federal District Court here.
The pilot of a plane that was seen stunting before it crashed in New Jersey killing six persons had been drinking so much that he could have been con- him victed of illegally driving a car.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies got down to the serious business of its 56th annual meeting today by taking a broad view not only of its own industry but also of the nation and the world.
A Federal grand jury in Manhattan handed down a 30-count. indictment yesterday against six men accused of having perpetrated a $750,000 stock fraud in a Tenafly, N. J., nursing home company.

Despite full-page newspaper advertisements by Mobil saying "gasoline is in short supply," a Mobil dealer here is pumping five times as much gasoline as he was a year ago when there was no announced shortage, and Mobil is giving him as much gasoline as he can sell.

The Stuttgart Ballet is a German company. But ballet is an international art. It was not surprising then that Wednesday's performance of John Cranko's "Romeo and Juliet" at the Metropolitan Opera House could be led by nearly an all-American cast of principals and that the company's newest and youngest ballerina is the Bostonborn Joyce Cuoco.

Today's sessions of the Senate Watergate hearings will be televised live and in full by the Columbia Broadcasting System (WCBS) and the National Broadcasting Company (WNBC), as well as by WNET, WNYC and WPIX.
The launching of the Skylab I astronauts was postponed again today until next Friday, May 25, to give them time to train for the necessary repair job on the overheated space station.

A young woman was killed and 45 people were injured-five of them critically-by a hand grenade hurled into a crowd outside police headquarters here at the end of a ceremony this morning commemorating a slain law enforcement officer.

The Wee Burn Country Club team scored the biggest victory yesterday in women's interclub challenge round golf, defeating Hudson Hills, 15-0, over the Glen Hollow course in Greenwich, Conn. Other winners in the Westchester interclub play were Fenway II, Twin Ridge, Leewood, Ardsley and New Canaan.

Mrs. Irma D. Greenebaum, who had been active in the women's division of the New York Federation of Jewish Philanthropies since 1917, died yesterday at her home here. She was 88 years old and he widow of M. H. Greenebaum.
The International Court of Justice will begin a hearing Monday on Australian and New Zealand protests over French nuclear tests in the South Pacific, the Court announced today.
Howard Coughlin, president of the Office and Professional Employes International Union, announced yesterday the granting of a charter for a West Coast hynotists local.

White House acknowledgment that the President ordered wiretaps on thirteen National Security Council aides and four newsmen--reportedly at the personal instigation of Henry A. Kissinger in some cases-offers further dismaying evidence of the degree to which individual liberties and the integrity of the executive branch itself have been compromised under the climate of self-righteousness, secrecy and suspicion in which the Nixon Administration has operated.

The United States team defeated the Indonesian team, 12-8, today, in the world bridge championships, regaining some ground lost yesterday, when it was defeated, 14-6, by Brazil, and 18-2, by the Aces, the defending champions here.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused 11 persons, including Otis Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, of involvement in a fraudulent investment scheme into which more than 2,000 persons poured about $30-million over eight years.

Grand juries in Manhattan and Brooklyn investigating loan-sharking, numbers gambling and other rackets operater by organized-crime figures returned 16 indictments yesterday based on court-ordered electronic bugs and wiretapped' telephones.
Mourners overflowed St. Bonaventure's Roman Catholic Church in Queens. for the funeral of the Rev. John P. Conlon, the pastor, who was found shot to death in the rectory on Sunday.
A building is being prepared here for experiments in which several thousand mice and rats will live in relative comfort, remarkable cleanliness and virtually complete security until old age.
Abraham Straus, Brooklyn's largest store and the most profitable store division of Federated Department Stores, Inc., is expected soon to un??dergo a major change in its top mangement.

President Nixon, accusing Congress of a "backdoor" assault on Presidential authority, vetoed today a bill that would require Senate confirmation of the director and deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget.
Henry A. Kissinger met today for a second time with Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam to discuss the carrying out of the Vietnam peace agreement.

When he was the champion, his manager was always with him. So were three or four others; waiting on him, catering to his every whim. But now that he's an exchampion, it's different. Joe Frazier was carrying his own equipment bag as he hurried into the Telestar Gym, a fifthfloor loft on West 28th Street, papered with old fight posters, stuffy with the aroma of perspiration that has seeped into its wooden floor.

The blue-law 'proposals sent to the Governor this evening would forbid the Sunday sale of a list of items in stores that have more than six employes. The limit does not pertain to members of a single family who run a food store,: nor does the list pertain to restaurants.

A $220,000 political espionage lawsuit was filed today against John N. Mitchell, Maurice H. Stans, Donald H. Segretti, Herbert W. Kalmbach and the Committee.for the reelection of the President by two campaign staff members for former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

Edward J. McGrath, a power on the New York waterfront in the turbulent nineteen-forties and fifties surrendered to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan here yesterday and was charged with refusing to testify before a grand jury last February.

The Maremont Corporation announced yesterday it might sell its Saco-Lowell textile machinery business to Stone-Platt Industries of London.' Maremont said the. sale, if consummated, would probably be for an amount of cash about equal to the $22-million book value of Saco-Lowell assets

Catch-driving is Lucien Fontaine's specialty. He is hired to drive harness horses on a nightly basis for trainers who don't drive or those trainer-drivers who have two or more horses entered in a stakes event.

The 36 community development corporations receiving Government support would be completely reorganized to reflect a "business orientation" under recommendations put forward today by the Office of Economic Opportunity.

James W. McCord Jr. testified today that an Administration official, who said that he was acting with President Nixon's knowledge, had offered him executive clemency,' financial aid and eventually a job to win his silence in the Watergate scandal.
Led by a bloodhound, policemen arrested three murder suspects today as they slept under a cliff in a forest near here. A fourth fugitive was caught last light.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market took their largest daily loss yesterday in more than a year in stepped-up trading.

Marjorie Elaine Siebern, an internationally known. judge of purebred dogs who retired in 1971 as an art teacher in the Purchase (N. Y.) School, died Thursday ?? (Pa.) General Hospital.
Elders from the Sioux tribes and supporters of the American Indian Movement asked Federal negotiators today for a Presidential commission to examine alleged treaty violations.

An air and sea search was conducted today for Alfred Willis, Wildwood Crest harbormaster, missing since yesterday on a fishing trip. The 21-foot outboard craft in which the 69year-old Mr. Willis sailed was found off the coast here yesterday with her motor running.

The United States team had a second day of disaster in the world championship tournament here yesterday. It held a slender lead at the halfway stage, but collapsed in the second half, losing 50 international match points.
Bayard Rustin, executive director of the A. Philip Randolph Institute, said today that the nation's building trades unions were to be "congratulated" for providing jobs to black work-0 ers.

In preparation for Sea Day tomorrow, a group of 30 volunteers wielded broom and shovels yesterday to clean up Fulton Street between South and Front Streets near the South Street Seaport Museum, which is sponsoring Sea Day.

Dave Hill, who had won this tournament three times in a four-year period, scrambled repeatedly out of potential trouble today and shot a threeunder-par 69 for the secondround lead in the $175,000 Danny Thomas-Memphis golf classic.

The Manhattan District Attorney's office reports that two people, a man and a woman, have come forward who say they witnessed the incident on April 28 when James Layne, 29 years old, allegedly tried to sell his 3-month-old daughter, Kim Cruz, on the IRT subway. Mr. Layne was freed on parole this week after the District'Attorney was unable to find any of the more than 30 witnesses to the incident.

Col. Nguyen Van Ve, replaced in 1971 as director of South Vietnam's Con Son Island prison after an international controversy over "tiger-cage" punishment cells, has been reappointed to the sane post, Government officials said today.
After meeting with 22 inmates who staged an 18-hour uprising in the Camden County Jail Annex, the warden said today that neither the inmates nor the guard involved in the incident would be punished.
Glenn Beckert, the 32-year-old second baseman of the Chicago Cubs who has a reputation as a tough man to strike out, continued his hitting streak last night.

Senator Ervin and his Senate select committee are showing only elementary prudence and fairness in warning that guilt cannot be established by hearsay. George Burns, who equaled the Garden City Golf Club noncompetitive course record of 65 last Aug. 8, shot a oneunder-par 36, 36-72 on that course today and won the medal in the 63d annual Walter J. Travis Memorial tournament.

The State Legislature tonight passed a revision of the offtrack betting law that establishes a state racing and wagering board, eases the financial problems of race tracks, permits new local OTB operations and allows Sunday racing.

It was not possible to figure out just what point, if any, the program of contemporary music presented in the Composers Theater May Festival concert at the New School on Thursday night was supposed to make, but the assemblage of works maintained a respectable level of quality, and there is something to be said for that.

On only 25 acres of farmland rolling gently down to a small stream, Dobrivoje Pavlovic, his wife and and his semiretired father have a comfortable, self-sufficient life with two houses, a Ferguson tractor, a car and esteem as one of the leading, hardest-working families in the Barajevo commune.

Mrs. Bawn Barrett Tinnerholm of Springfield, N. J., wife of Richard G. Tinnerholm, former. financial vice president of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, died Wednesday in Phoenix, Ariz., where she was a winter resident. Her age was 61.
Senator Jacob K. Javits has reported receiving about $17,000 last year through the New York County Republican Committee to help defray certain Senate-office operating expenses.

The Alibi Breakfast was nearly over, and even the influence of a new house drink called the Black-Eyed Susan had failed to alter the status of tomorrow's 98th Preakness as a heavyweight title match between Secretariat and Sham.

A Congressional leader in health legislation said today that the Administration's decisions on health policy and the men who make those decisions would face sharp scrutiny in the future.
a panel of three common pleas court judges ruled today that prayers could be included in the commencement exercises of suburban Mount Lebanon High School.

Her Honda was ideal. But on Aug. 15, 1968, at 5 P.M., in heavy traffic on Amsterdam Avenue between 62d and 63d Streets, she hit a pothole.

A freak spring storm broke a 91-year-old temperature record here yesterday and dumped up to eight inches of heavy, wet snow on western New York State, closing dozens of upstate schools and leaving Thousands of people without electricity.

Because Dr. Peter LaMotte-took another look at Cleon Jones's sore wrist and because Jim Gosger gave Manager Yogi Berra an honest answer, Wayne Garrett was able to knock in three runs with a homer and single for the New York Mets last night and make possible 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, pitched by Tom Seaver.

Zambia confirmed tonight that the two young Canadian women killed near Victoria Falls on Tuesday had been shot by a Zambian sentry, but said that the women and an American male companion had appeared to be on their way to attack a vital Zambian power station.

The urban crisis is not over, despite President Nixon's soothing suggestions to the contrary. Black, white and Puerto Rican middle-income taxpayers continue to leave center city areas; disadvantaged, low-income non-taxpayers continue to arrive. Crime rates remain unacceptably high, neighborhoods deteriorate, the schools still turn out too many functional illiterates.

In his newest work, given its premiere Thursday night at the City Center, Alvin Ailey takes us into some mythical Afro-Asian kingdom and offers an odd music-hall view of what takes place in such realms.

Greece's Orthodox Church delegated three Bishops today to mediate in the dispute that has split the Orthodox Church of Cyprus. The move coincided with increasing hopes of Greek-Turkish settlement of the Cyprus problem.
The makers of Peugeot, Mercedes-Benz and Opel diesel automobiles told Congress today that they can meet the 1975 auto-emission standards, but not the tough restrictions proposed for 1976.
Elliot L. Richardson today chose Archibald Cox, Solicitor General in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, as the special prosecutor in the Watergate investigation.

An electronic converter that was patented this week can provide cable television subscribers with four additional channels not normally available. Signals that fall between the regular channels can be received.

The National Tea Company, another major supermarket chain whose operating results have been impaired by rising costs and intensified price competition, reported yesterday a net loss of $36-million for the fiscal year ended March 31. In "Iberia," his monumental paean to Spain, James A. Michener fondly recalls a restaurant he loved in Seville: "Food in Sevilla during the spring festival is apt to be dismal." he wrote.
The inmates of Trenton State Prison presented a plaque today to former Superintendent William F. Fauver in an unusual display of confidence in a prison administration.

Weighed down by the Watergate hearings and a host of other problems, the stock market reeled yesterday under persistent pressure. The phrase "A crisis of confidence" echoed in Wall Street as the Watergate inquiry by the Senate dug into the scandal shaking the Administration.

Roy C. Muir, a retired president of the General Electric Company, died on an airplane yesterday en route from Florida to Schenectady, N. Y. He was 91 years old and lived in Osprey, Fla., and Schenectady.

State Department officials say that China may seek to buy more than $200million in United States agricultural products this yearmainly grain and cotton. Export figures for the first quarter of 1973, however, do not reflect this level. As of March 31, $33-million worth of exports had been sent to China and officials said the figures for cotton alone should have reflected sales of some $100-million.
As a prelude to bringing its operation closer to the coal fields, the United Mine Workers of America will hold its quadrennial convention here for the first time from Dec. 3 to 14.
Officials of the New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield healthinsurance plans agreed today to provide coverage for people with serious health problems at the rates charged to healthy subscribers.
Sally Little, a willowy blonde from South Africa, shot a four-under-par 69 today for a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $30,000 Bluegrass invitation golf tournament.

Johns Hopkins, rebounding from last week's loss to Maryland, scored five goals in the first quarter and went on to defeat Army, 11-5, in the first round of the National Collegiate lacrosse playoffs today.

Miss Margaret Adele Friederichs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Friederlchs, and William Henry Slattery were married in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Terence J. Finlay, the rector.

The marriage or Mrs. Anne Stroud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Boulton Dixon Stroud, to Adrian Irving Bradford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Bradford of Newport, N.J., took place here this afternoon.

Secretariat looked like a mine of pure gold today instead of a mere $6,080,000. The Meadow Stable colt won the 13/16-mile event by 2 1/2 lengths over the runner-up, Sigmund Sommer's Sham, who had eight lenghts over the third horse, Our Native, in the six-horse field.
Since the virtue of domesticity is its lack of drama, it's the hardest thing in the world to write about attractively.
With banners flapping and brass buttons glistening, more than 8,000 military men, reservisits and veterans marched on sunny Fifth Avenue yesterday in the 24th observance of Armed Forces Day.

Lag B'Omer, the joyous Jewish holiday, is to be celebrated in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn today with a parade involving 50,000 youngsters and other activities under the theme of a "Salute to Judaism."

Natural gas will be in short supply next winter in the New York area, according to the latest statistics. The Brooklyn Union Gas Company is an example. It has projected its total demand for the coming year at 81.19 billion cubic feet.

Willie Mays said yesterday he would decide next Friday whether to play again. "I've been on the disabled list for 10 days now," the Mets' star told 250 children at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. "In five days more I have to decide whether I'm going to play for the rest of this season.

In the garden at Westerly, the home of the bride's parents there, Miss Constance Alison McLean, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. McLean of Pawling and New York, was married to Brian Dale Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Smith of Key Biscayne, Fla.

As everyone knows who follows the news, a significant portion of "An. Untold Story" (the only truly significant portion, in fact) appeared in two issues of Ladies Home Journal prior to book publication, arousing with its "sensational disclosures" of the "private" lives of the Roosevelts a "storm of controversy" that no doubt warms the hearts of Putnam's sales staff.
A new Spillane-but under it beats the heart of the old Mickey. It's named THE LAST COP OUT (Dutton, $6.95), and it's the usual Spillane mix--sex, sadism, assorted fun and games with gun and fist.
President Nixon said today that Hanoi had "persisted in violations" of the Vietnam cease-fire agreement and had failed to provide adequate information about the fate of missing American servicemen.
ON May 2, the Senate voted to authorize $840-million in Federal aid to the arts and humanities during the next three years.
BONN--Russian power, in the form of the Soviet Army, reached the Elbe River deep inside Germany in 1945 and stopped, menacing and inscrutable.

The other day the Knight Newspapers placed a public service ad in its own and other publications. The ad's headline stated, boldly and ironically, "It Can't Happen Here." The illustration showed the famous picture of Storm Troopers in Berlin putting the torch to books that were "un-German."

During World War II, when Barbara Howar was a girl in Raleigh, N. C., she would dress up in the WAC uniform her mother brought her from New York, stand along the main highway that links New York and Miami and watch the convoys coming or going between Quantico and Fort Bragg.
The high cost of living has replaced the war in Southeast Asia as the major concern of the American public, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.
Grants totaling $245,770 were announced yesterday by Lucius Walker Jr., executive director of the Interreligious Foundation for Community Organization.

The Northeastern Unversity crew, the Eastern sprint champions, remained undefeated tonight, defeating Pennsylvania by one and a half lengths to win the Joe Burk Cup over the 2,000-meter course on the Charles River.

HUNTINGTON, L.I. -- A six-month study began here Thursday to determine the transportation needs of Huntington residents and evolve a plan to aid them, including young people and women to are "prisoners of their chauffeuring chores."

OUT of the Nassau County District Court a small claims court wherein plaintiff and defendant may plead their own cases, has come a decision that may establish a legal precedent that will compel travel agents to be responsible for the delivery to their customers of all the services and accommodations promised in their brochures.

Mrs. Katharine Graham, publisher of The Washington Post, and Senator Sam. J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, were cited yesterday for "distinguished contributions to the mass media" by the First National Symposium on Crime and the Media, The Associated Press reported.
" The militarization of the world continues unabated," the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute has reported in its fourth yearbook.

John Cheever's new collection of stories, "The World of Apples," his first collection in nine years, is an extraordinary book, a transfiguring experience for the reader, and Cheever at his best. There is more flexibility, daring, diversity and vigor in this book than in any other of Cheever's (except perhaps "Bullet Park"), as though Cheever were growing progressively young.

Miss Jean Whalen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Whalen of Manchester Depot and St. Clair Shores, Mich., was married here at noon today to Alfred Charles Carosi Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Carosi of Braintree Highlands, Mass.
The acting Consul General of the Philippines in Los Angeles has asked for political asylum in the United States to protest what he called the "dictatorial policies" of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

In its bare essentials, the 4-1 decision the Pittsburgh Pirates scored over the New York Mets at Shea Stadium yesterday went this way: Bob Robertson's ninth-inning home run off Tug McGraw matched one hit by Rusty Staub off Nelson Briles in the sixth, and Willie Stargell's three-run homer with two out in- the 10th settled the game, giving Dave Giusti a relief victory...

IF you stop to think about it, it's odd that anyone should have wished to make a musical of "Cyrano" be cause "Cyrano de Bergerac" is virtually a musical to begin with. The original Rostand melodies are, of course, all verbal melodies, rococo cadenzas that ripple from tongues that still seem to be tasting bon-bons.

The G.I. Bill of Rights, which helped educate and house World War II and Korean War veterans, is inadequate to the needs of the six million Vietnam war veterans and must be drastically revised, according to a report, that will be submitted to the White House.
EAST MEADOW, L. I.--With a blaze of muskets and a flourish of bagpipes, the Redcoats surprised the Colonial regiments, scoring a decisive victory in the Battle of Eisenhower Park.

To review movies is to leap precariously across the media, but the reader must bear with me: the reviewer of reviews dwells in his own special circle of hell. Andrew Sarris, Vernon Young and Penelope Gilliatt write about movies for The Village Voice, The Hudson Review and The New Yorker.

In response to Roman Catholic protest, the National Council of Churches has withdrawn a statement to a House committee charging that American Catholics are "unwilling" rather than "unable" to continue supporting their parochial schools.

WASHINGTON--The Supreme Court has set the stage - or at least raised the curtain - for a whole new line of antidiscrimination decisions that could strike down hundreds of Federal and state laws that differentiate between men and women.

A 32-mile backwoods railroad line in western Wisconsin, connecting the towns of Elroy and Sparta, isn't overgrown by weeds and forgotten today eight years after the end of scheduled train service. Instead it is the most successful part of a vigorous program by the State of Wisconsin to turn abandoned railroads into state parks.

A shoot-out by a parking lot here this afternoon left two own policemen wonder and set off a car-and-foot chase through quit residential streets in neighboring Bronxville and Tuckahoe.

The temptation to enact a state tax cut proved too great for the lawmakers at Albany to resist. Though the final figures on surpluses have not yet been made known, it is reasonably clear that surpluses do exist; hence the Legislature voted to suspend the state's 2.5 per cent surcharge on the state income tax for one year.

In the land of television commercials, a surprisingly large portion of the population seems to be afflicted with pinched faces, furrowed brows and whining voices. Peevish wives nag sulking husbands, shuddering grandparents prepare to receive a visit from boisterous grandchildren.
ENGLEWOOD -- The Burrows Gallerye looks like it might be a museum, for there certainly are enough art objects on hand and some are even displayed in museum cases.

WASHINGTON--The accountability' of the President is the central issue of the Watergate criminality. Over the years, the apparatus for unaccountable government has been building on many fronts. Pervasive secrecy, the loss of Congressional power to relentless Presidential seizure, the remoteness of bureaucracy' from citizens, growing governmental illegality-these are not recent phenomena.

AS popular culture, television is better than movies. On almost any given evening, you can watch a good program or two on TV; you would be fairly hard-pressed, on the other hand, to find even two enjoyable movies a week, and if you did find them, you would still have to get to them and, worst of all, pay a lot to see them.
Soviet scientists, using their biggest atom smasher in a continuing search for new forms of antimatter, reported today that they had created and detected nuclei of antitritium.
Americans for Democratic Action voted today to call for President Nixon's resignation as a result of the Watergate scandal.

WASHINGTON--To the extent we've been given a reason, the Administraw tion's war in Cambodia has been explained as implementing the "agreement on ending the war and restoring peace in Vietnam." The explanation wants both law and logic.
Nikolaos Makarezos, a Deputy Premier, left today for Peking on a sixday official visit, the first to China by a Greek Government leader.
Amin Hafez today resumed his post as Premier, from which he resigned May 8 at the height of fighting between the Lebanese Army and the Palestinian guerrillas.

John Cranko's "Eugene Onegin" is quite simply a superb spectacle. Although it has been at the Metropolitan Opera House before, its return with the Stuttgart Ballet on Friday night was splendidly welcome.
They'll hand out the Emmys on ABC tonight at 9, and one will go to an actress for her outstanding single performance in a leading role. The nominees:

WEST HAMPTON, L. I.--To help keep drunken drivers off the road, the Suffolk Police Department gave a party the other day. In three hours, 79 ounces of brand-name whisky were consumed by eight men, who for the sake of science and highway safety had agreed to get drunk to show just how alcohol affects driving.

To the Editor: Joyce Carol Oates, commenting in this space on my review of her book "Angel Fire," raises again the difficulty between poets and critics, that the poet is using "modes of self-expression that shouldn't irritate or upset anyone," that "the critic is firing a cannon at a butterfly .

Miss Mary Elizabeth Kiley, of daughter of Mr. and Mrs. to Henry Edward Kiley of Jr. Chatham, N. J., was married here yesterday afternoon to Fredric Samuel Newman, an associate with the New York law firm of White Case. Rabbi Eli Cooper of York, Pa., performed the ceremony at the New York Junior League. The Rev. Joseph O'Rourke, a Roman Catholic priest, participated.

The two top-ranked teams in 'the world team contract bridge championship here clashed this afternoon in the eighth qualifying round, and the defending champion Aces eked out a narrow victory.
Dr. Ralph B. Gaeta, an optometrist, died yesterday in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood. He was 60 years old and lived at 250 East Main Street.

BEHIND the cabinet shaking, headline making activities in Wash ington 'today, hidden in subcommittees in comparative obscurity among the big issues that are occupying the attention of major committees of the Senate and House, are several numismatic matters that could have a substantial impact on the hobby.

The nation's Republican state chairmen took the unusual step today of adopting a resolution pledging support to President Nixon and proclaiming their belief that he would arrive at the truth in the Watergate scandal.

Kansas City got home runs from Paul Schaal, Amos Otis and Lou Piniella in the sixth inning against Vida Blue today and defeated Oakland, 5-2. Blue and Dick Drago were locked in a scoreless duel until the sixth when the Royals suddenly broke loose.

Miss Claudia Miller Skylar and David Aaron Gressel will be married here on June 12. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Skylar. The prospective bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Alan Gressel of Cleveland and New York.

Kissinger aided by Ambassador William Sullivan, North Vietnamese Politburo member Le Duc Tho aided by Nguyen Co Thach.

Each time Stan Brodskytakes his sketch pad and pastels to a favorite spot near the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, he finds new inspiration. The water, the beach, the foliage along the shore-all eventually turn up as Prussian blues, wheat golds, or Kelly greens on the artist's canvases.
One person was killed and four others were injured in a five-car collision last night at the intersection of Yellowstone and Woodhaven Boulevards in the Forest Hills section of Queens.

The games politicians play. In Albany both parties stumbled all over each other last week in an effort to extract the most credit for a tax cut passed by the Legislature and signed by Governor Rockefeller. The object: to seize the most favorable positions at the starting gate for the gubernatorial and legislative elections next year.
The obituary may be premature, but there are those who believe that the . house tour-that lucrative form of fund-raising dear to the hearts of the city's clubwomen-is earmarked for extinction.

The New York Cosmos, in driving rain and before 2,364 paying fans, put on their best performance of the season at Hofstra Stadium today, but the scoring script was the same as in their last two games.
Randy Johnson, whose injury gave Norm Snead the opportunity to become the Giants' No. 1 quarterback last season, was the club's first seasoned player to sign for 1973, the Giants announced yesterday.

A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation says that in the nineteen-sixties the bureau used material gained in an electronic surveillance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in an apparent effort to undermine the late civil rights leader's support among his white backers.

A Coast Guard air and sea search for 69-year-old Alfred J. Willis of Wildwood Crest was called off. Mr. Willis, missing since last Thursday afternoon, disappeared from his 21-foot motorboat. Manitoulin, ridden by Bill Shoemaker, captured the $38,800 Cortez Handicap at Hollywood Park today and led two other horses trained by Charles Whittingham into the first four places.

After all the thought and effort that has gone into the concept of the Gateway National Recreation Area, it seems preposterous that it should now be threatened with postponement and weakening by the vague reservations of a single state legislator-one, incidentally, for whom we normally have great respect. Yet that will be the result if Senator John J. Marchi of Staten Island succeeds in his attempt to exclude Great Kills Park from the Gateway project.
Irene McCabe, who once waged an antibusing campaign that won national attention, is a sadder but wiser housewife again.

The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine celebrated its 100th anniversary and the installation of a new dean yesterday with prayer, pomp, carnival - and a disclosure that construction at the Episcopal cathedral would resume.

The Department of Justice has amassed evidence of widespread corruption in one of its own branches, the Southwest Region of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Government sources have told The New York Times.
Supermarket customers are about to witness the dawning of a new era in food merchandizing--automation of the checkout counter.

Nine women and 11 men have been awarded National Urban Fellowships in a program to develop leaders in urban government. The list of winners, selected from 311 applicants from all over the country, were announced here by Frank Lague, director of the program.

Brian Gottfried, a tennis player few people knew before this week, routed one of the game's big guns, Arthur Ashe, 6-1, 6-3, today for the $30,000 top prize in the Alan King tournament.

Beyond the threat of a summer or gasoline shortage, which is preoccupying Government energy planners, the oil industry and co motorists, looms the prospect of a shortage of home heating oil next winter that could be worse than the one last winter.

Mayor Thomas J. Powers and Dr. John F. Regan, the superintendent of Matawan regional schools, will meet tomorrow to discuss an incident last week in which the face of a 12-year-old boy was smeared with ink, apparently because he is Jewish.
Graduation days and June weddings inevitably bring up the question of presents. For the parent, grandparent or long-time family friend a good idea might be a gift of stock.

Miss Susan Levine, a January graduate of George Washington University, was married at the Tavern-on-theGreen yesterday to Malcolm Netburn, who expects to receive his degree from the university next month.

After a two-hour wait, yesterday's game between the Mets and Pittsburgh Pirates at Shea Stadium was postponed by rain.

The ostensible reason several thousand people turned out in a constant rain to gather on both sides of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday was that the bridge was having its 90th birthday party, thrown by the city.

Representatives of race track employes will vote today whether to call a strike that would halt all horse racing in New York State. If so voted, the strike could begin today, but it is more likely that it would begin tomorrow.

Gunmen Killed a Roman Catholic painter today, raising Northern Ireland's death toll in four years of sectarian feuding to 801. Patrick Coogan, 39 years old, was shot in the back in an ambush in the Antrim Road quarter of Belfast.
The Voice of America is pulling no punches in its reporting of the Watergate scandal overseas, and some members of the Senate are concerned about the candor.

Pennsylvania's latest primary election, described by one prominent judge a "the ultimate in absurdity," has brought re??ewed demands for a better method of selecting judges than direct election.

Prime Minister Gough Whitlam's six-month-old Labor Government suffered a setback in the elections yesterday in the key state of Victoria in southeastern Australia.
A Venezuelan airliner hijacked to Cuba returned here today with the passengers and crew members taken as hostages by armed leftists on an erratic trip through five LatinAmerican countries.

Declassified Pentagon figures on United States weapons sales show that Israel has bought almost $1-billion worth and more than three times as much as the Arab countries since the 1967 Middle Eastern war.

President Nixon announced today his nominees for two Pentagon vacancies. They are Terence E. McClary, 51 years old, of Lynnfield, Mass., to be Assistant Secretary of Defense, controller, and Jack L. Bowers, 52, El Cajon, Calif., to be Assistant Secretary of the Navy for installations and logistics.

The National Mediation Board pressed its efforts yesterday to mediate the strike of railway car men that has shut down the PATH railroad system for 52 days.

The dance music of the 15th and 16th centuries has an almost irresistible allure. This is hardly music of a Strenuous intellectuality, let alone profound religiosity, and it can hardly be taken as the quintessence of pre-Baroque musical art. But whether courtly or popular, this is music of unabashed appeal, and three recent records can serve as fine introductions to it.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has canceled plans for a controversial auction sale of 6,000 coins in Zurich, Switzerland, in September. The American Stock Exchange, many of whose specialists have absorbed substantial losses in the plummeting markets of recent months, confirmed yesterday that another of its specialist units had been dissolved.
Jefferson Prince, driven by Carmine Abbatiello, paced the mile in 2:01 3/5 in gaining his third straight victory at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

The Senate voted today by 43 to 33 to limit to Massachusetts and New Hampshire the use by mutual savings banks. of a form of checking account on which interest is paid. The vote was to adopt an amendment of Senator William Brock, Republican of Tennessee, containing this limitation.
The National Basketball Association Commissioner, Walter Kennedy, announced yesterday settlement of the dispute between the Milwaukee Bucks and the former Buck guard, Wali Jones.
A settlement was reached today with most of the craft unions whose strike has halted more than $2-billion worth of construction in New Jersey since May 1.
Consumer prices rose strongly again in April, but a little less rapidly than in the preceding two months, the Labor Department reported today.

President Nixon conceded today that there had been "wide-ranging efforts" in the White House to conceal some aspects of the Watergate case, but he said those actions had stemmed from his legitimate interest in protecting national security.
Antioch College officials were turned back by 230 angry students and faculty members today as they attempted to reopen the campus, shut down for 32 days by a student strike over financial aid.
Marcel Phillipe was timed in 1 minute 50.3 seconds for the 880-yard run and 4 minutes 8.1 seconds for the mile run yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
The three Federal prosecutors in the Watergate affair were on the verge of resigning from the case today, Justice Department sources said.
Lanford Wilson's "The Hot I Baltimore" and Joseph A. Walker's "The River Niger" shared top honors as best play of the year at the 1972-73 Obie Awards ceremony Monday night.
In the face of extraordinary pressures, President Nixon has furnished another elaboration of the role of the White House in the Watergate and associated scandals.
A 20-seat, electric-powered "minibus" that the State Urban Development Corporation is considering for use in its new Welfare Island community was demonstrated briefly in city traffic yesterday.
Volkswagen of America, Inc., announced yesterday the third increase this year in suggested retail prices for Volkswagen, Porsche and Audi models.
The dollar strengthened yesterday, which was indicated by a fall in the gold price abroad. The decline in gold in turn triggered some profit taking among owners of silver contracts.

Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, was reported today as saying that he was not certain he was told "it is the President's wish" that the C. I. A. block a part of the Watergate investigation.

David R. Porter, a retired executive of the Young Men's Christian Association, died yesterday at his home in Abingdon, England, near Oxford, where, in 1904, he had been one of the university's original Rhodes Scholars. He was 91 years old.

The nicest thing one can say about a furrier is that he isn't in awe of his materials and goes blithely ahead treating pelts as though they were wool. Birger Christensen, the Danish furrier, does just that and his new collection for Bonwit Teller is full of young, snappy furs a woman might wear as casually as a tweed coat or a sweater.

A law partner of Charles W. Colson, former White House special counsel, proposed last month that they "lean on" the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission to appoint a counsel for the commission that would help their clients, according to a memorandum published by The Washington Post in tomorrow's edition.
The Cahill administration formally agreed today to take part in a $36-million improvement program for the Lindenwold high-speed rail line that connects Philadelphia and South Jersey.
A former White House official told the Senate Watergate committe today that John W. Dean 3d, the deposed Presidential counsel, had ordered him to offer executive clemency to James W. McCord Jr.

Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, said last night that he did not know of any national security program under which breaking and entering for searches or photographing documents was authorized by the Justice Department during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, The Associated Press reported.
Just as New Yorkers are readying their terraces and pocket-size gardens for summer, along comes Greenwich House Pottery with a timely "Pots for Plants" show.
Jim Pattison, a Vancouver businessman, announced today that he had completed the purchase of the franchise and player contracts of the Philadelphia Blazers of the World Hockey Association.
The Federal Reserve Board appealed to the nation's banks today to "discipline" further expansion of their loans, which have been growing at a record pace and contributing to the boom in the economy.

A high-ranking Soviet official has come to Washington to seek a formal endorsement by the Nixon Administration of the $8-billion, 20-year fertilizer deal worked out by the Soviet Government and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation last month, a Commerce Department official said today.
President Nixon announced today a shift of many financial management responsibilities from the Office of Management and Budget to the General Services Administration.
The Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League obtained a goalie, Gilles Gilbert, today in a trade with the Minnesota North Stars for a center, Fred Stanfield.
National Maritime Day took on special significance yesterday as the city's maritime high school students got a new classroom.

Transportation officials here have been given a long-awaited "people-mover" report that recommends an elevated loop around Lower Manhattan and conversion of 48th and 49th Streets for use by buses and pedestrians only.
A labor leader identified with the conservative wing of Peronism was shot dead today by unidentified assailants in the city of La Plata, about 30 miles southwest of the capital.
Indian troops battled a state police force in Uttar Pradesh today in an attempt to put down a rebellion among the policemen.
Marcel Phillipe was timed in 1 minute 50.3 seconds for the 880-yard run and 4 minutes 8.1 seconds for the mile run yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

A patrolman shot a 23-year-old man aboard a Long Island Rail Road train in the Farmingdale station last night. The victim, John Carter of Bay Shore, was charged with two counts of menacing and with theft of services. He was reported in fair condition at Nassau County Medical Center.
New measures for tightening order in the Palestinian refugee camps in Lebanon are now in force as a result of last week's agreement between the Lebanese Government and Palestinian guerrillas.
The House Government Operations Committee voted 23 to 17 today against President Nixon's plan to reorganize drug law enforcement.

Rick Barry of the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Association won a Bay Area pro athletes' "decathlon" in Los Altos when he hit a softball 287 feet, bowled a 558 series, won the 50-meter swim in 0:31.1, tossed a football 61 yards 24 inches and played golf and tennis in creditable style.

The Firestone Tire Rubber Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended April 30, reflecting broadly based increases in domestic and international operations.

Interest rates continued to press broadly higher again yesterday although scattered signs of stability emerged in the bond market.

Seton Hall University captured the Metropolitan College Conference baseball championship today by defeating Fairleigh Dickinson University, 6-1. The Pirates thus earned a berth in the National Collegiate District II playoffs, which open Thursday in Trenton.

Everyone was in a hurry to get, the last New Jersey college baseball luncheon over as quickly as possible and go to watch The Game at Fairleigh Dickinson's campus. The Game was between F. D. U. and Seton Hall to decide the winner of the Metropolitan Conference, the two teams having tied for first at the end of the regular season.

If anybody doubts that sport brings out the best in men, he must be reassured by the way the recent success of the Houston Astros has illumined all that is sweetest and most sportsmanlike in Spec Richardson, their general manager. In fact, Richardson has exhibited such polished taste and simple dignity that one questions whether he belongs in a sweaty occupation like baseball and wouldn't be better suited to Roller Derby or professional wrestling.

New Jersey's grant of $650,000 in Federal operating antipoverty funds will be cut to $300,000 for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1974, according to a memorandum made public today.

The University of Miami In Coral Gables, Fla., has awarded five athletic scholarships to women during the past two weeks and has 10 more to give to women high school graduates able to enter the Miami freshman class next fall.

He discovered that although Europeans were far less alarmist than the vast majority of Americans about the international implications of Watergate, Europe nevertheless really didn't think too much of his Easter Monday speech urging a "new Atlantic charter."

The Federal Reserve Board denied today the application of the parent holding company of New England Merchants National Bank of Boston to acquire the Hancock Bank and Trust Company of Quincy, Mass.
The Soviet Union today introduced an improved version of its TU 144 supersonic airliner, de signed to take 140 passengers from Paris to New York in three hours.
A bill calling for a $100-million bond referendum to be used to build housing for the middle-income aged was approved by the Sen ate today and sent to the Assembly.

The threat of a shutdown of New York racing by track labor unions all but dis appeared yesterday after legisla tive leaders drafted several chapter amendments to the state's new omnibus racing andbetting bill.
Britain's sex scandals widened today with the resignation of Earl Jel licoe, leader of the House of Lords, who acknowledged that he had engaged in "casual affairs" with prostitutes.
Winnebago Industries, Inc., has called off plans for a a $20-million motorhome manufacturing plant at Reno,
Ron Evans weathered an afternoon-long rain better than 10 other competitors today and won the first decathlon of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America(I.C.4-A.).
Johnny Rodgers of Nebras ka, last year's winner of the Heisman Trophy, has decided to play for the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League.
James E. Smith, 42 a Deputy Under Secretary of the Treasury, was nominated yesterday by President Nixon to be Controller of the Currency, succeeding William B.Camp.
Two sizable exhibitions de voted to the art of drawing have opened this week, each bringing its own order of revelations and pleasures.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judg ment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments.

Although consumers are con cerned over inflation and the Administration's ability to deal with it, the strong demand and purchasing on the part of the public has had a favorable im pact on the upward profittrend of retail merchandisers.

The Nixon Administration dis closed today that it had told 10 states to submit by June 11 plans for further desegregation of public college faculties and students, or else face Federalfund cut-offs or court action.
United States Attorney Harold H. Titus Jr. announced today that one of the key figures in the Watergate case had agreed to plead guilty and serve as aprosecution witness at the trial.

President Nixon's latest explanation of his part in the Watergate scandal-which is quite different from his first two ex planations-is that everything he did, or failed to do, was motivated by his concern for "national security."
The stock market scored one of its sharpest advances in his tory yesterday in response to reports on economic develop ments. The Dow-Jones indus trial average soared 29.42points and closed at 922.44.

G. B. Lyman of Payson was accused yesterday of bind ing a coyote with wire and displaying the animal in front of a cafe. D. H. McGarry, a conductor for the Union Pacific Railroad, signed a complaint before Justice of the Peace E. L. Smith. Mr. Lyman was chargedwith cruelty to animals.

With only a few Assemblymen contesting it, both houses of the Legisla ture today approved Governor Rockefeller's bill to defer until 1975 a public referendum on the recommendations of the special State Commission to Revise the New York CityCharter.

United States District Judge Frederick J. R. Heebe postponed indefinitely yester day Clay L. Shaw's $5-million damage suit against District Attorney Jim Garrison. Judge Heebe gave no reason for the continuance, but said it was agreeable to both parties. Mr. Shaw's suit charges that his constitutional rights were vio lated as a result of a conspiracy by Mr. Garrison and severalothers to persecute him.

The Central Intelligence Agency reported in 1969 and 1970 that it could find no substantial evidence to support the Nixon Administration's view that for eign governments were supply ing undercover agents and funds to radicals and Black Panther groups in the United States, White House and intelligence sources said today.

Governor Cahill signed into law to day a "truth in labeling" bill for household appliances that he said was "another measure in the state's campaign to provide maximum protection for theconsumer in the marketplace.

Bert Blyieven pitched a one-hitter-Ed Kirkpatrick's bunt single-to lead the Minn esota Twins to a 2-0 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight. Kirkpatrick opened the fifth inning with a drag bunt thatthe third baseman.

While at least 500 pickets pro tested outside, the Atlantic City Hospital Board of' Gover niors announced last night that the hospital would begin to allow abortions during the first three months of pregnancy if approved by the woman's physician.
The stock market scored a spectacular gain yesterday in response to a wave of buying unleashed by a series of news items relating to the national economy.

President Nixon's speech to the former prisoners of war at the White House yesterday was an impassioned defense-not of telling the truth or of obeying the law or of dealing fairly with one's adversaries-but of secrecy. Secrecy is at the center of the ever-widening Watergate scandals.

Alexander Medvedkin, born in 1900, occupies a minor place in the history of Rus sian cinema, mainly for the production of documentary and propaganda films, be ginning in 1927 and extend ing into the nineteen-seventies.

Dr. Thomas H. McGavack, endocrinologist at New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals and Metropolitan Hospital from 1936 to 1957, died Wednesday n Martinsburg, W. Va., wherehe lived. His age was 75.
A Public Service Commission ex aminer has recommended re jection of a request by the New York Telephone Company for a $217-million temporary rate increase.

The Fifth United States Cir cuit Court of Appeals has af firmed a lower court's decision that the widow of the country singer Hank Wiliams is not entitled to damages although she had been libeled in "Your Cheatin' Heart," a movie abouthis life.
The current vogue for nos talgia was carried to un precedented - some might say preposterous - lengths on Wednesday evening at the Gershwin Theater of Brooklyn College.

A high-ranking official of the In ternational Brotherhood of Teamsters who had defied the union President, Frank E. Fitz simmons, by endorsing Senator George McGovern for President has been forced to resign fromoffice in his local union.
District Attorney's office here is investigating a school for welfare chiselers that charges a tuition of $5 a class and accepts only young pregnantwomen as students.
Elliot L. Richardson said today that as the new Attorney Gen eral he was determined to eradicate "a kind of sleaziness that has infected" the processes of government.

AREA A--Poor fishing is reported by John Falkiewicz at Surf City. Atlantic mack erel have come and gone and the same is true of most of the winter flounder. A few small stripes are being taken on live shrimp in Barnegatand contiguous bays.

Kenneth Allsop, a British author and researcher into the American way of life, was found dead last night at his home near here. He was 53 years old. The police said they dis covered the body in a bed. Thecause of death was not known.

The 33 cars that have qualified for the Indianapolis 500 partici pated today in Carburetion Day, traditionally the final practice session, before the 57th run ning of the 500 on MemorialDay, next Monday.

A 20-year-old man was ar rested last night after a police investigation into the shooting of a 3-year-old boy in an apart ment at 716 Bedford Avenue, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

A report on a major international education survey said today that home background tended to be the most important factor in a pupil's educational achieve ment. The conclusion was simi lar to those of earlier studiesin the United States.

A bill that would establish an ap pointed, seven-member New York City Board of Education picked up support from key lawmakers today and is expected to be approved by theLegislature in this session.

The Government's Committee on Interest and Dividends is aware of growing complaints that its dividend restraint poli cy is inequitable to stockhold ers and may relax its rule limiting dividend increases to4 per cent a year.

Representative William O. Mills of Maryland, a Republican whose 1971 special election was aided by an unreported cash transfer of $25,000 from the Nixon campaign committee, was found shot to death this morning, and the authorities called his death an apparentsuicide.
Frank Kneisel, a violinist who was a former teacher at the Boston Conservatory and had earlier been concertmaster of the Kansas City (Mo.) Sym phony, died here yesterday atthe age of 68.

Dr. Clifford L. Lord yester day announced his resigna tion as Chancellor of Hofstra University to assume the post of president and chief executive officer of Hudson Institute, the "think tank" devoted to national and international problems.

Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that his panel would hold one day of public hearings on an expected request from the White House for an increase in the public debt ceiling. The temporary ceiling of $465-billion will expire on June 30,

Israeli Arabs who have widely sup ported Premier Golda Meir's Labor party in national elec tions will now be able to join it. By 14 votes to 1 with 3 ab stentions, the party's executive bureau decided today to open its doors to Arabs who endorsethe party's program.
The American Stock Ex change turned in its best per formance in almost five months yesterday and ended a string of eleven consecutive sessionsof losses.

A Fifth Avenue gift shop that sold a $2 roll of film for $10, a $7 carved bottle for $125 and $200 worth of bric-a-brac for over $5,000 has promised to change its ways following an investigation in which a 21 year-old undercover agent worked in the shop for a week as a stock clerk, the Depart ment of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

Italy overwhelmed the Aces at the start of the World Team Championship final here this afternoon. The great foursome--Benito Garozzo, Giorgio Belladonna, Pietro Forquet and Benito Bianchi led after 24 deals by the mas sive margin of 102 international match points, 107 to 5.

White House sources offered an explanation today for Presi dent Nixon's assertion that The New York Times in three in stallments of Its presentation of the Pentagon Papers had. published "a majority" of documents not included in the 47volume Pentagon study.

Patrick J. B. Crowley, a law yer in charge of distribution cases, for the General Motors Corporation in the United States and Canada, died Mon day in Detroit at the age of 62. He lived in Grosse PointeFarms, Mich.

Skylab Repair Mission If all goes on schedule, three astronauts will blast off this morning on an unprecedented mission whose initial stages, at least, will be far different from those originally envisioned. This time their first priority is to repair the giant Skylab vehicle orbiting earth in crippled condition. They will try to erect a sunshade to protect the space station from the harsh sunrays that now pour in without hindrance.

Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached tentative agree ment with Tenneco Chemicals, Inc., for the acquisition by Reichhold of Tenneco's New port division, a major producer of wood and oil naval storesand derivatives.

The Chamber of Deputies tonight lifted the parliamentary im munity of the leader of the Italian Social Movement-National Right Wing, permitting the start of criminal proceed ings against him on the charge of having reorganized the outlawed Fascist party.

The Soviet Union, in a major break with secrecy, identified today for the first time some of its astronauts before they made space flights. The unusual disclosure of the names of four new spacemen came as Moscow announced its selection of four two-man crews that will train with Americans starting this summer for the joint Apollo-Soyuz mission scheduled for July, 1975.

WASHINGTON--The assorted crimes and scandals collectively known as the Watergate affair feature the involve ment of national security institutions--the C.I.A., the State Department, the National Security staff, the White House staff, the F.B.I., ex-C.I.A. opera tives, duped Cuban refugee clients of the C.I.A. These institutions and the men in them have, under a screen of secrecy, been trained and become practiced in lawless behavior.

With the fingertips of his right hand on a copy of the Old Testament, Ephraim Katzir was sworn in as Israel's fourth President. The new President, who was born in the Soviet Union, changed his name from Katchalsky after he was elected in April by the Knesset to the office, which is virtually powerlessand largely ceremonial.

The F.B.I. said yesterday that a search of headquarters of the Jewish Defense League on Wednesday was carried out with a Federal search warrant based on a telephone call warn ing that explosives would "be planted at the Russian or Iraqi missions to the United Nations."
