At least three dozen persons, including four county judges and one member of the Oregon Court of Appeals, have been sent packages of marijuana through the mails in the lasttwo days.

A bill that is expected to pass handily in the Legislature' would in crease its members' salaries in 1975 to $23,500 a year and replace the currento "lulu" ex pense system with a daily al lowance of up to $40 for "ac tual and necessary expenses in curred in the performance of duties."

The family of Yevgeny Levich, a Jewish scientist arrested eight days ago, believes he is now in a military labor camp above the Arctic Circle. The relatives say that the only crime of Mr. Levich, a 25-year-old astro physicist, is that he wants to emigrate to Israel with the restof the Levich family.
The three television networks are leaving their options open as to whether they will con tinue live gavel-to-gavel cover age of the Senate Watergate hearings when they resume June 5.

The United States Attorney in the Water gate case said he expected further indict ments within 60 to 90 days, and that a key figure in the case-reportedly Jeb Stuart Magruder-had agreed to plead guilty andserve as a prosecution witness.

A fly ball whose flight to Matty Alou was interrupted by an empty green seat in the second tier of the right-field stands was the most significant reason why the Yankees were return ing home tonight not in firstplace.
John W. Dean 3d was ques tioned behind closed doors for more than three hours today by the House Commerce in vestigation subcommittee on. two cases involving the Secu rities and Exchange Commission.
Following are excerpts from a transcript of testimony to day in the fifth day of hear ings on the Watergate cast by the Senate Select Commit tee on Presidential Campaign Activities:
Dean Ewell Reagin of Antioch College says another attempt will be made tomorrow to reopen the school, closed more than a month by student strikers.
A father of 10 was ar raigned today on a charge of murdering his brother 16 years ago. Skeletal remains of the victim were found yesterday ona farm near here.

Charles S. Brykczynski, who succeeded his father in 1942 as president of the Stuhmer Bak ing Company, died Wednesday in Brooklyn Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 295St. John's Place, Brooklyn.
President Nixon, in a spirited address to about 610 cheering former prisoners of war, lashed out today at those who threaten the secrecy of national security matters.

With out an abortion law and with out a chance of getting one in the twilight days of the 1973 session of the General Assem bly, Connecticut will attempt to control abortions by public health regulations, Health Com missioner Franklin M. Footesaid today.
When Dr. Hector J. Cam pora assumes the presidency tomorrow, he will begin what almost all Argentines consid er the most important chap ter in their history since Juan D. Peron was overthrown in1955.

American, Trans World and United Air Lines said yester day they had reached final agreement on a plan to limit by prearrangement the num ber of seats each may fly on four competitive routes for twoyears beginning Sept. 15.
Elliot L. Richardson, as one of his final acts as Secretary of Defense, ordered today that the Navy end its controversial use of the small Puerto Rican island of Culebra as a practice gunnery range.

Jim Riedel, a freshman, allowed only three hits today as Buffalo University defeated the regional favorite, Temple University, 1-0, in the opener of the National Collegiate District II baseball playoffs.

A 50-year-old Pompton Lakes man took the oath of citizen ship today after a Passaic County District Court judge held that charges that he had murdered inmates of a Nazi concentration camp were "hearsay and incoherent."
A 4-year-old boy who might have died of paralysis from an unknown cause is well today because a nurse attended a lecture on ticks and mites at the Long Island Jewish-HillsideMedical Center here.

Memorial Day is the traditional time for New Yorkers to make the year's first moves toward getting out of town, to search for greener pastures and to flee the town's huddled masses (although for many, a dayor so of this is more than enough).

In other circumstances the return of Argentina to elected constitutional government after seven years of military rule would be an occasion for rejoicing far beyond that country's borders. For many reasons, the celebration over the inauguration today of Dr. Hector J. Campora as President will be confined to the forces making up the Peronist coalition that elected him and their motley collection of admirers and supporters from abroad.

Steve Krisiloff's racing career has been a succession of learning experiences. The most important one has been the art of getting along with little money, which includes teaching yourself the innards of arace car.
The police rebellion in Uttar Pradesh was reported to have ended today with the surrender of the last two garrisons that were holding out against the army.

The House Government Oper ations Committee has recom mended a new law to overhaul government secrecy practices. In a report released last night, the group said that a two-year study had turned up abuses of the current classifica tion system through Presidential order, as well as over-classifica tion, accumulations of hundreds of millions of classified papers and estimated costs of more than $100-million a year to guard, handle, store, transportand declassify material.
The Board of Estimate last night approved the plan to build a $200-million convention hall on the West Sideof Manhattan. The hearing, sometimes stormy,
President Nixon, in a spirited address to about 610 cheering former prisoners of war, lashed out today at those who threaten the secrecy of national securitymatters.
Peter Paul, Inc., announced yesterday that it would in crease the size of its candy bars and advance their pricesfrom 10 cents to 15 cents a bar.

New Zealand today de livered a stinging attack on France for refusing to halt nu clear bomb tests in the Pacific. French contamination of the atmosphere with radioactive fallout is "pernicious and in excusable," the New Zealand statement added.

The House, as usual, has sustained President Nixon's veto, this time of a misdirected Congressional effort to re move two high officials from office, then to assert the Senate's right to approve their reappointment. This may suggest that the Watergate disclosures have not reduced Mr. Nixon's political

L. Patrick Gray 3d, former act ing director of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation, told a Senate appropriations subcom mittee today that he had warned President Nixon last July 6 that "people on yourstaff are trying to mortally
Gov. Marvin M. Mandel, with a gibe at President Nixon's eco nomic policies, signed into law today what is believed to be the first statewide rent controlbill in the nation.

The impending trip to China by a United States swimming team on a tour sponsored by the State Department-and the ath letes' certain suspension as a result by the Amateur Athletic Union-was the focal point of the Senate hearing today onproposed sports legislation.

A 570 million-year-old clam, the oldest yet recov ered, has been found near Albany, the United States Geological Survey announced today. The survey, a part of the Interior Department, said the clam fossil was 70 million years older than any previously known.

To the Editor: In spite of Watergate and its alarm ing implications, the people of our na tion should not lose sight of the fact that our Government must continue to function. It's a $250-billion business enterprise, and cannot be permitted to drift because of our preoccupation with the shocking revelations before the Ervin Committee.

Emperor Haile 'Se lassie opened the 10th anni versary celebrations of the 11 Organization of African Unity here today by calling for the creation of a "system of mutual defense" for the 41 member nations.
S. W. Calkins of Uniontown, publisher of newspapers in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Florida, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

HUDSON, N. Y.-The cam paign to eliminate billboards and other forms of "visual pollution" in New York State is entering its second year with transportation officials reporting modest success. Last spring, the State De partment of Transportation opened a drive to remove 80,000 illegal billboards in the state, with a target date of 1976 for completion of thetask.

Stockholders of the Xerox Corporation were told yester day that 1973 would be an other record year for the com pany. Archie R. McCardell, presi dent, cautioned, however, at the annual meeting at the Felt Forum against over-optimism. He told shareholders that the 22 per cent profit advance of the first quarter "will be diffi cult to duplicate in the remaining part of the year."

THE PARADISE KID by Donna de Matteo. Directed by Herbert Berghof. Tomor row through June 23 at 7:30 P.M. The H. B. Playwrights Foundation, Inc., at 124 BankStreet (YU 9-6540).

Hungarian and Polish officials of the International Commission of Control and Supervision said today they "strongly suspected" that two commission helicopters that crashed last month in Vietcong territory were also on an un authorized reconnaissance flight for the United States CentralIntelligence Agency.

A Collinsville, III., man and his wife, who were terrorized in their home by Federal nar cotics agents, filed today a $1-million damage suit against the Federal Government in United States District Courthere.
WASHINGTON--"When the Con gress appropriates funds it gives the executive branch an authority to in cur obligations. Certainly none of us hold that we give a mandate to expendthe funds appropriated."

Edward R. Sowders, a veteran of the Vietnam war who de serted from the Army in 1970, appeared before an informal House hearing on amnesty to day to announce that he wouldsurrender to military authorities.
"Employers have been led to the water trough," Lee Christie remarked, "but they don't know whether theywant to drink."

Yale Bowl was officially designated yesterday as the site of the last five New York Giant home football games this season, but the knotty problem of how the local television blackout wouldbe handled remained unresolved.
Samuel A. Schreiner, a lawyer who founded the suburban township of Mount Lebanon in 1912 and became an authority on town ship law, died here Tuesday. He was 91 years old.
Two British soldiers were killed and a third was seriously injured today by an explosion while they were searching a booby-trappedhouse near the Irish border.
The general manager of the National Transportation Safety Board has denied applying pres sure to staff members of that independent agency to bow toWhite House wishes.

The gen eral assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., at a nine-day meeting that ended yesterday, called for the United States to end mili tary intervention in Indochina, urged a Senate study of the Wounded Knee uprising and upgraded the status of womenin the church.
Johnny Rodgers of Nebras ka, last year's winner of the Heisman Trophy, has decided to play for the Montreal Alouettes of the CanadianFootball League.
The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week totaled an estimated $948-million, up 16 per cent from $814-million a year earlier.

William H. Sullivan, Deputy Assistant Sec retary of State for East Asia and Pacific Affairs, conferred with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam for an hour today on proposals to en force the Vietnam cease-fire. Mr. Sullivan then met with For eign Minister Tran Van Lam for further discussions.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Israel Museum in Jerusalem say they will definitely exchange exhibi tions in 1974 in commemoration of the Israel Museum's10th anniversary.

Mrs. David Eiscnhower, mingling among the guests at a tea at the State Depart ment for the wives, mothers and girlfriends of the former prisoners of war, said today that her mother "is holding up very well" under thestrain of the Watergate case.
Negotiations between the General Electric Company and unions representing 137,000 of its employes now appear likely to continue beyond tomorrow at midnight, when their presentcontracts expire.

The publishers of the city's three major daily newspapers have made a proposal to Typo graphical Union No. 6 that would permit the papers to in troduce and utilize automation, including "any and all" compuers.

DOROTHY THOMPSON, A Legend in Her Time. By Marion K. Sanders. Illustrated. 428 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $10. In one of her wondrously bubbly letters that nourish the vitality of this prudent biography, Dorothy Thompson described herself to Alexander Woollcott, the drama critic, who had suggested her for a New Yorker profile.
Visually it looked very elegant. Seals and Crofts, nicely contrasting in white and plaid suits, perched on high stools on stage at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday.

A 4-year-old boy who might have died of paralysis from an unknown cause is well today because a nurse attended a lecture on ticks and mites at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center here. The child, Rimpy Mundi whose mother is from Kenya,Africa, and father from Punjab,

Rainy skies and discourag ing statistics for Roosevelt Raceway's 70-session meeting, which closed tonight, before 17,698 fans, combined to dampen the spirts of George Morton Levy, president and founder of the harness-racingtrack.

The old three-run-homer-in-abunt situation trick, executed by Gene Michael, gave the NewYork Yankees a highly satisfying 9-7 victory over Texas last night in a game that saw the Rangers take a 7-0 lead in the second inning.

An official Soviet publication has hinted for the first time, perhaps inadvertently, at the magnitude of grain imports last year after a serious crop failure. The purchases, made at bargain prices, are believed to have insured an adequate supply of bread, a staple food in the Russian diet.

There is no shortage of help for students who want it at Haaren High School, the boys' school at 10th Avenue and 59th Street. Each afternoon, upwards of 30 students stay after school to help fellow students with assignments and tutoring in English, reading and math.

Here in the Libyan capital the foreigners talk about Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi almost all the time; Colonal Qaddafi talks about the foreigners; the Libyans talk about the Egyptians and the Egyptians about the Libyans.

John Hartnett of Villanova ran away with a title in the six-mile run today, but Navy muscle may have built an insurmountable lead for team honors in the 97th annual I.C.4-A outdoor track and field championships.

"From Within," is the very apt title for an exhibition of paintings and mixed-media works by the inmates of the Auburn Correctional Facility, a maximum-security prison. They are now on view at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle.

WASHINGTON-The United States was once a leading oil exporter. This year we will import about 5 million barrels a day, at a dollar outflow of more than $6 billion. By 1980 we will be importing about 11.6 million barrels a day, if we are still without North Slope Alaska oil, at a dollar outflow of about $16 billion a year.

In typically Irresponsible frenzy, the State Legislature is winding up five sluggish months of limited activity by rush action on a huge number of bills that should have been voted up or down long ago. This final scramble is a mockery of the legislative process, no less repulsive because it is part of Albany's dreary tradition.

Edward Villella and Patricia McBride seem to have become as necessary to the New York Philharmonic's Promenades season as domestic champagne. The solo dancers of the New York City Ballet returned to the popular-music series on Thursday night (Mr. Villella for his fourth consecutive year),

Thomas B. Morgan, Mayor Lindsay's press secretary, said yesterday that the Mayor was thinking of running in 1976 for the United States Senate seat now held by James L. Buckley, but the report was denied by the Mayor.

Heavy losses are expected in the state's attempt to counter a four-pronged invasion of eastern tent caterpillars, leaf rollers, cankerworms and gypsy moths, authorities said today. John D. Kegg, an Agriculture Department entomologist commanding the campaign against the woodland pests, said the first major battle of the war had already been lost.

The Composers Theater fourth annual May Festival ended at the New School on Thursday night with a concert of music for brass instruments. Carl Ruggles's "Angels," a work that is some 50 years old (though it does not sound it), was included in the program,

Litton Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it had net income of $18.7-million, or 49 cents a share, for its third fiscal quarter ended April 30. The total included a loss of $1.9-million from discontinued operations, a special credit from divestitures of $9.5-million and a profit of $11.1-million from continued operations.
A collision sensor for motor cars makes a decision 10 feet in front of the bumper and releases an airbag or other safety device.

The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday that rather than risk a strike they had decided to defer their plans for unilaterally deciding the size of the railroad's train crews.
The United States and Switzerland today signed a treaty designed to help American invest gators track down members of organized crime by uncover
A Federal judge yesterday signed an order that effectively tied up assets at Weis Securities, Inc., until next Wednesday morning. The brokerage house was suspended by all stock exchanges on Thursday.

Dr. Hector J. Campora, a loyal follower of former President Juan Domingo Peron, was inaugurated today as the president of a popularly elected government, ending seven years of military rule in Argentina.

Morning traffic on the Long Island Rail Road was disrupted again yesterday when the lead cars of two eastbound trains side-swiped each other as they left the Jamaica station in Queens, causing some third-rail damage. No injuries were reported, but the mishap delayed other trains going through Jamaica. It was the second accident involving a L.I.R.R. train this week. Last Monday, a train derailed in Woodside, Queens, resulting in injuries to 38 passengers.

Clergy and Laity Concerned, a religious peace group, has asked military chaplains to urge American pilots and crew members involved in the bombing of Cambodia to "leave the Air Force, resist. or disobey orders" rather than continue to participate in the bombing, which it called "an offense against both God and man."
"It's killing me, but what can you do," said Bowling Green's, and maybe the South's, best known madam as the rap of the auctioneer's gavel marked the sale of about 300 of her prized antiques.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market registered their second consecutive advances yesterday in stepped-up trading. The exchange's price index, which was up throughout the session, finished ahead 0.19 at 22.76, its high for the day.

Thomas B. Morgan, Mayor Lindsay's press secretary, said Yesterday that the Mayor was thinkingg of running in 1976 for :he United States Senate seat now held by James L. Buckley, put the report was denied by the Mayor.
The owner of the Buffalo Braves, Paul Snyder, said today he had signed Ernie DiGregorio to a "multi year contract" with the National Basketball Association club.

The newly expanded City Council has been such a dismal failure over such a long period that voters may well be prompted to cast a ballot for any challenger against any incumbent in primary contests for Council seats June 4. Ineffectual and unrepresentative though the Council has been, it does not follow that every replacement would have to be an improvement.

Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities to the highest level since June of 1970. The average rate for threemonth bills in the sale is 6.694 per cent, up from last week's 6.352 per cent,

The Trailer Train Company, a car-leasing concern in Chicago owned by 32 major railroads, announced yesterday a program for acquisition of 2,249 new railroad flat cars that will cost about $50-million.

The Board of Estimate's approval late Thursday night of plans to build a convention and exhibition center on the West Side made it likely, according to city officials and legislators, that the board and the City Council would vote the funds required for the center, which is expected to cost about $200million.

A Queens grand jury has exonerated a lawyer accused of passing heroin to his client in a courthouse detention cell. The lawyer, Abraham Werfel, 55 years old of Flushing, had been charged with receiving a
L. Patrick Gray 3d, the former acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a figure in the Watergate affair, is expected to return to private law practice in New London, Conn.

A nimbly pleasant little satire-revue with a succinct set of amusing fangs-and a decided cause-has the title of "?!" (Whitzit mean? Dunno.) The material is by the Westbeth Playwrights' Feminist Collective.

Italy coasted to victory in the world team championship here today against the Aces. The Italian team, a slightly modified version of the Blue Team that won 13 world titles, rested comfortably on a cushion of points gained during the first quarter of the match yesterday.

The Communications Satellite Corporation announced today that it had awarded a $40million contract to the Hughes Aircraft Company to build communications satellites for the Navy and maritime industry.
A man in a station wagon pulled to the curb as a white Nassau County police car with lights flashing and siren blaring pulled up behind him this morning.

Mrs. Dorothy Thompson Quinn of Field Point Park, widow of Martin Quinn, who was a stock exchange specialist, was married here at noon today to Randolph C. Harrison, a retired banker, of 200 East 66th Street, New York.
The last survivor of President Nixon's original Presidential campaign team-a political associate for more than 25 years--is expected to join the exodus of top Administration officials soon.

The Senate unanimously approved a bill late today authorizing New York City to cede 26,000 acres of land at the mouth of New York Harbor to the Federal Government for the development of the Gateway National Recreation Area.

Relatives and friends of some of the l,359 American servicemen listed 'as missing in action in Southeast Asia urged local congressmen yesterday to see to it that both the United States and North Vietnam made greater efforts to resolve the status of the men.

John Longua, who retired in 1971 as a partner in the New York Urban Servicing Company, a real-estate financing organization at' 60 East 42d Street, died Thursday at his home in Woodbury, L.I. His age was 68.

William H. Sullivan, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Eastern and Pacific Affairs, left Saigon this morning after three days of talks with South Vietnamese Government officials on carrying out the cease-fire.

While management exuded optimism on the continuing of near-record automobile sales next year, many shareholders at the 65th annual meeting of the General Motors Corporation today asked how the concern was dealing with current issues.

SAN DIEGO-This is the twentieth anniversary of the announcement of the polio vaccine. A strange and paradoxical situation exists now in the United States with respect to immunization. Although the incidence of the disease has been sharply reduced, nevertheless cases continue to occur. The reasons for this are clear. So is the remedy. Why, then, do the authorities who are aware of the problem seem to be looking the other way?

An official Soviet publication has hinted for the first time, perhaps inadvertently, at the magnitude of grain imports last year after a serious crop failure. The purchases, made at bargain prices, are believed to have insured an adequate supply of bread, a staple food in the Russian diet.

SUPER SONIC The Sonic Arts Union, which usually plays its contemporary electronic music in the regular concert-size package, is going all out this weekend with a performance that started yesterday morning and will run deep into Sunday night,
The United States and Switzerland today signed a treaty designed to help American investigators track down members of organized crime by uncovering

The wife of a Roman doctor who went to a downtown shop this week to have her mink stored for the summer was kept waiting for nearly two hours because all hands were busy with customers eager to buy expensive fur coats as an inflation hedge.
"Zoom," said Jack Nicklaus as his right hand cut the air, "that's the way I was hitting my drives straight down the fairways today." A six-under-par second round of 66 gave Nicklaus an 11-under,

Bonnie Cashin may be as much a national monument to the fashion industry in this country as Chanel was to Paris, but she's relaxed about it. When she introduced her fall collection of knitted clothes the other day, she asked her friends and neighbors to model. Catharine Percopo, who lives five floors above her at 866 United Nations Plaza, looked particularly at home in the long knitted cashmere dresses.

Afghan farmers are harvesting a bumper crop of opium poppies on newly irrigated land that has been developed with Foreign aid. American officials, who have sought to put pressure on the Government to curb, the growth and outflow of opium,

The Mayors and Councils of this borough and of neighboring Alpine will sit down with their attorneys in separate caucuses next week to decide what to do about the proposed shift of 14,homes from one town to the other.

"There is only death in the north," a refugee from droughtstricken Mali said. "The animals die first - the cattle, sheep, goats and camels--and then the people," he said. "First the old and then the children, the sickly."

A heavy rainstorm didn't deter p 44 starters in the first junior lumper class today at the openng session of the 8-day Devon horse show. But only Villa Eda Stable's Irish Song made a faultless run over the testing coursee to win the event.

John Hartnett of Villavona ran away with a title in the six-mile run today, but Navy muscle may have built an insurmountable lead for team honors in the 97th annual I.C.4-A outdoor track and field championships.

Miss Ruth Iris Gallin was married here last evening to Dr. Scott R. Spielman, who graduated this month from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgcons. The Rev. Dr. David Seligson of Central Synagogue performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gallin, parents of the bride.

The White House said today that the bulk of President Nixon's estate at San Clemente was controlled by an unnamed investment company formed by Robert H. Abplanalp, a multimillionaire businessman who is a close friend of the President.

Three heads of African states declared here today that the white minority regime of South Africa, the Portuguese African colonies and Israel were all involved In an Imperialist plot to retard independent African progress,

The Federal Trade Commission accused the Phillips Petroleum Company today of stifling competition by intimidating and coercing its 3,600 gasoline station lessees across the country into buying Phillips products.

The Mother Goose, second part of the triple crown for fillies, has attracted an overnight field of 11 for its 17th running at Belmont Park today. Poker Night of the Hobeau Farm is the long-range favorite for the 1 1/8 mile contest,

Three American astronauts rode an Apollo spacecraft into orbit today, rendezvoused with the crippled Skylab space station, failed to dislodge a jammed power wing, and then encountered mission-threatening problems in attempting to link up with the Skylab after having docked earlier.
The District Attorney's office in Manhattan announced the arrest yesterday of two men in the murder on the East Side four years ago of the son of a Florida millionaire.
Mark Ethridge Jr. has been appointed editor and vice president of The Akron Beacon Journal, it was announced today by John S. Knight,

A police raid on a warehouse in Maspeth, Queens, yesterday was said to have smashed a $2-million-a-year ring of car thieves who stole to order, cut up the vehicles and sold the parts to auto body shops.
The American Motors Corporation said today that it was recalling 1,624 cars, mainly police vehicles, equipped with an incorrect air cleaner cover.
Corporations seeking to acquire interests in Nevaaa gambling resorts must first get approval from the Nevada Gaming Commission, according to a new regulation adopted yesterday.

The Santos of Brazil-Lazio of Italy soccer game at Roosevelt Stadium tonight had all the characteristics of a match in Naples or Sao Paulo. There was scoring by the Brazilians and no scoring by the Italians.

The Storm Trysail Club's love affair with Block Island got going today with 149 yachts in eight classes setting forth on the 28th annual round trip. With a raw easterly of from 15 to 25 knots blowing in their faces, the skippers and their crews had a chilly night's work ahead of them as they beat their way out of Larchmont Yacht Club waters.
The White House identified a millionaire manufacturer and Presidential friend as the man who financed the purchase .of the Western White House property for President Nixon.
Archibald Cox took the oath of office as special prosecutor in the Watergate case today in a setting that seemed far removed from the men and policies of the Nixon Administration.

Shortly after he was elected Mayor of Camden this month, Angelo J. Errichetti endorsed Brendan T. Byrne for the Democratic nomination for Governor. Mr. Byrne also has the en. dorsements of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark, Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City and Mayor Thomas Dunn of Elizabeth.

His Houston teammates marvel at the smooth easy way Lee May hits, and they had cause to do so last night as May's two home runs highlighted an 11-hit attack and gave he Astros a 7-2 victory over the Pirates in Pittsburgh.

By a vote of 36 to 22, the Republican majority early today pushed through the State Senate Governor Rockefeller's proposal to create 100 new judges to handle the increase in narcotics cases that is expected to

Most of the city's nine superagencies - a trademark of the Lindsay administration-would be dismantled under reorganization plans advocated by all four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.
For its second, performance of John Cranko's version of "Swan Lake," the Stuttgart Ballet presented a new cast led by Richard Cragun and Birgit Keil on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Msgr. William J. Shannon, a onetime radio singer who became vice rector and administrator of the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception here, died today in Crouse-Irving Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 25-In retrospect it is easy to see that President Nixon loved secrets too much. He was not alone in that vice. Lyndon Johnson before him loved secrets to excess and often boasted of the secrets to which he alone was privy.

Bernard Yarrow, retired senior vice president of Free Europe, Inc., which operates Radio Free Europe, and a former assistant district attorney here, died yesterday at his home, 112 East 74th Street. He also lived at Twin Brooks Farm, Lyme, Conn. He was 73 years old.

When outsider from those alien territories like Queens or Brooklyn or-gasp--Manhattan try to use Nassau County's system of parks tomorrow, they will find it slightly tougher than in previous years.

Over the cold stone castle floor they glide. Past massive arches, gothic windows, between, rows of arc-lights, through mazes of cables,

Dr. Blanche Hinman Dow, former president of the American Association of University Women, died yesterday. She was 80 years old. Dr. Dow, who retired in 1965 after serving 16 years as president of Cottey College at Nevada, Mo., had served as A.A.U.W. president from 1963 to 1967.

The National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that it would look into allegations by a Chicago legal researcher that a United Air Lines jetliner that crashed Dec. 8 was sabotaged as part of the Watergate case cover-up.

The dollar rose sharply in European currency dealings today in apparent reaction to news of-the United States's trade surplus for April and the sharp rally on Wall Street yesterday. Simultaneously, gold fell heavily in most financial centers.

The retail cost of a "market basket" of foods produced in the United States continued to climb in April, moving 1.6 per cent above prices in March and 14.37 per cent above the figure a year ago, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
Bobby Clarke of the Philadelphia Flyers, a diabetic, was named yesterday as the winner of the Hart Trophy, given annually to the National Hockey League player judged the most valuable to his team.

In "The Twilight of the Presidency," George Reedy, former press secretary to the late President Johnson, wrote: "The White House Is a court.... This raises the greatest of all barriers to Presidential access to reality and raises a problem which will plague the White House so long as the President is a reigning monarch rather than an elected administrator." A 37-year-old man was stabbed to death late Thursday night when he apparently resisted an attempted mugging by three teen-aged girls and a male accomplice on 52d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, the police reported yesterday.

To the Editor: As an Englishman living in Canada and who makes periodic visits to the U.S., my sympathies go out to the people of America in this difficult time. Watergate and its far-reaching ramifications can only have, one hopes temporary, harmful effects on the American concept of democracy as seen from abroad.

An 8-year-old girl who was in a Bronx schoolroom when a 9-year-old boy shot a classmate in the neck with a pistol has told police that she saw the boy load the gun with two bullets before firing, according to a police report of the shooting.

Mel Pender tied the world record in the 60-yard dash with a time of 5.8 seconds tonight at an International Track Association meet. Pender's time tied the mark set by Herb Washington of Michigan State in 1972.

The stock market withstood a spate of profit taking yesterday morning and made another solid advance in the afternoon in heavy trading. The Dow-Jones industrial average, down 3.46 points at 11 A.M., rebounded and closed with a gain of 6.40 points at 930.84.

Despite occasional showers and forecasts of more to come, tens of thousands of New Yorkers joined the Memorial Day weekend exodus from the city in the late afternoon and evening yesterday, bound for beaches, resorts and country homes.

Jerome Robbins's new ballet, "An Evening's Waltzes," which was given its world premiere by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater on Thursday night, finds Mr. Robbins once more in his classical mood.
The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it was increasing the price of its 1973 Thunderbird models by 15.4 per cent, or $860, by standardizing a number of previously optional features.

Hank Aaron tied Babe Ruth yesterday, but it was not tile feat the baseball world awaits, although he moved a step closer to that, too.

Although his final-round score seemed more humane to his rivals than his previous ones, Jack Nicklaus won the Atlanta golf classic by two strokes with a 72-hole aggregate of 272 today.

Senator Ralph C. DeRose, campaigning for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, suggested here today that New Jersey's poverty-stricken central cities "can be rehabilitated without spending a lot of money."

A Federal judge in Brooklyn is expected to rule shortly on whether the United States Merchant Marine Academy acted constitutionally in denying a diploma to a former cadet from Irvington, N. J., because of his secret marriage.

To the Editor: The nightshade of Watergate is providing an unwitting cover for a farreaching Administration attempt to make a 180-degree change in direction and return to the workhouse era of public welfare 100 years ago.
Two mammoth warehouses, a petroleum plant and a food supply center were destroyed today by a series of explosions and fire.

Australians speak of the imminent arrival of Marshall Green, the United States Ambassador-designate, as if the veteran diplomat were a trophy like the Davis Cup. "We got Marshall Green," one high official declared triumphantly in a foreign affairs discussion in Parliament last week.

President Nixon ordered today an investigation to determine what forced an Army helicopter to plummet into the Atlantic last night while taking seven Secret Service agents to guard him and his family on a Bahama island. One agent died and nine men suffered minor injuries.

The amendment to assure equal rights for women"Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any state on account of sex"-has now been ratified by some thirty states, not far short of the number needed to incorporate it into the Constitution. The supporters of the provision still have six years during which to persuade state legislatures to vote affirmatively or to reconsider their negative votes.

Penny Loeb of Amenia, N. Y., campaigned Zim's Mr. Spoons all last year and won literally dozens of championships in horse shows. The 26-year-old Miss Loeb decided at the end of the 1972 season that Zim's Mr. Spoons had done his bit and semi-retired him to Meridale Farms.

Miss Meri Ellen Leeds, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Leeds of White Plains, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Frederick Pollak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pollak 2d, also of White Plains. Rabbi Bernard Schactel performed the ceremony on the terrace of the Tarrytown House.

Two Athens newspapers reported that Greece's army-backed Government had decided to hold a nationwide referendum soon to allow the Greeks to determine the future of their exiled King, Constantine, who is living in Rome.

NEW HAVEN--Over and beyond all the familiar sources of human error is a powerful source of defective judgment that arises in cohesive groups of decision makers-the concurrenceseeking tendency, which fosters overoptimism, lack of vigilance and sloganistic thinking about the weakness and immorality of out-groups.

Before ending his brief stint as Secretary of Defense to become Attorney General, Elliot Richardson came down decisively on the side of Culebra, the Caribbean mouse that roared at the United States Navy. Mr. Richardson ordered the Navy to terminate by mid-1975 the gunnery and air bombardment practice that for years has annoyed and harassed the 726 residents of the 7,000acre island off Puerto Rico's east coast.

Mrs. Frances Halper Jacobs, widow of Dr. William K. Jacobs, a physician, and mother of William K. Jacobs Jr., president of the Abacus Fund, Inc., died yesterday at her apartment in the Surrey Hotel. She was 93 years old.
A new rule requiring druggists to keep medical profiles of customers has pharmacists in the state scurrying to comply within the prescribed 30-day limit.
The Fair Campaign. Practices Committee called the Watergate affair today the low point in campaign tactics since the committee began monitoring political campaign activities nearly 20 years ago.

The German-American Soccer League's dominance in the United States Challenge Cup, the most coveted prize in American soccer since 1912 came to an end yesterday when Inter of Cleveland eliminated the New York Greek-Americans, 3-1.

Last week an Israeli Cabinet minister urged the Japanese, who have been accused of discriminating against Israel, to ignore Arab threats of boycotting Japanese exports and to improve their trade relations with Israel.
Harmon H. Cardozo, a New York real estate executive and member of the representative town meeting here for 16 years, died today at his home, 7 Hidden Hll. He was 59 years old.

Steps taken by the Federal Reserve 12 days ago to curb the lending ability of banks and thereby "help moderate inflationary pressures" - are being viewed by several analysts as likely to prove ineffective, perhapss even counterproductive.

During the first five days of hearings by the Senate Watergate committee, the seven-member panel performed largely as expected: Its tone was reasonably nonpartisan and lawyerlike, .its pace was slow and cautious, its immediate purpose was narrow and unusually restrained.

Chris Inman of Essex Catholic won the mile in 4 minutes 14.2 seconds and Tim Conheeney of Paramus Catholic the twomile in 9:16.8 at the New Jersey parochial track and field championships today at Williams Field.
The Los Angeles Dodgers, the hottest team in the West, made it three straight over the New York Mets today as Don Sutton outpitched Jerry Koosman, 2-1.

The world's dependence on Midville East oil has increased sharply in the last five years, according to the new edition of the British Petroleum Co., Ltd., annual statistical review of the world petroleum industry.

Kathy Heddy is everyone's image of what an Olympic swimmer should be: short-cropped blond hair, pixie face and a deceptively muscular frame. She also happens to be a long-range favorite for the 1976 United States team at Montreal.
Tom Gorman and Paul Gerken, two unseeded Americans, reached the quarter-finals in the men's singles in the $133,000 French open tennis championships today with straight-set victories.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland--In the small, cluttered living room of Noel and Brigid Hopkins Sunday is like a prison. Their apartment is on the ground floor of the Divis Flats, a gray complex in the rubble of the Lower Falls section of Belfast's Roman Catholic ghetto.

Richard S. Nye's Carina won the Storm Trysail Club's Block Island race today. The 48-foot, McCurdy Rhodes sloop based in Greenwich, Conn., which represented the United States last year in the Admirals Cup, found the home waters of Long Island Sound more to her liking and was awarded the Harvey Conover Memorial Trophy for best corrected time.

The Legislature early today passed, without debate, a bill that would increase lawmakers' salaries in 1975 by nearly 60 per cent and grant them $40-aday expense accounts. The bill was part of a lastminute drive toward adjournment in which the lawmakers also had to act on an $85-million supplement to the state's main $8.77-billion budget.
Jacques Lipchitz, one of the foremost sculptors of the 20th century, died. Saturday of a heart attack at the hotel where he was vacationing in Capri. He was 81 years old.

The Legislature approved a bill today that would establish an appointed, seven-member New York City Board of Education to replace the "interim" board created by the school decentralization law in 1969.

Jim Dietz, the United States singles champion, was upset today by Dr. Larry Klecatsky, a New York Athletic Club teammae in the elite handicap singles Memorial Day race of the New York Rowing Association.

The major oil-exporting nations and the biggest petroleum companies have backed away from a showdown over oil prices and decided to continue to negotiate their differences. The issue that caused the crisis is the exporting countries' demands for compensation for the loss of purchasing power resulting from the devaluation of the dollar last February.
If there is "nothing" inherently wrong in bigness--as bigbusiness men contend-bigness does present problems in the face of consumerism, executives acknowledged here last week.

Archbishop Molloy took seven events to retain the Catholic High Schools Brooklyn Diocese track title yesterday at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens.

The United States General Accounting Office plans to audit records of the now-defunct Executive Club of the Republican party of New Jersey to see whether errors it made in its formal filing of campaign expenditures last year "were inadvertent or an attempt to mislead."

The disabling of a British trawler by shells from an Icelandic gunboat has brought into a stage of active conflict the revival of the "Cod War" between Britain and Iceland. Renewal of the bruising struggle that first erupted in the late 1950's comes after British naval vessels had been dispatched to waters off Iceland in response to shootings, rammings and other incidents involving British trawlers and Icelandic patrol craft.

At Temple Israel here this afternoon, Miss Shelley May Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Fisher, was married to James Fishkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Fishkin of Oxon Hill, Md. Rabbi Byron T. Rubenstein performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Paul Kwartin.

Ch. Littleway Haranwal parrister, a wirehaired fox terrier, turned in another superb performance today to capture bestin-show honors at the 31st Plainfield Kennel Club all-breed event on the athletic field of St. Joseph's High School.
Diplomatic sources reported today that the Soviet Union had made a major concession on one of the most difficult issues facing the delegates in Helsinki preparing for a European security conference.
Representative Herman Badillo was both aided and upstaged by a Congressional colleague, Representative Ronald V. Dellums, on a walking tour through Harlem yesterday afternoon.

The towering shadow of the South Mall construction project intruded briefly into the Assembly this morning as the Republican majority voted to continue for two years a costly contract loophole that is keeping the Governor's favorite marbled project going.

Buddy Baker, driving a Dodge almost flawlessly, charged past David Pearson 16 laps from the finish today and captured the NASCAR World 600, stock car racing's longest event for the second straight year. His average speed was 134.890 miles per hour in a race slowed then halted for 40 minutes by rain.

The American Stock Exchange expects to present plans for a trading market in call options for the approval of its governors when the board holds its next monthly meeting on June 14.

One thing about the Safari Now boutique at Bonwit Teller is that its rather exclusive stock is constantly changing, so the women who pay the prices that prevail there are not likely to see themselves coming and going.

Is there anything that the C.S.C. Repertory Company cannot do and do well? Take "Loot." One way is to sit back, relax and laugh your head off. This is a truly blistering and diabolically clever play. C.S.C., at 89 West Third Street, has spun off the play as its last seasonal entry like a vest-pocket dream.

Tornadoes and heavy rair killed at least 18 people in six states over the weekend. Three others were missing and pre sumed drowned. The storms left scores ?? persons injured, including about 200 in Arkansas and several dozen in Mississippi and Alabama.

Fourteen persons were injured, one critically, when an Orange and Black line bus and a taxicab collided yesterday near the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken. The Hudson County police said the bus apparently struck the cab broadside at the intersection of North Marginal Highway and Pleasant Avenue at about 12:37 A.M. They did not know how many people were in the bus.

William Warren Bradley, former Rhodes scholar, rumored political aspirant and small forward for the New York Knickerbockers, urged the graduating class of St. Peter's College today to choose a life of introspection and contemplation and to reject the excesses of materialism.

The care of young children and adolescents from homes broken up by divorce, separation, desertion or other forms of family disintegration has become the first priority of New York Catholic Charities' child-care department. The organization reported yesterday that in 1972 it had provided residential and day-care services through its 36 affiliate agencies to 15,676 young people, 70.4 per cent of whom were black or Hispanic.

Allegheny Airlines has reported next earnings of 1.5million for April, up $506,000 from its net earnings for April, 1972.

Running for an office that historically has had little power and visibility, three Democratic candidates for the nomination for City Council president began the final week of the primary campaign stressing differences of approach rather than issues.
The British trawler Everton, hit by shells from an Icelandic gunboat, has been repaired by a British naval team and is no longer in danger of sinking, the British Defense Ministry reported today.

Public School 91 in Brooklyn's racially changing Crown Heights section is an anomaly, for it is one of a handful of schools in the city with a predominantly black and Hispanic enrollment that have higher reading-proficiency scores than the national average.

Two good candidates of unusual promise confront old-line, organization opponents in Democratic primary contests for Borough Presidencies on June 4. In each case, the Democratic nomination is virtually the equivalent of election.
Members of the Italian bridge team received their world championship trophies here last night following their victory in the Bermuda Bowl.
Gary Bettenhausen stood out today as the favorite for the 57th running of the Indianapolis 500, which is set to go tomorrow morning-weather permitting.

ROME, N.Y. - For many parents of retarded children at the Rome State School in upstate New York, it is a familiar scene. The child comes home for a visit, covered with welts and bruises. The school says the child took a fall or got into a fight with another child. The child says an attendant beat him.

Fred R. Lazarus Jr., chairman of the executive committee of Federated Department Stores, died at his home here this evening. He was 88 years old.

Judge W. Wallace Kent of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati, died today in a hospital, apparently of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

SAN JOSE, Calif.--On the east side of this city of half a million an hour's drive south of San Francisco, six schools are finishing the first year of a project that has made them the focus of national attention and controversy.

The International Chamber of Commerce, at its meeting here last week, drew up resolutions aimed at satisfying American hopes for a more liberal system of world trade and other nations demands for dollar stability.
Greece's military-backed Government declared today that 35 navy officers would be tried, probably on treason charges, in the mutiny that broke out last week aboard a destroyer.

Greece's military-backed Government declared that 35 navy officers would be tried, probably on treason charges, in the mutiny that broke out last week aboard a destroyer. The Government said that the episode was not merely a mutiny but a full-fledged attempt to overturn the leadership by blackmail.

A proposal calling for limited state linancing of governorship election campaigns in New Jersey, along with ceilings on the amounts private contributors could give and candidates could spend, has received a mixed reaction among the major candidates in the Republican and Democratic primaries for Governor.

In the year since President Nixon visited Peking, propaganda from the mainland has sough to influence the governing Chi nese Nationalists here and the Taiwanese people in the di reaction of accepting unification under the Chinese Communis Government.

"The function of the contemporary hero is to cancel the affirmations but to keep the setting of what once made him feel like a God." I found this one of the more interesting examples of Alfred Kazin's style in "Bright Book of Life."
Miloslav Rechigl, retired editor with Radio Free Europe and a Former member of the Czechoslovak parliament, died yesterday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 69 years old.

Every 93 minutes three men pass in the sky overhead on a route that takes them around the planet. Round and round they go, day and night. It is an astounding thing for men to be doing, but we are so inured to the daily occurrence of the astounds ing that we scarcely pause anymore to reflect how remarkable it is.

The Nixon Administration said yesterday that, despite its freeze on new Federal housing-subsidy commitments, it would consider applications to subsidize the extensive rehabilitation of 40 decaved Bronx tenements.
A group which hopes to gather all of the country's sportfishing interests in its embrace held an organizational meeting in the auditorium of the National Wildlife Federation in Washington, last week.

The city's Board of Higher Education convened in a special meeting last night to consider a protest resolution calling for the mass resignation of the 21member board, the annulment of the City University's budget request and, in effect, the transfer of City University's four-year colleges to the State University system.
The Skylab 1 astronauts reported today that their orbiting space station was "in excellent shape" and that they fully expected to complete their planned 28-day mission.
The forest-products industry suggested strongly last week that the time may be ripe for the nation's home builders to reduce prices. The home builders, in effect, replied "no chance."
Harry H. Greer Jr., a retired Navy captain who commanded the submarine that, mapped the Japanese minefields in Tokyo harbor during World War II, died Saturday at his home. He was 62 years old.

While almost a dozen writers of future books on the subject struggle to follow the incidents in the bizzare Watergate affair, a flood of games, records, trinkets and bumper stickers has already come from what started as "a third-rate burglary."

The most important pair championship in the New York tournament year was won over the weekend by one of the city's best-known mixed partnerships. Carol Krupp of Lawrence, L. I., and Paul Trent of New York won the Goldman Pairs at the Eastern Regional Championship, with Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N. J., in second position.
Steve Valdez, an apprentice and the No. 2 rider during the current Hollywood Park meeting, was suspended today for five days because of interference in a race yesterday.

An audit by State Controller Arthur Levitt has found that the city school system may have been overcharged as much as $6.3-million on its textbook purchase during the five-year period from 1967-68 through 1971-72.

The marriage of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and Sister Elizabeth McAlister was reported tonight by the Rev. Paul Mayer, a close friend. Father Mayer, a former Benedictine monk who is also married, said he had signed the certificate of marriage and that it had been mailed to the registrar's office in Montclair, N. J.

Followed by bad weather wherever they go, the Yankees lost a game to it yesterday when rain forced postponement of their game with Texas. It will be made up as part of a twilight-night double-header Aug. 7.

Topseeded Stan Smith struggled for. five sets in overcoming Erik Van Dillen in the $133,000 French open tennis championships tonight. Smith won by 6-2, 6-4, 6-7, 4-6, 6-1, and moved into the round of 16.

Although short of money, the four Democratic mayoral candidates plan extensive television advertising in the final week of the primary campaign to combat what their strategists believe is extraordinary voter apathy.
Pele scored the first two goals today and set up the third as he led Santos of Brazil to a 4-1 soccer victory over Lazio of Italy before an estimated crowd of 12,000 in Hanson Stadium.

Seventeen food-processing establishments in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx have failed a second health-code inspection, the Health Departnent has reported. Failure to pass a final inspection next month could result in closing orders.

A coalition of 25 national organizations, not all of them exclusively women's groups, is working out a master plan aimed at achieving ratification of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution by 1975.

Within the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, long the promoter of ever more atomic weapons, a changing of the guard is taking place that Could have far-reaching repercussions on the nuclear weapons program.

Blood tests that have been used in screening programs for sickle cell anemia have not detected all the abnormal blood traits that can be genetically transmitted and cause health problems, a report said today.
The United States Ambassador, Viron P. Vaky, denied today that the Central Intelligence Agency was harassing Robert L. Vesco and his associates in Costa Rica.
The New York Mets got their first look today at the "wonder team" of baseball, the San Francisco Giants, and the look cost them a 6-5 defeat for their fourth loss in a row.
The Skylab 1 astronauts, receiving their first news of world events since they blasted off last Friday from Cape Kennedy, asked today about the Indianapolis 500.
The annual Memodrial Day journey of college students to the Jersey Shore brought more than 100 arrests here and in North Wildwood over the weekend, mostly on drunkeness charges.

Mozart's operas resist the hand of the "inventive" stage director more than most, probably because Mozart not only knew what he wanted in terms of words and music, but also achieved it with a specificity that other composers rarely matched.

If there is one subject that has been studied, argued and microscopically analyzed for decades, it is the reform of American political campaign financing. White middle-class New Yorkers are continuing to move out of the city. If present trends continue, the blacks and Puerto Ricans together would constitute a majority here in about 12 years.

A 19-year-old Queens girl who was about to turn state's evidence against four co-defendants in a kidnapping case died yesterday of injuries suffered in a plunge from the roof of a six-story apartment house in Flushing Sunday night. President Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger will meet with Congresional leaders tomorrow to discuss foreign affairs developments--including the negotiations with North Vietnam to achieve stricter observance of the four-month-old cease-fire agreement.

Mrs. Marie Mealand, widow of Richard Mealand, novelist and motion picture executive, died Saturday in a nursing home here. Her age was 80.
Closing powerfully in the stretch, Favored Quack humbled five rivals today to capture the 20th running of the $110,300 Californian Stakes at Hollywood Park.

The renowned physicist and civilrights advocate Andrei D. Sakharov has denounced new action against the imprisoned dissident writer Andrei A. Amalrik as "an impermissible attempt against intellectual freedom," and a "threat of a new reprisal" against Mr. Amalrik.
The Manhattan District Attorney's office is looking into a shortage of just over $5,000 in the customer-service department of the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

Miss Margot Rose Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold R. Morris, was married here today to Michael Mikita, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mikita of Scarsdale, N. Y.
Ivan Trosch of Baltimore, vice president of the Maryland News Company, distributor of newspapers and magazines, died of a heart attack here yesterday while on a visit. His age was 58.
The San Diego Padres of the National League have been sold to a Washington syndicate for $12-million, heralding the return of major league baseball to the capital.
Iceland demanded today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization take immediate action to remove British warships from the 50-mile zone that she claims as her territorial waters.

It isn't exactly superstition on the part of Harry Gill. It's more like affection for a name. Gill's Idle Dice has been the most successful jumper in the horse show world for the last three years and has won more money than any other jumper in history.
Another American baby born with deficient bile ducts arrived here yesterday for treatment by a Japanese surgeon who has developed a special technique for correcting the defect.
The Illinois Attorney General said today he is starting criminal proceedings against the Equity Funding Life Insurance Company in connection with reports of massive fraud.
Anyone who went to Madison Square Garden for the circus over the holiday weekend paid more for a $2 program than an investor would pay for a share of the Garden's stock.

ZURICH, Switzerland Three simultaneous exhibitions here illustrate not only the creative upsurge of the years between the World Wars but also the troubles and shame of those same years and their consequences until 1945.

Eight terrorists arrested while laying land mines on bridges near the border with Iraq were executed today by a firing squad, the Government announced. It said that they were caught April 8, tried by a military court and confessed.
The Skylab 1 astronauts reported today that their orbiting space station was "in excellent shape" and that they fully expected to complete their planned 28-day mission.

Twelve spectators and four drivers were injured, one seriously, as an enormous ball of flame and a shower of debris from a 12-car accident stopped the Indianapolis 500 today an instant after it started.

William P. Wilder, an investment banker who hopes over the next few years to raise and then spend $5-billion for a naturalgas pipeline, is busily seeking support for the project through appearances from coast to coast.

After five years, Eli Lilly Co., has altered the thrust of its corporate advertising campaign. Since 1968 the theme of the advertising has been, in the words of Peter Geer, president of Lilly's agency, Geer, du Bois, "a small child in a big world."
The European Common Market bowed to demands by France today and toughened the language it will take into world trade talks with the United States later this year.

President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto has warned that if Pakistani prisoners of war go on trial in Bangladesh, similar tribunals will be held against Bengalis.
Spurred by Congressional pressures, major league base ball apparently will return to Washington next season after an absence of two seasons.
Hans SchmidtIsserstedt, the conductor, died today. He was 73 years old. Mr. Schmidt-Isserstedt was perhaps best known as chief of the Hamburg Radio Symphony Orchestra, which he assembled in 1945,

Stark County commemorated its war dead today and paid tribute to Sharon Lane, the first American servicewoman killed in Vietnam. Miss Lane was a 25-year-old first lieutenant in the Army Nurse Corps when she was fatally wounded at Chu Lai in June, 1969.
Representative Mario Biaggio found himself, unexpectedly, part of a memorable Memorial Day scene in Herald Square yesterday.

Antioch College, a symbol of academic liberalism for 120 years, is caught in a web of its own traditions as it struggles to resolve a student strike that has kept the school closed for 39 days.

Governor Cahill, in a statement intended to underscore his support of environmental protection for New Jersey's shoreline, today renewed his charge that Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. favored an oil port for supertankers in the northern part of the state and the New York Harbor area.
Hungarian Jews feel that it has become relatively easy to be Jewish in Hungary.

The Loyal Order of Moose has voted to amend its membership plicy, which has set qualification s based on race. The organization, meeting in Chicago for its 85th international convention, voted today to delete references to race from its constitution and by-laws.

Mrs. Susan Halpern and Stephen L. Cooperman were married here this morning at the Roslyn Country Club by Rabbi Abraham Feldbin. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Glanzberg of Bayside, Queens.

The International Commission of Control and Supervision ended its fourth month today with two of its members, Hungary and Poland, giving way on an issue that has deadlocked two previous commission meetings and brought a threat of a Canadian and Indonesian walkout.

President Nixon today named John R. Evans, 40, of Murray, Utah, for appointment of a new five-year term as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

On the mall next to City Hall, a sculpture by Alexander Calder, a 50-foot-high abstract rendering of the' stegosaurus in heavy steel plate, painted a brilliant orange-red color, has risen dramatically, much to the consternation of Mayor George A. Athanson.

Knockout victories by Albert Sandoval of Pomona, Calif., a flyweight, and Bob Stewart of Albany, N. Y., a light-heavyweight, paced the United States to a 6-3 victory over Canada in the fourth North American amateur boxing championships tonight at the Nassau Coliseum. It was the fourth straight victory for the United States in the series.
By their official statements the leaders of Libya and Egypt are committed to bringing about a full merger between their countries by Sept. 1, but the obstacles to real unity seem to be growing daily.

Pele scored the first two goals today and set up the third as he led Santos of Brazil to a 4-1 soccer victory over Lazio of Italy before an estimated crowd of 12,000 in Hanson Stadium.

The new Peronist Cabinet of Argentina today recognized the Cuban Government of Premier Fidel Castro.
All commodities futures advanced their maximum trading limits in light trading at the close today on the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange.

The San Diego Padres, running perhaps the most thrifty overhead operation in the National League, actually showed an operating profit estimated at $50,000 last year with an attendance of only 644.273.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka's Government, already weak, took another blow from the Opposition parties today as the Speaker of the lower house of Parliament was forced to resign.

St. Thomas Aquinas High School has one of the most ambitious baseball schedules in the state-40 games. It is quite an undertaking for a school that is only four years old and has its first senior class this season.

Gaudencio Thiago de Mello, composer-guitarist, left the Brazilian Amazon for New York in 1967, and has since built up a small but enthusiastic following for his special Brazilian-flavored jazz settings.

The Bank of Japan will raise its official discount rate early this week, Finance Minister Kiichi said today. Bank of Japan officials confirmed that such a move was being considered, but he declined to disclose details.

Rain driven in some places by high winds, and then drizzle, yesterday washed out parades and other Memorial Day events in the metropolitan area. The Argentine affiliate of the Ford Motor Company began paying money to children's hospitals today in response to an urban guerrilla threat of violence if. $1-million was not spent on welfare.

The Hanoi Hiltonthe ironic name captured American pilots gave their prison in North Vietnam-is gone. But if a group of architects and businessmen here have their way there will soon be a real, gleaming white Saigon Hilton Hotel, with 500 rooms.
Substantial increases in revenue and earnings were reported over the weekend in an interim yearend statement of Western Broadcasting Company, Ltd., for the fiscal year ended March 31.

To the Editor: As the Watergate and related disclosures continue to unfold, the commentators in the press have belabored the immorality inherent in such practices and the corruption of our democratic institutions which they represent.

Among the many memorable things that attended the winning of the Kentucky Derby by Citation in 1948 was the recollection of how brutally cold it was. I shivered on the roof alongside the television booth on a raw, intermittently rainy afternoon with the temperature plummeting to 42 degrees, lowest in the history of this mint julep classic. Not even a heart-warning performance by Citation could dispel the chill.

One unsolved puzzle that Watergate investigators are studying is the identity of intruders who broke into the offices and residences of Chilean diplomats in Washington and New York at least four times from April, 1971 to May, 1972.

John Bogan Sr., a sea captain who rescued a 67 people in the 1934 Morro Castle fire, died at his home here yesterday. He was 90 years old. Mr. Bogan was the operator a of his own six-vessel Paramont r Fishing Fleet at Bogan's Basin in Brielle.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers ended his 17day tour of Latin America and the Caribbean today after meetings with Jamaican officials.

President Nixon has done a good deal but, regrettably, not enough to dissipate the swirling fog of confusion he allowed to arise over the financing of his estate in San Clemente.
