In two books scheduled for publication this month, Prof. Morton Smith of Columbia University presents evidence that may alter understanding of the New Testament, of Christianity and of Jesus.
The Federal Government has spent more than $100,000 for improvements at President Nixon's San Clemente estate since he bought it four years ago, records have shown.
Mayor Sam Yorty and City Councilman Thomas Bradley ended their campaigns for the mayoralty today with last-minute charges and countercharges.

One of the last pieces of sculpture that Jacques Lipchitz was creating depicted a "Rebbe and His Hasidim." Rabbi Yudah Krinsky, a member of the executive staff of the Lubovitcher Movement, the worldwide Hasidic body, disclosed that Mr. Lipchitz had dedicated the work to Rabbi Menachem M. Schneeerson, the spiritual leader of the Lubovitcher movement.

A Pennsylvania woman was killed and two New York men injured when a tractortrailer struck an automobile near here on U. S. 22 Sunday night and plowed into a service station, causing an estimated $50,000 damage.

Edwin L. Andrew, who retired in 1959 as chairman of the Fuller Smith Ross, Inc., advertising agency, then of Cleveland but now of New York, died Saturday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 78 years old and lived at 3030 Park Avenue in Bridgeport.
A Federal grand jury investigating alleged irregularities in the financing of Governor Cahili's 1969 election campaign today indicted two corporations on charges of filing false income tax returns.

The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a criminal defendant adjudged too mentally ill to stand trial could not be committed to a New York State mental hospital operated by the Department of Correction unless a jury determined him to be "dangerous."

Today's activation of the Skylab solar telescopes marks the emergence of a new era in astronomy--one in which observations are made from above the atmosphere with manned instruments comparable in sophistication with those used on earth.

While much of the steam has gone out of the antibusing furor, the Legislature has placed New York in the company of diehard segregationists. It accomplished that feat of irresponsibility by voting for a resolution to call a Federal constitutional convention to seek an amendment to ban, as euphemism phrases it, the assignment of students on the basis of race.

Jack Nicklaus pulled ahead of Gary Player on the last three holes and finished with a one-under-par 70 today, winning the National Golf Day Round of Champions at the Canterbury Golf Club. Player carded a 72.

A new t list of contributors to Governor Cahill's re-election campaign made public today includes the name of E. Lawrence Bellante, the head of an engineering concern that was i indicted today on charges of Federal tax fraud involving concealed donations to-the Governor's 1969 election campaign.

Representative Mario Biaggi yesterday filed a $25,250,000 damage suit against The New York Post and two staff members over a Post headline in its issue of May 16 dealing with Mr. Biaggi's appearance before a special state grand jury.

The New York Mets broke a four-game slide tonight when they scored four runs in the ninth inning and defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-2. Tom Seaver pitched a threehitter for his fourth victory in a row, struck out 16 batters and even hit a home run.
The Government's composite index of leading indicators of the economy turned down in April for the first time since October, 1970, the Commerce Department reported today.
To some it was a lighthearted escapade providing a useful anecdote about the foibles of the Penn Central; to others it was a deeply frightening experience.

The Supreme Court broadened the power of law enforcement officials to search suspects and their property in decisions today on two criminal cases. Both decisions reflected a continuing trend on the Court toward majorities that favor the protection of society as a whole as against the rights of the accused.

It seems that almost everyone is into some sort of art or craft these days. If you Want to join the movement, don't let the fact that you don't know how to hold a crochet hook or operate a potter's wheel stand in your way.
The Ford Motor Company said today it had begun recalling 1,230 Ford and Mercury police interceptor cars that may have improperly fitted fuel hoses, which could cause fires under the hood.
After years of chasing the clock as his challenge and burden, Jim Ryun has finally learned how to win.
Two Manhattan patrolmen. were indicted for allegedly lying in connection with a Civil Court negligence suit about the details of a crash between their patrol car and another automobile.
Short-term interest rates surged again yesterday as the Federal Reserve's tighter credit policy continued to bear down on the economic boom.
Twelve houses were ruled uninhabitable by the police here today because of damage from a tornado--and possibly two --that slashed through this community last night.

Where is the price of gold going? Since the start of 1970 the official price has moved up from $35 an ounce to $42.22 as a result of two devaluations of the United States dollaralthough Congress has not yet ratified the second one of February, 1973.

INDISPENSABLE ENEMIES. The Politics of Misrule in America. By Walter Karp. 308 pages. Saturday Review Press. $8.95. It is a tempting notion that Walter Karp sets forth in "Indispensable Enemies: The Politics of Misrule in America."

Arvin Shaw 3d, a well-known architect who designed many office buildings in this city and elsewhere, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 150 East 65th Street until last fall, when he moved to Sagaponack, L.I.

Bjorn Borg, the 16-year-old Swede, conquered Dick Stockton, the United States Davis Cup playel, 6-7, 7-5, 6-2, 7-6, with another astonishing display in the $133,000 French open tennis championships today.

Stockholders of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway attending the annual meeting in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., yesterday were told that "assuming good business" continues through June that consolidated revenues of the system should cross the $500-million mark and net income should exceed $4 a share.

The story going around Washington is that when the name Robert Samuel Stone was mentioned a few weeks ago at the annual meeting of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences, few of those present could place him.

James F. Neal, an experienced prosecutor from Nashville, has joined the staff of the special Federal prosecutor in the Watergate case. According to informed sources, Mr. Neal has been assigned to master all the information that Government investigators have gathered up to now and to re. port to the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox.
Born six years ago out of the rubble and rhetoric of the riots of the nineteen-sixties, the National Urban Coalition will hold its first conference this week to assess its past and future.

Steve Vickers, New' York Ranger left wing, was named winner yesterday of the Calder Memorial Trophy as the National League's outstanding rookie for the 197273 season. He is the first Range to win the award since Camille Henry after the 1953-54 season.

A group of Kansas City businessmen have bought the Kansas City-Omaha Kings of the National Basketball Association, it was announced today. The purchase price was undisclosed. The Kansas City group is headed by Ray Evans, president of Traders National Bank, and H. Paul Rosenberg, president of Midland Lithographing Co. Evans was an all-America halfback at the University of Kansas.

Governor Cahill signed into law a bill authorizing a November referendum on a $25-million bond issue to provide facilities for the education of severely handicapped children. If approved by the voters, the bond issue would provide funds to be used for expansion of the Marie H. Katzenback School for the Deaf in Trenton and to construct five regional day-school centers for severely handicapped children. Mr. Cahill said:

The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the New York brokerage firm of Steindecker, Friedman Co. with fraudulent trading in 1968 and 1969 and barred it from doing business on the American Stock Exchange for 15 days beginning June 4.

Gen. Robert E. Cushman Jr., former deputy director of Central Intelligence, told a Los Angeles grand jury today that E. Howard Hunt Jr. had "violated" his "trust" by involving the C.I.A. in the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist.
The Environmental Protection Agency, seeking to ban the pesticides Aldrin and Dieldrin, charged today that they posed "a definite and considerable risk of cancer to man."

Dave Brubeck's attempt to retire from the life of the traveling performer at the end of 1967 after 17 steady years. on the road has proved to be a happy failure. He broke up his quartet then, intending to spend most of his time composing.

They met at the horse events at the Olympics in Mexico. They competed in jumping trials all over England. Their romance became the talk of the land. And tonight Buckingham Palace announced the engagement of the two young riders: Princess Anne and Lieut.
JAMES F. CLARITY

In his Bonn speech extolling East-West detente, Leonid I. Brezhnev spoke for growing openness in Moscow's global relations. "Our course," he said, "is not toward isolating our country from the outside world. On the contrary, we proceed from the fact that it will develop under conditions of growing cooperation with the outside world, and not only with socialist countries at that, but in considerable measure with the states of the opposite social system as well."
The Government, Which prommised an end to soaring food costs for the second half of the year, has become alarmed over the unabated surge in prices of soybeans, corn and wheat.

Rev. Daniel F. M. Millard, pastor since 1963 of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Maurice, died Sunday at his rectory. He was 50 years old. In World War II, Father Millard served in the Army Medical Corps.

The Texas Legislature last night designated Aug. 27--the birthday of Lyndon B. Johnson--as a state holiday. To avoid the cost of an extra day off for state employes, the Legislature combined two previously celebrated holidays into one.
Prime Minister Gough Whitlam said today that he would visit the United States this year even without the official invitation from President Nixon that has been awaited in vain till now.
The second postponement of the Indianapolis 500 today may have a back-up effect on the next race of the "United States Auto Club's championship circuit, the Rex Mays 150 next Sunday at Milwaukee.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that three of the city's major parks - Central Park in Manhattan, Prospect Park in Brooklyn and Forest Park in Queens - would be closed to motor vehicles from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Monday through Friday, beginning next Monday and continuing through September.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, who opened an inquiry last January into the legality of recent private sales of paintings by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said yesterday that his office had received a draft of the museum's "white paper" and had made suggestions concerning it to museum officials.
The Skylab 1 astronauts became solar astronomers today as they trained an array of telescopes to observe X-ray emissions and examine the structure of the sun's atmosphere.

THE BLACKS, a play by Jean Genet produced and directed by Robert Hooks setting by James Hooks; lighting by Jim Albert Hobbs, costumes by Quay Truitt; movement by Mike Malone; masks by Ed Love; makeup by Kenneth Daugherty; music by Clyde Jacques Barrett; production stage manager. D. S. Sutton. Presented by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts; associate producer, Robert Daughtry. At the Elsenhower Theater, Washington.
The school board in this predominantly Jewish community tonight rejected a plea for an investigation of why a so-called "Nzai youth song" had been scheduled for a recent junior high concert.

Dave DeBusschere, considered by many the key to the Knicks' two National Basketball Association championships, will quit as a player after one more season to become general manager of the Nets in the rival American Basketball Association.
Denis Du-For, a Broadway manager and producer, died of a stroke Monday evening at St. John's Hospital, Elmhurst, Queens. He was 81 years old and lived at 90-07 68th Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.
The Food and Drug Administration announced today the seizure of 90,000 Majzlin spring intrauterine devices and the recall of others because of possible harmful complication to users.
Alberto-Culver has found a way to overcome the con. flict problem at its ad agencies-become the first client of a brand new shop. And this is just what it has done, not once but twice.
The people who are tearing down one another's campaign posters this week - and who are denouncing one another in time for the 6 o'clock news all know one another.
Britain and Iceland exchanged angry words today in letters sent to the President of the Security Council over the fishing dispute between the two countries.
Plans for a major redesign of Union Square, develop by students at the Parsons School of Design, were unveiled yesterday and presented to public officials.
A Czechoslovak rack and field official was killed by the hammer of a young athlete during a meet at Pardubice near Prague, according to the Czechoslovak newspaper, Lidova Demokracie.
Hona Kabos, a well-known piano teacher who taught or coached many celebrated pianists, including Gina Bachauer, John Browning and Tamas Vasary, died in London on Sunday. Her age was 75.
Gov. Reubin Askew signed into law today a measure restoring the name Cape Canaveral to a geographical area of Florida that President Johnson renamed Cape Kennedy on Nov. 29, 1963.

Tens of thousands of homebound Penn Central commuters were stranded or delayed last night after a fire broke out in the engine of a train stalled under Park avenue at 76th Street, prompting a power shutdown that halted all service into and out of Grand Central Terminal.

A Book of the Sonnet: Poems and Criticism, edited by Martin Kallich, Jack C. Gray and Robert M. Rodney (Twayne, $6). And Then We Moved to Rossenarra, or the Art of Emigrating, by Richard Condon (Dial, $7.95). The author's 20 years of worldtrekking.

Night falls early in this city rimmed with snowstreaked mountains. In the bleak downtown quarter the only sounds are donkeys with carts clattering and sporadic rock music from the dozen flophouses and cheap restaurants that line the bazaar.

Compagnie de Saint-GobainPont-a-Mousson announced yesterday it was purchasing 2,3 million shares, or about 52 per cent of the approximately 4.4 million shares of the CertainTeed Products Corporation tendered to it during its recent tender offer.

A public offering of 1.6 million shares of Bond Shares of America, Inc. common stock at $15 a share was made yesterday by a group of underwriters headed by Loeb Rhoades Co. The minimum number of shares that may be purchased of the newly formed closed-end diversified management investment company was set at 60.

The House of Representatives approved today a bill ratifying February's 10 per cent dollar devaluation after defeating several amendments that would have set a specific date for allowing Americans to buy and sell gold.

The United States served notice today that it would block any efforts to push through the United Nations Security Council a new resolution on the Middle East that would differ from what was worked out to the satisfaction of the Israelis and Egyptians in November, 1967.

son of Robert L. Payton, president of C. W. Post College in Brookville, L. I., died yesterday of Hodgkin's disease at the Sloane-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research. His father was named president yesterday of Hofstra University in Hempstead, L. I.

President Nixon urged Japanese businessmen today to invest in the United States, saying that "throughout American history, investments from abroad have made important contributions to the growth of our economy."

The Texas Legislature has voted to reinstate the death penalty for murder under five specific conditions. The Legislature acted last night at its closing session in response to the June 29, 1972, ruling by the United States Supreme Court, which declared most state capital punishment laws unconstitutional.

ANTELL-Rose, devoted mother of Stanley, Claire and Judith. Beloved grandmother. Services at "Park West," 115 W. 79th St., Wednesday, May 30th at 1:30 P.M. ARONOWITZ-Louis, Suddenly May 28, 1973. Beloved brother of Max, Murray, Ida, Edna Lillian. Services Thursday, 9:30 A.M. at Schwartz Brotherrs "Forest Park Chapels", Queens Blvd. 76th Road, Forest Hills.

Six years ago in a book prophetically entitled "Famine 1975," William and Paul Paddock warned that world population growth was outstripping food production and that an international food crisis was probable by the middle of the decade.
Some Roman Catholic Churches in this area have been circulat. ing petitions calling for a financial boycott of Atlantic City Hospital because of its liberalized abortion policy.

Clive J. Davis, president of the CBS Records Group and the man responsible for changing the Columbia record label image from classical and show music to rock, was dismissed yesterday, and a civil suit was filed against him charging him with illegally spending almost $94,000 in corporate funds.

They met at the horse events at the Olympics in Mexico. They competed in jumping trials all over England. Their romance became the talk of the land. And tonight Buckingham Palace announced the engagement of the two young riders: Princess Anne and Lieut.

The Indianapolis 500 became the Twenty-Four Hours of Indianapolis today as rain forced a second postponement, and if this weather keeps up it may yet become the Twenty-Four Days of Indianapolis. Admission tickets to Indianapolis Motor Speedway have only two rainchecks, and after tomorrow there will be none left.

Phil Zofrea has been in the construction business for some time, but the one thing he always wanted to build was a college football team. Now that he has been appointed to head William Paterson's football program, his wish will perhaps come true.

John C. Shinn, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Labor for labormanagement relations, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in McLean, Va. he was 54 years old. Mr. Shinn, joined the Labor Department in 1940 as an interne in the Wage-House division at $1 a year.
The Canadian Government, maintaining that its cease-fire observers in Vietnam were not being permitted to do their job properly, announced today that it had decided to bring them home within 60 days.
J. N. Barnette, a divisional vice president for Latin America of Pan American World Airways, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home, 627 Nassau Avenue, Freeport, L. I. He was 57 years old.

The United States Supreme Court ruled today that New Jersey's , $19.5-million program of state aid to private and parochial schools could remain in effect While it decided a state appeal of a Federal Court decision that had struck down the program as unconstitutional.

The privately run National Safety Council has been understating the nation's actual number of disabling accidents and occupational injuries, Irving Bluestone, a United Auto Workers vice president, said today.

The Supreme Court broadened the power of law enforcement officials to search suspects and their property in decisions today on two criminal cases. Both decisions reflected a continuing trend on the Court toward majorities that favor the protection of society as a whole as against the rights of the accused.
The theory that husbands and wives cannot play bridge together effectively received a substantial setback Monday in the Eastern Regionals mixed team championship at the New York Hilton. Two.

Tens of thousands of homebound Penn Central commuters were stranded or delayed last night after a fire broke out in a train stalled under Park Avenue at 76th Street, prompting a power shutdown that halted all service into and out of Grand Central Terminal.
Albert Franklyn Howard, who retired in 1966 as vice president of Marsh Mc Lennan, Inc., international insurance brokers of New York, died today at his home here. His age was 72.
Robert L. Payton, who had resigned as the president of the C. W. Post College Center of Long Island University, effective Aug. 31, was named today as the new president of Hofstra University.
The Soviet Union has allowed a South Korean theatrical director to enter to attend an international conference in Moscow, it was reported here today.
PALM BEACH, Fla.-Women ditchdiggers, long a familiar sight in the Soviet Union and occasionally encountered in Israel during its formative years, are now being seen along South Ocean Boulevard.

Abbott Laboratories, Inc., and five of its present or former officers were indicted by a Federal grand jury today in a case involving the sale of allegedly contaminated intravenous fluids in 1970 and 1971.
Until a tornado hit Flanders, N. J., Monday night, only 25 had touched down in New Jersey and 49 in New York State in the last 20 years.
Newspapers here, with unusual unanimity, said today that the immediate consequence of the Greek naval mutiny of last week would be the early abolition of the monarchy, by decree not by a referendum.
Eight Civil Court judges will be elected in the city this year and there are primary contests to be decided June 4 for four of these positions.
William O. Wooldridge, once the Army's top-ranked enlisted man, was given five year's probation today on a bribery charge. He was also ordered to

Japan today raised her official discount rate from 5 to 5.5 per cent. The new rate will go into effect tomorrow.

Representatives of striking mechanics and Ozark Air Lines are to meet tomorrow in Washington before the National Mediation Board in a new effort to end a 41-day-old strike that has paralyzed Ozark operations in 62 cities.

The Walter E. Heller International Corporation and the American National Corporation said yesterday that a formal agreement merging American National into Heller would be submitted to directors of both concerns on June 15.

The Cambodian High Command said today that Government troops with intense United States air support had broken a two-month rebel stranglehold on Route 5 that cut off Phnom Penh from the rice provinces in the west.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. excused himself briefly from the Watergate hearings one day last week to go off on what the audience presumed was an important mission. It turned out he had to meet with a delegation of constituents representing junior colleges in his home state of North Carolina.
BERLIN -- When Leonid I. ??ezhnev came here for a it in mid-May, officials of the East German Communist party marshaled thousands of young people to pay him a ?? welcome.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan announced the indictment yesterday of two policemen on charges that they had lied about a crash between their patrol car and another automobile.

Carl B. Molander, who retired as sales director of United Press International in 1967 after 45 years with the wire service, died apparently of a heart attack, on Monday at Elmhurst (Queens) General Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 34-50 80th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, and on Shelter Island, N. Y.
Impeachment Is not the only remedy provided by the Constitution where the integrity and conduct of the Chief Executive or his ability to govern, may be called into question.
Harold (Fats) Wicsman, the agent who decides which horses Jacinto Vasquez rides, doesn't believe in hedging his predictions with uncertainty.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association bent just enough last week from its usual rigid policy of rules enforcement to permit Fred Samara of Pennsylvania and Dennis Walker of Adelphi to compete in the I.C.4-A. track and field championships.
The Supreme Court ruled today that radio and television stations have an absolute right to refuse to sell time for advertisements dealing with political campaigns or controversial public issues.

The Legislature has, in effect, given the city's interim Board of Education a vote of confidence. This is clearly the intent of the overwhelming support in Albany for establishment of a permanent New York City board in 1974 differing very little from the present one, which was originally created to preside over the transition to decentralization.
A growth in a back yard garden turned white today and appeared to be dying. Mrs. Marie Harris of suburban Garland called the growth a "blob" and said it was the fourth to show up in her yard.

President Nixon will not testify, either orally or in writing, to either the grand jury or the Senate committee investigating the Watergate case, the White House said today. "We feel it would be contitutionally inappropriate," said the Presidential press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, in response to questions at a news briefing. "It would do violence to the separation of powers."
The price of gold remained firm at near-record highs and the dollar lost value in European money exchange markets today.
cluttering many front yards in the residential neighborhood behind the United States Capitol are piles of broken bricks, crumbled plaster and rotted two-by-fours.

Huang Chen, one of China's most seasoned diplomats, arrived today to open his Government's liaison office and declared that the detour in friendly relations between the Chinese and American peoples had ended.

In Quito, the Cookie Monster gobbles tacos. Big Bird is Bibo in Hamburg and Garibaldo in Sao Paulo. In Latin America, Oscar the Grouch has left his garbage can to become Paco, the opinionated parrot, in Mexico City, and Gugu, a cantankerous (but good-hearted) junk collector in Rio de Janeiro.

The Rev. Don Emerson Hall who retired April 30 after 15 years as director of the United Presbyterian Foundation, died Sunday in Denver, where he and his wife, Mrs. Mildred Lilyquist Hall, had been visiting friends. He was 66 years old.
Steel production for the week ended May 26 eased, but total output of 3,010,000 tons was the second highest in the industry's history, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
State Senator Ralph C. DeRose declared today that Brendan T. Byrne, his main rival for the' Democratic gubernatorial nomination, had a "do-little" record as a Prosecutor in Essex County.

The White House has reacted strongly to a report in The Washington Post that the Watergate prosecutors have told the Justice Department that there is justification for calling President Nixon to answer questions before the District of Columbia grand jury which is investigating the case. Mr. Nixon, according to his press spokesman, would not consider appearing before the grand jury under any circumstances and would not even answer written questions.

William M. Fine, who resigned last week as president of the Bonwit Teller specialty-store chain, has been named to the new post of president of the Wamsutta Domestics division of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., a leading textiles and textile-products manufacturer, effective July 15.

Steve Ferrar, a St. John's junior, upset second-seeded Barry Lazar of City College, 1-6, 6-4, 6-3 en route to the quarterfinals of the Metropolitan College Tennis Conference championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

Broad in its sweeping movement and cushioned in the sound of a dozen old nostalgic songs, Don Redlich's "Everybody's Doin' It" has the exuberance of a street festival. And as part of the City Center's Spring Dance Festival, it was seen Friday evening near the Lincoln Center fountain.
Construction contracts in April totaled $8,814,128,000 up from $8,212,059 in April of 1972, it was reported yesterday by the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw Information Systems Company.

Wearing a black and white striped suit with matching cap and a blue turtleneck sweater, Ernie DiGregorio, the flashy former guard at Providence College; finally showed up to meet the Buffalo press yesterday at the fourth news conference called to announce his reported $1-million dollar contract with the N.B.A.'s
On what would have been President dent Kennedy's 56th birthday, the Kennedy family today unveiled the long-awaited, long-delayed plan for the John F. Kennedy Library.

Dr. Harry R. Litchfield, senior pediatrician at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home, 870 Fifth Avenue. He was 73 years old. Dr. Litchfield was a former instructor and lecturer

Elected officials from the New York suburbs met with Mayor Lindsay yesterday to discuss his plan for regional financing of mass transit and then flatly rejected a key feature of his plan, a regional payroll tax. "It would be political suicide for us," said Ralph G. Caso, Nassau County Executive.

An Air Force colonel has charged five Army and three Marine Corps enlisted men with misconduct while they were all held as prisoners of war in a North Vietnamese prison camp near Hanoi, the Defense Department announced today.

Opponents of the United States bombing of Cambodia won a key procedural test on the Senate floor today in their effort to cut off funds for the air war. There were indications, however, that the Nixon Administration's supporters in the Senate were prepared to filibuster against the cutoff of bombing, at least for a few days.

The Canadian Government, maintaining that its cease-fire observers in Vietnam were not being permitted to do their job properly, announced that it had decided to bring them home within 60 days. "We have come to the conclusion that our concept of the role we are supposed to play there is just not being accepted by the other parties involved," explained Mitchell W. Sharp, Secretary of State for External Affairs. [Page 1, Column 8.]

Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and her daughter, Mrs. David Eisenhower, will attend the funeral tomorrow in Greenwich, Conn., of J. Clifford Dietrich, the Secret Service agent who was killed in a crash of a Presidential helicopter in the Bahamas Saturday.

Budget of $8.77-billion for operations of government for the fiscal year that began April 1 and a supplemental budget of $85-million for items unanticipated when budget was prepared. The Legislature had trimmed $110-million from the Governor's original proposal.

E. Howard Hunt Jr., a Watergate conspirator and a former Central Intelligence agent who helped plan the abortive 1961 invasion of Cuba, has said he recommended to his superiors that Fidel Castro be assassinated as part of the plot.
Higher costs for automation and other projects - coupled with the effects of lower trading volume-resulted in a firstquarter loss of $107,000, the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday.
The Canadian Government, maintaining that its cease-fire observers in Vietnam were not being permitted to do their job properly, announced today that it had decided to bring them home within 60 days.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that three of the city's major parks -- Central Park in Manhattan, Prospect Park in Brooklyn and Forest Park in Queens -- would be closed to motor vehicles from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

To the Editor: We are living a sad hour of American history. Those of us who, being through our profession in touch with citizens of other countries, had for years supported the claims of American democracy to serve as a model for the rest of the world, have reason to be dejected.

Orlando Cepeda, rescued from baseball's scrap heap by the designated-hitter rule in force in the American League this season, won another game for the Boston Red Sox last night. Cepeda, bothered by bad knees during most of his National League career, hit a two-run homer off California's Nolan Ryan in the second inning that provided the Red Sox with a 2-1 victory.
The Soviet Union ran such a large deficit last year in trade with the West that it produced a deficit in Moscow's total world trade for the first time since World War II.

Three major companies in the consumer goods field, the Rapid-American. Corporation, the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, and J. P. Stevens, Inc., reported yesterday substantial gains in sales and earnings for their latest fiscal quarter.
One of Wall Street's leading economists launched a blistering attack yesterday on the Nixon Administration's management of the national economy.

Mrs. Caroline Randolph Chapman, for 60 years a psychic medium often mentioned in literature on the subject, died Monday of a stroke in Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. She was 92 years old and lived at 155 East 34th Street.
A Philippine army field commander said today that a naval blockade had cut down foreign assistance to insurgents in the central Mindanao region and restored relative stability to the area.

Because James Frazier, the American conductor who won the Guido Cantelli International Competition at La Scala in 1969 was a success at Royal Festival Hall in London last month with the New Philharmonic Orchestra, he'll be going to Spain next fall for conducting and television debuts.

The new 40-cent-a-bushel daily trading limit on soybeans effective yesterday failed to curb speculative buying. Traders pushed prices up the Limit In all delivery months. Adverse weather in the Midwest growing areas was a major factor.
Mayor Lindsay. announced yesterday a program to save housing in transitional neighborhoods where blight has entered its first stages.

Opponents of the United States bombing of Cambodia won a key procedural test on the Senate floor today in their effort to cut off funds for the air war. There were indications, however, that the Nixon Administration's supporters in the Senate were prepared to filibuster against the cutoff of bombing, at least for a few days.
Henry A. Kissinger said today that he expected to conclude "new understandings" with Hanoi next week to strengthen the Vietnam cease-fire agreement.

Minutes before the Legislature adjourned last evening, the Democratic and Republican leaders indulged in their annual display of self congratulation and praised themselves for their independence and legislative achievements.

Jacques Lipchitz, the expressionist sculptor, was buried in Jerusalem today. He died in Capri Saturday, and his body was flown to Israel for burial in a cemetery plot he had bought during a visit to Jerusalem.

STAR TREK There's an air of show biz that hovers over Catch a Rising Star, a night spot at 1487 First Avenue, near 78th Street (RE 4-9777), right from the euphoric name down to the photos on the wall and the sign that hopefully proclaims "Broadway" over the tables. The place attracts a young crowd and is a fairly cheerful looking establishment.
President Nguyen Van Thieu today indicated for the first time that he was concerned that the Watergate scandal might have affected American policy toward South Vietnam.
Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, the prominent advocate of black capitalism, has been indicted on two further counts of grand larceny, Queens District Attorney Michael F. Armstrong announced yesterday.

The White House has turned down the petitions of four Kent State University students who sought a Federal grand jury to further investigate the shooting deaths of four Kent State students in 1970 antiwar demonstrations.
Housing Patrolmen John Sepe and Louis Telano, the plainclothes anticrime team that has become history on the streets of Brooklyn as the Lone Ranger and Tonto, will be promoted to detectives today.

The arrival of Memorial Day is the traditional signal for New York's first open-air concerts of the summer. Although Monday's cold, rainy weather early in the day forced the Harlem Philharmonic to cancel its afternoon concert in Damrosch Park, the skies cleared by evening and the 68th annual Naumburg series began as scheduled on Central Park's chilly but dry Mall.

James F. Neal, an experienced prosecutor from Nashville, has joined the staff of the special Federal prosecutor in the Watergate case. According to informed sources, Mr. Neal has been assigned to master all the information that Government investigators have gathered up to now and to report to the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox.
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday while the over-the-counter market ended slightly lower in much slower trading.

A pair of New York sires stakes will be raced at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night. The contests are for 4-year-old trotters bred in New York. Six mares will meet in the $7,325 opener and nine horses and geldings will battle for an $8,000 purse immediately afterward.

An Air Force colonel has charged five Army and three Marine Corps enlisted men with misconduct while they were all held as prisoners of war in a North Vietnamese prison camp near Hanoi, the Defense Department announced today.
Test crashes of six 1973-model automobiles have demonstrated deficiencies in fuel tank design that "needlessly" expose occupants to fire, a Congressional hearing was told today.

Declined to review a decision that permitted three mining companies to attach Chilean copper mining property in an effort to recover a $12-million debt, despite claims by the Chilean Government that industry, had been nationalized and thus enjoyed sovereign immunity.

Vesco without knowing him very well. In fact, he said in a fourhour interview last weekend it his country home near here, they are still not personally close.

"No Gas" signs that went up more than usual over the holiday weekend added frustration and bitterness to the oftenangry debate over the reason for the nation's gasoline shortages. One of the issues is whether the shortages are real or manufactured.
Premier Kakuei Tanaka's shaky Government was stunned again today when a second senior official in two days was forced to resign under pressure from the leftist Opposition parties.

WASHINGTON - When the White House receives a request these days for a Presidential aide to turn out for a public forum to discuss the Watergate case, it is not unusual that the only one with nerve enough to make the appearance is a Southern woman named Anne Legendre Armstrong.

President Nixon declared Alabama and Arkansas major disaster areas today because of weekend tornadoes and the White House promised similar action would be taken soon for other states hit hard by the storms.

Until a tornado hit Flanders, N.J., Monday night, only 25 had touched down in New Jersey and 49 in New York State in the last 20 years.
The stock market settled back yesterday in slow trading and consolidated last week's sharp gains.
The new Commander in Chief of Argentina's army pledged his support of the new Peronist Government today, but asserted that it would have to abide by the Constitution.

The 11month-old centrist coalition Government of Premier Giulio Andreotti lost its narrow majority in Parliament late last night when a small party that had supported it announced that it could no longer do so.

A 10-year-old boy was fatally shot in the forehead with a .38caliber revolver here yesterday in what the police believe may have been a game of Russian roulette. Three teen-agers, including one youth who said he had seen the victim place the gun to his head, were being questioned.
A Federal grand jury investigating alleged irregularities in the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign today indicted two corporations on charges of filing false income tax returns.

Ernest H. Schroeder, a vice president of Reichold Chemicals, Inc., in White Plains, died at his home here yesterday. He was 57 years old. Mr. Schroeder, who had been a member of the company since 1956, was in charge of the Eastern region.

LONDON-English newspapers correctly assess this country's brief sensation involving politicians and call girls as about like a dirty postcard compared to the exploding letter-bomb of America's Watergate.

The New York Stock Exchange decided late yesterday not to come to the rescue of the customers of Weis Securities, the brokerage firm charged with fraud last week. Instead, it left the problem to the courts and the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.
The Government's composite index of leading indicators of the economy turned down in April for the first time since October, 1970, the Commerce Department reported today.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association bent just enough last week from its usual rigid policy of rules enforcement to permit Fred Samara of Pennsylvania and Dennis Walker of Adelphi to compete in the I.C.4-A. track and field championships.

On the eve of President Nixon's departure for a conference with President Pompidou of France, Henry A. Kissinger said today that the Administration still hoped for a new Atlantic charter in some form.
Henry A. Kissinger said today that he expected to conclude "new understandings" with Hanoi next week to strengthen the Vietnam cease-fire

In a display reminiscent of the days when such lusty hitters as Ruth, Gehrig, Lazzeri and Dickey were making the Bronx Bombers a feared name, the Yakees clouted four home runs last night in defeating the Oakland A's, 7-1, at Yankee Stadium.

A new list of contributors to Governor Cahill's re-election campaign made public today includes the name of E. Lawrence Bellante, the head of an engineering concern that was indicted today on charges of Federal tax fraud involving concealed donations to the Governor's 1969 election campaign.
Controller Abraham D. Beame said he would "demand" a special session of the Legislature to save the 35-cent fare on the city's transit system.

Robert M. Lichtenberg, an economic analyst for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died Monday night in Memorial- Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 51 years old and lived at 165-17 33d Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

One of the mysteries around the White House these days is why Ron Ziegler remains as the President's spokesman rather than being called to testify before the grand jury and the Ervin Committee on the Watergate case.

The first of a projected series of live, closed-circuit telecasts of New York stage productions over pay and cable television facilities will be "Antiques," a new musical revue written by Alan Greene and Laura Manning, with special material by Dore Schary.

A plague of locusts in the Sudan, an infestation of trees at the mouth of the Rio Grande and a chain of restless Central American volcanoes are typical targets of the Skylab earth-scanning that began today.

Meshulam Riklis, chairman of the Rapid-American Corporation, using the word "very" six times in one sentence to describe how "well" his company was faring, told shareholders here yesterday that earnings for the consumergoods conglomerate would rise at least 25 per cent in the current fiscal year.
The missing $10,000 check from Nebraska Republicans the Committee for the Re-Elec tion of the President was probably never written, party offcials said yesterday.
The disintegration of the water-supply system for the homes of 124 families in the Post Brook Farms development near here has forced them to improvise.

The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday that it would limit the amount of gasoline it will sell its service stations, starting tomorrow. Texaco said it would ration drivers to 10 gallons at its stations on toll roads, the Associated Press reported.

The wife and a son of the director of the state crime laboratory died today when a blast damaged their home on Normandy Street. The state police and local authorities declined all comment on the explosion.

Directors of the Canteen Corporation approved yesterday a previously announced agreement to merge Canteen with a subsidiary of Trans World Airlines, Inc.

The assistant air attache at the Soviet Embassy in Paris, Lieut. Col. Yevgeny N. Mironkin, was arrested by the French police on charges of trying to steal an item on exhibit at the Paris air show, the police reported today.
A policeman's memory has led to the removal of a State Supreme Court grand jury foreman and may result in nullification of 39 indictments handed down in Albany County in recent weeks.

With the Democratic mayoral primary only four days away, three of the four candidates were scheduled to produce last-minute television and radio commercials yesterday and even today as funds for production costs and air time became available.

Low - cost flight - insurance policies, quietly removed from all airports in New York State nine months ago, will be of fered once again beginning tomorrow, state insurance regu lators said here yesterday. The industry closed down the machines last Labor Day after it refused to accept a state order to charge less for the insurance or raise the benefits.
Georgia Southern scored three runs in the fourth inning yesterday and defeated Miami (Fla.), 4-1, for the National Collegiate District 3 he baseball championship.

The new Peronist Government today took control of national universities in Argentina by appointing special trustees who will have ultimate power in all administrative and ideological questions on those campuses.

From an orbit 270 miles ,high over the western part of the United States, the Skylab 1 astronauts began today a survey of the earth that should expand man's understanding of his mineral resources, crops and forests, pollution and weather.
Nineteen schoolchildren on class outings were injured here today, none of them seriously, in an accident on the roller coaster at Bertrand's Island Amusement Park.
Voltaire Volly DeFaut, jazz clarinetist was found dead yesterday in his house trailer in South Chicago Heights. He was 69 years old.

Dave DeBusschere's appointment as general manager of the New York Nets, effective June 1, 1974, with a 10-year contract for an estimated annual salary of $75,000, was confirmed yesterday but he foresaw no conflict of interest during his final season with the New York Knicks.
Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, today urged Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. either to quit the Army or to resign as President Nixon's top assistant.

With two on and two out in the first inning last night, Thurman Munson hit a drive to right field that Reggie Jackson snared before it reached the stands. "I was teed off; I thought it was a home run. I was mad, Munson said.

A dozen national religious, civil liberties and women's organizations joined today to ask the House of Representatives to reject an amendment restricting the availability of abortions.
Three men have been charged in the murder of a 69year-old widow who disappeared after an auto accident on April 20, the state police said today.

For the second time in a week, a legal challenge has been filed against the legal and regulatory barriers currently being erected by many Southern states against the entry of out-of-state financial institutions.
Three poets in search of an audience arrived in City Hall Park yesterday for a scheduled lunch-hour reading of their works but found the local "people's culture park" seriously overbooked.
President Nixon, on the first foreign journey of his second term, met tonight with the leaders of Iceland's Government.

The Organization of African Unity has survived the bitterest internal squabbles of its 10-year history, brought on when delegates forced the explosive issues of the EthiopianSomali border dispute and the African nations' relations with Israel.
Connecticut will replace all automatic toll machines with people next month, Transportation Commissioner A. Earl Wood said today.

Nassau County signed a contract today to take over all 10 private bus companies in the county effort to improve service for the 75,000 daily riders. The county will become the new owner at 12:01 A.M. Sunday.
" I don't want to damage anyone's candidacy by wrapping my arms around him," Mayor Lindsay said yesterday in what he described as "teasing a little bit."

" Yin Yang" is the title of a new musical by Joseph A. Walker, author of "The River Niger." The work was written for Mr. Walker's company, The Demigods, and is being presented this week as part of the Negro Ensemble Company's series of special events.

A too-vigorous charge at home plate, a beanball pitch or two, a near free-for-all, a game-winning home run and a game-saving catch-all that marked Boston's second straight victory over California, 2-1, in Fenway Park last night.

The National Football League Players Association asked the Government today to prohibit the installation of synthetic turf until safety regulations were devised, Ed Garvey, exectuive director, said the club owners had "refused to cooperate in a moratorium" on artificial turf. He told the Consumer Product Safety Commission that players "are concerned not only about their own careers being shortened, but also for thousands of high school and college athletes."

The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission in Lyndhurst, N. J., unanimously passed a resolution that would ban the dumping of solid waste from out of state. About 10,000 tons of non-New Jersey garbage, most of it from New York City, are now dumped on the 20,000-acre Meadowlands every week. A public hearing on the proposed ban, which would take effect Aug. 1, will be held June 18, starting at 10 A.M. in Kearny.

South Vietnam's foreignexchange reserves are plummeting and both American and South Vietnamese economists are worried. Prices have leaped dangerously high, heavy unemployment persists and the plaster has been steadily declining in value, but so far the Government has taken few corrective steps.

The New York Mets found trouble from coast to coast today. In New York, they lost Cleon Jones for at least a month. And here in San Francisco, they lost a 3-2 decision to the Giants and also lost their second straight series in California.
The Federal Trade Commission accused 26 chemical companies today of falsely advertising flammable plastics as nonflammable or self-extinguishing.

A new strain of influenza virus against which Americans have little or no immunity has been identified in Hong Kong, Australia and Birmingham, England, according to a report from the National Center for Disease Control.
Mira Luy, an antipoverty assistant, crouched in the middle of the office floor and spoonfed milk and honey to Jana, a lethargic 76-pound Rottweiler puppy.

The General Accounting Office referred to the Attorney General today a report alleging that four Wisconsin newspapers violated the Federal election law.

The West German Government announced today an increase of a full percentage point in its official lending rates. In reaction, the United States dollar weakened in money markets across Europe, and the price of gold hit new highs.
Weis Securities, Inc., the brokerage firm cast adrift by the New York Stock Exchange late Tuesday, will be liquidated by the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

The Nixon Administration is quietly dismantling the Intelligence Evaluation Committee, the super-secret. body created by President Nixon in an attempt to strengthen relations among the Federal Government's intelligence-gathering agencies, Justice Department officials said today.
A group of students trying to reopen the strike-torn Antioch College won today a preliminary injunction that bars striking students from barricading campus buildings.

Bombing raids by B-52 bombers over Cambodia have been cut nearly in half in the last few days, according to sources at the Pentagon.

The historic Reisinger Team Championship, which dates to 1930 and has been won at various times by most of America's greatest players, is being played this week at the New York Hilton Hotel.

The stock market declined sharply again yesterday. The Dow-Jones industrial average plunged 16.70 points, its third largest drop this year, and closed at 908.87. The selling apparently came in response to renewed pressure on the dollar in European currency markets.

Libya accused the United States today of a series of military actions in an effort "to provoke a confrontation in which the Libyan Arab Republic has no alternative but to defend its sovereignty, security and safety."

George Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" is so much a part of our pop culture that it seems to have been with us always. Because it retains a contemporaneity, it is also hrd to believe that it will be 30 years old next year. It was played in the GershwinTchaikovsky Promenade on Tuesday night by the New York Philharmonic, with Agustin Anievas as pianist.

A prominent member of Yemen's Government was assassinated in front of his home in the southern town of Taiz early today, according to an official announcement on the Government-controlled radio in Sana.

A secondary offering of 300,000 common shares of the Otter Tail Power Company at $20 per share was oversubscribed yesterday according to Paine, Webber, manager of the underwriting group. The company's stock, traded on the over-thecounter market, closed at 193/4 bid, 201/4 asked, up 1/8.

Fyodor N. Petrov, one of the oldest Russian revolutionaries, an early Soviet science administrator and an encyclopedia editor, died here on Monday. He was 96 years old.
The Seoul district criminal court handed down prison terms to three former opposition members of the National Assembly today after finding them guilty of extortion and bribery.

Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia, who has said he intends to visit Washington without benefit of an invitation from the White House, seemed to be offering President Nixon advice that may or may not be welcome.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and tehe over-the counter market dropped sharply yesterday in continued slow trading.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, promised business today that no changes would be made in either the investment credit or the tax treatment of depreciation.
Thomas Bradley said today that his election as the first black Mayor of Los Angeles could help open a "new thrust" of black leadership into electoral politics.
The Mount Sinai School of Medicine here was named yesterday as the site of the nation's seventh environmental health sciences research center.

Linda's Chief exhibited his front-running capability to perfection in the Withers Mile at Belmont Park yesterday. Neil Hellman's Florida-bred colt broke last in the field of six but under the guidance of Jorge Velasquez flashed into the lead in short order and stayed there to win by three lengths.
Short - term interest rates soared again yesterday as the money market continued to reflect strong demands for credit at a time when the Federal Reserve has become much stingier in supplying it.
Carmine Tramunti, the reputed boss of one of New York's five Mafia "families," was found guilty in State Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday of three counts of criminal contempt.
The first envoy to represent Communist China in the capital of the United States met for 25 minutes with President Nixon in the White House today.
Today, hundreds of thousands of Americans stricken by multiple sclerosis need help.

American spotter planes and fighter-bombers helped conduct a convoy of 10 barges and empty fuel tankers safely down the Mekong River to the Vietnamese border today, naval sources said. The United States warplanes flew cover after the convoy came under fire.

A 74-year - old woman was killed and a 69-year-old man was critically injured in an explosion just before midnight last night in the woman's thirdfloor walkup apartment at 504 East 12th Street near Avenue A in the East Village.

The missing $10,000 check from Nebraska Republicans to the Committee for the Re-Election of the President was probably never written, party officials said yesterday. .

John B. Connaily, a possible Presidential contender who recently switched from the Democratic to the Republican party, trailed Senator Edward M. Kennedy by 14 percentage points, 50 to 36, in a recent trial heat of the 1976 Presidential election, the Gallup poll reported yesterday.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today said First Home Investment of Kansas, Inc., a Wichita concern, has filed for bankruptcy and will undergo reorganization.

Thirty years ago the Marshall Chess Club, at 23 West 10th Street, was enemy territory. Tragedy struck the 1973 Indianapolis 500 again today as a pit-crew mechanic was killed and a race driver was critically injured in related accidents at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.
Arthur Ashe played tennis in the rain for six minutes today and made sure of his place in the fourth round of the men's singles at the $133,000 French open championships.
The Federal Government acknowledged yesterday that it overheard a prominent radical lawyer 23 times from 1955 to 1970 on national security wiretaps apparently made without court consent.

Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. today urged a halt in work on the Hackensack Meadows sports center and a "freeze" on further development of the vast Meadowlands area "until we know where the money is coming from and what is going on."
Norway and Brazil are among nations under consideration to replace Canada on the fournation cease-fire commission in Vietnam, a Nixon Administration official said today.

Gary Trudeau, author of the "Doonesbury" cartoon strip, has been "burned," as he puts it, by the Watergate scandal. Mitchell.
The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission passed a resolution today that would ban the dumping of solid waste from outside the state.
Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan has pledged to help women expand their opportunities in occupations not now open to them.

The Federal National Mortage Association today auctioned $140-million of fourmonth Federal Housing Administration-Veterans Administration mortgage commitments and $74-million of four-month conventional mortgage pledges at record yields.

In another West German step toward reconciliation with Eastern Europe, negotiations were corn pleted with Czechoslovakia today on a treaty to establish normal relations, ending 35 years of hostility.

Jack Nicklaus considers next week's pro golf tour site, the Whitemarsh Valley course outside Philadelphia, similar to the Oakmont (Pa.) Country Club, where the United States Open will be played starting June 14, But Arnold Palmer disagrees.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference will trim the field for its December Holiday Festival basketball tournament from eight teams to four in 1976 because the competing colleges are not earning enough money at the annual Madison Square Garden event.

Japanese acceptance of Australian demands for raising the dollar amounts of iron-ore contracts is viewed here as the first victory for Prime Minister Gough Whitlam in pursuing his new "resources diplomacy."

Negotiations between the Writers Guild of America and the Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which collapsed in mid-May, will resume Saturday, at the invitation of the association.
Naomi Sims, the fashion model, has a small, elegant head set on a remarkable length of body, huge black eyes and skin the color of rich, espresso coffee.
Gov. Thomas J. Meskill and other rescue workers aboard a helicopter found an 8-year-old retarded boy in a swamp today, more than 24 hours after he wandered from his rural home.

The chairman of a House Post Office subcommittee, Representative Charles H. Wilson, Democrat of California, asked for an investigation today into reports that the mail of two Democratic Presidential candidates was illegally opened.

The airline industry said today that there was no immediate threat of a fuel shortage that would ground any of the nation's 2,326 airliners. "The industry has no fuel crisis," said Stuart G. Tipton, chairman of the Air Transport Association, a trade organization representing the major airlines.

About 1.5 million aged blind and disabled welfare recipients will lose eligibility for food stamps, and up to 150,000 other persons may no longer receive Medicaid benefits when a new Federal guaranteed income plan takes effect next Jan. 1, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

New York's World Hockey Association team officially changed its name from Raidars to Golden Blades yesterday, then announced a trade involving the league's top two scorers, Andre Lacroix and Ron Ward.

By a vote of 2-1, the Federal Power Commission approved today three long-term contracts for the sale of offshore Louisiana natural gas at a wellhead price 73 per cent higher than. the ceiling price for that area set by the agency just two years ago.
Anthony Salerno, who is reported to be one of the most powerful Mafia figures in the metropolitan area, was indicted yesterday on charges involving a multimillion-dollar loanshark ring.
Johann, Strauss's "Fledermaus" and Puccini's "Tosca" will be brought to New York parks this summer by the Metropolitan Opera in its seventh season of free opera concerts in the city's five boroughs.

A resolution commending The New York Times "for its defense of freedom 'of the press against the threats of the People's Republic of China" was introduced today in the House by Representative Edward .J. Derwinski, Republican of Illinois.

Robert L. Vesco, the financier under Federal indictment in the United States, issued a statement today in which he essentially dissociated himself from remarks made Sunday by his friend and former business associate, Norman P. LeBlanc.

Ajax of Amsterdam scored a 1-0 soccer victory over Juventus of Turin, Italy, today and won the European Cup Mi for the third straight year. Ajax's outside right, John Rep, took a centered ball from Horst Blankenburg in the fifth minute and headed the ball into the upper left corner of the net for the only goal.

Mrs. Richard Nixon and her daughter, Mrs. David Eisenhower, came to Greenwich today to attend a funeral service for J. Clifford Dietrich, a Secret Service agent who had helped guard the Nixon family.

CEDAR GROVE, May 30-This tiny community in northern Essex County has a rich pole-vaulting tradition, With only 310 boys in the upper three grades of the 10-year-old high school, Cedar Grove has continually produced some of the state's outstanding vaulters since 1964. The last four county record-holders have been from Cedar Grove and the latest, Mike Remus, appears ready to set the state record and become the state's first 15-foot schoolboy vaulter.

Gordie Howe, 45-year-old retired hockey superstar, said yesterday he planned to meet with officials of the World Hockey Association's Houston Aeros on Monday to discuss playing again. His two sons, Mark, 18, and Marty 19, are on the team.
A wave of selling tumbled into the stock market late yesterday and doused much of the remaining hope that had been kindled in last week's rally.

A glow on the moon's horizon at lunar dusk, observed by a Surveyor mooniander in the the late nineteen-sixties, is probably caused by scattered dust clouds that are lifted off the surface by electrostatic forces, two American scientists reported yesterday.
The General Electric Company is expected to make a formal contract offer today to two major electrical unions representing 100,000 of its workers, according to labor sources.
30-President Nixon, on the first foreign journey of his second term, met tonight with the leaders of Iceland's Government.
In another West German step toward reconciliation with Eastern Eucope, negotiations were completed with Czechoslovakia today on a treaty to establish normal relations, ending 35 years of hostility.
Soviet authorities in Minsk have unexpectedly closed their investigation of so-called "Case 97" in which more than 100 Jews were questioned about illegal activities, a Jewish source said today.

Davis.
Jane Bowles, a dramatist and novelist, died in Malaga, Spain, on May 4. She was 56 years old and lived in Tangier with her husband, Paul Bowles, a composer and writer.
The early curtain was apparently a great shot in, the arm for New York theater, but isn't 7:58 A.M. carrying it a bit too far?

Jury selection began yesterday in Federal Court in Manhattan in the trial of two 19year-old members of the Jewish Defense League accused of participating in the fire-bombing of Sol Hurok's midtown office last year.

Federal District Judge Albert Eagle issued a preliminary injunction here today preventing United Air Lines from canceling a 7:45 A.M. flight from Muskegon, Mich., to Chicago. The order is believed to represent the first time a Federal court has ever ruled in a case involving airline scheduling.
The blob in Mrs. Marie Harris's backyard is dead and probably will not return, two Texas scientists said today.

The wife and a son of the director of the state crime laboratory died today when a blast damaged their home on Normandy Street. The state police and local authorities declined all comment on the explosion.

John D. Ehrlichman told a Senate subcommittee that six days after the Watergate burglary President Nixon knew that Federal agents were investigating "Mexican aspects" of the case and that he had relayed the President's orders to have the Central Intelligence Agency make the Federal Bureau of Investigation call off that part of the investigation if it would jeopardize C.I.A. operations in Mexico. Sandman Jr.'s financial disclosure statement shows that one of the contributors to his campaign in the Republican gubernatorial primary election was Herman Orman, who has been identified by Federal and state law enforcement authorities as the "kingpin" of organized crime in Atlantic City.
An autograph seeker at a Broadway opening once walked up to Mrs. Samuel I. Newhouse and asked: "Are you anybody?"

We first met up with high-toned grub at Boy Scout camp 40-plus years ago, when the chef honored some visiting state dignitaries with a banquet that included, to our childish wonderment, a salad of iceberg lettuce, canned pineapple, cottage cheese and mayonnaise, topped with a maraschino cherry.
John Bass, New York philanthropist, wants a third party to settle a dispute with the City of Miami Beach and get his namesake museum, with works once valued at $7-million, reopened.

Today was declared Lorraine Hansberry Day by Mayor Walter E. Washington, and this evening at the Arena Stage a new musical, "Raisin," opened, based on the late Miss Hansberry's most famous play, "A Raisin in the Sun."

Claude S. Brinegar, Secretary of Transportation, sought to assure the Senate Surface Transportation subcommittee today that the Northeast could Support one or more solvent railroads in addition to the Chesapeake Ohio and Norfolk Western railway systems.

As one of the fringe benefits of their liberation, women are beginning to realize that they have fully as much right to disappoint the world's expectations as men do.

Four men who hijacked a Colombian airliner and forced it to fly here threatened today to blow up the plane on the ground with 58 passengers aboard unless the Colombian Government releases 39 Communist guerrilla suspects and pays a $200,000 ransom.

The suspended police chief of Newburgh, who has been suspended and is under conviction for several felony counts, is assisting a Federal grand jury in New York City that is investigating official corruption in Newburgh.

Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said today that the State Department had assured him the United States had no information that Israel was planning military action against any other nation.

Canada's decision to withdraw from the International Commission of Control and Supervision will not mean the end of the commission, but it will probably be the end of the effort the Canadians sponsored to make the commission into an active and effective investigative body.

A high Nixon Administration official has signed a written agreement with labor lobbyists promising to make "inoperative" a section of a Governmental reorganization plan to consolidate drug law enforcement operations.

Idle Dice, the premier jumper in the United States for the last three years, won the Gambler's Choice event at the Devon horse show tonight, but he needed a tactical error by one of his rivals to gain the blue ribbon.

A Transit Authority changebooth clerk was a slain by a gunman shortly after midnight at the IND station at Nostrand Avenue and Fulton Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, according to the police.

John D. Ehrlichman told a Senate subcommittee today that President Nixon knew six days after the Watergate break-in that Federal agents were investigating "Mexican aspects" of the case. Mr. Ehrlichman was Mr. Nixon's chief domestic adviser until he resigned April 30.

The stock market declined sharply again yesterday. The Dow-Jones industrial average plurlged 16.70 points, its third largest drop this year, and closed at 908.87. The selling apparently came in response to renewed pressure on the dollar in European currency markets.
Eric Leon Applewhite, the actor who portrayed the inspector in the film "Dial M for Murder," died yesterday in the Miami Heart Institute. He was 76 years old.

Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday that New York taxpayers might have to pay more for public assistance to the aged, the blind and the disabled next Jan. 1 when the Federal Government takes over such programs from the city without any improvement in benefits.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has begun preliminary tests for construction of a high-speed rail line between Newark International Airport and Plainfield. In a report submitted to Governor Cahill, the authority said test borings began Tuesday in Newark.

The new Peronist Government today took control of national universities in Argentina by appointing special trustees who will have ultimate power in all administrative and ideological questions on those campuses.

A career professional in the city's housing bureaucracy, who started as an $840-a-year Buildings Department clerk during the Depression, was named by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to become chairman of the Housing Authority, which operates the low-rent public housing program here.
E. Evan Reynolds, an artist and former art director of The New York World-Telegram and The Sun, died yesterday in Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, L. I. His age was 68.

Employes of Weis Securities, Inc., the defunct stock brokerage firm that was put into liquidation late Wednesday, were locked out of their offices yesterday as the Securities Investor Protection Corporation took over.

Dean Rusk said today that he could not recall any use of wiretaps during his eight years as Secretary of State on Government personnel or reporters to trace news leaks, a procedure he called "rather futile and unwholesome."

Robert N. Caldwell, assistant editor of The Record, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in his office here. He was 64 years old and lived at 226 Prospect Street in Ridgewood.

United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern said today that a Federal grand jury had indicted two more corporations on incometax charges as an outgrowth of an investigation of alleged irregularities in the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign.

A 29-year-old New York City detective, under suspension in connection with rape charges in Queens and Suffolk County, was indicted here yesterday for alleged attacks on five Manhattan women last fall. The detective-James Farley of Holbrook, L. I., who is also under investigation in a drugtheft case-was arraigned yesterday before Justice Gerald P. Culkin on 18 counts of rape, sodomy, robbery, burglary and grand larceny.
Arthur Ashe was eliminated in straight sets and top-seeded Stan Smith was fighting to hang on today as rain halted completion of the fourth round of the French open tennis championships.
Terrorists bombed two taverns in downtown Belfast last night and sprayed one of them with machine-gun fire, the police reported. Two men were killed and at least nine other persons were injured.

June always comes as a surprise, for some strange reason. Winter frays away and it is March and early April, pussy willows and red-wings and peepers yelping. Something marvelous is about to happen. Leaves begin unfolding from the buds, hepaticas and anemones bloom, grass makes the meadows and the lawns green again. Then it is May, and violets, and apple blossoms, and lilacs.

Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher, the former captain of the intelligence ship Pueblo, is retiring from the Navy today and says he intends to become a freelance writer.
The Sony Corporation announced yesterday in Tokyo that it would terminate production of desk-top calculators at the end of July because of price competition.

A perjury indictment will be sought against a principal prosecution witness in the trial of Martin Sostre, who was convicted in 1968 of selling narcotics and sentenced to 30 to 40 years in prison, the District Attorney's office announced today.

The police searched the rundown area around 12th Street in the East Village yesterday for clues to the origin of a pipe bomb that killed a 74-year-old widow and injured her male friend Wednesday night.

Governor Cahill of New Jersey said yesterday that two of his objections to the controversial Tocks Island dam project had been Resolved but that five others remained to be met before he could approve the project.

From southern New Jersey to Rhode Island, the most encouraging angling news is probably the amazing influx of northern weakfish in Narragansett Bay. For the past several years, weakfish have been appearing in the bay in greater and greater numbers and now the fishing for the species there is better than anyone can remember.

Liquifin Aktiengesellschaft, a German wholy-owned subsidiary of Liquigas S.p.A., a large Italian industrial concern, announced yesterday it was offering to purchase 2.2-milion shares of common stock of the Ronson Corporation at $8.50 share, or total price of $18.7million.

Senator James L. Buckley and six other Senators introduced today a constitutional amendment designed to prohibit abortions except to save the life of the mother.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., reported yesterday net earnings for the three months ended April 30 of $24.1-million, or $1.09 a share, on a fully diluted basis, up from $17.1million, or 81 cents a share, for the corresponding period last year.

The Pennsylvania and Wisconsin crews won the two heats for varsity eights today as the Intercollegiate Rowing Association championships began. The Red and Blue and the Badgers thus qualified for Saturday's final.
The credit markets continued to sag yesterday under the combined weight of high inflation, tighter money and a growing schedule of tax-exempt and corporate financing.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged C. Arnholt Smith, a California financier and long-time confidant of President Nixon, with a massive fraudulent manipulation designed to misappropriate the assets of a West Coast conglomerate he heads and a San Diego bank.

The United Rubber Workers and B. F. Goodrich Company reached a tentative agreement on a new contract today following all-night negotiations, a company spokesman said. The details of the agreement, which is subject to ratification by union members, were not disclosed.
Widespread and recurrent rumors that President Pompidou's health is failing have been a major subject of unofficial talk during the French leader's meeting with President Nixon here.

Mary Carillo of Douglaston, Queens, defeated third-seeded Adria Price of Roslyn Heights, L. I., 2-6, 6-3, 6-4, today to gain the semifinals of the Eastern women's hard-court tennis championships at the Woodbury Country Club.

John L. Loeb, an investment banker and philanthropist, pleaded no contest in Federal Court yesterday to three charges of having disguised campaign contributions to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's 1972 Presidential race.

The Toronto Dominion Bank announced today it was increasing its prime lending rate one-quarter of one per cent to 7 1/4 per cent. The increase follows a similar raise announced by the Bank of Montreal last weekend.

Peter G. Peterson, former Secretary of,Commerce, and most recently President Nixon's roving ambassador of trade, is about to move from Washington to Wall Street. He was named a vice chairman of Lehman Brothers, Inc., and a senior partner of Lehman Brothers, predecessor of the corporation.

An official of the Urban Development Corporation said tonight that the "next move" in developing low-income and middle-income housing in northern Westchester County was up to the region's Town Supervisors.
Henry Hall Wilson resigned his $115,000-a-year post as president of the Chicago Board of Trade today to seek the Senate seat now held by Sen. Sam J. Ervin Jr., of North Carolina.

A jazz band playing "Blues March" instead of "Pomp and Circumstance" and the first six women graduates of Rutgers College highlighted Rutgers University's 207th commencement day today. Frederick Langton Corwin, publisher of The Suffolk Times, until his retirement in 1969, died Tuesday in the Eastern Suffolk Nursing Home. He was 84 years old.
Nearly 90 per cent of the hospitals in the city have standby electric generators ready for use in case of power blackouts, according to the resuits of an inspection by the Health Department.

A taped telephone conversation between a Fire Department dispatcher and a Penn Central supervisor last Tuesday night indicated that some railroad officials were aware of the fire in the train stalled under Park Avenue but delayed notifying the Fire Department.
Vice President Agnew told a Republican fund-raising dinner to night that the Watergate affair would not have a permanent effect on election of Republican candidates.
Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. says secret papers of the former White House counsel, John W. Dean 3d, show a "Gestapo mentality" in the highest levels of the Nixon Administration.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 31-Maybe it was a big deal 21 years ago, when young Tom Scott became the first black policeman in the Village of Hempstead. He recalls "a Jackie Robinson situation," but doesn't say much more about it.

Told he was under arrest for trying to sell 18 ounces of cocaine to two Federal under cover agents, a 28-year-old man was shot to -death in a Queens apartment yesterday when he allegedly pointed a loaded pistol at them.

William Hannan Spier, former radio and television director and producer and husband of June Havoc, the actress, who appeared in some of his shows, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 66 years old.

JHOTATTWARA, India-The sun beats down mercilessly on the whitewashed farmhouse. In front there is desert sand; to the rear a few crops miraculously grow. In the shaded huts where buffaloes were once tended, three Jersey crossbred cows chew fodder developed in America.
The Shaw Festival, which opened 11 years ago in the converted Old Courthouse here, will inaugurate its 12th summer season June 12 in a new $3-million theater dedicated to Shavian wit and wisdom.
Once practically invincible in a primary, the five county democratic organizations are now so badly split that they are having little impact in next Monday's citywide Democratic primary.

The main subject of conversation here today was the miracle of David (Swede) Savage's survival in that fiery crash and explosion in yesterday's Indianapolis 500. Savage's condition is still listed as critical at Methodist Hospital.
