The House passed today, by overwhelming margins, three bills likely to cause a serious confrontation between Congress and the Administration on health policy. The Administration is opposed to all three bills and has lobbied against them.

Four Brooklyn men on trial for the second time for the murder of a policeman during a 1972 holdup at a Fort Greene meat market were found guilty by a State Supreme Court jury yesterday, and may thus be subject to the death penalty.

Walter F. Rockwell, industrialist and a pioneer in the automotive component business, died at his home in Grosse Pointe Farms Tuesday. He was 73 years old.
An energy crisis continued aboard the Skylab station today, but the three astronauts went ahead with medical experiments and the operation of solar and stellar telescopes.

A Republican member of the Senate Watergate committee said today that the panel should move "faster and more decisive ly" on the question of whether President Nixon played a role in the Watergate scandal.
Federal investigators today studied material found near an explosion here to determine if the blast, which killed the wife and son of a state crime expert, yesterday, was caused by a bomb.

Beginning today, New York State consumers will have to make do mostly with phosphate-free detergents. The law bans the sale of all detergents containing phosphates except those designed specifically for dishwashing machines and for cleaning commercial food-processing machinery.

Ralph Nader and Friends of the Earth, an environmentalist organization, asked a Federal court today to close 20 nuclear power stations, contending they pose a threat to life, public health and property.

The Central Park Sheep Meadow swarmed yesterday with a combined gardenparty, carnival and play day for more than 15,000 children and adults who came from institutions and special-education classes to the second annual One to One Festival for the Mentally Retarded.

Investors' concern over the increasing pressure on the dollar abroad and the continuing inflationary trend again depressed prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market.

Humble Pie headlined a fine and frenzied rock'n'roll concert on Tuesday at a packed Madison Square Garden, even if it did end on a sentimental note with Vera Lynn's voice proclaiming, "we'll meet again."
Greece's army-backed Government tonight dismissed the navy chief amid reports that it was speeding plans to end the monarchy and set up a republic.

Westchester County officials today displayed models of the bus of the future in the rotunda of the County Office Building. Six floors above, they were grappling with the question of who, if anyone, will be riding them in an increasingly caroriented society.

Tom Weiskopf, runner-up last Sunday in Atlanta to Jack Nicklaus, scored 65 today in the $200,000 Kemper open. Weiskopf's seven-under-par round equaled the course record of the Quail Hollow Country Club and gave him a one-stroke edge over Lanny Wadkins.
The New York Mets finally found somebody with more trouble than themselves today when they arrived in San Diego limping like-to use a locally unpopular term - a lame duck.
Conflict between top former White House aides and officials of the Central Intelligence Agency over their roles in the Watergate case widened today.

Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee of the City University proposed yesterday a one-year contract, retroactive to last September, for the City University faculty nd staff union, the Professional Staff Congress.

Spellpound, Peanut Painter and Royal Blue all won green working hunter championships at the Devon horse show tolay - two with consummate Base and one in a hackoff, which is as close as a contest can be.

A 29-year-old New York City detective, under suspension in connection with rape charges in Queens and Suffolk County, was indicted here yesterday for alleged attacks on five Manhattan women last fall.
The Transport Workers Union is offering a $1,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the robber who shot and killed a subway clerk in Brooklyn after taking $138.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night gave William J. vanden Heuvel, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan District Attorney, its lowest rating: "Not approved."

Virtually all charges of corruption that have dominated New Jersey's gubernatorial primary election race were born in the shadowy world of campaign fund-raising. Both major parties and their state and local candidates traditionally raised most of their campaign funds in secret.

Senator Stuart Symington, acting chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has properly questioned the dual role of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. While serving as head of President Nixon's civilian staff, General Haig also continues to hold the position of Army Vice Chief of Staff.
All the top-seeded teams survived second-round play in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship Wednesday at the New York Hilton Hotel, but two of them had hair-breadth escapes from defeat.

OPERA BUFFET The Stuyvesant Opera and its Monteverdi Repertory SingMrs are back for a short run, with a rare work unheard of here for more than 50 years, and a post-opera buffet ack accompanied by wine.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court dismissed today the attempt of saratoga Raceway and Roosevelt Raceway, harness tracks, to block quarter-horse race tracks in Albany and Suffolk Counties. The harness tracks had contended a section of the quarter-horse racing law was discriminatory in allowing quarter-horse tracks to be established in the two counties so long as they were more than 35 miles away from existing tracks.

The old orange reduced-fare transit cards for people 65 years of age or older expired yesterday, and new blue or yellow cards are required beginning today. Those who have not received the new cards can get them at any of the city's centers for the elderly, at neighborhood government offices or by calling the City Office for the Aging at 349-6600.
A Federal grand jury indicted the Oklahoma State Treasurer, Leo Winters, today on charges of extortion, mail fraud and conspiracy to misapply bank funds.
Middle-class voters in South Jamaica, Queens, seem to like Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mavor.

When Seton Hall University inducts nine members into its first sports Hall of Fame tomorrow night in the Galleon Room of the Student Center it will mark the culmination of work by a 33-man committee that started last October.
A special telephone number, 267-9800, has been set up by the city's Board of Elections for New Yorkers with questions about the primary election.
The National Broadcasting Company and the Soviet Union signed an agreement yesterday providing for the future exchange of television and radio programs.

A 17th-century Japanese cavalry sword brought a record price of $70,000 at an auction held by the Sotheby Parke Bernet galleries yesterday. The Koto Tachi blade was crafted in 1603 by Suketsugu, one of the finest sword makers of the time, a gallery spokesman said.

Stanley Dancer, who two decades ago drove winners regularly at Yonkers Raceway but has been in action here less frequently the last few seasons is being seen on a regular basis again on the Westchester County track.

The conflict between top former White House aides and officials of the Central Intelligence Agency over their roles in the Watergate case widened today.
How would you judge the nation's top car salesman? Is he the guy in the lot who moves the most merchandise or is he the guy in Detroit who sees to it that the most are moved?

The Senate acted decisively on behalf of the rule of law in the United States and against further bombing in Indochina with its 63-to-19 vote to cut off all funds for United States military activity in Cambodia and Laos. The votes that have now been taken in both houses leave no doubt of Congress' intention to reassert its constitutional responsibilities in the war-making process.

Securities and Exchange Commission today charged C. Arnholt Smith, a California financier and long-time confidant of President Nixon, with a massive fraudulent manipulation designed to misappropriate the assets of a West Coast conglomerate he heads and a San Diego bank.

Ask almost anyone who C. Arnholt Smith is. If he knows-- and the chances that he will are very slim - he will probably say that he's the guy that owns the San Diego Padres, a somewhat less than successful baseball club.
Robert H. Abplanalp, a close friend of President Nixon, is a principal stockholder in a bank in Yonkers that was one of four new banks to receive Federal charters in New York State in 1971.

Said Dick Clark, who was one of the first disk jockeys to recognize the potency of rock'n'roll: "In the nineteenfifties people used to ask me, 'How long can rock last?" For Clark it has lasted 20 years at least-1973 is the 20th anniversary of "American Bandstand," the dancerecord show in which he sprang to fame. And Clark is still running.

Beginning today, New York State consumers will have to make do mostly with phosphate-free detergents. The law bans the sale of all Detergents containing phosphates except those designed specifically for dishwashing machines and for cleaning commercial food-processing machinery.

This is a gubernatorial election year in New Jersey. On Tuesday, the day after primary balloting in New York, voters will go to the polls to pick both the Democratic and Republican nominees. Under New Jersey law, a voter can enter either primary irrespective of previous party affiliation.

Manufacturers' inventories showed no increase in April after strong growth in the first three months of this year, the Commerce Department reported today. The report confirmed the earlier preliminary estimate of a drop in new orders in manufacturing. However,

Normalization of trade between the United States and China cannot be attained until a number of political problems dividing the two sides are solved, William J. Casey, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs cautioned here today.
With gold prices at record levels, executives of the International Mining Corporation discovered yesterday that each shareholder knew exactly how he wanted to capitalize on the good fortune.
FORT LEE, N.J.,--What's a nice Jewish Democratic Mayor like Burt Ross doing with the daughter of a Republican Irish cop? They're getting married, that's what.

The PATH railway system and Lodge 1330 of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen reached a tentative agreement yesterday on terms for settling the carmen's 61-day-old strike that has forced thousands of New Jersey and New York commuters to find alternative means of travel.
Erskine Childers, an English-born Protestant, has been elected as President of the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland, final returns should tonight.
An Indian Airlines jet crashed into a residential area while approaching Palam Airport in New Delhi tonight, killing 48 of the 65 people aboard. Two Indian officials were among the dead.
Mrs. Margaretta Lammot du Pont Carpenter, the mother H of R. M. Carpenter Jr., owner of the Philadelphia Phillies baseball team, died today at her home near here. She was 89 years old.

Evelyn C. McKay, executive director and founder of the Louis Braille Foundation for Blind Musicians, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Beth Israel Hospital on Tuesday. She was 74 years old and lived at 23 West 12th Street.
All the top-seeded teams survived second-round play in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship Wednesday at the New York Hilton Hotel, but two of them had hair-breadth escapes from defeat.

All four of Governor Cahill's appointees to the Rutgers University board of governors voted earlier this year in favor of giving a contract for designing a $9-million university sports center to a concern indicted this week for covering up contributions to Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign.

It's probably an exaggeration to say that as David Merrick goes so goes Broadway, but since 1954, when he opened "Fanny" on a shoestring and a G-string, he has been the theater's busiest and, on balance, most successful producer.
Teenagers from seven counties650 strong-are tuning up for their debuts in the New Jersay high school band and choral festival, scheduled for tomorrow night at the Garden State Arts Center.

To the Editor: The Vietnamese are indeed the political footballs Frances FitzGerald lucidly analyzes them to be in her May 4 Op-Ed article on the Mylai refugees in Quang Ngai Province. The war continues, not for their hearts and minds anymore but for their bodies. However,

The White House has rejected the concept that it can enter into treaty negotiations with American Indians who are attempting to assert their sovereignty and to dismantle the structure that the Government has built to deal with Indian affairs.

The Federal Trade Commission has filed a complaint against the Phillips Petroleum Company accusing the Bartlesville, Okla., concern of anticompetitive lease agreements. The commission announced last Nov. 6 that it would issue the complaint under its consent order procedure.

WASHINGTON--It began slowly and built into a crescendo which has consumed the attention of virtually everyone in Washington and millions of Americans around the country. At first, it was dismissed as a petty burglary, an isolated incident. Now,
Mrs. Kate Chambers Seelye, a former teacher at the American Junior College for Girls in Beirut, Lebanon, and the American College for Girls in Istanbul, Turkey, died today in the Plaza Nursing Home.

The Senate voted overwhelmingly to cut off all funds for the Cambodian bombing, going further than the House, which has passed a milder restriction. The vote came several hours after the Pentagon announced a reduction in bombing missions over Cambodia, partly because Congress had not authorized a requested transfer of defense funds.

A tentative agreement in a 24-day United Rubber Workers strike against the B. F. Goodrich Company calls for wage increases of up to 80.8 cents an hour over three years, the company and the union said today.
The Senate Watergate committee is investigating the Justice Department's campaign against radicals.

Central Intelligence Agency officials asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation last June not to interview two C.I.A. employes in connection with the Watergate case for fear that they would be exposed, Justice Deapartment sources said today.
A $5-million endowment and a Mount Kisco, N. Y., estate belonging to the late Eugene Meyer, publisher of The Washington Post, have been donated to Yale University for study and conference use.

Consumer buying moved at a fast clip in May, according to reports yesterday of sharp sales gains by several of the country's largest retail chains. Strong Mother's Day buying, as well as continuing interest in women's sportswear and seasonal purchases -of outdoor furniture and leisure-time sporting goods, helped increase the month's activity.

My Gallant contributed a sparkling performance at Belmont Park yesterday, and in so doing "qualified" for the Belmont Stakes. The Kentuckybred 3-year-old son of Gallant Man defeated five older horses at a mile and an eighth, racing in front all the way.

A taped telephone conversation between a Fire Department dispatcher and a Penn Central supervisor last Tuesday night indicated that some railroad officials were aware of the fire in the train stalled under Park Avenue but delayed notifying the Fire Department.

The State Public Utilities Commission granted a $47million rate increases yesterday to the Public Service Electric and Gas Company as an "interim relief measure" aimed at providing the utility with adequate revenue to finance construction programs.
The United States and France failed today to narrow significantly the questions that divide them, but their Presidents agreed to a new series
From southern New Jersey to Rhode Island, the most encouraging angling news is probably the amazing influx of northern weakfish in Narragansett Bay.
Mechanical problems and the rain delays of the Indianapolis 500 have forced postponement of the next race on the United States Auto Club's Championship Trail, the Rex Mays 150 at Milwaukee.

The academic, ideological and political debate about the relative importance of heredity and environment in determining intelligence raged again here yesterday around the person of Richard Herrnstein, a Harvard psychologist.

The slaughter that marked the 1973 Indianapolis automobile race cannot be categorized as accidental deaths. What happened on the infamous speedway has come to be a routine form of homicide. In 57 years of racing in Indianapolis there has not been a single year without a serious accident. Furthermore, the annual mayhem at Indianapolis only encourages it elsewhere.
Brendan T. Byrne, campaigning here for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, said today that as Governor he would not allow a super port to be built on the Jersey coast for large oil tankers.

The downtown building that housed the Japanese Embassy until last fall, when Tokyo broke relations and recognized Peking instead, is now the headquarters of a Japanese organization called the Interchange Association.

Skylab instruments have detected an enormous "hole" in the sun's upper atmosphere, or corona. Such coronal holes, one of the most recently discovered solar features, are thought to be magnetic funnels whereby gas from the sun escapes into space to form the solar "wind" that continuously sweeps past the earth.
The Dow Coming Corporation announced yesterday increases of 7 to 10 cents a pound on its total line of high-temperature coating resins that are used in paints and delivered in drums.

The exhibition called "Stravinsky-Diaghilev," which opened Wednesday evening at the Cordier Ekstrom Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, is both a dazzling evocation of a legendary era and an affectionate hommage to two of its principal geniuses.

The American Civil. Liberties Union and the Network Project filed a lawsuit today aimed at prohibiting any control or influence over what is seen on public television by the White House, The Corporation for Public Broadcasting or the Public Broadcasting Service.

President Nixon has changed the cast of characters in the Cabinet and the White House staff, but the new men are still working under the same old closed system and perpetuating the poisonous atmosphere of suspicion and secrecy.
The Administration's hopes of reducing inflation received a setback yesterday as the Department of Agriculture reported that farm prices, after dipping in April, resumed their sharp rise in May.
The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 10.5 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Truck tonnage was 0.2 per cent above the week-ago level.
A hijacked Colombian airliner, under terrorist command for more than 30 hours, landed at the Caribbean island of Aruba late tonight for the third time.
The atmosphere in the investment community remained gloomy yesterday and the stock market absorbed another shellacking. The Dow-Jones industrial average fell 7.46 points and closed at 901.41.

A non-registered secondary offering of 78,500 common shares of Cutler-Hammer at 29 1/4 was made yesterday by the First Boston Corporation. The company's stock closed unchanged at 29 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Henry A. Kissinger disclosed today that an experienced Chinese diplomat now stationed in Washington was his secret contact during a crucial period prior to President Nixon's journey to China.

Benny Goodman spent his 64th birthday on Wednesday in bed at his home in Greenwich, Conn., nursing a back condition that has bothered him for more than 30. years.

The complaint of Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery that Penn Central personnel failed to sound an alarm when fire broke out in the engine of a crowded commuter train on Wednesday constitutes a grave charge of dangerous negligence. A Nashville father and his son agreed yesterday not to violate Federal securities laws in a court-approved injunction by consent that settled a lawsuit by the Securities and Exchange Commission involving "insider" dealings.

The primary fight for the Democratic nomination for Chief Judge of the state has been a blistering one, with the initial lawyerlike veneer of a "nonpolitical" and "dignified" race lost in squabbles over bar association pronouncements, campaign spending and even the endorsements from some Queens Democratic district leaders.
The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week set a single-week high of an estimated 17.2 billion tonmiles.

C. Arnholt Smith, chairman of West gate-California Corporation, to day described as "unfounded" charges of fraud involving millions of dollars contained in a Securities and Exchange Commission civil suit against him two associates and other con cerns he controls.

The owner of a chemical company who lives on his yacht at the West 79th Street boat basin and habitually eats at better restaurants staged a one-man revolt against inadequate service and won yesterday when a restaurant that had brought charges against him failed to appear in court.
Governor Cahill took his campaign for renomination to the women of New Jersey today, stressing the home and family and the woman's role in making the state a better place in which to live.
The staff of the Senate Watergate committee is studying the question of how its full-scale airing of the scandal might affect criminal trials growing out of the case.

North Korea has requested and received official observer status at the United Nations European headquarters in Geneva. North Korea's allies here have said Pyongyang might want to have a representative here this fall for the General Assembly.

Representative Herman Ba dillo was endorsed yesterday by former Senator Eugene McCar thy, who called him "a man deeply committed to the genera good of the country, state and city of New York and especially concerned about the problems of the poor and deprived."

Roman Gabriel, the disgruntled Los Angeles quarterback, who has two years to go on his contract with the Rams but apparently has the right to trade himself; has come to terms with the Philadelphia Eagles, it was announced yesterday.
King Constantine II sent word tonight that the Greek military regime's announcement that it had deposed him came as a painful surprise.

The Montreal Canadiens who beat the Chicago Black Hawks in six games to win the National Hockey League championship, placed three men on the N.H.L. all-star first team and one on the second. The Montreal goalie, Ken Dryden, fell two votes short of a unanimous 240 from the Professional Hockey Writers Association. The defenseman, Bobby Orr of the Boston Bruins, got 236 in the balloting announced today.

Several of President Nixon's senior economic advisers are reliably reported to favor an increase of at least 5 cents a gallon in the Federal gasoline tax, and maybe even 10 cents. The tax is now 4 cents.
The president of the Richard Nixon Foundation said today that plans to construct a multi-million-dollar Nixon library and museum were moving ahead despite the Watergate scandal.

The Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board asked banks and savings and loan associations today not to raise their interest rates on savings deposits as a result of the lapse, almost sure to be temporary, in the Government's authority to put ceilings on these rates.
BROOKLYN BASHES If the skies don't open, you'll be able to spend a busy afternoon tomorrow in and around Prospect Park in Brooklyn.
A total of 2,300 production workers struck three Johnson Johnson plants in this area yesterday after rejecting a contract package including a 27-cent hourly wage increase.

Dr. Herman Theaman, who had practiced dentistry in New York City and in Scarsdale, where he formerly had lived for more than 60 years, died today in Norwalk Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 720 Milton Road.
The unemployment rate remained at 5 per cent of the work force in May, about where it has been for six months.

The chief rackets investigator in Queens for the last six and a half years has been indicted on charges of extortion, bribe receiving and conspiracy for allegedly taking more than $4,500 in cash and services from the Avis Rent-A-Car System.

A 9-year-old Brooklyn girl, whose unconscious body was found lying on a stairway in a Coney Island apartment house yesterday, died a few hours later at Coney Island Hospital, apparently a victim of strangulation.

The Netherlands has raised her bank rate to 4 1/2 per cent from 4 per cent, effective Monday, the Dutch central bank said today. The rate had stood at 4 per cent since Nov. 6, 1972.
The New York Mets assigned Cleon Jones to the 21-day disabled list tonight, lost Bud Harrelson with tendonitis of the shoulder and then dropped a 4-0 decision to the last-place San Diego Padres.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that, despite his objections to Governor Rockefeller's narcotics program, he had ordered preparation of a coordinated plan in the city to implement it

Two Queens teen-agers, 17year-old Ruta Gerulaitis of Howard Beach and Mary Carillo, 16, of Douglaston, reached the final today of the Eastern women's hard-court tennis championships at Woodbury Country Club.
Carl B. Teisberg Jr., senior assistant manager of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, died in Memorial Hospital on Thursday. He was 63 years old.

A suit asking a total of $380million for damages from Walter E. Heller Co. has been filed in California Superior Court here by trustees representing the bankruptcy estate of United States Overseas Airlines, Inc.

An official of the State Public Employment Relations Board ruled yesterday that New York City school principals were not "managerial employes" and consequently could continue to belong to a union and have collective-bargaining rights.

MOSCOW-The Concorde's controversial development is being closely and sympathetically watched in Russia. There is no question of anyone being opposed to the project here and when Pan American Airways and Trans World Airlines dropped their options in January, the Soviet Government paper Izvestia compared their action to "wrestling, no holds barred."

In time, The House That Ruth Built may be remembered as The House That Blomberg Remodeled. Before last night's game, Ron Blomberg was leading the American League with a .400 batting average. Two prisoners were charged today with the murders of the warden and deputy warden at Holmesburg Prison here. Charges of conspiracy to commit murder and assault with intent to kill also.. were lodged against the inmates, Frederick Burton, 25 years old, and Joseph-Bowen, 27.
Karel Vogl, a retired director of the Skins Trading Corporation here, died May 25 on a visit to Prague. He was 80 years old and lived at 244 West 72nd Street.

"Get the first good pitch. Hit the ball. Don't go up there to get a walk, that's not what Little League is all about."--Murray Braunstein, a Little League team manager in Oceanside, L. I., giving a pre-game pep talk.
Yoshizo Ikeda, 62, has been elected president of Mitsui Co., Ltd., Japan's $20-billion international trading company, the company's United States subsidiary, Mitsui Co. (U.S.A.) announced yesterday.

Voters in the William Floyd School District here voted 1,013 to 922 yesterday to approve a $13.8 million bond issue for construction of two elementary schools and a junior high school and for additions to an existing elementary school. The bond

The Wall Street brokerage community struggled in embarrassment yesterday over rule changes-effective next Monday--that threaten to drain revenues from the beleaguered industry.

His administration's record of legislation to protect and conserve New Jersey's environment is one of which Governor Cahill is quite proud, one which he speaks of publicly and often, and one on which it would seem he is least vulnerable.
The Skylab 1 astronauts are expected to make another attempt next week to release a jammed solar-power wing and thus relieve the orbiting space station's energy shortage.

The star of exploratory est drilling into possible oilbearing deposits on the Atlantic Outer Continental Shelf has been postponed for at least a year as a result of an order by President Nixon calling for further study of the environmental impact of such exploration.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, was reported today to have told Henry A. Kissinger last month in Moscow that the Soviet Union would permit Jews to emigrate at the current rate of 36,000 to 40,000 a year and that the education tax on emigration would remain suspended.
Two teen-age cousins helped to provide the major upset in the third round of the ReisingerKnockout Team Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel Thursday night.

The world record-holder and Olympic champion, Rod Milburn of Southern University, shattered a meet record today in the 120-yard high hurdles in the National Collegiate Athletic Association College Division track championships.

Three sprinters equaled the world indoor record of 6.8 seconds for the 70-yard dash tonight as the professional track tour entered its final weekend before it reaches Madison Square Garden next Wednesday.

The chief rackets investigator in Queens for the last six and a half years has been indicted on charges of extortion, bribe receiving and conspiracy for allegedly taking more than $4,500 in cash and services from the Avis Rent-A-Car System.

A Colombian airliner under the command of two exhausted gunmen landed at Buenos Aires Airport early today. They were involved in the longest hijacking on record-some 15,000 miles over a four-day period.
John Patterson Sr.'s Speedy Rick, undefeated in five starts this year, faces his toughest opponent of the season in tomorrow night's $22,500 handicap trot at Yonkers Raceway.
Northeastern's crew, the best in the East this season, showed its class today with a finishing sprint that wan a place in the final of the national championships on Onondaga Lake tomorrow.

A San Francisco clothing manufacturing company has charged that its former president-who has been ousted from his job--misrepresented himself under an alias as a past "military security" expert when he was in fact a self-confessed stock swindler who testified for the Government in the 1970 trial of Angelo De Carlo, a reputed Mafia leader.
The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was recalling .1,906 medium duty Dodge trucks built from 1969 through 1973 because of a possible defect that could cause reduced braking power.

Emile Francis, the architect of the Ranger renaissance that saw the team leap from National Hockey League obscurity has decided to step down as coach but to retain the general manager's reins of the club he has led to the playoffs the last seven seasons.
Japan's Opposition parties, led by the Socialists and Communists, appeared this week to have achieved their avowed aim of bringing Premier Kakuei Tanaka's Government to a halt.
The staff of the Senate Watergate committee is studying the question of how its full-scale airing of the scandal might affect criminal trials growing out of the case.
Parsons College's acting president, Everett Hadley, announced today that the college would discontinue operations, because of its $16-million debt.

Western petroleum companies yielded to the price demands of the major oil exporting countries early today to end a dispute that had threatened new production cuts by exporters and intensification of the world's energy crisis.

Israel's Finance Minister, Pinhas Sapir, announced today that 40 new joint, and independent business ventures involving more than $500-million in investment capital had been agreed upon during g the Premier's third International Economic Conference held here this week.

To the Editor: There is currently a great controversy concerning the amount of Federal monies spent on the defense program. Supporters of these expenditures have stated that advanced weaponry (nuclear armament in particular) is necessary in order to defend the United States in the event of attack.
1. Vote on the germaneness of an amendment to the supplemental appropriations bill that would prohibit use of funds for bombing in Cambodia. Amendment was ruled germane, 55 to 21, May 29.

For five months residents have watched the new span of the Gold Star Memorial Bridge over the Thames River here with mixed amusement and concern as the longest and costliest bridge in the state sat idle despite the completion of all but minor construction work.
A Special offering of 62,000 common shares of Union Fidelity at 5 7/8 per share was continued by Jefferies Co: The company's stock closed at 5 1/2, up 1/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

A freighter sliced through an oil-laden tanker in the Narrows early this morning, engulfing both vessels in balls of flame, setting off a series of explosions and sending flames more than 50 feet above the upper roadway of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

The conference between President Nixon and President Pompidou of France ended today after more than six hours of face-to-face meetings that kindled hopes for future progress while producing no concrete agreements.

The Boston Red Sox, almost halfway through a ninegame home stand in Fenway Park, where they hope to reach the .500 plateau in the won-lost column, continued in the right direction last night. They beat the stumbling Oakland A's, 6-2.

Wil liam McChesney Martin Jr. told Congress today that the nation' economy is characterized by "a flood of business froth which is now cresting and will, I think result in at least a moderate re cessionn by the end of this year or the middle of the next."

A suit to guarantee fishermen access to an Allenhurst jetty, which was financed in part by almost $350,000 in state funds, was dismissed today by a Superior Court judge.

Tom Okker of the Netherlands, taking advantage of poor serves by top-seeded Stan Smith in the final game, eliminated the American from the French open tennis championship today in a rain - plagued five - set match played over two days.
With the exception of wheat and oats, futures prices of farm commodities rose yesterday. Showing increases were soybeans, soybean meal, corn, cattle, hogs, and pork bellies.

TwoDemocratic contenders for the party's nomination for GovernorBrendan T. Byrne and State Senator Ralph C. De Rosewere talking about Jersey crime yesterday and who is to blame for failure to control it.

Ralph Houk was not disturbed that Ken Berry hit his first home run of the season with two men on in the third inning. Nor was he upset that Jerry DaVanon drove in his first runs of the year-two--with a bases-loaded double in the fifth.

Back in 1934, in the midst of the Depression, Congress passed a law making it illegal for United States citizens to own gold except for ornamental, artistic, industrial and similar purposes. WASHINGTON--A misleading, relative air of calm last week replaced the storm of sensational disclosures in the Watergate scandals. Charges that there are not enough blacks on the staffs of high school publications and that school administrators censon student publications with regard to language and social issues were raised here yesterday at a "hearing" on high school journalism.

The Liberian Government has arrested a Liberian citizen on charges of having irmpersonated an American intelligence agent and of having falsified and sold documents that said the United States was involved in planning coups d'etat and political assassinations in several African countries.

To the Editor: I read with interest Stephen Kinzer's Page 1 article of April 22, "Youth in Canada: Drifting Around With the Government's Blessing." Should the United States Lawn Tennis Association withdraw from the International Lawn Tennis Federation? As preposterous as this question may have sounded several years ago, it now is being tossed around by some American tennis officials as the only logical long-term move to sustain the quickening growth of the game in the United States.

The Smithsonian Institution and Harvard University have announced that they will establish a joint Center for Astrophysics here to coordinate related research.

The Democratic national chairman, Robert S. Strauss, has asked Senate investigators and Federal prosecutors to look into a mysterious ransacking of his Dallas home last July, in light of recent Watergate revelations, an aide confirmed here tonight.

MILLTOWN -- Twenty women, eight children and two infants showed up at a church basement here one recent morning. The women were there to hear two home economists, Carol Kaiser and Margaret Lawson, tell them how to refinish furniture.

TRENTON--Electronic devices have come to the aid of New Jersey bird watchers. Simply by dialing a number, bird watchers can hook into the "Metropolitan Rare Bird Alert System" and hear a taped report on whatever rare species have been spotted in the area lately and where they can be seen. Directions are given right down to street and house numbers, if the bird is a backyard visitor.
A 23-year-old off-duty policeman was shot and killed yesterday morning by one of three men who tried to hold up a bar and grill near Lincoln Center. The robbers escaped.

Louis Pronsky's wife told him, "Louis, you've got to do something. There's no room to walk around the house." So Mr. Pronsky, a life-long woodworking hobbyist, took his collection of handmade bookends, mirror frames, pedestals, benches, candlesticks and what all and opened Knoek On Wood, a tiny showcase of a shop at 169 Seventh Avenue, comer of First Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

The 12.3-acre Connecticut estate of the late W. T. Grant, founder of the department store chain, has been sold to an anonymous buyer for $1,325,000. The price is believed to be the highest ever paid for a single residence in the affluent community of Greenwich.

Flynn, who had been the ranking P.O.W. in North Vietnam, spoke for more than 400 prisoners of war who were honored by the Vietnam veterans homecoming celebration here.

Dissident Antioch College students announced today that they would try to "retake campus buildings" tomorrow and risk arrest for violating a court injunction against their strike that has closed the school since April 20.

Josephine Baker celebrated her 67th birthday yesterday with a press conference at the Plaza Hotel. The entertainer, who first took Paris by storm in the nineteen-twenties, is here for a series of four Carnegie Hall performances beginning Tuesday night.

Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, announced today that he would ask the House of Representatives to consider whether President Nixon should be impeached for "obstruction of justice."

A South Vietnamese helicopter was shot down yesterday by a Sovietmade heat-seeking missile north of Tay Ninh, 55 miles northwest of Saigon, military sources reported today. All six crewmen were killed.

The Soviet Union's supersonic airliner exploded while tens of thousands of spectators watched it making a demonstration flight at the international air show at Le Bourget Airport, near Paris. It was the first known crash of a civilian supersonic airliner. The crew of six, the only persons aboard the Tupolev 144, died.

The Russian TU-144 supersonic airliner that crashed yesterday incorporated recent major design changes that increased engine power, lengthened the fuselage and raised passenger capacity from 120 to 140.

Peter Oosterhuis of Britain captured the French open golf championship today by one stroke. He carded a 68 for a 72-hole total of 280.
Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets out of their trance today with a 9-2 victory over the San Diego Padres. In the process the Mets lost two more players through injuries.

Although the polls will be open seven hours longer than usual, mayoral campaign aides expressed concern yesterday that there would be widespread confusion in today's primary election in the city.

Former President Juan D. Peron will end 17 years of exile and return to Argentina on June 21. The decision was announced at an airport news conference here by Jose Lopez Rega, for many years Mr. Peron's private secretary in Madrid and now Minister of Social Welfare in the new Peronist Government in Argentina.
Seven of New York City's largest department stores recorded a minimal gain in sales in May, averaging 1.6 per cent over the year-ago month, according to a monthly survey by The New York Times.

Space engineers are studying two other ways of supplying additional electricity to the power-short Sky lab space station, should the astronauts fail in their second attempt to free a jammed solar-power wing.

There are very few really funny ballets in the international repertory. To be sure, there are those that offer the occasional chuckle, but, at least for this observer, the ones that remain consistently amusing,
The Parks Department concedes that many trees in Central Park are badly neglected, improperly maintained, foolishly planted and, in some cases, dying unnecessarily.
Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia captured her fifth French tennis championship as she posted a 6-7, 7-6, 6-4 victory today over 18-year-old Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today the Philippines hope to find new markets for her sugar exports, including China. Traditionally the Philippines has supplied sugar to the United States, and he said the nation would fulfill its quota to America.
With William D. Ruckelshaus's selfimposed tenure of two months as acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation barely half over, he finds himself in a perplexing position.

Dutch elm disease is a constant threat to all elms. It is caused by a fungus that is spread by bark beetles and it is incurable. When a tree has the disease, it must be destroyed, preferably before May 1, when the beetles emerge and infect other elms.
To many casual observers, the American family of the mid-20th century appears headed down the drain in a swirl of divorce, drugs, venereal disease, alcohol, adultery and group sex.
Alonzo Smith (Jake) Gaither, football coach at Florida A. and M. for 25 years and a legendary figure in black college athletics, will retire as athletic director Aug. 31, the school announced today.
Among the many British Broadcasting Corporation products being displayed on American television these days is a half-hour children's program called "Vision On."
Former Queen Frederika is urging her son, King Constantine II, to fight the military Government of Greece more actively than he has in the last few years, wellinformed Greeks here say.

Following are excerpts from a recent series of articles about. the United States written by Boris Strelnikov, Washington correspondent of Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, and by Vasily Peskov of Komsomolskaya Pravda, the youth daily:
The scheduled climax to the Latin Festival offered Saturday night at Madison Square Garden was the reunion of Tito Puente and La Lupe, and the occasion was celebrated with all due hammy hysteria.

Capt. Edward A. Brudno of the Air Force, who spent more than seven of his 33 years in a North Vietnamese prisoner-ofwar camp, was found dead yesterday in the home of his wife's family in Harrison, N.Y., apparently a suicide.
For several hours yesterday afternoon, the sounds of music and the smells of ethnic foods permeated the great meadow in Co-Op City in the Bronx.

One of the oldest hospitals in the city quietly assumed a new identity yesterday. With a brief round of speeches and a briefer ribboncutting ceremony, a new $10million geriatric center was dedicated at Sea View Hospital on Staten Island.

" Nobody can tell you much about her because she was a real loner," said a desk clerk at the Times Square Motor Hotel, where an eccentric 70-yearold resident was found stabbed to death in a fourth-floor lavatory Saturday afternoon.

Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, charged today that major oil companies had "artificially contrived" an oil and gasoline shortage by deliberately withholding crude oil supplies from Middle West independent refineries.

Three persons died yesterday when their single-engine plane crashed into the Atlantic Ocean, 300 yards off the Steel Pier in Atlantic City. The police identified the victims as Robert L. Custer, 55 years old, of Willow Grove, Pa., his daughter, Nancy Lynne Custer, 15, and her friend, Michelle O'Donnell, 15, of Upper Marlton, Pa.
A cluster of three dance programs over the weekend explored the imaginative use of props, sheer movement and an unusual space.

A comprehensive "retrospective" of Walt Disney films will be presented at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall beginning July 9 and continuing through Aug. 4. The tribute celebrates the 50th anniversary of the founding of the company by Walt and Roy Disney in October, 1923.

Three of the candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination focused their major criticism yesterday on the fourth, Controller Abraham D. Beame, who is thought to be the front-runner, as a tepid campaign drew to a busy end.

The Sullivan County District Attorney, Louis B. Scheinman, said today that the murder of Dr. Jose Gil had been a "professional job" and a spokesman for the state police said it had "gangland overtones."
His voice hoarse from campaign oratory, but his spirits high, Governor Cahill greeted 600 visitors to a Polish Day Festival at the Garden State Art Center today.
A man was found banged in the abandoned Brooklyn Palace theater in Brownsville last night by firemen who were summoned to put out a small fire.
Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the President of Libya, took his cultural revolution a big step further last night, in the process creating new obstacles to the merger with Egypt scheduled on Sept. 1.

To the Editor: Before the Democrats begin to salivate in contemplation of the 1976 Presidential elections, I suggest that they recall the historical ability of Republican administrations to ride out the most sordid of past scandals involving the Executive Branch of the Government.

Canada's decision to withdraw its cease-fire observers from Vietnam is understandable, but regrettable. The great Canadian contribution in Vietnam these past months has been an activist determination to contribute as much as possible to help end the fighting. But, as the chief Canadian delegate put it: "We came here to supervise a cease-fire. In fact what we have been doing is observing a war."
The Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government has established diplomatic relations with 32 nations, Hanoi's press agency said today.
Arizona made a bit of legal history early in May when it became the first state to enact a law based on the Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act.

ADELSON-Ida J. (nee Jackson), beloved mother of Morion J. and Ellin Oppenheimer, devoted sister of Nathaniel, Lee, Dr. Samuel and the late Ruth J. Holman, cherished grandmother. Services Monday, 12:15 P.M. at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.
With hopeful anticipation in many cases and confusion in most, a million New York City families are wondering these days what their refit bills will look like next January.

WASHINGTON - As each new chapter in the Watergate tragedy unfolds, I have an increasing sense of grim foreboding as I look at the future. The extent of the damage already sustained, and the worsening of the Administration's posture as further revelations occur, emphasize the fact that this is no time for partisanship.

Matthew J. Sheridan, 24 years old, a convicted killer who has spent the last five years in Bordentown Reformatory, today became the first prison inmate to be graduated from a fouryear college in New Jersey's history.
Locals of the United Rubber Workers at two of seven B. F. Goodrich Company plants ratified a tentative contract agreement today with the company.
The Rev. Billy Graham left Seoul for Tokyo on his way home today after preaching to what he said was the largest crowd of his career on the last day of his five-day crusade here.

Disillusioned contributors to President Nixon's $50-million reelection campaign fund are complaining that they were misled or betrayed by Mr. Nixon's fund raisers and that their money helped to pay for political crimes. Some are even demanding-and receiving-their money back.

The Senate Watergate investigators have been told that Government operatives have committed a number of other burglaries besides the Ellsberg breakin, Newsweek magazine reports in its issue that is due on newsstands tomorrow.

Tiled roofs were collapsed and smoke rose from the rubble of little stucco houses in this town near Le Bourget Airport this afternoon after the explosion that destroyed the Soviet supersonic airliner.

A University of Pennsylvania archeology team joined a dig north of here today at a site termed by an expert "the best by far in the Delaware Valley" for learning about American Indians who lived in the East thousands of years before the arrival of the white man.
Speaking at the University of Virginia commencement today, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson stressed individual action and faith in the future as the keys to happiness in later life.
Charles B. Wrightsman, oil industrialist, art collector and philanthropist, has donated $1-million to the endowment of New York University's Institute of Fine Arts on his retirement as a trustee. Mr.

Dr. Igho H. Kornblueh, an internist and a specialist in physical medicine and rehabilitation, died here Saturday at the age of 73. Dr. Kornblueh, was a consultant to the department of physical medicine and rehabilitation of the Graduate Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania and had served as chief of a similar department at Northeastern Hospital.

Continuing to show spectacular price advances, the July soybean contract yesterday jumped 80 cents a bushel to a record of $12.12 a bushel. By contrast the low for this delivery was $3.27 1/2 about a year ago.
Minor league affiliates do not produce all of the talent for major league baseball teams. Senior leagues, sometimes referred to as semipro circuits, also funnel players to the big time.

Gerald Martin Zelmanowitz, a confessed bond thief who has furnished pivotal testimony for the Government in two New Jersey Mafia trials, last week eluded United States marshals who had been protecting him from possible underworld reprisals, a Justice Department source said yesterday.

Although the common snapping turtle is not a thing of beauty, its meat makes a tasty base for a hearty soup. Ranging from southern Canada through the eastern two-thirds of the United States to Ecuador, the snapper,

Voters in New Jersey go to the polls from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. today to nominate a Democratic and a Republican candidate for Governor. Under New Jersey's electoral laws any voter can participate in either party's primary balloting regardless of previous party registration.
A police officer was wounded and two gunmen were killed late last night in a shootout on Pitkin Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

Short-term interest rates continued to soar to new peaks yesterday as tighter credit policy countered a surging economy and its voracious demands for money. Certificates of deposit were written by some banks yesterday at 8 per cent for three-months' duration, up from 7.90

The police said, a man wanted in Pennsylvania on a murder charge was captured in suburban Greece today after a high-speed chase. Identified as John Delmar Taylor, 26 years old, of Meadville, Pa., the man was said to be wanted on murder

The National Association of Insurance Commissioners, watchdog of the insurance industry, vowed at its annual meeting here today to eliminate surveillance techniques that failed to uncover the mammoth insurance scandals at the Equity Funding Corporation of America.

A time-tested maxim in labor relations is that the better things are, the worse they are. In less Aesopian terms, that means a period of expansive economic boom, with prices and profits soaring and jobs plentiful, is one in which to expect unions to strike for outsize pay increases.

The Soviet leadership, after long hesitation, came down squarely today on the side of modern Western- oriented economist, who are seeking to break with Stalinist planning practices to insure a slower, but more balanced and orderly, growth of the Soviet economy.
Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodian leader, to-day promised a general amnesty for what he called "the traitors of Phnom Penh" as part of peace proposals he has made to the United States.

The incumbent Borough Presidents of Brooklyn, the Bronx and Richmond won nomination as Democratic candidates for re-election by decisive majorities yesterday. There were no contests in Manhattan and Queens for Borough Presidents.
The State Highway Patrol said a tornado lifted up a section of a moving Penn Central freight train yesterday and slammed it into another parked on a siding near here.

City College has admitted 62 students for a program that will integrate the first two years of medical school into the undergraduate curriculum, enabling them to earn medical degrees in six years instead of the usual eight.

The American Natural Gas. Production Company-and the Michigan-Wisconsin Pipe Line Company, both affiliates of Michigan Consolidated Gas, announced plans today to begin natural gas exploration offshore from Texas and in the Rocky Mountains.

The Federal Aviation Administration, following five months without a hijacking in this country, is studying the possibility of ending the mandatory electronic-screening of all airline passengers and searches of all carry-on luggage.
Chu Chu Malave, a part-time actor and the darling of boxing's mod set, was knocked out last night by one punch, a left hook, at the 16-second mark of the eighth round in the Felt Forum.

The dollar today took its biggest one-day plunge in recent months, falling 1 and 2 per cent against leading European currencies, and the price of gold soared by more than $6 an ounce to another new high.

A Newark resident who says he wants to run for Governor as an independent in the November general election challenged the constitutionality of tomorrow's New Jersey primary in a suit filed today in State Superior Court of Mercer County.

Dr. Joseph R. Ridlon, medical director of the United States Public Health Service from 1934 until he retired in 1946, died Saturday in the Maine Medical Center in Portland. Dr. Ridlon was 91 years old.
Eight young people from the New York area were among 121 high school seniors named today as 1973 Presidential Scholars by President Nixon.
Students taking marketing at the Harvard Graduate School of Business will have to face another final examination this fall.
When George Foreman makes the first defense of his title against Joe (King) Roman in Tokyo on Sept. 1, it will be the first heavyweight championship fight staged in Japan.
Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., said yesterday that it had increased its published list prices for fabricated copper and copper-alloy products by a cent a pound,
Commuters who returned to the Port Authority TransHudson trains yesterday after a 63-day strike found a warm welcome at the end of the line, but not all the commuters went back.
Paul J. Curran was sworn in as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York yesterday in a private ceremony performed by Chief District Judge David N. Edelstein.

Sam Snead, who has never won a United States Open, and Fred Marti led qualifying for the Open today with three-under-par 139's. Thirty-nine berths to the Open, to be played at Oakmont Pa., June 14-17, were filled.

Police Chief William Wallace, who was accused by the State Commission of Investigation last month of conducting a lax inquiry into the theft of parking fines from the Village Court, committed suicide this afternoon in his home, authorities said.

Space agency officials, concluding that the "potential gain outweighed the risks," approved plans today for the Skylab 1 astronauts to take a space "walk" to attempt to deploy a stuck solar-power wing on their orbiting space station.

The dollar today took its biggest one-day plunge in recent months, falling 1 and 2 per cent against leading European currencies, and the price of gold soared by more than $6 an ounce to another new high.

A crucial question that sooner or later must be raised in the Watergate matter is to what extent a President may commit criminal acts in order to protect what he believes to be the "national security."
With three of four eligible voters expected to stay home, New Jersey Democrats and Republicans will choose party nominees tomorrow for Governor and all 120 legislative seats.

Robert C. Scull, the art patron and taxi executive, will sell 50 paintings and sculptures next fall from his private collection in what might be one of the most important auctions of contemporary art this year, it was learned yesterday.
Israel has opened a major campaign to persuade the Nixon Administration to drop its tentative plans to sell Saudi Arabia 24 to 30 F-4 Phantom jet bombers.
The New York Yankees headed west yesterday for a 13-game four-city tour, making no secret of their desire to acquire another starting pitcher, somehow, somewhere.

Andrei Volkonsky-he makes no use of his title, Prince -one of the Soviet Union's most advanced and therefore least played composers, as well as a noted harpsichordist, pianist and conductor, arrived here a few days ago as a refugee from Moscow.

Dr. Abel A. Hanson, professor emeritus of higher education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and former general secretary of the college and executive officer of its development program, died yesterday in a hospital in Asheville, N. C.

William J. Dickson, retired assistant manager for personnel research at the Western Electric Company, died Saturday in Strathpeffer, Scotland, on a vacation trip. He was 69 years old and lived at 10 Parkview Terrace, Summit, N. J.
County Clerk Edward N. Vetrano, the official party choice, tonight won the Republican primary contest for Westchester County Executive.

A coalition of black and white, rich and poor, young and old that met here last week was reminiscent of the civil rights days of the sixties, going through all the motions except joining hands and singing "We Shall Overcome."
Asterisk (*) denotes incumbent. Where more than one name appears for a single seat, the outcome is undecided.

High school teachers call it "senioritis." The seniors themselves call it a drag. Some parents-and educators--are beginning to call it scandal. The problem they are all referring to is the growing realization that for many high school seniors the spring term is a yawning stretch of anticlimax and boredom.
Canada's, seasonally adjusted gross national product rose 4.4 per cent in the first quarter of 1973 from a year ago to $12.6-billion, Statistics Canada reported today.
The Air Force began in investigation today into the death of Capt. Edward A, Brudno, the first apparent suicide of a former captive in the war in Indochina.

The collection of papers, correspondence and unpublished manuscripts of William E. B. DuBois, America's foremost black scholar, has been purchased from his widow by the University of Massachusetts for $150,000.
Although nine Civil Court judges are scheduled to be elected this fall, there were primary contests yesterday for only four of these positions-in the Bronx, Manhattan and Staten Island.
Archibald Cox, special prosecutor in the Watergate case, presented today a series of arguments for delaying the Senate Watergate hearings.

Forty private, nonprofit hospitals agreed yesterday to pay retroactive wage increases totaling $20-million to 35,000 workers who are members of the Drug and Hospital Union, Local 1199. The agreement between the metropolitan-area hospitals and the union calls for increases of $12 a week of 7.5 per cent, which ever is larger, retroactive to last July 1. 1.

TORMENT Walk along Grand Street, a broad and, on a sunny day, even pleasantly bustling thoroughfare. When you come to the corner of Pitt Street, raise your eyes to the side of the Henry Street Playhouse on the northeast corner and you will be quite shaken by a large mural-100 feet long, 50 feet high.

Central Park, Prospect Park in Brooklyn and Forest Park in Queens were closed to auto traffic from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. yesterday, the first day of a program that extends the weekend closings and that will run through Sept. 15.

The American Automobile Association said today it had begun a weekly survey of hundreds of gasoline service stations along major travel routes to try to gauge more precisely the fuel-supply situation for motorists.

Returned to District Court for revision in the light of the Supreme Court's January ruling against curbs on all but late-term abortions, two cases that permitted welfare mothers to obtain free abortions under New York's medicaid program.

A remarkable veteran who won his first title a half century ago, before contract bridge was invented, added another to his long list of tournament successes during the week-end at the New York Hilton.

A Federal grand jury in Newark has questioned a former assistant to Clive J. Davis, deposed president of Columbia Records, in connection with an interstate drug investigation, sources close to the case said yesterday.

A former South Vietnamese President today proposed the scrapping of all laws oppressive to non-Communist opponents of the Saigon Government. He also called for the immediate release of all political prisoners.

Burglars during the weekend stole $100,000 worth of art objects, mainly contemporary oil paintings, from the office-furniture showroom of Samuel Lakow and Son, Inc., in the former Golet town house at 20 Beaver Street in the financial district.
Ilie Nastase, using spin shots and lobs, defeated Tom Gorman, 6-3 6-4, 6-1, today and reached the final of the $135,000 French open tennis championships.

Acting a day before the case was listed publicly as up for discussion and decision, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals has approved construction of the final stage of a controversial 720-bed nursing-home complex in the Bronx, setting off community charges of irregularities and conflict of interest.

Central Park, Prospect Park in Brooklyn and Forest Park in Queens were closed to auto traffic from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. yesterday, the first day of a program that extends the weekend closings and that will run through Sept. 15.
County Clerk Edward N. Vetrano, the official party choice, tonight won the Republican primary contest for Westchester County Executive.

An Israeli court today forbade Rabbi Meir Kahane from flying to the United States lest he organize disturbances there during the forthcoming visit by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.
Charges were dropped today against David Hanley, a businessman who rammed his car into the nose gear of a jet-liner last June 24 in an effort to halt the plan from being hijaceked.

Kuwait, the wealthiest of the Persian Gulf oil sheikdoms, said today that the $500-million in arms that she is arranging to purchase from the West was "not for use against anybody" but for her own defense. Official sources said that the arms would be used to protect the nation's enormous oil resources.
Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor in the Watergate investigation, asked the select Senate committee today for a delay of one to three months in its hearings in the matter.
Steel production for the week ended Saturday dropped by 2.1 per cent from the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

In a move to encourage school desegregation lawsuits, the Supreme Court ruled today that the lawyers who prosecute such cases successfully are entitled to fees paid by governmental agencies under all but "special circumstances."
The fact that Garry Maddox is choking up more this year is helping to keep the San Francisco Giants alive and it certainly helped them in their 7-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates last night.
The Syrian Army officers and soldiers who were released yesterday by Israel said they had been subjected to physical and psychological torture during their captivity, the Damascus radio said today.

TINIAN, Marianas Islands--In the movie "Twelve O'Clock High," an American visiting England many years after World War II bicycles out to the airstrip from which his bomber squadron flew raids over Germany.

The White House acknowledged today that President Nixon conferred frequently this year with John W. Dean 3d about the Watergate scandal but said that logs detailing the time and place of such conferences would not be turned over to investigators.
Manhattan's "Mr. District Attorney," Frank S. Hogan, yesterday overcame the first challenge in his 32-year reign and easily defeated William J. vanden Heuvel in the Democratic primary.

In depositions filed in a civil suit arising from the Watergate affair, co-workers of Sally Jackson Harmony have disclosed that she told them she perjured herself to protect her former boss, C Gordon Liddy, a convicted Watergate conspirator.

The collection of papers, correspondence and unpublished manuscripts of William E. B. DuBois, America's foremost black scholar, has been purchased from his widow by the University of Massachusetts for $150,000.

Donald Starr, retired assistant managing editor of The Chicago Tribune, died today in Washington. He was 67 years old. Mr. Starr, who retired in 1970, joined the Tribune in 1934 as night picture editor.
